My current iPhone 15 has the maximum amount of storage I could obtain without investing in a more expensive Pro model. That is 512 GB. I have already put most of this capacity to good use. Now, I'm able to keep substantially more audiobooks, music, and other resources onboard and ready at all times. For the iPhone 16 Pro given to me, I requested and was thankful to get that same amount of storage. Given my personal needs, this means that I've escaped having to really decide what kind of overall use I put my iPhone versus other devices towards. I can now keep the bulk of what I digitally own and value the most onboard, and shuffle things in and out far less frequently than ever before. That lowers the amount of data I use and eliminates the likelihood of incurring high data costs while away from home. I'm also more likely to have digital resources I would like to be able to access even while offline. Those who may have been given older iPhones which have less than 64 GB of storage will have to consider whether they want to do most of their audiobook reading on their device or whether they want their music collection on tap ready to go. While using her iPhone 5S, my wife Sara frequently found that she didn't have enough storage space for everything she wanted onboard, such as apps and audiobooks. Thankfully, she has plenty of space on her iPhone 13 and shouldn't need to worry about storage capacity very often at all based on how she currently uses it.
    A major upgrade that was introduced in iOS 13 is a far more robust capability to handle files and use external storage with your iOS device. These include flash drives, SD cards, file servers, etc. It is possible now to integrate these external file repositories into the Files app, where they'll act similarly to iCloud drive storage. This is similar to how Windows computers can access files on SD cards, flash drives, etc, and treat them all the same, allowing for easy copying and movement. These external storage methods can relieve some issues around not having enough onboard storage. However, they'll be potentially less convenient than if you had invested in higher onboard storage. For the truly tech-savvy among us, there are ways to set up personal cloud servers which may well be just as convenient as virtual cloud space. You'd still want some iCloud space to back up your iPhone, but wouldn't need to pay for a higher cost iCloud Plus subscription.
Common Aspects of iOS Devices
All of these devices are rectangular. Some older devices have a round indented button near the bottom of the touchscreen called a Home button. These buttons are actually sensitive, small round button-like areas that don't press in. However, tactile feedback is given through a vibration motor in the device that gives the sensation of pressing a button. It can take a bit of getting used to.
    Devices that lack one of these virtual buttons will make use of cameras and sensors located behind the top of your device's touchscreen to scan your face. This is how they will verify who you are to unlock or approve purchases, among other uses. At least one type of iPAD now features a Touch ID sensor integrated into the action button on the device.
    IOS devices are all quite thin but rigid structures composed mainly of special glass and metal. They can break if dropped. The first thing I obtain for a new iOS device is a case to protect it from accidental falls. The very first day my father owned an iPad, he stood in the driveway of my brother's house and tried to take a picture of his grandchildren. He accidentally dropped the iPad on the driveway, and it cracked. It was the first time they saw their grandfather cry. Thankfully, Apple was wonderfully kind and replaced the broken iPad at no cost. It could have been an expensive object lesson. I recount the story above so others may learn from it. Your iOS device will find its way into your daily life in countless ways. Do yourself a massive favour and protect your investment. It's painfully easy to overestimate our ability to be careful. While I have yet to seriously damage an iPhone by physical impact, I have unintentionally knocked and dropped each of my iPhones onto hard floor or ground. I have also bumped it against walls, door frames, and other hard objects. And then, there's water and other liquids that are even more dangerous to the wellbeing of iPhones. As blind and visually impaired people, we are even more vulnerable to such accidents than the average user. Due to the sacrifice in sound clarity which waterproof cases demand, I have more sympathy for people who choose to rely on the water resistance built into their device. You will notice a muffling effect which, especially for people with hearing loss, can be troublesome when not using headsets or earbuds. I have reached a point where I selected a case for my current iPhone which doesn't offer water protection beyond resistance to small amounts such as raindrops. I wouldn't worry about holding it while in a rain shower. However, I would very much worry if it fell into a full sink or was in the path of a spilled large drink. 
    Along their edges, iOS devices have short volume buttons right near each other on one side. Above these is either a small Action button on modern devices, or else a small rocker switch that allows you to mute the device. The Action button is capable of serving many different functions when it is pressed and briefly held in. Along the top or the opposite edge of the volume buttons, you'll find another similar button called the screen lock or power button. It is primarily used to turn on or lock your device while it's on. It can also be used to perform other operations not done via the touchscreen. Holding this button in for around half a second can be used to summon Siri, a digital assistant. Clicking it three times quickly can perform an accessibility related shortcut which might activate the VoiceOver screen reader for example. These buttons feel like thick slivers that protrude ever so slightly outward from the edges.
    A short distance above the bottom of the right edge of iPhone 16 and 16 Pro models, you'll find a smooth flat area slightly raised above the rest of the side. This is a camera control. It is sensitive to touch as well as pressure. People can use this to take pictures with their iPhone held in one hand. It can also summon visual intelligence which can describe an answer questions about objects in view of the camera.
    The bottom edge of your device features a small slot where a charging cable is plugged in. On substantially older devices, there will also be a jack for EarPods or other headsets or microphones. These disappeared after the 6th generation iPhones. You'll also find grilled sections on the very left and right of the bottom edge where a speaker and microphone are located.
    Other than that, the rest of your device will be a flat, featureless surface. It is a touchscreen. Tiny sensors under the surface can tell where one or more fingers are touching it. This lets you do a surprising number of things.
iPods, iPhones, and iPads: What's the Difference
It all comes down to capabilities and physical size. iPhones are a range of smaller, more portable and in some ways, such as having built-in cellular data and GPS, more capable devices. They can fit comfortably inside a pocket. iPads, on the other hand, are larger tablets whose main attraction is a substantially larger touchscreen display. The Pro line of iPads offer significantly more computing power than iPhones. However, the cheaper kind of iPad, simply called "iPad," offers a slightly less powerful chip than comes in mid-range iPhones.
    Being connected to the Internet is a major strength of these devices. If you choose the iPhone, you will be able to connect using your cellular data. iPads may be equipped with cellular capability for a higher price. However, they can't then be used as overly large cellular phones. You would pay for a data plan and use the data for working online while out of range of Wi-Fi connections.
    Having the capability to connect to cellular networks is simply built into every model of iPhone from the start. Some people will buy iPhones and then only use them while connected to Wi-Fi. This is certainly a more portable approach and adds the benefit of built-in GPS. However, the abilities you gain by investing in a data and phone plan are substantial. Being able to communicate and use apps that leverage online services and artificial intelligence from wherever you are is absolutely revolutionary and of immense benefit to blind people.
    Overall, any kind of iOS device allows you to use the same apps. Newer devices without Home buttons have some different gestures and uses for the Action button that you'll need to master. There should be no major cause for concern that your choice will disallow you from using apps. However, there are cases where a special version of the app was developed for the iPad to fully take advantage of its additional resources or display size. A case in point is Fantastical 3, the calendar and reminder app I used for many years. The majority of available apps are universal, meaning they'll work on either device, but they may change how information is displayed depending on which device is used. Which option is best for you will depend on what your abilities and needs are. Let's explore the differences and advantages of each kind of device.
iPods:
These are no longer sold or supported.
iPhones:
These devices are by far the most famous. They are fully featured pocket computers that also happen to be cellular phones. In addition to Wi-Fi, they can also access the Internet using cellular data. They have GPS and other sensors built in, such as accelerometers. They are also equipped with very capable front and rear cameras. There is currently a wide array of iPhones available from Apple, ranging in price from around $400 Canadian to well over $1,000 for an absolutely cutting-edge, top-end iPhone.
    Many people acquire their iPhones through different cellular carrier companies that subsidize the up-front cost by offering contracts. In Canada, these typically span two years and spread the payment for the device out over that time. While this ultimately costs more money than purchasing an unlocked device outright, it can prove easier for people on tighter budgets who find it challenging to have enough money at one time. It's very much like buying a house. By the time you finish paying for it, the value will have gone down regarding how long it will remain a viable digital home.
iPads:
The basic idea behind an iPad or other tablet is that it's a sheet of glass that can be whatever you need it to be. It can show you the page of a book you want to read, become a word processor, display photos, let you watch movies, or be your portable game system. Anything you might want. Rather than paying a bill each month for cellular service and data, blind people hoping to use iOS apps might choose to pay for an iPad and use it with Wi-Fi in their homes or elsewhere. This is certainly a less-costly option, as the only expense incurred beyond Digital goods and services purchased is when you eventually wish to upgrade to a newer device.
    If you take this route, you give up a degree of portability and gain a larger display that won't be as advantageous as it can be for sighted people. This is particularly true if you have spatial intelligence difficulties like I do. For me, it is far easier to conceptualize where everything is and develop a good degree of muscle memory using my iPhone's much smaller display surface. Due to these difficulties, as well as the pandemic, I decided to give away my iPAD soon after completing the first edition of this guide. Other than allowing me to learn about the implications of this larger size, I simply found that I naturally gravitated to using the iPHONE for everything I did. The people who I gave the iPad to could see and thus take far better advantage of the larger screen, which so confounded my gestures and sense of orientation. For others, this larger size may prove to be advantageous even without sight. For example, entering Braille characters is much more comfortable and natural given the length of iPads versus the shorter iPhones. Sound produced from the speakers on higher end iPads will sound substantially better than from the speakers built into smaller iPhones. However, people who want high-quality sound will hear precisely the same thing on any kind of device if they use Bluetooth headsets, earbuds, or speakers.
    While you can use the same apps, the experience will differ more than might be anticipated. The operating system and gestures are essentially the same. However, iPads now run a completely separate operating system called iPadOS. This branching from iOS allows the development of a system which is specially designed to take advantage of the size of iPads and the different ways people can put this size to use.
    The app layouts and position of the keys is very different on iPads versus iPhones. I have spatial difficulties, and this has made using an iPad substantially harder for me. There's more space to have gestures go crooked and be misinterpreted. I'll try to do a three-finger swipe and have it misunderstood unless I manage to do it very straight. I've also found that double taps with two fingers may be interpreted as a tap with one finger if they're too close together. More things are on the same screen, since the surface area is so much larger. For sighted people, this means a lot fewer taps and swipes to get where they want to be. For blind people, it means figuring out where more things are crammed into the same space. With good spatial awareness and mental mapping skills, this will be a possibly large advantage, much as it is for people who can see. For me, it proved to be very frustrating. I've used an iPhone for about fifteen years and often don't have to consciously think about where things are due to muscle memory. On my iPad, everything seemed in a different place. It's like switching to a new Bluetooth keyboard. It's still a QWERTY layout, but the shift keys are different, or the spacebar is small. Old habits are hard to break, and things are so similar that the differences throw you all the more. Had I been using an iPad since day one, I might not feel quite the same frustration. I would presume that people who choose an iPad will eventually gain a similar competence to what I have on my iPhone. It's a matter of developing muscle memory and an understanding of how apps are typically laid out to take full advantage of the substantially larger screen. Past a certain point of competence, you won't have to put as much effort into learning how to use apps efficiently, since you'll have absorbed the basic conventions on where controls and interface elements tend to be.
    A good example of this sort of different layout is the Settings app. On the iPhone, things are neatly separated into different areas. You double tap to go into Bluetooth settings, for instance, and those Bluetooth-related settings will be all that remain on the screen. You'd then use the Back button to get out of that area and back to the main settings. On the iPad, it's set up like a tree, with all Settings branches visible on the left side of the screen and areas of focus opening up on the right side as you double tap a branch to select it. Flicking over the screen becomes a much less efficient means of navigation on an iPad's larger display. You need to think spatially a lot more to get anything done quickly. Flicking left and right is still useful, though, since you can touch near what you want and then flick over to it.
    The larger size of an iPad may prove to be a real boon for Braille users. They will be able to use something called Braille Screen Input far more comfortably than on any iPhone. This basically lets you position your fingers on the touchscreen like you would on a Braille writer and enter Braille characters rather than using the normal onscreen keyboard. Instead of learning where all the normal keys are, you can place your fingers comfortably on the edge of the screen and enter Braille characters. I find this especially good with the iPad in landscape mode. This gives you the maximum length to find a comfortable position for your hands and quickly enter Braille characters. No iPhone will give you as long a side to work with as an iPad. I'd never use Braille screen input on my iPhone because my hands are too large to get them comfortably positioned. I'm a slow Braille writer, even on a Perkin's Brailler. On shorter iPhones like my iPhone 7, I found it quite arduous and uncomfortable. On longer iPhones like my iPhone 15 or 16 Pro, the spacing of my fingers is somewhat closer to what I remember typing on a Perkins Braille writer. It's not fast for me, but it's at least comfortable. The longer edge of an iPad allows me to truly find a comfortable hand position for Braille input as suitable as possible to my particular hands and finger spacing. My wife Sara has smaller hands and finds Braille Screen Input very useful on her iPhone 13. I haven't written in Braille seriously since my days in secondary school. For me, it's slower than using the onscreen keyboard, and way slower than using my Bluetooth keyboard. However, I can appreciate what a big advantage this is for people who write in Braille all the time.
    When choosing your iOS device, here's something else to think carefully over. iPhones have GPS receivers built into them. If you go the iPad route, you will need to purchase an external GPS receiver to use navigation apps like BlindSquare or Nearby Explorer. These apps will use data to supplement GPS information with up-to-date maps and points of interest drawn from online sources. An iPad won't be able to do this without cellular data available. You'd have to preload any information while on Wi-Fi before you started to travel. Also, it's much easier to use an iPhone while on the move than trying to use an iPad while walking. On the other hand, maps have a larger display area on an iPad and may be easier to comprehend. Presuming they can be obtained or explored while in range of Wi-Fi connectivity, this may prove a workable solution for iPad users. GPS apps which store landmarks and map information offline could combine nicely with a Bluetooth GPS receiver to provide a robust if bulky and battery-draining approach to navigating with an iPad. An iPhone has everything built in, so there wouldn't be the extra device to carry and worry about its battery charge.
    The cameras on iPads are good, but it's harder to position them when doing OCR on a sheet. Apple didn't think that cameras on iPads would be used like those on iPhones. The iPad throws a shadow over the page, and the camera is in the top-left corner of the large rectangular slab of an iPad you're trying to wield. An iPhone is far easier to hold in one hand over or near an object or page. If identifying objects and reading print pages is important to you, I strongly recommend an iPhone over an iPad. It's certainly possible to use an iPad for this kind of thing. Apps like Seeing AI and KNFB Reader will absolutely work, but you have to put more thought into positioning the camera and light conditions to get good results.
    One aspect often considered a major advantage of iPads is the ability to have multiple apps open and working on the same screen. The size of iPads means that there is enough room to display more than one app at once in a useful manner. This can be used in countless ways. You might work on a document while having your notes open and available in a separate app. Perhaps, you want to write an email while still keeping an eye on a show you're watching. That's straightforward to accomplish for users with sight. Blind people can also make use of this kind of multitasking. However, they had better have more spatial skills than I do. I've never been successful at using this capability. It's far easier for me to switch between apps displayed one at a time.
Device Longevity
I like my digital home to last a long time. I get comfortable with my computer or iOS device and don't relish the prospect of changing to a new one just for the sake of having the latest and greatest. Provided you remember your Apple account and password, you need not worry about losing anything. Once you purchase an app, ebook, album, etc., it can be downloaded onto a new device with ease. The lifespan of these devices depends on how careful their owners are with them. Setting that aside, I have found that they typically last and perform quite satisfactorily around four to five years. Having no moving parts aside from a very few buttons, there's not much to really break given appropriate care. During that time, you will receive free iOS upgrades that will improve how your device functions. They can work longer than this, especially now that Apple has increased its focus on having iOS support older devices for a longer time than previously. However, they will eventually be unable to keep up with advances in iOS, which is the operating system that runs them. When this happens, you won't be able to update to current releases of iOS. Apple supports older devices going back at least a few generations, so if you're happy with what you have, you can keep using it and updating your version of iOS until Apple eventually stops supporting it.
    To give you a sense of possible longevity, Apple released the iPhone 4S in 2012. It began its life using iOS 5.02, and people were able to upgrade to the latest version of iOS until iOS 9.36, which was released in 2016. The iPhone 6S currently holds the record as the longest supported iPhone. Released in September 2015, it was capable of updating to make use of iOS 15 released in late 2021. That makes six years of iOS upgrades. Presuming at least one battery replacement and good care taken, people would still be able to use the latest iOS version and many of the improvements made. However, they would miss out on features relying heavily on artificial intelligence or features requiring actual new hardware built into the latest chips.
    When devices reach the end of their useful cycle, they will become more sluggish and have a harder time using the current iOS version. Long before this point, most users would be tempted to upgrade to newer devices due to rapid improvements in their capabilities. These include everything from longer battery life, faster processors, better displays, better cameras, audio improvements, and cellular data improvements among many other possibilities.
    My iPhone XR could certainly have served my needs adequately for at least four or five years from when I acquired it in 2019. However, like so many others, I've upgraded twice on my own initiative and a further generation thanks to generous donors. I now use an iPhone 16 pro as my main device and the iPhone 15 I'm still paying for as my backup and secondary device. Had I not done this, I would long since have absolutely needed to replace the battery. It isn't just a case of having to recharge more frequently. Battery degradation effects performance. It is possible that other components such as the storage drive will wear out. However, it is far more likely that my iPhone will suffer physical damage, and that this would occur before I wanted to upgrade anyhow due to capability advancements.
    Sometimes, features that are introduced take a long time to be widely adopted. One example of this is something called Apple Pay. This is a system taking advantage of a kind of transmitter in newer iPhones and other iOS devices that can transfer payment information to equipment in restaurants and other places supporting the system. You authorize payment with your fingerprint or face when you want to pay for something. No more digging out your credit card and using those little inaccessible payment machines. Very nice for blind people, provided the system is actually supported where you would like to do business. It took quite a while before Apple Pay was widely adopted in Canada. For over a year past its introduction, I only made use of it occasionally, partially due to how long it took to be widely supported by restaurants and shops. This is one example of why it is sometimes better to wait while new features mature before upgrading. Another good example is the new 5G wireless networks. The iPhone 13 came equipped with a modem allowing their use. However, these networks were only starting to become widely available enough to make a practical difference in 2023 when I got my iPhone 15. I suspect that integrating and fully exploring the capabilities such a major network upgrade will make possible may take a generation or two of iPhones as Apple learns to maximize its utility. Particularly if you're in a rural area away from any major cities, having an iPhone which can access these networks wouldn't be a major driver for upgrading until perhaps 2026 or so.
    Similarly, Apple Intelligence is taking more than a year to fully emerge as envisioned by Apple. Changes originally slated for 2025 will now be delayed at least until 2026 and be part of changes to appear in iOS 19 through updates during 2026. This is a major new element of smartphones. Apple is working hard to balance safety and privacy concerns with the need to catch up in this area to other brands of smartphone. Safety being an overriding concern for Apple, they are being cautious to test features before releasing them. Many people are suggesting, in early 2025, that it would be wise to wait for the iPhone 17 range to be released. These are likely to have even more RAM or random access memory, and have other advancements which will make large language models essential to Apple Intelligence work more rapidly and smoothly on your device.
    The LIDAR scanner which appeared in the most expensive iPhones of 2020 is an example of a potentially more compelling development. This is even more the case if it should ever appear in more lower-priced iPhones. Apps have already been developed which take advantage of this capability to inform blind people exploring unfamiliar spaces how far away they are from objects and what's in their environment. Combining this scanner with the camera and artificial intelligence built into iOS devices has some very impressive implications for blind users. As I write this in mid-2025, apps and features using Lidar have become more abundant. Apple incorporated a suite of them into iOS, so you don't even need to consider third-party apps to get use out of Lidar. However, things simply haven't proved to be compelling enough for me and others on limited incomes to spend the extra money to get a Pro model iPhone which has the Lidar scanner built in. The difference in price is simply too great unless your lifestyle makes having these capabilities particularly valuable. This might be the case if you travelled to new places frequently. It may not be long before Lidar positively impacts blind users more widely. Especially if the Lidar capability is brought to lower cost iPhones or incorporated into more affordable head-mounted spacial computing glasses.
    Such advancements plus growing concern about shortages and economics did indeed compel me to upgrade to a new iPhone 13 at least a year earlier than I otherwise might have. Additional storage, better responsiveness, better artificial intelligence, and being ready for 5G when it arrived seemed like good ideas as the pandemic ground on and shortages began to impact everyday costs. Two years later, in October of 2023, I was tempted enough to upgrade yet again to an iPhone 15. Plenty of significant changes and upgrades had been introduced. The most immediately notable being the switch from Lightning to USBC. This major change opens the possibilities for many more accessories to be connected directly by cable rather than Bluetooth. Also, a new feature called the dynamic island went from being only available on pro models to being a feature across the entire iPhone range. Another thing which compelled me to upgrade was that my iPhone XR was likely in its last year of being able to accept iOS updates. I rely on having my older iPhone as a backup and second computing platform. This lets me read Braille notes while teaching the course based on this book and demonstrate things to people when giving presentations to groups. Of course, a new iPhone means some new accessories which I'll discuss later in this section.
Accessories
In an effort to cut costs and save the planet, Apple has stated that they will no longer include charging bricks or wired earbuds with iOS devices. You will need to specifically order them if you don't already have them from prior devices. At the time of this writing, you should still find an appropriate charging cable included which is either Lightning or USBC depending on your chosen device. The small end of the cable fits into the Lightning or USBC port on the bottom of your device. It's a kind of small slot. When properly inserted, it will noticeably click into place. The other end of the cable can either be plugged into the USB port of a computer or charging hub or into the port on a small charging brick. The 25-watt brick is a suitable option since it allows for fast charging and contains technology to help make certain your iOS device doesn't overcharge. Many other third-party chargers also have this facility. Be certain you have an appropriate charging solution for your device. A 25W charger and cable should cost around $30 to $50 if ordered from Apple. Third-party options may cost more but could offer more capabilities.
    EarPods are Apple's improved version of earbuds that are sculpted to better fit in the ears of most people. They now come in Lightning and USB-C varieties. Be certain to order the ones which will work with your device. They have a microphone housed in the tiny control set that you'll find hanging below your right ear when wearing them. There are three buttons on the controls. The control set feels like a thin cylinder with a flattened section in the middle. The top and bottom buttons flank the flat central portion and will raise or lower the volume when pressed. The flat central button has several functions. Pressing it will pause or resume playback. Should you receive a call, you can use that button to answer or end it quickly. Clicking it twice rapidly will skip to the next music track or audio file you may be listening to. Holding it in will invoke Siri, a digital assistant available to owners of iOS devices. A set of wired USB-C or Lightning-powered EarPods will cost around $20.
    Modern iPhones are also capable of wireless charging on chargers compatible with the Qi standard. This method is slower than charging via cable. However, it frees the port on your device for wired EarPods or other accessories. Wireless charging pads and docks range widely in price and capability. Prices range from around $40 to well over $100 for a more advanced charging solution capable of handling multiple devices.
    Another new addition to modern iPhones is called MagSafe. The basic idea is that tiny magnets found in the back of iPhone 12 and above are strategically placed to guide magSafe compatible charging pucks and other accessories into the precisely optimal position for best effectiveness. When I put my iPhone down on a standard wireless charging pad, finding the ideal position can be a problem. I need to slide it around and make certain it's properly centred. What's more, it is likely to move out of position while I'm operating the phone making gestures on it. This can cause charging to stop.
    MagSafe eliminates this concern by guiding the puck into the best position and then keeping it securely there. The MagSafe charger might slide on a smooth surface, but it will never come free of its spot on the underside of your iPhone unless you free it with a gentle effort. Other accessories can take advantage of these magnets to be held securely in place and charge your phone or simply be held firmly on the back of it. This is helpful with MagSafe compatible wallets and stands for example.
    This small group of accessories will prove more than sufficient for getting started. Indeed, some people never feel the need to equip themselves further regarding accessories for their devices. It all depends on what you choose to do with your iOS device. On one hand, there are people like my father who intends only to use my old iPhone 13 to make calls, read websites, etc. For him, a charger and cable may be all the accessories he needs. At the other end of the spectrum, there are people like me who use their iPhone as a very portable computer for many different tasks. Making and receiving calls is almost an afterthought. I typically have a power bank, charging cable, Bluetooth keyboard, Braille display, and other accessories ready to enhance what my iPhone can do.
    Should any of the more standard basic accessories break or ware out, you can easily obtain replacements from the Apple Store. You can download the Apple Store app onto your device and order replacements or spares using that app. There are many alternative sources for these accessories such as Target, Amazon, and local retail stores. I would recommend that at the very least, you get a spare charging brick and Lightning or USB-C cable as well as a spare set of EarPods. Cables do fray or break if they become snagged on things.
Accessories Beyond the Basics;
Leaving Your Laptop Behind:
    As iOS devices and apps have improved, the notion of leaving the laptop behind and using your iOS device plus portable accessories grows more tempting. As I update this section for the third edition, I have long ago crossed over that line. For over four years now, my laptop is frankly never used and stays in a safe storage space. Meanwhile, my iPhone and a small, light bag of accessories comes along with me nearly everywhere I go.
    Generally speaking, I don't miss the laptop at all. However, part of the reason for this is that I'm very familiar with how to do things on iOS. If you're just learning the basics, keep the laptop handy until you've grown comfortable with iOS and any accessories you choose. To achieve the same speed as when using a laptop, you need to know VoiceOver gestures as well as what your options are in terms of the ideal apps for what you want to do. This isn't a transition made overnight. You will initially take longer to do things until you become more proficient with the iOS environment.
    There are an overwhelming number of accessories and plenty of choices in all categories. These include different cases, external batteries [often called power banks], speakers, headsets, earbuds, keyboards, etc. Accessibility for blind people is not typically a consideration when these are designed. However, there are devices that are more accessible than others by sheer accident. Especially when it comes to headsets and speakers, there are increasingly good chances that you'll end up with something that has voice guidance and talks to you. Also, more Bluetooth accessories can report their battery charge level to the battery widget you can have in the Today view on your iOS device. Below, we'll look at some accessory choices I've made and how I approached them. Your travel kit will likely differ from mine depending on your specific needs, budget, and priorities. Never presume that I've found the one and only option or, indeed, even the "best" option available. I have plenty of unused souvenirs that I once had high hopes for.
    Adding to the difficulty of selecting the best possible gear, it's hard to try before you buy when it comes to physical accessories. Sometimes, you can go to a store and find demo units available. However, most often, there won't be that option as stores prefer not to open items and then not be able to sell them. This is especially true for less expensive items. Perhaps, you'll be lucky enough to have a family member or friend who has taken the risk before you and has an accessory he or she is happy with. Frequently, there will be information making its way around the blind community about particularly accessible or affordable accessories that are workable by blind people. Following in the footsteps of others is certainly a relatively safer choice. However, don't make the mistake of thinking that all possible options have been explored. You might very well take a chance and come away with the next smash hit accessory hitherto unheard of in the blind community.
    Much of the time, you'll be ordering accessories online and relying completely on reviews and descriptions found there. This is especially true if you include devices that are being crowd funded on Kickstarter or Indiegogo. You can come across some very innovative ideas there. For instance, one idea that came up during the writing of the first edition of this guide was called a Power Cap. Funded on Kickstarter, it was a hat outfitted with solar panels and a small rechargeable battery. A good thought in theory. You're unlikely to leave such a cap behind while in the sun, and the battery would be all topped up and ready presuming you spent enough time outdoors. Just because a large company hasn't thought of exactly what you might want, that doesn't mean someone with the skills and resources isn't trying to fund production and get started. Crowdfunding has proved to be a very effective way of funding products aimed at niche markets and devices that are sometimes more accessible to blind users. You also have the opportunity to ask questions of the creators and backers, who can see any pictures or videos about the product you're backing. Just be aware that things don't always turn out as well as might be wished.
    My first try at an ideal Bluetooth keyboard was a case in point. I found the campaign to fund it on Kickstarter and backed the Hexgears X1. It was a well- constructed mechanical keyboard. It had a tactile on/off switch, reported its battery status to my iPhone, and was physically about as well-designed as I could want. The only problem was that every so often, such as when I typed the "i" in "its" earlier, the keystroke failed to register. This seemed to have something to do with how the Bluetooth connectivity worked between that particular keyboard and my iPhone. I never had this difficulty with most of the keyboards I've used ever since.
    I was equally unlucky with a pair of small round Bluetooth speakers I backed on Kickstarter. Those were quickly buried in a desk drawer due to the creators implementing a power-saving mode that puts the speakers to sleep whenever no sound is playing through them. This means that they must awaken each time VoiceOver starts speaking if no other sound is coming from them. You therefore miss the first part of words while the speakers wake up again. For pure listening, they're perfectly fine. When my niece wanted some Bluetooth speakers, I gave them to her. She was delighted.
    Thankfully, there are reviews and descriptions of pretty much everything on the web. Mine them for the info you need to make the most informed choices possible when selecting your gear. Written reviews, podcasts, and video reviews are all very useful tools. Even if you can't see the video, reviewers tend to describe important tactile aspects in passing. You might also hear any sounds made by accessories, such as how keys or buttons sound when pressed or voice prompts spoken by accessories. This gives you a much better chance to come away with an accessory which you are happy with as a blind consumer. Look beyond what the manufacturers say. Chances are good that someone has tried what you're interested in. Learn from their experience whenever possible.
Why not a Notetaker or Laptop:
Inevitably, people will ask why you'd go through all the bother of acquiring accessories to overcome shortcomings of your iOS device rather than just taking a laptop or notetaker. It all comes down to portability, ease of repair, and economics. If something goes wrong with your laptop, you're completely out of action digitally speaking. It's a single unit that, if it needs repair, you'll have to do without any of its capabilities in the meantime. If your keyboard is damaged, you could certainly attach a Bluetooth or USB keyboard. However, if you want the one built into the laptop to work properly, you'll have to spend some time without the whole thing while it's fixed. Meanwhile, your iOS device is already a powerful enough computer for most student or travel needs. The iPhone further gives you a fully accessible smartphone plus GPS capability in a single pocket-sized device. Information is stored in the Cloud, so the risk of information loss is very minimal should disaster strike your iOS device. The accessories are individually far less expensive to replace if necessary. If you send a broken Bluetooth keyboard away for repair, you aren't missing the rest of the capabilities of your iOS device while it's being worked on. Also, there are usually inexpensive accessories like the AmazonBasics Bluetooth keyboard, for instance, that you could purchase if desperate.
    Once you've found the gear you really love, it will likely last as long or longer than your iOS device. Accessories such as batteries, speakers, and keyboards typically last a long time so need not be replaced when you upgrade to a new iOS device. When it's time to upgrade a laptop or notetaker, you're generally replacing the entire device, paying a substantial amount of cash to do this. Having external accessories last potentially long enough to be used with several iOS devices maximizes economic efficiency, so you can pick your moments when it comes to upgrading various components of your overall system. Excellent for people on tight budgets. For example, I waited for improvements promised by Bluetooth version 5 to make their way into the next generation of speakers. Once that happened by mid-2021, I did my research and chose a Stormbox Pro speaker created by Tribit. The speaker turned out to be more weighty and larger than I had envisioned. However, it's solidly built, has great battery life and produces amazing sound for its price. Even better, it reports the battery level to my iPHONE, so I can tell how charged the speaker is. There are sounds for pairing and activation. All of the buttons are distinguishable by touch. For some reason, VoiceOver fluctuates in volume while this speaker is in use even though VoiceOver isn't heard on the speaker but remains speaking via the iPHONE's speaker or ear-pods. A minor annoyance if you're using the speaker to share music or podcasts with others in the same place.
    Based on a friend's helpful recommendation, I've finally upgraded my Bluetooth speaker. I have an Avantree BoomByte. This combines an FM radio with reasonably good sounding stereo speakers. The device fits easily into a bag or pack and has physical controls. Sound prompts indicate connectivity and also indicate when the unit is turned on or off. Tuning is done digitally with the physical buttons on the speaker. There's also a prominent volume and power knob.
    As of November 2023, I carry an even smaller Bluetooth speaker in my pack. It's the first one I've gotten which is produced by JBL and is their Go 3 model. It's easily held in my palm, uses Bluetooth 5, has audio indicator sounds for pairing and low battery, and produces excellent sound for its size. While it's too small to give a stereo effect, it is designed to emit sound in all directions and fills a space nicely.
    Generally speaking, the iOS ecosystem is far more economical than others. Apps are often far less expensive and take advantage of the work Apple has done adding accessibility features to the operating system. You can make use of many of the same apps everyone else does. They need not be specially produced for blind people. That lowers the cost of adding capabilities to your iOS device like you wouldn't believe. It also makes relating to sighted people who use the same iOS devices easier. Sharing information, communicating, and tapping into the same markets for digital goods like books, music, and apps as everyone else are huge advantages blind people simply haven't experienced before iOS devices became accessible.
Bluetooth Keyboards:
For me, finding a good and affordable Bluetooth keyboard has become an ongoing obsession. On a laptop, you will likely stick to the keyboard already built into it. This is especially the case while travelling. However, when you want a physical keyboard to use with an iOS device, you're starting from scratch and the options are positively endless. Typing fast enough to take class notes on an iPhone or iPad is pretty much impossible for most of us. People with excellent muscle memory might manage. Feeling around making certain you have the right character slows me down considerably. Don't even think about trying to use Siri to dictate your notes in a classroom setting. Touchscreen keyboards are good for writing short emails, notes, and contact info, but for serious rapid sustained writing, a tactile keyboard is a must.
    Finding the perfect keyboard for your specific preferences can be a quest worthy of an epic poem. The pitfalls are plentiful. I've now tried and at least briefly owned somewhere close to twenty different Bluetooth keyboards. I haven't even come close to running out of keyboards I could try. However, at long last, I seem to have arrived at a nice plateau in this area. I actively use three of them currently for different situations. At one time, I believe I had eleven keyboards in the apartment at the same time. I'm down to five or six in total now having found good homes for the rest. Different people have very different priorities for their keyboards. The imperfect one for me might just be ideal for somebody else's needs.
    Why does finding my ideal keyboard matter so much to me? There are several reasons. I happen to do a lot of writing. It's my best form of art and mode of expression. I might not get paid for it, but it's still worth finding one's favourite tools for the task. Some people have their favourite paints, brushes, pencils, etc. I have my cherished apps and keyboards. Also, there are different tools for different circumstances. I might want something small, functional, and quiet to take on a short excursion. Alternatively, I might want something spacious but quiet for those occasions on a longer trip away when you want to type comfortably without disturbing anybody. And then, there's the one you have for when you're at home at your desk, wanting the very best possible functionality and typing feel. Such choices say a lot about a person and are therefore also akin to the fashion statements which people who have sight might make by wearing various articles of clothing. There's a deep satisfaction when one comes across perfection or something close to it.
    One question I get asked all too often by stunned and horrified friends and family is: "You're getting another keyboard?" There are so many factors to consider and promises of typing perfection to be found just over the next financial hill. Perhaps, the key switches aren't quite perfect. Maybe, there are no multimedia keys allowing for easy switching of music tracks while working. Or else, there's no way to find out how charged the keyboard is without sighted assistance, since the battery status isn't reported to your iOS device. Sometimes, it can be hard to tell whether the keyboard is even on or off due to there not being a physical power switch. Blind people aren't typically in mind when these keyboards are designed. There are many ways in which keyboards I've gotten have proved less than ideal. However, there are usually ways to cope if one must. Barring abject imperfections like the sad case of the Hexgears X1 keyboard I briefly mentioned earlier, getting something truly unusable is thankfully rare. There comes a point where you simply need to take the plunge, try something new, and hope for the best. However, there are ways to go about this pursuit which can sharply reduce the chance of such unfortunate disappointment.
    Step 1: Think about what your ideal keyboard would be like. Have a firm grasp on what you're after. You won't likely get exactly what you want, but it gives you a starting point. My ideal keyboard would be rigid and long enough to use on my lap when necessary. It wouldn't be too compact and would stick as closely as possible to a QWERTY design. Good tactile key travel and multimedia function buttons were important characteristics. I didn't want situations where I accidentally invoked a function like muting sound that was controlled by a flat pad, which I couldn't quickly distinguish by touch.
    Step 2: Pick one or two characteristics and start looking for keyboards that have them. Alternatively, think of what kind of person might want a keyboard like your ideal one. For me, that was authors. It had to be comfortable to do serious lengthy writing on. That comfort clearly trumped smaller size. It also had to be rugged, so it would withstand bumping against things. Sadly, that's just part and parcel of a blind man's lot in life. All the more so when said blind man requires hearing aids. If I go through the trouble of getting used to a keyboard, it had better last a long time. This thought exercise gives you plenty of good ideas for words to include in online searches. Google is superb at dishing out meaningful results from a few well-chosen keywords or phrases separated by commas. For instance, "rugged, Bluetooth keyboard, writers".
    Step 3: Go through reviews that your initial criteria pointed you to and narrow down the prospects by what you read about them. If a particular item seems especially promising, take the time to search on YouTube and your search engine of choice for more reviews specifically about that particular item. Think long-term satisfaction here. It's worth paying a little extra if you intend to live with your decisions for as long as possible, like I do most of the time. I would even go so far as waiting until I had the money to obtain a really critical part of your kit like a good comfortable keyboard. Hopefully, you'll do better than I have at measuring twice and cutting once.
    After the failure of the Hexgears X1, the first keyboard I chose was a Microsoft Universal Mobile keyboard. I read reviews and descriptions of many different Bluetooth keyboards. However, the Microsoft one kept coming up as being the closest thing to what I wanted. Video reviews let me hear the sound of the keys in use and also described aspects like the power button on the side. It had a rigid magnetic cover that folded open like a book and could be removed to be used as a stand. It would also serve as a tray to put my iPhone on while typing with it on my lap. Reviewers praised its comfortable size of 85% of a full keyboard and good tactile feedback. Battery life was excellent, letting people go at least a week of average use without charging. Closing the cover turned the keyboard off automatically. It was still one of my more expensive investments, but I found it on sale and pounced.
    When the keyboard arrived, it turned out to be somewhat shorter than I had envisioned. My spatial difficulties made themselves known as the keyboard was too short for truly comfortable use on my lap. It was perfectly possible with my knees close together, but not as comfortable as I had hoped. The keys felt good, and it was nice and sturdy. It was somewhat cramped when compared to a full-sized keyboard, but I had expected that. The function buttons turned out to be an even more valuable addition while using AirPods. I was thrilled overall with this purchase, especially while travelling. For increased comfort and efficiency, I later acquired a Grifiti lap desk designed for tablets and small keyboards. This let me set my iPhone in portrait mode beside the keyboard with both items being very stable and comfortable in my lap. A very nice combination that fitted into a small shoulder bag along with other items. After years of use, an unfortunate drink spill ended my ability to fully trust the keyboard. I definitely got my money's worth from that one.
    For home use, I initially wanted something with higher-profile keys more akin to a computer keyboard, but not a mushy membrane kind. The answer was to look for affordable Bluetooth mechanical keyboards. One lesson I had learned from the Hexgears board was that I initially preferred linear mechanical switches. There are many choices of switches typically named by colour. For instance, red switches are linear and travel smoothly up and down. On the other hand, brown switches have a tactile bump at the point where your keystroke is actually registered. I must say that it was a strange experience, having never actually seen colour, to have meaningful consequences and differences attached to words that had been devoid of such real visceral meaning throughout my life. Skilled light-fingered typists using a keyboard with brown switches can lift their fingers once this bump is felt and not press the key all the way down. I'm a heavy-fingered typist, so my keystrokes always "bottom out", as the keyboard aficionados would say, with a definitive noisy clack. There is a widely used solution to cut down on this noise. Basically, it involves you taking the time to remove each keycap from the board and put an O-Ring around the stalk of each key before putting the keycap back on the switch. This does help with reducing the clack of "bottoming out". However, it also introduces some of that mushy feeling common to membrane keyboards back into the equation.
    My second attempt at a good keyboard for home and travel resulted in a compact and cheep keyboard from a company called Kemove. It was what is known as a 60% keyboard. It's a mechanical keyboard with red linear switches. Priced at around $50 Canadian, it was one of my more affordable and successful keyboard gambles that I bought on Amazon. As usual, there were pluses and minuses. One of the reasons that it was so affordable is that there were only 63 keys on it. There were no number pad or function keys. There was a key called FN that allowed for extra capabilities such as adjusting the lighting on the keyboard and switching between connected devices. I had hoped this would allow me to use the number keys as multimedia control keys while holding the FN key down, but this didn't pan out. The keyboard was solidly built and had a physical on/off switch. Even better, it reported the battery charge level to my iPhone. Unfortunately, it was somewhat noisy to type on, so I didn't use it while travelling as I had hoped to.
    Wanting a relatively quiet but less cramped solution, my keyboard quest continued. I acquired my next three keyboards from a company called Keychron. Initially, I was scared away from the K3 keyboard due to reviews talking about poor build quality, allowing for too much flexibility unless on a solid surface. Thankfully, the K3 version 2 addressed those issues nicely. Using aircraft grade aluminium and a steel plate reinforcing the plastic bottom of the keyboard resulted in a sturdy keyboard with no flex at all. Being a 75% keyboard, it includes twelve function keys which are used as multimedia controls among other things while connected to iOS devices. This means I need only press a single key to pause, skip, etc. The F8 key, used on iOS to pause music or pick up a phone call, is right between the USB-C port found on the back of the keyboard and a small noticeable pinhole or marking. This helps find the important keys quickly. The length and sturdiness plus the low profile design made it possible for me to use this keyboard on my lap in comfort without a solid surface beneath it. There are feet at the back of the board which can go flat or fold out to make it possible to adjust the angle. It isn't at all dust or waterproof thanks to the floating keycap design. I chose red switches and have also ordered an alternative set of recently invented mint switches which incorporate a tactile bump as the key is pressed. Removing the old switches and installing the mint ones proved to be perfectly possible if a tad stressful. I ended up only replacing the character input switches. The letter, number, and punctuation keys all now have the mint switches. These feature a quiet tactile bump felt at the top of the keystroke, which I find very helpful on the low profile keys. The red linear switches are used for any command or function keys such as arrows, shift keys, etc.
    While it won't report the battery charge to my iPhone, it does have a 1550 milliamp hour (MAH) battery, as well as a physical on/off switch. I can live with this compromise. The battery charge should last roughly 90 hours, provided the backlighting is turned off. To tell whether backlighting is on or off, I can use a light detecting app like Seeing AI. Meanwhile, I could use an app like Be My Eyes if I need to know the level of charge. There is no noticeable lag with the Bluetooth version 5.1 connection. I have a keyboard pouch which I put it in while travelling. It comes with a custom designed dust cover which fits over the keys perfectly. The typing feel is excellent and exceeded my best hopes for low profile switches. That floating keycap design was what worked against my continued use of that board. The gap between the keycaps and keyboard base meant that they could catch on-things. This resulted in at least two broken switches and nearly losing several keycaps, which dropped quietly onto soft carpet and came off the keyboard silently.
    While at my desk, I wanted a full-sized keyboard. My first try was a Logitech MX Keys keyboard. It's a notably heavy keyboard with a long base which juts down from the back of the keyboard. This base contains the battery and electronics. The keyboard is weighted and angled so that it is very stable on a table or desk. This sadly makes it a horrible choice for use on a lap or as a travelling keyboard. On the plus side, the typing, and Bluetooth are both exceptional. Pairing to devices is done via dedicated buttons at the top of the board. Connectivity doesn't get any easier. The battery charge is reported to iOS, so I can tell when to plug the keyboard in. All in all, a great keyboard for home use, which I thought I'd be happy with for years.
    It's a good idea to have a backup keyboard around. Should something happen, you'll keenly feel the lack of a keyboard while using the touchscreen for typing. There's simply no comparison. Physical keyboards are simply always going to offer better speed provided you're a skilled typist to begin with.
    Sadly, accidents do happen to keyboards. I spilled water on my Microsoft keyboard while it was open, and I was certain it had been ruined. So certain, in fact, that I bought a cheaper Bluetooth keyboard, which sadly exhibited too much lag to be used very well. Thankfully, the Microsoft keyboard stopped turning my typing into gibberish after around a week of being left lying open to hopefully dry up the water. It seems to be in full working order, but I can't quite trust it as I once could.
    By the time I was finishing the second edition, I had pounced on what seemed like a much better keyboard yet again. A company called Nuphy makes superb mechanical keyboards. I'm especially fond of their low profile Air75, which is the perfect size for travel and sturdy on my lap. The second version of this marvel had enough tempting upgrades to wear down my resistance. I have now acquired it, and I am typing on it at this very moment. I settled on the Moss tactile switches offered by Nuphy which require more force to push down than standard brown switches. This has proven to be a stable favourite keyboard for desktop use and works very well on my lap. Unlike the Keychron K3, the keycaps on the Air75 V2 aren't floating above the frame with edges of keys liable to snag on packs and come off. The frame protects them even when the keys are totally raised. Also, wonder of wonders, the keyboard reports the battery charge status to the iPhone's battery widget. I have found something very close to perfection with this particular Nuphy keyboard. Eventually, I will doubtless upgrade to their latest version of the Air75 design. How many generations I'll wait before upgrading is an open question.
    While close to perfection, there are a few drawbacks. The Air75 V2 is by far the most exquisitely wonderful typing experience I've discovered. Typing on it feels like you're building something with your hands as well as your mind. There's a feeling of absolute sturdiness, heft, and solidity to this keyboard. It also has all of the multimedia functions I need. However, it's somewhat loud to type on. There are times when this well and truly sucks. If Nuphy ever comes up with silent tactile switches which prevent the keys from bottoming out, I would cheerfully buy those and do the work of installing them.
    Another drawback is that it's somewhat heavy. There are many situations when something quieter, lighter, thinner and smaller are preferable. To be ready for such occasions, I've acquired two more keyboards! Yikes! They're everywhere!
    Based on my positive experience with the Logitech MX Keys full-sized keyboard, I got the Mini version. This keyboard is weighty and lacks some of the multimedia functionality of my Nuphy keyboard. However, it's extremely quiet to type on while still being very comfortable and spacious. It fits nicely on the lapdesk I mentioned earlier, taking up its entire length but leaving room at the top. Enough for my iPhone to fit sideways behind the keyboard if space is at a premium.
    There are times when you'll be out for a short amount of time or want to really minimize what you're carrying with you. My second very welcome acquisition was a folding keyboard from Protoarc. Built for travellers, the XK04 is a keyboard which is very light and folds in half to the size of a small pocket notebook. It has a PU faux leather cover which moves as you open the keyboard so that it sits level on a flat surface. There's a physical on/off switch on the right edge below the USB-C port. Thankfully, there's no backlighting to worry about. Two hours of charge gives you around a hundred and fifty days of standby time and over a hundred hours of use. It's a 65% keyboard so there's no number pad, six-pack, or function row. However, holding down the fn key found to the right of the left control key gives you all of the six-pack and multimedia functions. For instance, holding the fn key and hitting the number eight will perform a magic tap. This picks up or hangs up phone calls, starts and stops music, etc. Holding down the FN key and the letters q, w, or e will let you switch between devices you have paired with the keyboard. Holding the same key combinations and keeping them down for over two seconds puts the keyboard in pairing mode, so you can connect a device to that particular combination. The typing is a bit cramped but the keys are all in their proper places, and it's a very quiet keyboard. A much better experience than the iClever folding keyboard I tried earlier. As of March 2025, the Protoarc XK04 was available for under $50 Canadian on amazon.
    Between these three keyboards, I feel like I have the best possible keyboard for any writing environment or situation I'm likely to encounter. From the desk or balcony table I work long hours at to a crowded table at a restaurant where I might want to type out an idea while waiting to order, I can come ready to write. For now, at least, my quest for the perfect keyboard has concluded. My quibbles with these keyboards are minor enough that I can't justify spending money barring some major new development or keyboard destroying disaster.
    I wish everyone the best of good fortune in your quest for a good keyboard. There's endless choice. Even mechanical Bluetooth keyboards are becoming quite affordable. There are some keyboards that connect via the USB-C or Lightning port on your device and don't require batteries. I have yet to try one of these. They would offer some compelling advantages. No need to charge a separate battery or carry the weight of one. There would also be absolutely no lag whatsoever or any chance of a dropped Bluetooth connection. A possible disadvantage is that such a keyboard would drain a minimal amount of power from your iPhone's battery and take up your Lightning or USB-C port. iPad owners can find cases that have keyboards built into them. This pretty much turns an iPad into a basic laptop. For people who struggle with touchscreen typing, having a physical keyboard can make a world of difference. There are keyboard commands in iOS and VoiceOver to accomplish pretty much everything, and you can create your own shortcut commands if what you need doesn't exist already.
Beware the Lag:
When it comes to keyboards, speakers, earbuds, and headsets, blind people have a major concern that supersedes nearly all others. That is to minimize or completely avoid Bluetooth lag. Lag results from the time it takes data to be sent via Bluetooth between devices. Bluetooth uses radio waves to transmit data. Techniques are used to eliminate interference from other devices and check for any errors introduced in transmission and maintain connectivity between devices. A lot is happening behind the scenes to provide basic connectivity. Blind people require VoiceOver's responses to their actions to be as close to instant as possible. Even a split-second delay can be very frustrating and lessen your ability to competently control your device. If you're sighted, imagine having to wait a half second before the character you typed appeared on-screen.
    Lag matters more in some contexts than others. Sound delay doesn't matter as much for listening to music, podcasts, or audiobooks. You're not interacting much with your device while this happens, and the sound can simply play. However, lag becomes bothersome and even a serious concern when you rely exclusively on sound to actually control your device. Enough lag might result in you thinking that you're on one control while you're actually on another. Instead of pausing your book, you might skip back a whole chapter. You could accidentally hang up an important conference call rather than muting your microphone while attending to something private. It's vital that VoiceOver reports the current status or the result of a gesture as soon after it is made as possible.
    To avoid lag, look for a high Bluetooth version number. Don't get anything using Bluetooth 4. Bluetooth 4.1 is as low as you should be willing to go. Higher is better. Bluetooth 5 is now the market standard. Products that use improved versions up to 5.3 are not uncommon. This will give better speed, more reliable connectivity and range. Bluetooth 5 hasn't quite eliminated all lag, but it has become far less of a deal-breaker issue than when I wrote the first edition of this guide. That has certainly been my experience with the growing collection of Bluetooth 5 and 5.1 accessories I've begun to accumulate. Apple uses its W1 and newer W chips to further enhance Bluetooth connectivity, solving many problems with connectivity between its devices and accessories.
Audio Accessories:
Sound is a blind person's primary sense. Good audio is thus of massive importance to us. My third generation AirPods have almost no lag, are dirt simple to pair, and have good battery life. They don't seal the ear canal, so it's possible to use them while wearing hearing aids if you're careful. For me, the lack of volume and other control on the AirPods was a small price to pay for completely wireless operation and extreme portability. I don't mind using my iPhone to perform these functions. Also, when I'm using any of my current Bluetooth keyboards, there are keys letting you control these things without needing to touch your iPHONE. AirPods work wonderfully for me along with my hearing aids and combine unexpectedly good sound with extreme portability. However, I wouldn't use AirPods while walking outdoors. They are tiny, and it would be too easy to lose them if they ever fell out of your ears. Also, earbuds block too much of your ability to hear your surroundings.
    The latest AirPods Pro attempt to address this concern while sealing your ear canal entirely. I acquired a pair of second generation AirPods Pro in late 2023. They offer excellent noise cancellation. With my hearing loss, that's the last thing I actually need in all but horrendously noisy situations. However, they also have transparency mode among other audio tricks to help people keep aware of sounds in their environment. In the accessibility settings, there's an area called headphone accommodations. A great deal of fine-tuning is available here. A key feature is called transparency mode. I'm able to amplify this and partially compensate for my hearing loss while in safe, relatively small places. This came in very handy when my hearing aid broke and took weeks to repair. They acquired a new hearing aid mode in 2025 which lets them function as over-the-counter hearing aids.
    Concern is growing even for sighted people about this constant quest for sound isolation. For blind people, it's vital to hear what's happening around us.
    These concerns led me to seek a good outdoor alternative. Shokz offers wired and Bluetooth bone conduction headsets. Basically, transducers positioned in front of your ears send sound through your bones, leaving ears free to hear what's around you. These have tactile controls, voice guidance, and don't block your ears, leaving them free to hear your surroundings. They are also very unlikely to fall off. You lose some sound quality compared to other headsets or AirPods, but it's worth the trade when outdoors or while your ears are wet after swimming or taking a shower.
    The shopping procedure is the same for audio accessories as with the keyboard. Think about what you want, and then seek options that give you as much of what you're after as possible. Think long-term. Many accessories can get updated firmware. This allows manufacturers to make improvements after products are in the field. AirPods can receive such updates so that Apple can improve them, taking customer feedback into consideration. I expected my AirPods to last years and made my choice with long-term satisfaction in mind. After a little over three years, my original AirPods were showing their age with decreased battery life and connection dropouts. Overall though, they were a superb investment, and I had no hesitation about more recently purchased AirPods discussed earlier.
    Be mindful of the power required by these accessories. Apple AirPods last around five hours, but have a charging case that contains enough for multiple charges. I likely won't have to use an external battery to recharge them between opportunities to plug in most of the time. You can use and charge them separately, charging one while using the other. That won't be an option with headsets. While they're charging up, you're out of action unless you have a backup plan like using Lightning or USB-C EarPods. Sadly, these are no longer included with each iPhone, and you'll have to purchase them.
    I got curious one morning and decided to chase down the actual MAH capacity of my original AirPods. Thanks to a site called www.ifixit.com. I found my answers. These people take products apart to see how easy they are for people to repair. In that process, they find out some nifty stuff. In their teardown of Apple AirPods, they determined that the tiny batteries in each AirPod hold a charge of 93 MAH. The case holds a charge of 398 MAH. Theoretically, you could fully charge both AirPods at least twice. Presuming you fully charge everything before starting your day, that gives you the initial five hours plus enough charge for ten hours of both AirPods plus some extra charge.
    While navigating outdoors or waiting for my ears to dry before popping in the hearing aids, I'm currently using an Aeropex headset from Shokz. It's a nice upgrade from the older Trekz Titanium headset. The helpful voice guidance has been retained. Bluetooth 5 offers solid relatively lag-free connectivity. The transducers or smaller and the headset is far lighter than its predecessor. The sound quality is also much improved, but still not what you'd get from more ordinary earbuds or headphones. The mic built into the headset is also much better for phone calls than prior headsets.
    Sometimes, you can find devices with impressive extra features. For instance, there are Bluetooth speakers with built-in FM radio capability. The USB charging cable that comes with these devices often serves as an antenna allowing for good FM reception, in addition to providing a method for recharging the batteries. Read reviews carefully to help determine how easy to operate and how tactile the controls on devices are. If devices use touchscreen controls or buttons that are hard to feel, you may not be able to use them. Also, there are companies who are more aware of accessibility issues. Shokz are a good example, as they equip their headsets with voice prompts and have tactile controls.
    The Fugoo line of Bluetooth speakers come equipped with built-in voice guidance. A radio announcer voice can inform you of the battery level, connection status, and which mode the speaker is operating in. For instance, there is a loud volume mode for outdoor use and a power saving mode. The controls are all tactile buttons located on the top and at the ends under the top edges of the speaker jacket. The sound is quite good, and there is very little lag. Other speakers may also feature built-in digital assistants such as Alexa that are voice operated. Still, other accessories might produce sounds to inform people who aren't looking or, in our case, can't look, about their status or when options are chosen. The Stormbox Pro speaker I recently obtained offers sound cues for when devices are paired, power is turned on or off, etc.
Extra Power:
Blind people can put heavy demands on the batteries in iOS devices. Increasingly, I've been hearing that using the VoiceOver screen curtain works the same as setting the Screen Brightness to 0% when it comes to conserving power. People with low vision will save power by finding the lowest brightness setting which works for them. While we save power needed for screen brightness, GPS, Bluetooth, cellular and Wi-Fi connectivity, and constantly producing audio drains power. You can turn off things like Wi-Fi if you're not using it. Airplane mode shuts down all transmission of any kind from your iOS device and is helpful when you want to recharge your device rapidly. However, if you turn off Bluetooth, AirPods, and other Bluetooth audio accessories won't work. You'll likely need Bluetooth on all the time. The more connectivity you turn off, the less potentially useful your iOS device is. You can't receive a phone call or text message while in Airplane mode unless you specifically turn on the needed capabilities. The same goes for handy apps like Seeing AI that need Internet connectivity. These devices are so helpful that we want them to be ready whenever we need them. Extra portable power doesn't cost a fortune and just makes sense.
    Apple sells cases that contain additional battery power for their products. For people likely to forget extra gear like external batteries, this can be a very good idea. They offer an additional advantage of communicating their level of charge to your iOS device, so you can know how much you have remaining. I have yet to find an external battery which does this. However, cases built for your current iOS device might not be useable on future ones. Changes in size and the position of ports can easily render a case useless once you trade in your old iPhone for a nice new one. Presuming you'll be using an iOS device for two or more years, battery cases designed specifically for your device can absolutely prove a worthwhile investment.
    Going with external batteries, you will almost certainly be able to use them on future iOS devices for as long as the batteries can keep recharging. All rechargeable batteries will eventually wear out. However, they are relatively inexpensive to replace when that's necessary. The only possible thing you'll sacrifice when using an older battery is charging speed. Newer iPhones and batteries will be able to charge faster than older batteries will allow. I have yet to hear of a talking external battery or one that communicates its charge level to your iOS device. Short of asking a sighted person with you or using an app like Be My Eyes, there's no way to know how much charge your external battery has. Therefore, you need to get into the habit of charging them up regularly. Get more power than you need so that if you forget to charge the battery or are away from power sources for longer than expected, you'll be ready to cope.
    One way to help counter the threat of forgetting to keep your power bank charged as well as your iPhone is to buy a power bank which has a foldable plug built right into it. The Anker GAN Prime 733 combines a 67 Watt charger with two USB-C and one USB Ports as well as a 10000 MAH power bank in one handy device. You can leave it plugged in and use it to charge your devices. Then, when you're heading out and about, simply remove the device from the outlet and fold in the plugs. You now have a fully charged power bank which easily fits in a pocket or bag ready to go. The power bank is designed to charge your devices first and then recharge itself. Provided things are left plugged in overnight or as a general rule, the power bank will be fully charged when you need it to be. The battery management software built into your iOS devices will make certain they never become overcharged. Having them plugged in whenever possible is a far safer practice than it once was.
    There is currently one accessible power bank that I'm a happy owner of. It's made by a company called Energrid and is designed specifically for blind people. With a USB A and a USB-C port capable of rapid charging, it has a capacity of 20000 MAH. It could charge an iPhone four times with power to spare. They also have a smaller 10000 MAH version of their accessible battery. This is potentially more suited to smaller bags than pockets. These power banks are available at:
    www.atguys.com
    The energrid company will also ship to Canada and can be ordered from directly at:
    https://accessibility.energrid.us.com
    The two current versions are the VS810PD and VS820PD. The battery costs around $100 Canadian. Compared to other regular power banks, this is expensive. You can obtain power banks with a lot more capacity for far less than this price. These power banks will almost certainly be lighter, have more ports to charge devices, and may be smaller in physical size. The dimensions of the older Energrid battery I had are 14 centimetres long, 6.5 centimetres wide, and 2 centimetres thick. This is about 51/2 inches long, 23/4 inches wide, and just a tad under an inch thick; 13/16 of an inch to be exact. The newer 20000 MAH battery is a comparable size to this.
