There are also settings for Language & Region preferences, Date & Time, VPN connection if you need that, and more. Be sure to take the time to look around this branch carefully. There's quite a bit tucked in here, and it's all useful at least occasionally.
Control Centre Settings:
While never absolutely essential, the Control Centre is a very handy feature of iOS. The settings in this area let you customize what can be found in the "Centre" and when it can be accessed. There is a toggle that lets you decide whether the Control Centre can be accessed from within apps or only from the home screen.
    Immediately to the right of this setting, you'll find a button called Customize Controls. Double tap this, and you will be in an area that lets you select, remove, and reorder controls to maximize how effective the Control Centre is for you. There's a heading called Include, beneath which you will find any options you have selected for inclusion in the Control Centre. Double tap these to remove them if you wish. You may also rearrange them via the rotor or by dragging the Reorder buttons next to them up or down. The rotor will let you move controls up or down one space at a time. Learning to drag controls by double tapping and holding down the Reorder button and then moving your finger up or down can accelerate the process when you've gotten the hang of it.
    The last option in this area lets you reset your control panel to factory default. This is useful if you've gone too far in your efforts to customize the control centre and need to start fresh.
    As of iOS 18, you can further customize the control centre from within it. When in the control centre, touch a control so that it's in focus and then flick up or down. You'll hear VoiceOver say "edit controls". Double tap this to enter a mode where you can add, remove and rearrange controls.
Display & Brightness
This area has one of those nice, self-explanatory names. You can select between a light or dark overall appearance. Alternatively, you can have your device automatically switch to an appropriate mode based on options that become available if Automatic mode is turned on. The default there is Light Until Sunset. The next settings have to do with screen brightness. I habitually have this set to 0% to save battery power. However, you might want to set this higher so that a sighted person can see and read your display if you think you may need assistance. The next setting is called Night Shift, which you can schedule or disable. It removes colours from the display during the evening that are known to cause sleep difficulties. I have no idea whether this effects totally blind people.
    Your device may or may not support True Tone. This feature uses light sensors in your device to adjust the colour pallet of your display according to current ambient lighting conditions. This is presumably helpful for those who can see. Should this feature prove troublesome when making digital drawings or something, it can be disabled.
    The Auto-Lock feature causes your device to dim and then fully lock the screen if enough time passes without action being taken. The intentions of this feature are to save your battery power and enhance your overall security. However, this feature can be most annoying if you like to pause and think about what you're doing before doing it. I disable this feature by setting to Never. Provided you remember to lock your device when you're not using it, this is perfectly good. However, you can set it to various lengths of inactive time before it dims and locks on you. The default is annoyingly brief, especially while you're learning the ropes. I think it's thirty seconds. Certainly, no more than a minute. It's one of the first things I attend to when I get a new device.
    The Raise to Wake feature causes your device to become active when it is lifted or tilted. This is a basic on/off toggle that I prefer deactivated. I find that more often than not, it causes my iPhone to go active in my pocket when I don't want it to. The text size and choice of views don't make much difference to totally blind people, but may prove useful for people with low vision. However, I believe that the features found in Accessibility settings will likely address their needs far more capably.
Accessibility Settings:
There are a lot of settings in this space. Paradoxically, the two most useful branches in this area are VoiceOver and Voice Control settings. Because these two branches of accessibility settings are so integral to the accessibility tools they control, these particular branches will be discussed in the major sections dedicated to VoiceOver and Voice Control. When dealing with things as pervasive in your experience of iOS, it seems more sensible to keep all the information you'll need in one place. Other parts of this large and useful area will be discussed below. We won't cover everything as exhaustively as we will with the VoiceOver and Voice Control settings elsewhere in this guide. However, we'll go over some of the settings that are most likely to benefit people who are blind. People with specific disabilities should explore this area of settings thoroughly, and also consult the user guide for their device and version of iOS put out by Apple. There may very well be options here that will help with your particular disabilities.
    The Accessibility settings branch is divided up into sections via headings based on type of disability. The topmost heading is Vision. Below are Physical and Motor, Hearing, and finally, General. We'll explore each section for useful treasures.
Vision
Most people who are classified as legally blind actually have some impaired but potentially useful vision. Apple has incorporated extensive tools to maximize what people with different eye conditions can do with their iOS devices. The very first and most often used of these features is called Zoom. It magnifies areas of the screen as needed. You can customize how this feature behaves in many ways. Once the feature is turned on, you can cause Zoom to occur by double tapping with three fingers on the screen. Dragging three fingers over the screen will cause the affected area to move to the part of the screen you require "zoomed". You can change the Zoom level by double tapping with three fingers and then dragging them over the screen. You can have Zoom follow where iOS or the app you're using thinks focus should be so that this is magnified automatically. There are keyboard shortcuts you can set, much like with VoiceOver. You can have a Zoom Controller constantly available on screen that lets you adjust various aspects of Zoom as needed. You can also choose how large a region will be automatically zoomed. The default setting for this is Full Screen. You can apply filters to Zoom including Grayscale, Inverted, and others. There is also a setting to set the maximum Zoom level. The default is 5.0x. This seems like a brief description of a very powerful feature. Being totally blind, I don't feel qualified to go much further.
    Occasionally, you need to magnify something in the real world, like print on a product or sign. Apple includes a Magnifier option that takes advantage of your device's built-in rear camera. This seems to be a pretty simple option to use. When turned on, you can use the Accessibility Shortcut to activate and dismiss the magnifier. Unlike Zoom with its many settings, there's just one for the magnifier. This is whether or not you want Auto-Adjust Exposure. Basically, this lets the artificial intelligence in your device adjust brightness and contrast based on ambient light settings. Sounds like something worth taking for a spin.
    The Display & Text Size button should definitely be checked out thoroughly, as there's an awful lot tucked away behind it. There are colour filters, adjustments that can be made to labels, the ability to reduce the white point, and numerous other things which will forever be utterly beyond my experience. People with any sort of visual difficulty short of total blindness should certainly explore all the options in here. There's bound to be something that can help at least a little.
    Generally, people seem to like the animated look of iOS. Elements move in an out of focus as needed and are animated in other ways, providing for a lively environment. For some people, the animation, and motion of elements on the screen can be troublesome. The Motion area has settings to reduce things like the parallax effect present in the normal interface. These settings are unlikely to benefit totally blind people, besides the one that disables the automatic playing of videos. These often have sound that can make other elements of websites harder to hear. People with low vision may find various options in here to be helpful, as they can reduce clutter.
    The Spoken Content settings let people who don't need a full screen reader still enjoy having text spoken aloud when desired. This can be helpful for people with reading difficulties or people who have vision difficulties that make reading a strain on their eyes. Of course, some people simply like to be read to every now and then. Settings in Spoken Content let you select text to be read out loud. Alternatively, you can swipe downwards on any screen with two fingers and have the contents read aloud. For blind people encountering a speaking bar as they go about their business, turn off the Speak Selection option and all your hang-ups with the speaking bar, which has somehow become active, will be a problem of the past.
    The Audio Descriptions setting is the last in the Vision area. You can use this to make any descriptive audio included in videos, shows, and movies be played automatically by apps that support this setting. This can make a tremendous difference in the ability of someone who is blind or can't see well enough to follow action on the screen. The Apple TV and iTunes apps, plus others like Netflix, will honour this setting and play descriptive tracks when they're available. If you have the Audio Descriptions setting on but don't hear described audio while using a third-party app, remember to check for options within that app. Especially after you start content playing. Seek options in the controls that emerge when you double tap on the video.
Physical and Motor
The settings in this section help people who find it physically difficult to use the standard touchscreen interface. The difficulties can stem from a wide range of causes, from cerebral palsy through to paralysis. This is where the Voice Control setting is found. Voice Control will be described in its own section later. Meanwhile, there are a whole range of other settings to help people adjust the interface to their needs.
Touch
The settings behind this button are designed to help people who find it hard to touch and operate the screen. Some of these may prove helpful, but I've found some features that I've actually chosen to disable. These include Reachability, which lowers the top half of the screen when you swipe down at the bottom of the screen so that the top is easier to reach. You hear a small hiss indicating when this has occurred. I find this very annoying and disabled Reachability, so stuff would stay the heck where it was.
    Another potentially annoying or helpful feature depending on your circumstances is Tap to Wake. This will, as its name suggests, cause your display to wake up when you tap it anywhere with a finger. This feature won't unlock your device for you. You still need to do that. However, I found that when I carried my iPhone in my pocket, it would tend to come alive and start reading out the time or my notifications as I walked along. I doubt this would be as likely to occur while using an iPad. It can be nice not to have to use the Action button to awaken your device from slumber.
Switch Control
This lets you operate your iOS device using any of a wide range of devices that are all basically "switches". These can be on or off, and you would perhaps nod your head, breathe, blink, etc. to indicate your intention. I've never heard of a blind person using this in conjunction with VoiceOver. However, given how flexible these features are, I believe it should be possible if possibly frustrating. The cursor moves over options, and you need to activate the switch when it reaches what you desire.
    You can adjust all sorts of things including how options are grouped, how fast the cursor moves over things, and much more. There are sound settings, so you might find it helpful to use these in conjunction with VoiceOver. I have never had occasion to use any switch devices, so I have no idea how well this might work. I've heard that it's possible to use the camera built into your device as a switch. You can nod your head and possibly do other facial gestures to indicate your intent.
Hearing
These settings are for people with anywhere from mild hearing difficulties through to people who are completely unable to hear sound. Some hearing devices are made for use with Apple products and take advantage of Made For iPhone (MFi) technology. If you use such devices or other hearing aids, you'll find settings in this section to help maximize what you can do. This includes streaming sound via Bluetooth to your hearing aids. You will also find a TTY setting letting you use the Phone app to make and receive TTY calls. I see no reason why this wouldn't work in conjunction with VoiceOver. If you have a hardware TTY device, you can pair it to your iPhone and have it used rather than Apple's TTY software if you prefer.
    The Audio/Visual button has settings to do things like adjust the balance between left and right or force mono audio playback. These settings don't require hearing aids and may prove useful to blind people with hearing difficulties. One of these is called "power on and off sounds". Having this set to on will cause your iPhone to vibrate and play short musical sounds to indicate when your iPhone is turned on or off. Helpful when turning your iPhone on with the power button, this audible and tactile confirmation can be especially useful when your iPhone restarts during the updating process.
General
This area currently contains four small branches. The first is Guided Access. This may be useful for people with attention issues. It keeps you in a single app and allows you to control which features you want to use. You can set time limits and a passcode to override this confinement. The Accessibility Shortcut can be used to turn this feature on or off. I've most often heard of this being used in the classroom to keep the attention of students focused on apps used for assignments.
    The next item is Siri. If you cannot speak clearly enough for Siri to understand your voice, you can set an option in this branch that lets you type your commands and queries. When you invoke Siri, a typing field will appear. SIRI can still respond via voice and text on the screen as normal. You can also choose when you want to receive voice feedback rather than just text on the screen.
    The next item under the General, Accessibility heading is a crucial one. It is the Accessibility Shortcut. On devices with a Home button, press this three times rapidly to invoke the Accessibility Shortcut. On devices without a home button, press the Action button on the side of the device three times rapidly. The Accessibility Shortcut can be set to activate and deactivate one or more accessibility options that you find useful. Most blind people will set the shortcut for turning VoiceOver on or off. You can set it to also turn on other features such as Zoom, Voice Control, Switch Control, or Invert Colours, among other features. Be aware that if you do this, VoiceOver won't automatically start speaking when the shortcut is invoked. Instead, a menu of any selected option will be put on the screen. For instance, VoiceOver and Hearing controls. To make a choice, drag your finger across the bottom of the screen. When you move over a choice, it will be announced out loud. Once you've found the choice you want, simply lift your finger after hearing it spoken and the feature will be toggled on or off. People should set up this shortcut right away after setting up their iOS device so that the accessibility features they need will be easy to turn on or off as desired.
    A new addition to this area as of iOs 18 is called per-app settings. Sometimes, it's use-full to have different accessibility settings active or behaving differently for certain apps. This area allows you to customize mainly touch and vision related features. For now, this doesn't include any settings which I've personally found useful being totally blind. However, people with other disabilities in addition to blindness may ind some useful options here. Also, Apple might add to the features which it's possible to customize on a per-app basis in future updates.
Action Button:
This will appear on any iPhone which has an action button rather than a mute switch positioned above the volume buttons along the left side. There's a simple slider letting you make a primary selection. For instance, you might select the Voice Memos setting so that holding the action button in will cause the Voice Memos app to continue recording a new memo until you release the button. The options along the slider include accessibility, silent mode, focus, and numerous others. After choosing an option, flick right to find an additional "choose" button, which will let you specify further what you want the action button to do for you. For instance, after selecting the controls option on the slider, flicking right will reveal a button which you can use to select which control you want the action button to invoke. For example, quicknote.
Apple Intelligence and Siri:
This area contains settings that let you customize how you invoke Siri and which apps are allowed to tie into Siri. This is also where you'll decide aspects of how the new Apple Intelligence will interact with your activities and apps. These settings are covered later in this guide in a section called Siri and Apple Intelligence.
Camera:
There are a great many settings in the Camera branch. On the latest iPhones, these include settings for the camera control. This smooth sensitive patch is a combined touch surface and button found along the right side a small distance below the lock and power button. You can set it to do things like control the zoom of the camera when you slide your finger along it. Clicking the camera button and holding it in will always activate the visual intelligence feature if your iPhone supports it.
The Security Grouping:
Past this point, we enter a short stretch of branches which relate to security and privacy of information on your iPhone. This area contains Touch/Face ID and Passcode, Emergency SOS, and ends with Privacy and Security. Apple has moved a number of options which used to be their own branches into offshoots of these three. Others which somewhat broke up the theme of security have been moved to other places. For instance, the Battery branch is now found before the general settings branch.
Touch/Face ID & Passcode
This is where you set up your passcode and other biometric security measures that keep your information safe on your iOS device. To learn more, please read the section in this guide called Privacy and Security.
Emergency SOS
This feature lets you easily use your iPhone to call emergency services if you're ever in need of them. This requires that your iPhone have a SIM card or ESIM. There are a number of settings in here that are all fairly self-explanatory. If your device has a Home button, you can press it rapidly five times to trigger the Emergency SOS feature. When this is done, any contacts you have set up in the Health settings will be alerted and shown your location. Also, the phone will count down and then call whatever the local emergency number is. For instance, in Canada, this is 911.
    As of iOS, 15, the new default method to initiate an emergency call is to hold in the power button and one of the volume buttons at the same time. After a short period, the emergency procedures will start. This should work much better for blind people and prevent them from accidentally triggering an emergency call while attempting to do the triple click accessibility shortcut to activate or deactivate VoiceOver. There is a setting that appears if you've elected to use Automatic Calling. In this case, a warning sound will play as the countdown before the call is made happens. You can turn off this warning sound if you wish. If your iPhone has no Home button, the power button is used instead. The Call with power Button setting may be a good setting to turn off. Recall that pressing the power button three times is how you invoke the Accessibility Shortcut. Some people have accidentally triggered a call to emergency services when they were clicking the Power button too rapidly and not putting a pause in between sets of three clicks. Turning off the setting will prevent this ever, resulting in five rapid clicks being counted and acted upon. This makes it safe to invoke the Accessibility Shortcut quickly. Unfortunately, this safeguard doesn't seem to be available on older iPhones with home buttons, like my iPhone 7. When Call with Side Button is turned off, you can still invoke Emergency SOS by holding down the Volume Up and Side buttons for around a second. A menu then pops up containing an emergency option as well as an option to shut down your iPhone.
Privacy Settings
These settings are discussed in the section called Privacy and Security.
Wallet & Apple Pay Settings
This branch lets you set up Apple Pay. This feature lets you pay for things in the real world as well as online using your iOS device. Rather than presenting a credit card, you can simply hold your device near a point-of-sale machine and follow the steps to use Apple Pay. This involves verifying your identity using Face or Touch ID, holding your iOS device near the point-of-sale machine, and double clicking the Side button. This branch of settings is also where you can add cards to your Wallet for use with Apple Pay.
    Other settings in this branch let you choose whether Apple Pay is available from the lock screen, set up a transit card, and more. Apple Pay is widely supported at retail stores and other places of commerce. This adds the security of not divulging your credit card details, since a one-time code is used for any purchase you make with Apple Pay.
Passwords & Accounts
This setting is discussed in the section called Privacy and Security.
Apps:
As of iOS 18, you will find a button called "Apps" at the very bottom of the Settings options. Double tapping this will get you into a large area where any settings related to various apps can be found. This is the case regardless of whether they're made by Apple or by a third-party developer. This is whee to look for settings related to such things as mail, Contacts, Calendar, Notes, Reminders, Voice Memos, Phone, Messages, FaceTime, Maps, Compass, Measure, Safari, News, Stocks, Health, Shortcuts, Music, TV, Photos, Camera, Books, Podcasts, etc. If there's an app with the appropriate name on your iPhone, this is where you'll find the settings for it. Apps in the list are always kept in alphabetical order. Simply double tap on the name of an app to get to its settings. Navigate quickly through to the app you want using the slider or the index, which lets you flick up or down quickly to each letter. Alternatively, there's a search field where you can type in the name of the app you are looking for. These facilities for navigation will grow increasingly useful as your collection of apps expands over time.
App Store Settings
In this small branch of apps, you can make decisions regarding whether content and apps you purchase from the app store or iTunes are downloaded automatically or not. You'll find on/off toggles for a number of purchase categories. These include apps, updates to those apps, music, Apple Books and audiobooks. Next, you'll find a heading called Cellular Data. Below it, you'll find an option to choose whether automatic download can occur using cellular data, rather than just when connected to Wi-Fi. Next to this, you'll find an option where you can decide to be asked if a download will be larger than a set number of megabytes.
    Other settings let you decide whether videos play automatically while in the app store. When VoiceOver or other accessibility settings are active, they may set this to off so that you're not distracted by videos playing. The final setting here lets you determine whether you'll be asked for ratings and reviews. These can be helpful for others making decisions about which apps, books, or music to purchase. Providing such information is always optional, even when this setting is in the on setting.
Mail Settings
This branch gives you the ability to configure the Mail app that comes with your device. There are many options, including whether you want messages organized into conversation threads. There are choices about when or if you want to be notified when new messages arrive. You can manage blocked email addresses, decide whether you want images to be loaded automatically onto your device, and much more. For more information, please refer to the user guide that Apple makes available for your device. Also, remember that if you aren't happy with the Mail app these settings help you configure, there are many other options available in the app store.
Contacts Settings
This branch lets you configure how the Contacts app behaves. You can determine how contacts are organized. Most of the settings deal with this. However, at the very end of these is a button that lets you import contacts from a SIM card. This may ease the process of transferring to an iPhone from another kind of phone if you've already put contacts on the card.
Calendar Settings
There are a few settings in this branch that configure the calendar. You can choose a default calendar, override the current time zone, so appointments are displayed in a time zone of your choosing, determine which calendars are used, etc. The last toggle setting determines whether Siri will offer location advice, such as an estimated time to travel from your current location.
Notes Settings
The Notes app provides a way to quickly write or draw things as the need arises. There are a number of useful configuration options here. For example, you can secure your notes with a password, keeping them safe from others who might use your device. You can decide how notes are sorted or whether grid lines are placed automatically on notes to aid in drawing, etc. For blind people, the most useful of these settings is at the end of the branch. The Access Notes from Lock Screen setting will let you choose to have a new note open whenever you use the Control Centre to access the Notes app. This can be very handy if you are on the move and need to quickly get to a space where it's possible to write or dictate information. You can have it start a new note or simply continue in the current note.
Reminders Settings
This is a small branch, as the Reminders app doesn't require a lot of settings. You can set a default list if you want one apart from the automatically generated one. You can also set a time when you'll be notified of any reminders that don't have a specific time during the day. You can also decide whether reminders are shown as overdue starting from the day after their due date.
Voice Memos Settings
Again, there isn't a lot here. However, you can choose whether the Voice Memos app saves recordings in compressed or lossless quality. Also, you can choose whether these memos are named based on the location where they're recorded.
Phone Settings
This is where you would go if you have an iPhone and you want to configure anything related to actual phone service. You can do things like silence all unknown callers so that all unknown calls are automatically sent to voicemail. You can manage blocked callers, choose whether calls are announced, and much more. Please refer to the user guide for your iPhone.
Messages and FaceTime Settings
There are many settings here that let you optimize how messages are dealt with. The Messages app lets you send and receive text messages to people who have other kinds of cellular phones. It's worth exploring the settings in here to make certain that the Message app behaves as you would like it to. Please refer to your user guide for more thorough discussion of the options here. There aren't any settings of particular use to blind people here, and the default options have served me quite well.
    Similarly, there are options for FaceTime that largely mirror those for messages. As FaceTime is exclusively for communications between Apple devices, there are fewer settings for it. One setting of note lets you determine whether live photos can be captured during a conversation. For blind people, there may be no audible indication when someone you're talking to decides to capture a photo. If you're worried about this, you can turn this feature off to help insure your privacy.
Maps Settings
There are many settings here. You can choose a preferred style of travel to be used when getting directions. It is also possible to choose units of distance, have weather information displayed, and much more. In the Driving & Navigation button, you can select the volume of navigation announcements, and choose whether other spoken content like podcasts are automatically paused during announcements. You can also choose how relatively loud you want such announcements to be. For more details, please refer to the user guide for your device as well as the section called Maps, Taps, and GPS Apps.
Safari Settings
There are a lot of settings that allow you to configure the Safari web browser included with your device. Please refer to the section called On Safari to learn about these settings and more.
Health Settings
There are a number of settings here that determine how the Health app behaves and what data it has to work from. For blind people, one of the more important aspects is the Notifications setting. You can have health-related notifications delivered in a style that differs from your default settings if you wish. This is also where you can enter your health profile and Medical ID. The Medical ID can be accessed from the Emergency Dialer even when your device is locked. It contains information about you, such as allergies or medical conditions that emergency attendants should know about. The Health Profile contains other information such as sex, age, and blood and skin type, etc. More is added depending on which apps and accessories you might use.
    The Data Access & Devices button lets you control what can access and be a source of data for the Health app. This includes third-party apps and equipment such as smart scales, fitness machines, etc. It also includes other Apple devices, such as an Apple Watch or iPad. You can always revoke access to this data. For a lot more information, please refer to the user guide provided by Apple for your specific device.
Music, Books, TV, and Podcast Settings
Each service has a number of useful settings that will be discussed in the appropriate sections of this guide. There are a number of very useful settings that allow you to configure the Music app. These include an EQ option, which has a lot of different choices to alter how your music sounds. Please refer to the section called Carrying a Great Many Tunes.
    Settings that affect how books are displayed, how large an interval is jumped backward or forward when navigating audiobooks, and more are found here. Please refer to the section called Read All About It.
    The Podcasts app has a number of significant settings, especially when it comes to how much data is used. Please refer to the section called Internet Radio and Podcasts.
Further Thoughts on Settings
This is by no means an exhaustive tour. However, we've now covered a lot of the major settings where it makes sense not to cover them elsewhere in the guide. This section could easily have reached over fifty thousand words had we included painstaking explanations of all settings in the same place. Apple has done a lot to lessen the sprawling nature of the root and branches of Settings. It feels a lot more approachable and organized. Moving the settings of all the apps produced by Apple into the ever expandable "Apps" area certainly reduces clutter. This is the change which has taken the longest for me to become accustomed to. With over four hundred apps, I have a lot to move through. However, the index slider and headings rotor do a lot to eliminate any irritation. I can get to where I need to be relatively quickly.
    This is the main point of overall control between you and iOS. Just because we didn't discuss an option doesn't mean it's not present. Always check Settings if you want an app to behave in a certain way, but can find no way to achieve that from within the app itself. For instance, the game Six Ages has a number of special settings. One of these is a way to set the volume of sounds and music. You could use this to lower the volume to make it easier to hear VoiceOver during game play while still enjoying the full experience. Lots of little treasures like that await you in the farther reaches of Settings. Never give up until you have looked in Settings to see if there might be an option that does what you wish.

Managing Sound on iOS Devices:
For blind people, sound tends to loom large in everyday life. It takes on a primary role that is often not fully appreciated by people with sight. One thing which tends to be important to blind users is how an operating system handles sound from various sources and how one controls this. For example, can you be certain that you'll always hear the VoiceOver screen reader even if you're listening to loud music or a show? On the other hand, is it possible to make certain you don't miss part of an online conversation because an unwanted notification suddenly read by VoiceOver blots out a speaker's words? How easy is it to alter the overall balance in order to hear higher frequencies more clearly?
    The iOS operating system has evolved as the hardware grew in power from a time when iPhones were looked at as little more than accessories. As a result, many of its tools for managing sound are outgrowths of this earlier more simple time. Now that these devices are as powerful as many desktop computers, decisions made back then are showing their age. Ways to manage sound are scattered throughout various areas of iOS. There's no central point for sound management or mixing. This section is my attempt to help you navigate and know about all of the audio related capabilities at your disposal. I'll also point out where you need to go in iOS to take as much control of what you hear as iOS allows you to do. Thankfully, things have markedly improved in iOS 18. Readers of previous editions of this guide should particularly pay attention to the updates to audio ducking. Let us begin this ramshackle trip at an obvious starting point.
A Volumetric Mystery Tour:
Checking my email one morning, I found a rather panicky message from a man whose iPhone had gone unexpectedly silent on him overnight. He had listened to music and read a book before falling asleep. Not at all an unusual way for an iPhone owner to wind down. He had a very pleasant time. There were no problems hearing the music, the book or the VoiceOver screen reader. Upon waking up, he tried to check the time by pressing the action button. Since the iPhone was left on and plugged in to charge overnight, he was surprised to hear nothing at all from his iPhone. What happened?
    The cause of this stubborn silence on the part of his iPhone turned out to be the way iOS handles volume levels. He had been enjoying the music and other audio while wearing his AirPods. Apple separately keeps track of the volume levels you last set while wearing AirPods, using other headsets or Bluetooth speakers, and when you listen using the built-in speakers in your device. The presumption being that people will prefer different volume levels in circumstances when they use any of these different methods. This way, when they next use a particular method of listening, the volume will be closer to what they're likely to want, and they'll have to adjust it less often.
    This tends to work quite well for people who can see. They can quickly ascertain the volume level visually. For people who need to hear their iPhones to have any kind of control over them beyond a very basic level, this can cause trouble. It's hard to change settings if you can't even navigate to them. Moments of terror might not be too overly dramatic.
    This fellow plugged the iPhone in while still wearing his AirPods. He therefore heard the bing made when the iPhone began charging. Next, he locked his iPhone, took out his AirPods and plugged them in to charge. Placing both items on a nightstand, he went to sleep.
    The unexpected and unwanted moments of silence from his iPhone which he experienced upon waking certainly got him galvanized in a heaping hurry.
    The seeds of this rude awakening were actually set in motion much earlier. Just before putting his AirPods in for an evening's enjoyment, he had gotten himself a drink and settled into a comfortable chair. His iPhone was in his pocket. Reaching to set down the drink on a table, he unknowingly pressed the lower volume button in against a harder point of an armrest. Because no sound was made as the volume dropped quickly to zero, he had no idea of this. The volume button was held in by being squished against the armrest. It was released when he straightened in his chair and removed his iPhone from his pocket. He hadn't expected to hear anything from his iPhone until putting in his AirPods. As usual, he heard the friendly bong indicating his AirPods were ready and proceeded to enjoy the evening.
    The iOS operating system remembered the volume he last set while using AirPods and had switched to that level. Meanwhile, the speaker volume was at zero. Having no idea that iOS kept separate track of volume levels, this man had no cause to suspect trouble. Thankfully, others on the email list had experienced this before and all was quickly set right again.
    Beyond keeping track of different volume settings for different accessories, there are other volume related quirks to be aware of. The volume buttons will raise and lower the overall volume of all sound sources. This is true even if they have separate volume controls. Therefore, you can have the VoiceOver volume set all the way at a hundred percent but won't hear any speech if the general volume level is set to zero. VoiceOver can't ever be louder than the general volume level. However, it's quite possible to set the VoiceOver volume all the way down to 1%. You won't hear VoiceOver speaking even if your iPhone volume is set to 100% unless your ear is very close to the iPhone and there's no other noise where you are.
    The bit exception to this is for a category of sounds called "ringer and alerts". If you go into settings and into an area called "sound and haptics", You will find a heading called "ringer and alerts". After that heading, there is a volume slider which you can use to set a different volume level for these important sounds. This way, you can be certain that you'll hear the phone ring and hear other critical notification sounds. Meanwhile, you can have music or other media you're listening to be at a quieter volume.
    Here's another potential trouble spot for the unaware. You can choose whether to be able to adjust the ringer and alert volume level with the volume buttons, or have it only be adjustable by going into Settings and moving that slider. The latter option is what I recommend. If you let the volume buttons adjust the ringer and alerts, keep in mind that changes you make in a panicked moment when the phone ringer goes off too loudly for a given situation will persist afterwards. You might get a message sound during a meeting and quickly quiet it via the volume buttons only to miss a phone call later on because the ringer was now set very quiet. You can only use the volume buttons to make adjustments while the ringer or alert sounds which are long enough are playing. Raising the overall volume when no alert sound or ringer is playing won't affect the volume for ringer and alert sounds. If you have the volume buttons unable to adjust the ringer and alerts, you can set a level you prefer in most situations and know that it'll be locked in until you go into Settings and adjust it.
    Rather than providing users with a group of sliders which control the volume level for various audio sources, Apple has taken a different path. Basically, you adjust the volume of whatever audio is active at the time. Thus, if you're listening to music, this is what will decrease or increase when you use the slider in the control panel or the volume buttons on your device.
    Many apps have their own handy volume controls. This is especially welcome and likely when you're dealing with apps which create ambient background sound. The Nature Space and My Noise apps are two good examples of this. You can use volume controls inside the app to set the volume of the ambient sound to a level lower than the general volume and lower than VoiceOver speech output. This way, you can have steady soundscapes in the background while you work. There's a volume control in the Music app. However, it seems to be set to adjust the general volume level. This works well for sighted users who aren't reliant on hearing a screen reader. VoiceOver volume can be controlled via a rotor setting or in the VoiceOver quick settings if you have volume as an active option. However, it's still relative to the general volume level. For example, let's say you're hearing music at the volume of 75%. If you set VoiceOver to 100%, it will be just as loud as the music. You can lower the VoiceOver volume to 75% and the music will be 25% louder than the speech output from VoiceOver.
    In the event that you're faced with the situation where you've accidentally set your VoiceOver volume down to 1%, raising the overall volume level to maximum should allow you to hear VoiceOver speaking very quietly. With your ear near the iPhone, you should be able to hear it enough to get to the VoiceOver volume in the rotor, Quick settings or regular VoiceOver settings where you can raise it. If you put VoiceOver volume in your quick settings and remove it from your rotor, this should reduce the chances of accidentally adjusting the VoiceOver volume.
    Overall volume can be adjusted by the volume buttons even while your iPhone is locked. This wonderfully facilitates changing the volume while the iPhone is in your pocket. However, just like what happened to our man with the silent iPhone, the same thing could potentially happen in other circumstances. The volume buttons will move the level up or down by around six percent when pressed in. When VoiceOver is active, you'll actually hear a kind of tick each time you do this. However, if a volume button is held in, it will change the level rapidly and make no ticking sound until you release the button. Apple has introduced tactile feedback which can alert you. However, if you have it turned off or set to a weaker level like many people opt for, you likely won't feel it while the iPhone isn't in your hand. Given this, the first thing to do if you're faced with a silent iPhone is to push the upper volume button and release it quickly. Keep doing that until you hear ticks and use those to fine tune your volume. That's far less potentially startling than having VoiceOver speak and possibly say something loudly. 
The Safety And Peril of Audio Ducking:
One feature Apple included in VoiceOver is designed to make absolutely certain that speech output supersedes all other audio which might be coming from your device. Audio ducking instantly, and potentially drastically, reduces the volume of any audio while VoiceOver is speaking. You'll never miss an important notification, even if you're listening to an action movie at full volume.
    So what's the peril with this kind of arrangement? Basically, if you have audio ducking set too high, you'll cause other audio to be ducked so low that you may miss significant information conveyed by it rather than VoiceOver. The audio remains ducked for around a second after VoiceOver has stopped speaking.
    Thankfully, Apple has finally given you control over how much the other audio is ducked below speech. Also, you have the very welcome option of setting audio ducking either to always on, or only when speaking. These settings can be made available on the rotor or in VoiceOver quick settings. Now that this is the case, you have a high level of quick and flexible control over the balance between VoiceOver and other audio. Just remember that audio ducking effects the ringer and alert sounds. Setting audio ducking too high might result in those being missed. One solution to this is to turn on haptics so that you'll at least feel vibrations when things happen in the background.
    Let's say you're attending an online conference with live panel discussions. In that kind of situation, you might want to turn audio ducking off and even decrease VoiceOver volume so that the discussion voices are loudest, but you can still hear VoiceOver well enough to take notes. On the other hand, if you're putting in long hours writing, you might want a stable level of background sound or music to help you stay focussed. In that kind of situation, having audio ducking set to always on and finding the most suitable amount of ducking is the best way to keep everything steady. If you have audio ducking set to only drop the audio when VoiceOver speaks, the level of the other audio will keep fluctuating. Entering a character which is read back by typing echo will cause a second of ducking. This may work well if you only need a low level of ducking, but you'll find it jarring at higher ducking levels. . Sticking with that movie example, you might miss key information such as a moment of dialogue or events which happen while VoiceOver is speaking. This will cut into your enjoyment of the movie for something you could just as well have waited to hear after you finished. Each time you navigate to controls to pause or take other action, VoiceOver will drop the level of audio, and you'll miss possibly key moments entirely. Change these settings as you need to with the rotor or quick settings.
    One approach to having adjustments be more automatic is through VoiceOver activities. You can take advantage of VoiceOver activities to have settings like audio ducking turn off automatically when you're watching a show, using Zoom, etc. This approach has the advantage of only having to create activities once for each circumstance where you want different settings to apply. The catch is that you might not want the same circumstances all the time when using particular apps or doing certain things.
Headphone Accommodations:
If you have Apple or Beats headphones, including all types of AirPods and EarPods as well as Beats headphones, you can tap into this handy feature. It boosts the volume of a range of frequencies. You can use Apple's default settings for boosting balanced tones, vocal range, or bright high frequencies. This can make things much easier to hear. Especially if you have any kind of moderate hearing loss.
    You'll find this capability in the Accessibility settings. Specifically, head to the audio/visual area found under the "Hearing" heading of accessibility settings. Once there, double tap on headphone accommodation. You'll find several options. One of these will let you create a custom audio setup. This will guide you through asking questions and getting a sense of what you want to hear more clearly. For many of us, this might be overkill. Instead, you can do what I've done. I used one of the three generic choices. The first of these boosts a balanced range of frequencies so that softer sounds or parts of music are louder. Another choice concentrates on the vocal range, so voices are more clear and easy to distinguish. The third choice raises the volume of higher frequencies so things sound brighter. This can be very helpful making VoiceOver speech output stand out more clearly. There are three levels of strength from light, moderate or strong. This lets you further customize how much the sound is modified without choices becoming overwhelming.
    In my case, the balanced strong combination works very well for me. I can typically hear VoiceOver even while listening to background music, podcasts, etc. This is a much appreciated option which can sometimes let me avoid needing to use audio ducking while I work. I don't need to worry as much about missing out on notifications or being pulled out of my sound environment.
    For people who have hearing aids and have access to their audiogram, you can import that and have it adjust the frequencies specific to your hearing loss. This might make all the difference for your experience with using VoiceOver. Especially while listening to additional sound on your iPhone like music, podcasts, etc.
Music Related Settings:
The other area where you'll find plenty of settings to change how things sound is in the music settings. I go through these settings in some detail in the section related to music. However, I'll highlight a few especially important ones here.
    The sound check option will attempt to normalize the volume of the music you play so that you aren't plagued by large jumps in volume level. This certainly helps keep things within tolerable variance from track to track. I basically leave the setting on. Some albums might intentionally vary the volume of songs as part of the overall performance. You may want to disable the feature if this is the case in order to allow that variation to happen.
    The other major treasure in the music settings is the EQ button. This lets you pick from a wide range of different EQ settings which change how music sounds. This can be helpful in making it possible to listen to music while still being able to hear VoiceOver speech output. In particular, people may wish to try the "Late Night" setting. There are quite a few options in the music settings so I would encourage everyone to explore these thoroughly.
Sound Thinking:
Besides various volume levels, iOS also records what audio you last played. Let's say I'm listening to some music and want to switch to hearing a podcast. I go into the Castro app, my podcast player app of choice. If I thoughtlessly try to start it playing using the two finger double tap or "magic tap", I'll hear the music that I was previously listening-to continue to play. It still as focus as the last active audio source. I need to use the play option in the Castro app to start hearing the podcast I expect, and for that app to now have the position of default audio source. If I go back into the Music app, I need to use the play or Shuffle buttons to start hearing music again. After I do this, I can then pause or resume playback using the magic tap from where-ever I happen to be in iOS.
    When we hold small objects, such as an iPhone, we tend to think in smaller terms. Naturally, you think of earbuds, a headset, or perhaps, a small hand-held Bluetooth speaker. However, we shouldn't limit our thinking. That small slab has tremendous potential for sharing unlimited sound. Using Bluetooth and a feature called AirPlay, your iPhone can send audio to a broad range of speakers, headsets, TVs and more. I can show up at a friend's house with my iPhone ready to tap into Bluetooth capable outdoor speakers in the backyard during a barbecue dinner. The four thousand plus songs I have onboard should last hundreds of hours if necessary. I can bring my own portable battery powered Bluetooth speaker plus a power bank containing enough juice to easily last a weekend in a small bag I carry over my shoulder. On a rainy day, I could just as easily provide movie entertainment sending the latest movies to a home theatre setup with Dolby Atmos or 5.1 digital surround sound. The technology has arrived at the stage where there's no choppy buffering or anything like that.
    For blind people who have no use for big screens, an iPhone is a splendid audio entertainment system when paired with appropriate accessories. Two HomePod Mini speakers, no larger than baseballs, serve my wife and I quite admirably from two corners of my desk in our apartment. We listen to everything from radio stations to online events to movies and audio dramas together. AirPods, or even USBC powered EarPods, offer excellent sound considering their tiny size.
    Data storage, cellular data and Wi-Fi speeds make your iPhone a fantastic device to carry audio with you while travelling. Even a 64 GB iPhone can store hundreds of hours of audio. Once you understand how to use VoiceOver and learn the conventions of iOS, you can do quite a lot with your iPhone working with audio. This holds true for recording and creating audio as well. From the basic to the very complex, there are apps which can turn your iPhone into a powerful recorder and processor.
    I very much enjoy being able to cary so much sound, which inspires me everywhere I go. From full cast audio dramas recorded in surround sound to all my favourite audiobooks, podcasts, pop and instrumental music, I'll never run out of things to listen to and share with others who are so inclined.

Privacy and Security:
These days, the selection of music, audiobooks, ebooks, apps, movies and more that you can enjoy on your iOS device is staggering. So is the amount of personal information you'll soon have stored on the device if you make good use of it. Everything from addresses and contact information to health and other data. I remember reflecting after a year with my first iPhone about how much of my personal information and other things were stored there. You don't tend to think about it in totality as you slowly start adding information, so you can do this or that more conveniently. And then, one day, it hits you. The stuff of your life is contained in a flat, light slab of high technology no thicker than a pane of window glass.
    It is also in "the Cloud", as people tend to think of it. In reality, that cloud is a bunch of theoretically secure data storage and servers where you can retrieve it whenever needed, rather than storing absolutely everything on your device itself. This reduces the amount of storage space you need to have on your device. For as long as I've owned an iOS device, I have only heard of one case where someone's iCloud was hacked.
    These devices are designed to be as light and portable as possible. They're supposed to be your digital companions at home and while on the go. They learn a lot about you. There's all the information you intentionally enter like contacts, addresses, locations important to your life, messages, and more. Beyond that, your device learns more about you as you make use of it thanks to onboard artificial intelligence. This very portability and all the information they contain makes them tempting targets for theft. It's in Apple's best interests to protect all that information from theft or abuse by others.
    This goes far beyond your personal information. Protection must also extend to making certain that other people can't steel the addresses of friends and family, books, apps, movies, and music you choose to have on your device. To this end, Apple has gone to great lengths to provide a safe and secure environment for iOS users and those who provide digital content. Many of these measures happen behind the scenes, unnoticed by users going about their lives. For instance, all apps found in the app store must be checked and approved by Apple staff, who are on the lookout for troublemakers. Incidents of malware and viruses are very rare in the iOS ecosystem. No security is foolproof, but Apple has done a superb job in that department. All data on your device and stored in iCloud is encrypted in a way that even Apple can't break. To gain access to a dead terrorist's iPhone, the FBI was forced to engage the services of a security company, who were able to hack into the iPhone at a high cost. Doing so is no trivial exercise. Apple was willing to go to court and refused to create any kind of universal back door to unlock iOS devices suspected of containing valuable information. They can, and will, help law enforcement in any way possible that doesn't reduce the security of innocent owners of their products.
    This section will focus on elements of information security over which it is possible to exercise some direct control. These include privacy settings, passwords, passcodes, and restrictions you can activate or deactivate. This may seem a bit daunting for the non-technical people who might be reading this. By its very nature, security nearly always means a degree of inconvenience. In today's world of information, having at least a basic grasp of these measures is essential for a safe and happy experience in the iOS ecosystem. Apple keeps everything pretty simple from a user's perspective. You don't need to be a technology expert to put security features to good use. What I tend to worry about the most is people who have a hard time remembering passwords or numbers. You only need a few such items to be easily remembered when asked for. However, having them easily recalled and ready to be used is absolutely vital. I would strongly urge anybody with these difficulties to keep a recording or text file handy with that information clearly written or announced. Also, provide a copy of that information to someone who you trust. That will make it much easier to resolve security issues quickly and painlessly with a minimum of inconvenience or involvement from others who might not be as trustworthy.
    Overall, I have had a very positive and safe experience with iOS. Not once have I had to contend with a virus or data theft. While I don't go out of my way to court danger, I don't hesitate to follow links to search results that point to new items of interest. Having been online for over twenty-five years, I have a pretty well-developed but not infallible sense of what's safe and what likely isn't. Were I ever to have my iPhone stolen, I would be far more annoyed at the massive immediate inconvenience this would cause than concerned about my information falling into the wrong hands. I think Apple does a good job with security. There's a balance that needs to be struck between protection and annoyance. Apple has done a good job of minimizing that annoyance while maintaining a very high level of safety.
    Some people find the thought of Apple keeping an eye on things and limiting the apps available for your device to what they approve distasteful and worrying. Personally, I'm pleased they're doing this. I have yet to be stopped from doing anything I wanted to do on my device. I have, on the other hand, been saved from having to deal with some nasty surprises people using other operating systems such as Android have found lurking on their devices.
    Some people will get these devices and then refuse to create an Apple account or use other features due to a paranoia of big bad corporations watching their every move. Honestly, if you're that concerned about big data snooping on you, save a lot of money and get an old-fashioned dumb phone or cheaper Android tablet. In fact, you could theoretically get one of each if both were on sale and still come out ahead financially. Choosing not to create an Apple account or not bother with a passcode will place drastic limitations on what you can do with your iOS device. It would be like purchasing a car and not getting brakes an engine or windshield wipers. You couldn't do much besides roll down hill on a clear day. Other than using the apps included on the device, you won't be allowed to get more apps or update the software on your device, etc. Also, any information stored on such an unsecured device would be available to anybody who got their hands on it. You're not saving time or protecting yourself from the big bad corporation. You're just being very stupid. To enjoy the benefits of an iOS device, you simply have to accept that you're entering an economy of information. You essentially make a bargain with Apple and companies whose services and software are used through your device. In exchange for some truly remarkable revolutionary capabilities, including more access to information than blind people have ever before known, you incur the risk that information about you might be stolen or used inappropriately. Either the benefits of participating in activities one uses these devices for is worth the risk to your information privacy, or it isn't. Don't shoot yourself in the foot over misplaced fear. Provided you're not doing anything criminal with an iPhone or iPad, Apple really doesn't care what you're up to. Take precautions using the security tools discussed here and enjoy what owning an iOS device will let you accomplish.
Setting up or Changing Security:
If you don't skip the steps during initial setup of your device, you'll be putting security in place while completing the overall process. The steps will be appropriate to the technology included in your particular device. At a minimum, you will be asked to create an Apple account if you don't already have one. If you're setting up a secondary device or upgrading to a new one, you should use the same Apple account. This gives you access to any personal information stored in iCloud plus apps or other things you've already purchased from Apple. For each device you own, you'll have the option to set a passcode. Next, depending on the device you have, you'll be able to set up Touch or Face ID. Apple strongly encourages the use of security features. However, it is possible to skip some of these steps during setup. This may seem like a good move while you're learning how to work with your device. However, I think it's far better for people to get used to working with the security features right from the start, so they're part of your process and don't seem as burdensome. For people with learning disabilities or difficulties remembering things, skipping the security steps might ease the initial stages of becoming proficient. You can always change your mind and turn on features later once you're more comfortable using your device. Do this as soon as possible so that you're protected and able to use the features which require that you make use of security options.
    After setup is complete, you can go into areas within the Settings app to change security. These include the first item in Settings labelled with your name, the Touch ID & Passcode area, the Privacy area, and the "Screen Time" area. Also, there is the Auto-Lock setting found in the Display & Brightness area.
Your Apple account:
In the process of setting up your device, you'll be asked to log in with an Apple account you already have or create one if it's your first device. Ideally, each customer should have one Apple account. It's your central account with Apple. When you create an Apple account, it is used to keep track of all information of your dealings with Apple. You use it in the app store when you buy apps and in Apple Books when you buy books. It's also used when making subscriptions to services like Apple Music. Any information you store in iCloud is also tied to your Apple account.
    An Apple account consists of an email address and password. It is absolutely vital that you remember these. They're your way of proving to Apple who you are. The email address should be one you actually check because there may be occasions where Apple contacts you. Also, you are sent receipts for any purchases via this address. The password you choose needs to be something you can recall, while still being hard for someone else to figure out, even if they know you. When deciding on a password, you should err on the side of it being easy for you to remember, rather than being some complex alphanumeric sequence that confounds everyone including yourself. I've spent hours failing to help people start from scratch after forgetting their password or the code they've used to lock their devices. The bottom line is that all I can do is try to help you remember your passcode and password. Beyond that, you'll need to call Apple or make use of other account recovery options I'll review below. Apple's tech support staff cannot circumvent security. While there are recovery steps, they take time and are done by a separate department. Apple would rather deny you access than risk all of your information getting into the wrong hands. Remember your Apple account and the password you picked for it. They're your ultimate key. Keep it handy and safe, like you would do for the key to your home. These devices will be like a digital home.
    When asked to enter your Apple account and password, a form will appear on-screen with separate fields for each piece of information. The email address will typically be filled in already and occupies the first field near the top of the screen. You can double tap on a field to go into Edit mode, allowing you to enter or change information. When in Edit mode, you can find the Go or Done button that should be double tapped to indicate you're finished with that field. The Delete button will be above the Shift and Go buttons near the bottom-right corner. The next field will be for your password. Enter that and then find the Go button on the bottom right when finished.
Account Recovery Options:
Depending on your security needs, you have a few choices as of iOS 15 when it comes to getting access to your account and data if you forget your Apple account and password. If you can still log into another trusted Apple device, you could simply get a verification code which you could enter on the device you're locked out of. You would then be able to verify that you're the owner of the device and regain access.
    Past that point, you'll need to use Apple's other recovery options. By default, you would be using Apple's data recovery service. This doesn't recover anything which is end-to-end encrypted, like passwords or other sensitive information. However, it will give you access to photos and other things like notes. This process involves you calling Apple and convincing the staff that you're who you say you are. This process may take days and is designed to err on the side of caution.
    A far easier process, presuming you have someone you trust implicitly, is to add them as a recovery contact. This will be of tremendous help to forgetful people. If you forget your Apple account, password, etc, you can call your contact or ask them in person for help. The person you add as a recovery contact must also have an Apple device running iOS 15 or later. They must have two-factor authentication turned on and also be using a passcode to lock their device. He or she must be 13 or over.
    To add someone as a recovery contact, go into the Apple account section at the top of Settings. It usually has your name as the title. Flick right until you get to "password and security". Next, double tap on this and then flick right to "account recovery". Double tap on this and then flick right until you find "add recovery contact". You should then double tap this and flick right. You'll be presented with some information about what a recovery contact has and the basic process. Flick right and double tap on "add recovery contact". You can then choose contacts from Apple's suggestions or add someone else entirely. Once you've selected the person, Apple will present you with a default message to send which asks them to be your recovery contact. You will be notified when they accept or decline. You can always remove recovery contacts, and they can remove you. If this happens, you'll be notified and possibly asked to pick another recovery contact.
    If you're unable to remember your password, you can call your contact or see them in person. They can then use their Apple device to get the code you'll need to recover access to your account. Once you use this code, you'll be taken through the process of deciding a new password, which you'll hopefully remember better. The recovery contact can't use the code they get for anything. It's only good for giving you access to your device. Of course, if he or she is present with you, they could overpower you and use the code to reset your password. It's up to you to pick someone you trust not to do something like that.
    For people who don't want Apple or anybody else having access to their stuff under any circumstances, there is a third option. You can create a recovery key. If you do this, Apple can no longer help you recover any information. Nor can a recovery contact. The key is a twenty-eight character combination of letters and numbers. Once you create the recovery key, you'll need it whenever you reset your password unless you have another trusted Apple device such as a second iPhone, iPad, etc. If you lose the recovery key, you lose access to everything. There's no way to get at your data without that key. I wouldn't recommend this option unless you have a good reason for using it. Keep copies of the key written down or available to access securely, or you will simply have to start from absolute scratch with a new Apple account.
Having a Passcode:
A passcode is a number or alphanumeric sequence that you can use to lock your device. It's exactly like the PIN number you need to access your bank account. Think of it as your first line of defence, or the lock on your front door. A passcode also encrypts mail messages and other data on your device, so you can only access it if you know the number. You should choose a number that you can remember easily. Apple recommends a six-digit passcode, but you're not stuck with that. During the passcode setup process, find the Passcode Options button. Using this, you may opt for an easier four-digit number or a totally customized alphanumeric code of your choosing. You are allowed to use different passcodes for different devices, which are all tied into the same Apple account. Even if you use Touch or Face ID, you'll still need to use the passcode if you restart your device or don't unlock it for a while. You can set things up so that after ten failed attempts to enter the correct passcode, all the data on your device is erased. If that happens, you'll either have to set up your device as a new one or restore from a backup. For the latter course of action, you'll definitely need to know your Apple account and password.
    Make certain you pick a number you can remember easily. This is especially important if you have things set so that everything is erased after ten failed attempts. I can't help people who are completely locked out of their device. Remember your passcode, Apple account and password. They're your keys to everything.
    To enter a passcode, input the digits using the number pad that appears on-screen. There is a Delete key near the bottom right if you make a mistake. If you touch a bit below near the top of the screen, VoiceOver will announce how many values you have entered. For instance, it might say "3 of 6". Once you've entered the correct number of digits, wait a moment. If you've entered it correctly, your device will be unlocked. If not, you'll be informed that the code was incorrect and may try again.
Touch ID:
I tend to think of my fingers as being rather average ones. However, while fingertips may feel similar, they are unique to the point of being able to serve as identification good enough for security checks and court evidence. Apple takes full advantage of this uniqueness to secure the information your device contains.
    Beneath the Home or action buttons of some iOS devices, there is a sophisticated fingerprint scanner that reads your fingerprint and unlocks your device if it matches one that you've authorized. This is what is known as "touch ID". Instead of entering your passcode to unlock your device or approve purchases all the time, you can simply touch the Home button with a finger. You can set up more than one fingerprint for Touch ID. All fingerprints are stored in a secure place on your device called a "secure enclave" that even Apple can't access. Apps and services using this data receive only pass or fail information. You can use Touch ID to approve purchases, use Apple Pay, and many other things. The chances of someone else having a fingerprint similar enough to your own is said to be one in fifty thousand.
    To set up a fingerprint, place your finger on the Home button and then lift it as VoiceOver instructs during the setup process. It will have you place and lift the finger several times, and then have you change your grip before continuing this process. This makes certain that your device has an accurate recording of your finger. When I owned an iPhone 7 which used Touch ID, I did this process for one finger on each hand for greater convenience, so I could unlock my phone using whichever hand worked better at a particular moment. When asked to use Touch ID, simply touch your finger to the Home button on your device, maintaining the contact until you hear a ding and feel a vibration. If you are inaccurate in your placement, it is possible that your finger won't be recognized, and you'll have to make another attempt. I've never had to do this more than twice to be properly recognized.
    Overall, I had a pretty good experience with Touch ID before moving onto iPhones which used Face ID. It was handy to be able to unlock your iPhone using one hand while it was still in your pocket. I could then do things without ever removing my iPhone from my pocket if necessary. For simple tasks like reading books or navigating music, this was a nice convenience. Also, it sped up things like purchasing books or apps marvellously. Instead of entering in passwords, you just touched your finger to the Home button, and your purchase was approved.
    One issue I did occasionally find annoying is that after I washed dishes or if I had wet hands, it became almost impossible to use Touch ID. Especially if your hands were in hot water. I often needed to resort to my passcode to unlock my iPhone until my hands returned to a dry state and normal temperature. Cold weather doesn't help either. You either have to remove a glove to unlock your device or have cold fingers that may not be recognized by Touch ID.
Face ID:
Being totally blind all my life, I've never seen my own reflection. Nor do I have any frame of reference for comparison. One of the first things I was asked to do while setting up my iPhone XR was show it my face. Holding the iPhone in front of me while facing straight ahead, I followed the spoken instructions that told me how to move my head. This movement allowed tiny advanced cameras and sensors mounted near the top of my iPhone to construct a highly detailed, three-dimensional digital model of my face. So highly detailed that it's good enough to be used for payment and banking apps. Thanks to infrared lasers and other sensors, the iPhone I had just brought home now knew more about my face than friends and family who had known me all my life ever could. To unlock my iPhone or approve a purchase, I would simply have to face the camera at the top of my device and click a button twice to confirm my consent. After completing the setup process, I intentionally locked my iPhone and tried using Face ID as I was instructed. It worked like a charm. Each time I used it, artificial intelligence in my iPhone learned more about how to recognize my face from different perspectives in different ambient light.
    This technology is said to be more convenient and far more secure than Touch ID. On the more high-end advanced devices such as the iPhone X or newer, a group of cameras and sensors can recognize your face, allowing it to be used instead of a passcode and Apple account. It can even tell whether you're actively paying attention, presuming you're capable of actually looking at your device. The chances are one in a million that anyone else's face will be similar enough to yours to fool Face ID. The chances are somewhat better if they're related, or you're twins. Every so often, you'll still need to use a passcode to unlock your device, such as after you restart it or if you haven't used Face ID in over forty-eight hours. The same is true for other things like approving purchases. For sighted people, it is very convenient, since they must look at their devices to use them. For blind people, it's easy to use but less convenient than Touch ID, since you need to actually face your device rather than touch the Home button while the device is in your pocket or pack.
    Apple has taken blind people into consideration when designing this security feature. If you have VoiceOver enabled, it will guide you through the setup process, telling you how to move your face, so it can be properly scanned. It will also disable the part of Face ID that looks for attentiveness so that you just need to face your device rather than look at it. This does reduce how secure Face ID is. Someone could knock you out and hold your device up to your face, for instance. However, take this in proper context. If somebody threatened you with bodily harm or worse, you'd probably much rather unlock the device for them anyhow. These things are only as secure as you are.
Setting up Face ID
There was some initial panic back when Apple introduced Face ID. However, it was completely misplaced. VoiceOver guides you through the setup process quite well. It tells you to hold the iPhone in front of your face and to rotate your face so the camera system on the front of your iPhone takes in all the details of your face. I ended up going through this process twice, having rushed through it too quickly the first time. The second time through, I heard and followed more of the instructions I should have waited for the first time. If you go too quickly, VoiceOver doesn't catch some instructions. If you aren't getting good results after your first attempt setting up Face ID, simply double tap on Reset Face ID and go through the procedure again.
    First, after double tapping Set Up Face ID, read the instructions and description of the animation that is displayed. It shows what you need to do. Next, double tap the Got It button to start the procedure.
    Hold your iPhone in portrait mode around half an arm's length away in front of your face. I get good results if the top of my iPhone is around nose level when I start. You then follow the directions to turn your face as if it were a hand on a clock face, where the iPhone is the centre of the clock. If you've never felt an analogue clock, imagine your face is the handle on a crank that turns around the iPhone you're holding in front of your face. This lets the camera see the bottom and top of your face and build a 3D digital model that is stored on your device.
    The second scan needs you to turn your face from side to side. During each scan, you'll be told how close to completion you are, and you will hear a series of beeps increasing in pitch to help determine how far along you are.
