After the second scan is done, you'll be told whether or not the process succeeds. Presuming it has, Face ID will be up and running.
Going Beyond Setup of Touch and Face ID:
One big advantage to using biometric information is that it's harder to steal than a password, since the information never actually leaves your iPhone. Any facial or fingerprint data is stored in a specially secure area on the specific device on which it was created called a secure enclave. When you are asked to verify your identity using these systems, the actual testing is done entirely on your device. A token is then sent to any app or service which requires this verification, which simply indicates whether or not it was a positive match.
    There are more settings in the Touch/Face ID & Passcode area. These help you determine where and when you'll be using it, rather than using your Apple account and password to verify your identity. The first heading is Use Touch/Face ID For. Beneath it, you'll find a series of toggle buttons that can be on or off. The first one will be for unlocking your device. Other choices include using Touch or Face ID when purchasing apps or other digital goods from Apple. You can also use it to verify your identity so that any passwords and credentials used on various websites can be autofilled for you. This can save a great deal of time.
    After these, you'll find a heading that will say either Fingerprints or Face. You can add additional fingerprints or remove them. After these options, you'll find options to change or turn off your passcode. You'll need to enter it before you can disable it.
    The next heading has to do with what can be accessed while locked without needing Touch or Face ID. You can always control music playback and make phone calls through using your voice. Again, there are a series of toggles for the Today view, Control Centre, Siri, etc. Towards the end of this branch of settings, you'll also find a toggle for Erase Data. This lets you choose to have data on your device erased after ten failed attempts to unlock your device with passcode or biometric options.
Passkeys:
Passwords have been around forever. Unfortunately, the more secure they are made through length and complexity, the less likely they will remain long in the minds of their creators where it's most important that they be. The major tech companies have formed an alliance in this area to come up with a solution to this longstanding problem. Passkeys are what they have arrived at. Now that most devices can have biometric authentication, or are secured by a passcode, you can verify your identity using only these things. An encryption key system only needs to know that a trusted device like your iPhone has verified your identity. The rest happens at the other end and eliminates the need to remember passwords. Even it you switch to a device from a different manufacturer, the passkey will still work because of an encryption key generated when the passkey was made. These keys are specifically created for one website or service. The key stored on the server owned by the company or service is useless without the encryption key created on your device when you made the passkey. A very high level of security is thereby matched with a high level of ease of use and convenience. For Apple users, passkeys are synched across devices using the same Apple account which are connected to iCloud. This way, you don't need to generate new passkeys when you switch to a new device. Set up Touch or Face ID and a passcode on your new device and they should work as normal. Should something ever go wrong, you can always use your password and email or other previously created credentials to log in and then create a new passkey.
    This system should really cut down on issues with people becoming locked out of their various accounts when they forgot their password. Just be certain to always remember your Apple account password and the passcode used to unlock your iPhone or other Apple product. Provided you make use of the iCloud keychain and Passwords app, you should be in excellent shape to live your digital life securely.
Two-Factor Authentication:
Designed to protect your Apple account from theft, "two-factor authentication" sends a verification code to trusted phone numbers or devices. To access your Apple account or do other potentially security-critical things, two-factor authentication means that you require information that only you theoretically know, plus something only sent to trusted devices in your possession. In this case, a randomly generated verification code that is sent to your device when required and only works for a limited time. Wait too long, and you'll need a new verification code. If a criminal has your device, he or she may see the verification code but won't know your Apple account, passcode, or password. If a new device tries to log in with your Apple account, it will be asked for a verification code. Blind people will need to memorize this six-digit code long enough to enter it correctly when required. If that number happens to be for the iPhone that has been stolen, the criminal will certainly hear or see that number. However, that's only "one" of "two" factors securing your information. They would also need your passcode, fingerprint or face, and your Apple account and password for complete access to your information. Any time a verification code is used, you will receive an email that would let you know of this occurrence. It would stop someone trying to log in via a website and cause trouble using your Apple account. They wouldn't have the verification number, and you would be alerted to the danger. If they did have the verification number on a stolen device, they wouldn't have your passcode, face, or fingerprint or other necessary information. You could then change your password or take other precautions. You can use the verification code to recover control of your Apple account and reset your password if you believe you've been compromised.
    Since only trusted devices and phone numbers can receive the verification code, you no longer need to remember the answers to security questions. You can have more than one trusted phone number or device set. Parents could have their phone number be a trusted number for their child's device. This would also be useful for people who have difficulty remembering things.
Taking Charge of Security with Settings:
For a worthwhile experience on iOS, it's vital to have a good idea how to set and manage security so that it doesn't inconvenience you unduly. The Settings area is where this management can be accomplished. Options related to security are concentrated in a few key areas of Settings. Let's begin our tour with the very first item past the Search field.
    Presuming you've set everything up and haven't skipped steps, the first item after the Search field will be labelled with your name and email address you used to create your Apple account. This is where you manage things having to do with your Apple account, password, payment information, etc. Think of this area as having to do more with your identity in the Apple marketplace rather than about securing your particular device. In the passwords and security area, you can change your password and also choose whether you want to use two-factor authentication. Unless you have major difficulties remembering a six-digit code, I strongly recommend having it turned on. This way, you can use services that require top security, like Apple Pay.
The Auto-Lock Feature:
To prevent battery drain and improve security, the Auto-Lock feature will cause an iOS device to lock itself after a short period of inactivity. This setting can be found in the Display & Brightness area of settings. You can set it between 30 seconds and 5 minutes, or set it to Never. Normally, I have it set to never lock automatically. It gets annoying having to unlock your phone to continue doing something after merely pausing for a moment's thought. It won't suddenly lock while you're reading an ebook or typing, since the cursor is constantly scrolling while that happens. However, if you're listening to a podcast or audiobook, your iPhone will lock itself. As long as you're actively doing things or contents of the screen are actively changing, the auto-lock won't inconvenience you. I'd use auto-lock if I felt at all nervous that my iPhone might be stolen or misplaced. That way, there would only be a short time before your device locked itself and required your fingerprint, face, or passcode to be used.
The Screen Curtain:
To help protect your privacy, VoiceOver contains a feature called "screen curtain". Since anybody using VoiceOver is likely to be totally blind and not looking at the screen, you can invoke this feature to make certain nobody else can see what you're doing without you knowing this. It will cause your screen to be blank. This doesn't save battery power, so you'll still need to reduce display brightness to achieve that. I have the display brightness set to 0% and maximize my battery life. However, you may be in a situation where you often want sighted people to be able to assist. In that case, having brightness set to around 30% or lower might be a good compromise. I don't mind having to go into the Control Centre and raise the brightness on those rare occasions I want sighted people to see what's on my screen. You turn "screen curtain" on or off by tapping three times quickly with three fingers. A three-finger triple tap.
Privacy and Security Settings:
Privacy and security settings are used to allow or prevent access to the information on your iPhone by people or various apps. For instance, you might choose to prevent an app from accessing the microphone or camera or from accessing your social media accounts.
    In the Settings app, you'll find the Privacy and security button just past the Emergency SOS button and before the Game Centre button. These are all past the General button.
    This area of settings has been updated and streamlined since the first edition of this guide was released. Apple has doubled down on its bet that users of its products value their privacy. Apps must ask permission to track you to personalize advertisements, among many other things. You can deny permission to track your location, website use, and other things at any time. Options having to do with specific social media platforms have been taken away, since these are now redundant by the control you presently have over what data apps are allowed to collect about you.
    The first group of buttons in this area each give you control over whether apps can access capabilities or information present in your device, which they may or may not require to function properly. Before being able to access this, apps you install and run for the first time will request various permissions to do so. No such decision is carved in stone. You can also double tap on any of these buttons and then change the permission granted to the apps which have requested it. In each case, you'll first find a master switch to give a default position or global decision for that category. After that, flicking right will reveal more granular choices for allowing or disallowing individual apps which have requested access to a given capability or information source.
    Location services comes first. Double tap this button, and you'll gain access to the master switch to turn off location services entirely if you wish not to be tracked at all. I don't recommend this unless there are exceptional circumstances. Instead, I recommend using the settings you'll find by flicking right through this category to disallow apps which have requested location information which you don't wish to have it. There are many very helpful uses for your location, including providing travel directions, local weather information, better network connectivity, and many others.
    Tracking is the next setting. This has to do with whether apps can track your online activity across websites and domains. This is most often used to provide companies information about your interests and let them send more relevant advertising to you. Turning the master switch off in this area will cause iOS to automatically deny any requests which apps make to do this. Normally, you would be presented with such requests and could decide at the time to allow or deny permission. I've decided not to turn off the master switch and deal with the requests as they come. There are apps such as news, weather and even some shopping apps like Uber Eats which I have allowed to track me. This results in news apps being better aware of my areas of interest. I also receive more applicable deals from shopping apps like Uber Eats, which have actually saved me money. However, I've chosen to disallow FaceBook from tracking me. Although I still use Facebook, I don't feel that this company has earned the right to any more information than is necessary.
    The next series of buttons in Privacy settings give you the ability to decide which apps can access information such as Contacts, calendar, reminders, and photos. Many apps will make use of this information to help you socialize, keep organized, etc. As always, you can deny access to any app you want to avoid having this information.
    Past that, you'll find more network and communication related areas including Bluetooth, local network, microphone, speech recognition, and camera. As always, there are many legitimate and helpful reasons for apps to access these things. Social apps use your microphone and camera to allow you to communicate with others using the same app. Many apps helpful to blind people need access to the camera and photos to describe objects and scenes, or let sighted people help from a distance.
    The next group of buttons provide access to more varied areas such as health data, research sensor and usage data, HomeKit, media and Apple Music, files and folders, motion and fitness, and focus information. That last one has to do with the focus setting you're in. This lets apps know this and perhaps send a message informing someone trying to contact you that you're sleeping or don't wish to be disturbed.
    Past these settings, you'll find a line explaining that information will be added to the above categories as apps request it.
    The journaling suggestions button lets you decide which apps may be watched by artificial intelligence on your iPhone to generate suggestions for you to write about. This is perfectly safe, but for people wanting to limit access to their information, the option is there.
    Safety Check is a new addition to your suite of security tools, which was added in iOS 16. It is used to help you be aware of and quickly manage which people, services, and apps have access to data that you share. Developed in consultation with organizations who help women who have suffered abuse and stalking, Apple has endeavoured to make it possible to quickly block access to your data if a relationship turns dangerous. If a dangerous person enters your presence while you're doing this, it is always possible to quickly get out of the safety check and security settings and back onto a home screen if necessary so they don't realize you're taking that step. The check has an option to quickly reset all sharing permissions so that only your device can access the data. You might want to do this if you've left an unsafe place and have a moment where you're not in physical danger and are unobserved. There is also an option to go through a more methodical procedure of reviewing who and what has access to your data. It will also cover your overall account security. Just go through each step and follow any instructions which make sense in your situation. For more in depth instructions, please refer to the "learn more" link found immediately upon entering the safety check area. There are checklists and extensive resources available in a downloadable PDF.
    The next item is a feature which checks any images you are about to view on your iPhone for graphic or explicit content, such as nudity. It uses artificial intelligence on your iPhone and doesn't share anything with Apple. It will warn you in advance so that you can make sensible decisions about what you expose yourself to. This may be of use to blind parents seeking peace of mind on that front regarding what imagery their children might see while using iPhones set up for family members.
    There are some buttons which deal with Apple's ability to advertise to you and to analyze activity on your iPhone to improve the overall experience. I don't have a problem with this, and hope my data will help app developers and Apple fine-tune things in future iOS updates.
    There are a couple of buttons under a heading called transparency logs. These are Apple Intelligence report and "app privacy report". Both of these buttons present you with information about when apps make use of the information you've given permission for. Regarding Apple Intelligence, this gives you a sense of the information being used on your behalf to accomplish things for you. Meanwhile, the app privacy report includes what information was requested, as well as which websites or domains were used by apps. The information is quite extensive and should allow you to make informed decisions about which apps you trust and use. If you wish, you can always find the option to turn off this reporting at the very end of the settings. If this is turned off, you'll find a button to turn on the app privacy report. The same is true for the AppleIntelligence report. I recommend leaving these turned on and checking every so often to determine whether you are happy with how the apps you make use of are dealing with your information.
    Beneath a heading called "Security" near the very bottom of this area of settings, there are two final options to discuss. The first is called Stolen Device Protection. The basic idea is to thwart anybody who might get hold of your device and have somehow found out your passcode. Perhaps, they watched you enter it surreptitiously and grabbed it while it was unattended. In such an event, this option will require the use of Face or Touch ID before allowing a range of critical actions to take place. It will also impose an hour's delay before making any changes to security critical settings or passwords. You can have this requirement waived when you're in trusted locations, such as at home or work. Alternatively, you can have the extra safety measures applied regardless of location.
    Under normal circumstances, a failed check for Face or Touch ID would result in an immediate ask for your passcode to complete whatever you were trying to do. For example, I make use of my banking app and have it check for my Face ID to log into my account. Occasionally, I'm not quite looking the right way, or the lighting is poor. The Face ID check will fail and I'll then be asked for my passcode. If Stolen Device Protection is turned on, I would have to close the app and make another attempt to pass the Face ID check. I couldn't simply enter my passcode. This also protects your credit cards from being used without a successful Face or Touch ID check.
    Personally, I've had occasions where this protection is frankly inconvenient. I'm not always conscious of the lighting conditions or if I'm facing the camera quite as directly as I should be. This has resulted in some occasions when I've had to wait to make changes until I had passed a Face ID check. Given my ordinary circumstances, I have chosen to leave this turned off. However, if I'm travelling in less safe conditions, I would certainly turn it on. Sometimes, it's just a lot more convenient for blind people to be able to fall back to their passcode. Remember that you can always change your passcode if you want. Just make certain it's one you'll remember.
    Lockdown mode is the final option in these settings. Using this option should only be done if you're under direct personal threat from sophisticated hackers because of who you are or what you do. This isn't made for the ordinary everyday iPhone user. It will introduce major inconveniences and cripple some aspects of your iPhone to protect you. Please review the information found in the "learn more" link made available when you double tap on the Lockdown Mode option before you turn it on.
Advanced Data Protection:
This setting can be found in the iCloud settings which are located in your Apple Account settings. It's the area labelled with your name and picture at the very top of Settings. Basically, advanced data protection encrypts all information stored in iCloud using a very high level of encryption. If you make use of this, Apple will not be able to help you recover any information if you become locked out of your account. Because of this, you will need to have set up a recovery contact or recovery key before turning on this feature. I don't recommend that beginners use this option until they are very comfortable with VoiceOver and competent in general with their iPhone over all. If you lose your recovery key or your recovery contact is unavailable, you won't be able to get into your account unless you can remember your password and passcode. If advanced data protection is off, Apple staff will be able to be of some assistance once they're certain you're the owner of the iPhone you're locked out of. I've encountered people who would be absolutely out of luck having forgotten their Apple account password, passcode, etc. Nobody would have been able to help them regain access had they turned on this feature. Think carefully before you do so. As always, avail yourself of the information in the "learn more" link found when you double tap on this option before activating it.
Thoughts on Privacy Settings:
Overall, I don't spend a lot of time worrying about privacy. Having owned an iPhone and hundreds of apps for over a decade, I have yet to find that permission I've given to apps and companies has caused me any problem or put me at a disadvantage. Most typically, I tend to give apps permission to use the information or capabilities they request. I don't tend to adjust these settings frequently. IOS asks you as soon as an app requests access to these services, so I don't need to go into the Privacy area unless I change my mind from my initial decision about what access an app should have. That happens from time to time.
    I mainly prefer apps to only use Location Services when I'm actually using them, so I've adjusted those settings the most. Other than that, most of my privacy settings remain unchanged. I very much approve of the new tougher stance Apple has taken on transparency when it comes to what information apps are allowed to use. It's nice to have the tools to only share data with apps and services you truly value and support, or which provide you enough benefit to justify sharing of data. This should help raise the bar for advertising and apps which make their money from that rather than directly from their users.
Screen Time and Restrictions:
Restrictions are used to prevent actions from being taken without your permission on your iOS device. You can use these to prevent children from making purchases while they use your iPad to play a game. You can also prevent people from browsing the Web or using Apple Books, among many other things. This can give you peace of mind if you allow someone else to use your device that they can't do anything potentially harmful to you.
    Apple has recently consolidated all such options into the Screen Time settings area. This puts all the tools available to manage what people can do with your device under one digital roof. To manage Restrictions, go into the Screen Time area. This button can be found to the left of "General". The first thing you'll encounter is information about your recent activity. Flick right past all of that information. You'll be at the end when it says "updated" followed by the most recent time this has happened.
    Past this, you'll be inside the area where you can start to set restrictions. The first group has to do with setting time limits based on communications with people and with how long or whether apps can be used at various times. This was the original reason for Screen Time. It was all about making you aware of how much time you spent doing things on your iPhone and giving you the ability to restrict activities and thereby deal with digital addiction. Flicking right, you'll eventually come to a button called "Always allowed". This gives you a category to place apps in which makes them allowed to be used at all times even if other apps in the same category would normally fall under restrictions.
    The "content and privacy restrictions" button comes next. These are turned off by default. If you wish, you can prevent restrictions and other Screen Time settings from being changed by protecting the settings with a four-digit Restriction passcode. The option to set this passcode is found immediately past the "Content and privacy restrictions" button. Choose a four-digit number you'll remember. You'll need to enter it a second time to confirm. Once that's done, you'll need to know that code to disable Restrictions. The only other way to get rid of the Restrictions would be to use your Apple account and password to then be able to reset and deactivate the passcode.
    Double tapping the "Content and Privacy restrictions" button puts you into the branch containing these. The first button in this area is a master on/off switch. This lets you turn off restrictions all at once, leaving your particular set of restrictions ready to be reactivated with the same toggle. The next button is for restricting iTunes and app store purchases. These settings give you quite a lot of control here. You can require passwords all the time or only occasionally. You can disallow installing, deleting and downloading of apps. Not only that, but you can also disallow in-app purchases. This means that a child, for instance, wouldn't be able to spend your real money buying advantages in a game.
    The "allowed apps" button lets you allow or disallow a bunch of major applications on your device. You can, for instance, disallow the use of your digital wallet or the Safari browser. If disallowed, the app in question won't even appear on your screen until you turn off the restriction or use a passcode to bypass it.
    The next button is "Content restrictions". This lets you restrict inappropriate content from your device so that it's safer for a child to use. For instance, the first button lets you choose whether to allow explicit content in podcasts, news, workouts, and music to be allowed or not. There's a separate button for whether to allow music videos. Another button deals with movies. If you double tap this, you can select the rating of movies that can be viewed on your iOS device. You can specify which country's ratings you want to use. It defaults to US.
    All sorts of different kinds of content can have restrictions placed upon its consumption. Everything from podcasts, to books, to music, to news. You don't always have a lot of flexibility. Choices are more often between allowing everything or disallowing things entirely. For instance, you can restrict explicit content in books so that your child won't even come across books featuring such material. However, you can't do more complex things like eliminate violence or taboo topics. Websites are similar. You can restrict explicit adult content or only allow visits to certain sites you approve of. For apps, you can restrict apps by their age-appropriate ratings. Using these restrictions, parents could make their children's iOS devices quite safe while still allowing for some exploration on their part. Without knowing the four-digit passcode, they may not even see what they're not allowed to access.
    The settings under the Privacy heading within the "Content and Privacy" area of Screen Time are the same as the ones in the Privacy area of Settings. However, if you use the settings within the Screen Time area, you can lock them in place with the Screen Time four digit passcode. The restrictions will be in effect unless you use that passcode to change them, even if your privacy settings are different outside Screen Time.
    The "Allow Changes" heading is another important area. Beneath it are seven buttons that deal with significant areas and give you the power to disallow any changes that might cost money or compromise safety. For instance, you can use the Accounts restriction to prevent any changes being made to account information. This prevents anybody from adding a new user account to your iOS device to get around restrictions. Other areas include Cellular Data, Volume Limit, Background App Refresh, and TV Provider. A change in cellular data, for instance, might result in you inadvertently using expensive cellular data for things that you didn't want to be able to.
    The settings under the Game Centre heading allow you to restrict things like adding friends or playing multiplayer games. This will be especially useful for parents who don't feel their children are ready to deal responsibly with this unsupervised contact with strangers. There are three settings here. You can disallow playing multiplayer games entirely. You can disallow adding new friends. Lastly, you can disallow screen recording. Screen recording is often used in games to share proof of noteworthy accomplishment or other information during group play. However, it could also reveal sensitive information if used carelessly.
Passwords & Accounts:
Another feature that tries to make security a little more convenient is called iCloud Keychain. This keeps track of any passwords for various apps and websites you might use. They are stored in iCloud, so they won't be lost even if your device is. Instead of having to enter all of that information, which may be unique for each app or website, you can use your Face ID or Touch ID, or passcode to prove who you are. You will then have the needed information filled into the login form in the correct places. This drastically speeds up signing in. You can change or delete information stored in the "keychain" using the Passwords & Accounts area of Settings. You'll need to verify your identity before making changes in here.
    Recently, Apple has improved this Keychain feature. It will make certain that you don't forget to save a username along with a password. Also, you can add notes to entries, such as security question information or other details you might need. This should be helpful for people who can't remember security details well, provided they can use Face and Touch ID as needed.
The Passwords App:
New to iOS 18, the Passwords app makes managing your various passkeys, passwords and accounts a lot easier. Instead of going into settings, use the Passwords app. You'll always need to use Touch ID, Face ID, or your passcode to gain entry to this app. Once inside, you can browse through and search for any passwords, passkeys, saved verification codes, Wi-Fi information or security related information stored in your iCloud keychain. You can also share this information with other trusted people who might need it.
    The app has a very simple interface. There are buttons to search in various categories like passcodes, passwords, etc. You can double tap on one of these buttons or make use of a search box to find what you require. Once you've found the entry of interest, double tap on it. At this point, you can flick left or over the various information, You can also flick up or down to get a series of actions. These let you share the information, reveal it so you can read it, copy it directly to your clipboard, and share the information with someone. Take time to review the information on the various screens and you'll find the Passwords app a very handy feature.
Sign in with Apple:
Many of us want to use social media, search engines, and other online services. However, we worry that we'll then have our online activities tracked, be targeted for ads we don't want, or that our data will be mined. A new feature introduced in iOS 13, "Sign in with Apple" lets you forego using Facebook, Google, or other commercial services to easily log into various websites.
    Facebook and Google certainly provide a convenient and popular identity verification service. However, they are motivated to get as much data from their users as legally possible. This is what they sell to advertisers, and how you in effect pay for convenience with privacy. Instead, you can use Apple. Their motivation is keeping your data and privacy as secure as possible. They don't make money from targeted advertising except in clearly defined circumstances that they inform their users about. They make their money through your buying their devices and using their services. The less annoyed by advertising you are while using their stuff, the better you're likely to think of Apple.
    If you use this feature, Apple will create an email and password for you. As long as you have your device, all you'll need is Face or Touch ID to log into services you've chosen to use "Sign in with Apple" to create accounts with. Any communications to the fake email created for you will be forwarded to your actual email unless or until you don't want them anymore. You can then simply stop these communications from being forwarded and be left untracked and in peace.
Additional Defensive Measures:
One addition to iOS 15 was something called iCloud private Relay. This is available for people who subscribe to Apple's iCloud Plus service. It will act as a sort of VPN and prevent your web browsing from being tracked. All data coming in and out of your browser will go through Apple's iCloud server, thereby disguising your location and other identifying details. You may encounter problems if you use it but need to access websites which require things like your location to work correctly or verify who you are.
    A more established, similar thing can be done with VPN networks and devices. If you have one of these services, look in the General settings area for the "VPN" button. This will provide you with options to make use of these networks and devices. I have absolutely no experience with these, and must leave it to my readers to delve into this area if they feel the need.
    There are many other steps you can take to guard your information and privacy. One place to seek additional options would be in the Safari settings. Your web browser is one of the most powerful tools on your device. This power comes with responsibility. Many people have gotten into serious trouble by going to websites run by bad actors and thieves. The iOS operating system does its best to warn you if things seem suspicious, but it's a constant arms race between them and the unscrupulous hackers, making the web a more dangerous place. You'll need to keep aware of the dangers and make decisions regarding how convenient things are versus how secure you want to be. It's a bit of a balancing act.
Parting Thoughts on Security:
I would encourage all of my readers to consult the various sections of the user guide for your specific device. There can be differences depending on the age and type of device, especially when it comes to biometric security measures. Regardless of which device you have, there will be many ways to keep your information safe. This is an important aspect of owning an iOS device. If people are careless with the information stored in their devices, it can put you and your contacts in danger of fraud and other consequences. Please use reasonable precautions.
    Remember that good security comes as much down to good habits as it does to any of the settings discussed above. Think about where you and your device are. If you're in the open, perhaps making certain your screen curtain is on before entering your banking password might be wise. Are people close enough for you to hear and understand what they're saying? They may be close enough to see and hear what your device is saying and doing. How are you currently connected to the Internet? Think about whether you want to make purchases or do other potentially sensitive things while connected to free, public, possibly insecure Wi-Fi. There are all sorts of little habits and tricks you can use to increase your overall security.
    In most cases, apps where information is stored allow you to lock that information, making it necessary to use a password or Touch or Face ID to access information. A good example of this can be found in the Notes app. If it suits you, a note that contains information of a sensitive nature can be encrypted, requiring your fingerprint, face, passcode, or password to unlock it.
    Another thing to consider, as blind users, is that your device announces things whenever you use it and sometimes, while it's in your pocket. A great deal of what gets spoken aloud while you may not be wearing EarPods or other headsets is due to Notifications. You can set them to be delivered quietly, so they appear in the Notifications Centre but aren't spoken aloud. As a kind of middle ground, you can have a sound play when a new notification arrives for a given app. In fact, many apps come with their own unique sounds for this very purpose. Look in the Notifications settings and take advantage of those options. Not all notifications should be spoken aloud upon arrival. You can also disable the ability to access the Notifications Centre from the lock screen, requiring your device to be unlocked before gaining access to notifications. This is less convenient but more secure. Adjust this sort of thing if you're going into potentially troublesome environments. You can always adjust such settings back to more convenient options when back in safer conditions.
    If you need to unlock your device or enter a password while not waring EarPods or other headsets, you can minimize the chances of people easily overhearing that information. For instance, if you're using "touch typing", run your finger intentionally over wrong numbers and letters, only lifting it when you reach the correct next item to enter. If you're using the default "standard typing", you can safely touch as many wrong numbers or letters as you like, only tapping twice quickly on the correct ones which will then actually be entered. It will be harder for any unwanted observers to tell exactly which letter or number is correct when you get good enough at this. Hold your device facing you below head level. After all, you don't need to see it yourself. This way, it'll be harder for people to know what's being entered and precisely where your active finger is when you actually enter things.
    Apple has a section in the user guides for its iOS devices called Privacy & Security. Anyone who has any concerns about security should give this nicely written section a read. Apple does a much better job than I at going through the array of tools at your disposal to guard your information. You need not be an expert to understand this and will be able to make informed choices, finding the right balance for you between security and convenience.
    On the other side of the coin, don't use extra security you don't really need. I can't count the number of people I've been powerless to help because they've set Restrictions and then forgotten the four-digit code. They'll disallow Safari and then wonder where their web browser went. They'll want to purchase an app or an in-app purchase, but discover that they've restricted that ability on their iPhone and then forgotten their code and can't disable the Restriction. I've even had one fellow restrict his GPS app from using Location Services. I wish I was joking there, but I'm sadly not. There's simply no point of having a GPS app to help you get around if you prevent it from knowing where you are. People do some really stupid things, getting all paranoid and hung up on security and privacy concerns. Take reasonable precautions, but don't go overboard with this stuff.

Braille on iOS Devices
I'm part of a generation who has learned Braille naturally as part of my school experience, while there was really no other credible alternative. However, we have now been liberated from the cost, bulk, and weight of Braille by the advent of synthetic speech and more widespread accessibility to mainstream ebooks and computing. In everyday life, now that I know how to read, I haven't felt the need to constantly use Braille. Quite the opposite, in fact. While reading for entertainment and even when referring to books as references, speech output has proved more than sufficient and ever so convenient.
    While I can fully appreciate why one might think Braille was no longer needed, I would contend that mastering the art of reading is essential to everyone's education, be that print or Braille. If sighted parents faced the prospect of their children not being taught to read and write due to a lack of resources, they'd be horrified and never stand for it. Parents of blind children should feel no qualms about insisting on Braille literacy. The many lessons I learned while gaining literacy have served me well in countless ways. Like riding a bicycle, literacy is one of those things you never forget, even if you don't read Braille beyond signs and labels for years. The lessons it teaches about proper use of punctuation, sentence structure, and other aspects of writing have stayed with me. As a result, I have been able to use my writing and language skills to help others and express my thoughts clearly and with confidence.
    I was never a particularly fast Braille reader, and don't feel I've lost what speed I achieved. The same applies to writing. I'm far faster on a QWERTY keyboard than I ever was on a Braille one. In most circumstances, text-to-speech access has proved far superior regarding portability and actual access to books. Other than my spelling having deteriorated over the years, I don't feel that the absence of Braille has done me much harm. And yet, I'm profoundly thankful that I was taught Braille reading and writing. The lack of actual literacy would have had a strongly negative impact on my quality of life. Now that you have and idea where I sit in the great Braille debate, let's continue.
    Who would have thought that a device with a smooth surface might prove to be a wonderful conduit for Braille? Apparently, Apple did. Right from the start, when VoiceOver first appeared, there has been support for Braille displays. I never thought much about it when I got my iPhone 4. It was so intuitive and easy to use speech, and the capabilities of the platform made learning how to use Braille on it far less attractive than it would be currently. Before embarking on writing this guide, I hadn't given the implications a lot of thought. As I've taken the time to dig into what iOS offers in terms of Braille support, the implications become very apparent. Unfortunately, it has also become apparent that Braille is a part of iOS which is the most prone to having bugs and serious issues remain unaddressed for long periods of time. I address this in a subsection below called Always A Catch. I recommend anybody who is considering using Braille with iOS read this before making any purchases.
    You may wonder why I've chosen to give the Braille experience its own somewhat lengthy section. I have several reasons for doing this. First of all, if people don't intend to use Braille displays, all the extra commands are out of their way. Those who wish to learn how to use refreshable Braille will find all they need in this section that isn't covered elsewhere. Experiencing iOS through a refreshable Braille display is markedly different from via the touchscreen and speech output. Rather than a whole screen surface that can be explored with a finger plus immediate speech feedback, using a Braille display may change your approach. You can explore the screen similarly with one hand operating the iOS device and another on the Braille display. Alternatively, you could operate entirely from the Braille display, using all the key commands to navigate. That will feel very different and be more similar to using a traditional screen reader. People who struggle with using a touchscreen may well find this mode of operation to be preferable. In either case, you will find that the Braille display gives you a window in the form of a line of characters whose length depends on that of your display. The position in exact focus, such as the current character in a document being written, is shown by one or two dots on the bottom of the cell that tick up and down repeatedly.
    Another advantage to separating the Braille-specific information in this way is that people can more easily grasp how much support there is and how integral Braille can be if you wish or need it to. Those who might think to presume that Apple has paid mere lip service to Braille support do Apple and themselves a serious injustice. There's a lot of ground to cover, so let's begin connecting the dots.
    Over time, Apple has gone to considerable lengths to support the use of refreshable Braille with its devices. In fact, it's possible to purchase a Braille display from the Apple Store app for your iOS device. If you already have a Braille display or a Braille notetaker capable of being used as a display and connecting via Bluetooth, you can pair it with your iOS device. VoiceOver has been designed to allow complete access via Braille throughout the operating system. While you can't completely avoid using the touchscreen, you can certainly minimize the need to. Doing this requires the learning of commands, making use of key combinations or other buttons that your Braille display may have.
    iOS has support that allows far more than simple Braille input and output. Similar to an ordinary Bluetooth keyboard, you can take full control of your device using only your Braille display. There are key commands to do everything you can do with gestures. If you can memorize the commands, you could have excellent and accurate control of your device. This includes things like summoning Siri, controlling the volume, and much more, all without lifting your fingers from your Braille display.
    The catch is that there are a heaping ton of commands to know if you want that kind of complete control. People may find that these commands feel less intuitive and easy to learn than the touchscreen gestures they are designed to replace. Personally, I find a middle of the road approach works best, where I still use the onscreen gestures but learn the commands of particular use to me.
Bye-bye Braille Book Bulk:
Ebook sellers are starting to get onboard, making certain that the apps everyone uses to read them offer support for accessibility. What this means for someone with an iOS device and Braille display is that they are completely liberated in their choice of reading. Braille books used to take hours and hours to translate and be very costly to produce. They also used to weigh quite a bit and take up a lot of space. I can still remember a vest pocket dictionary which took up an entire shelf in my grade school classroom. It comprised seven massive hardcover volumes of double-sided Braille. Now, that same dictionary would take up a tiny fraction of the data storage available on even the cheapest iPhone. A Braille display that you could comfortably carry in one hand would let you access that dictionary and thousands of other books on your iPhone in perfectly readable and translated Braille.
    One thing to keep in mind is that the apps you'll use to read these books are designed for people who can see. They're fully accessible, but things are done in such a way as to maximize reading pleasure for people who can take in a lot of a page at once. Current Braille displays only present one line of text at a time. There may occasionally be slight problems as the apps and book formats are updated over time. Moreover, it may be easier to use the touchscreen when accessing menus and other functions that reading apps have. For instance, it's far quicker to learn the locations of tabs across the bottom of the screen or use menus that appear when you double tap on the screen. In exchange for putting up with these small issues, you can read damned near anything you want as soon as it's published and at the same cost as anybody else who buys an ebook.
Always a Catch:
There are some possible trouble spots for those who choose to acquire a Braille display and iOS device rather than opt for a more traditional Braille notetaker or other solution made especially for blind people. Very significant difficulties which would need to be addressed right away if they happened to ordinary users of these devices have a way of persisting for Braille users. There are likely several reasons for this. A major one would be the comparatively small number of Braille users and the even smaller number from that group who take the time to report their issues. In order for bugs to be fixed, they need to be easily reproduced by Apple staff who work on them. This requires that people who report bugs take the time to give the most information possible about when they experience them and what they were doing when it happened. The more heavily you rely on Braille, the more grave the issues you face may be. I mostly use my iPhone via text to speech output provided by VoiceOver. This requires no external hardware of any complexity. However, with Braille output, everything needs to be translated back and forth from print to Braille on the fly as it travels to and from the Braille display being used. There are many Braille displays which may have their own differences in function that Apple must consider in order to support them.
    Since there are so many different displays, you run into the situation where bugs which affect some displays won't even be noticed on others. There's also the question of what users choose to do with Braille versus what they do with text to speech. Someone who is deaf blind relies totally on Braille for absolutely everything they do on their iPhone. They have no other option short of having someone else do things for them and communicate the results. If they experience a disconnection between their Braille display and iPhone, that effectively renders both devices useless until the connectivity can be restored. Other long-standing issues which thankfully now seem to be fixed involve lost input from displays or things working very slowly. Again, these are crippling issues for anyone who relies on being able to communicate with their devices using Braille input. To help with connectivity, there is now a setting in VoiceOver which forces Bluetooth to be turned on whenever VoiceOver is started. This would certainly eliminate one possible reason for loss of connection.
    One way which I've seen recommended to get around some freezing and lockups currently plaguing Braille users of iOS involves turning off Braille messages. These are notifications from apps which typically interrupt what the user is doing. In Braille, these take priority and the reader is pulled out of what he or she is doing. The notification is available to be read for a given period of time before the user is returned to what he or she was doing previously. Turning off these notifications essentially means that Braille users won't be informed of possibly critical warnings or messages from others which may be time-sensitive. It's one thing to miss a notification from a game being played. Quite another to miss a warning that a fire alarm might be going off or that a ride to a critical appointment is waiting.
    News typically spreads quickly, as people find out the hard way about issues with Braille. However, it is often too little too late to allow people to forego updating to what should by all rights be a better experience. Mistakes like that do cost Apple in terms of bad publicity. It can take months and further small iOS updates before problems with Braille support are largely fixed. Meanwhile, Smaller updates will be pushed out rapidly to deal with security and other issues that effected a larger portion of Apple's user base. Each time one of these appeared, you'd wonder whether the Braille display issue making your life miserable would be fixed and discover that yet again, it hadn't. This can be very frustrating, and it's tough even for me to keep from losing my generally patient and largely grateful outlook on behalf of those who truly rely on it working.
    Not being a frequent Braille user, the display issues discussed above didn't affect me to the point of holding off getting updates. For some months, it became very annoying to try to read an ebook using my Braille display because of an issue with scrolling to the next page. You'd be reading along and suddenly realize that a substantial chunk of a page had been skipped over. You'd have to backtrack to the top of the page and then continue reading from the correct spot. I could simply choose to read books using VoiceOver with its synthetic speech, which worked perfectly fine. Had I been a deaf-blind user who relied on his Braille display working reliably to communicate with others, it would have been a showstopper. Because Braille is a secondary tool for me, I don't experience these issues in the same way. If my Braille display becomes disconnected, I can simply turn speech on and sort out the situation. If there's a problem with input, I can simply use a Bluetooth keyboard. The missed messages would potentially affect me negatively if I happened to be reading or have text to speech turned off. However, that's a rare circumstance for me which I can take steps to mitigate.
    I mainly use Braille for reading books and notes during presentations. Even with this more limited use, I have experienced occasional disconnections plus other issues involving the reading cursor not keeping its proper place when pages in an ebook are turned. This latter issue was very vexing and essentially stopped me from being able to enjoyably read books using Braille for months until the issue was eventually thankfully resolved. Issues may also be due to how third-party apps interact with VoiceOver. This can add a further layer of complexity which effects how often issues appear and how easy they are to reproduce reliably.
    There may be times when your Braille display will disconnect, since the Bluetooth software is constantly trying to save battery power. If this happens, simply lock the screen with the power button on your device and then unlock it again. This should result in your display reconnecting. Some displays can be more problematic and require more steps to get them reconnected. This kind of thing also happens with other Bluetooth devices, such as keyboards or even Apple's own AirPods. The AirPods are designed to reconnect rapidly and do so automatically nearly all the time. There are so many different Braille displays that having the same kind of Bluetooth reliability would be impossible. This is very similar to my having to press a button on my Shokz Trekz Titaniums to make them reconnect if I stop hearing things through them.
    There is now a setting in the VoiceOver Braille settings area which makes certain that Bluetooth is enabled whenever VoiceOver starts. This will at least eliminate the possibility of Bluetooth being disabled when measures to reestablish a dropped connection with a previously paired display are attempted. This should make things somewhat more reliable for deaf blind users. Turning VoiceOver off and then back on again should make recovering connectivity much less complicated.
    We saw an instance of another potentially major pitfall when iOS 11 was released. People who updated suddenly found that they couldn't enter text quickly on Braille displays. Words would simply be lost and not be recorded in the document or edit field on the iOS device. Because people's fingers were busy typing in Braille, they couldn't immediately realize there was a problem if they weren't also using speech. You can't read Braille while you're in the act of typing it. Muting speech while using a Braille display is a very common practice. The issue was reported by testers but not addressed prior to the release of the update. Braille display users would be a minimal percentage of the overall number of users of iOS. Every so often, their issues won't be dealt with in time and may take a while to address.
    iOS is a very complex operating system. The more unusual your particular needs are, the higher the chance that concerns like the examples above will be encountered for hopefully short periods of time. Apple has learned from these mistakes and has introduced public testing of upcoming iOS updates in an attempt to catch major issues.
    When looking for pitfalls, I spent some time putting myself in the worst possible case. For people who are deaf-blind, Braille had better work because there's no other way. If you absolutely can't hear speech or see enlarged print, touch is your only pipeline of information. In such circumstances, you may well want to seek alternatives or have a backup plan such as sighted assistance if things go wrong.
    There are some things that might require sighted assistance to resolve. Certainly, you'd need such help to set up your device and then connect your Braille display initially. I don't believe there's any way to get at the Braille settings in VoiceOver until after the setup process is complete. Another thing that might be troublesome at first is entering your passcode to unlock your device. Some Braille displays require the iPHONE to be unlocked before they will connect and let you type characters using them. Mine didn't, so I had to enter it using standard typing mode on the touchscreen. I had one hand on the Braille display, feeling which number was highlighted, as I used my other hand to find and then enter the numbers using the split tap method. This is the best way I've found for making certain you enter the passcode correctly. You can, of course, find the delete key at the bottom right of the virtual number pad on the touchscreen and get rid of mistakes. I found this process somewhat nerve-racking without speech output, but I think it would become second nature after a while. There's really no avoiding the need to enter the passcode every so often and after any time you shut down and turn on the device. Once that's been done, you can then use easier methods to unlock your device most of the time, like Touch ID or Face ID.
    While Braille focus will jump to where new messages are displayed, other things such as choices or controls may need to be more actively searched for by Braille users. Everything will be reachable, but without such proactive exploration on your part, you might not realize there are choices or controls present in some apps. The ability to actively explore the screen is a key part of iOS accessibility that works differently from other screen readers that may look for and announce more things automatically.
Mainstream Economics and Wider Horizons:
There are several advantages that iOS devices bring to the table for blind people wanting to make use of Braille in daily life. Braille notetakers work extremely reliably and typically have excellent battery longevity. However, they are also very limited in what they can do. They offer a set number of highly perfected functions that work flawlessly, but they don't offer much ability to grow beyond those. On the other hand, iOS gives you good but sometimes imperfect access to an ever expanding ecosystem of apps, ebook markets, and other things available to sighted people. Even though only a fraction of the total apps available for iOS are accessible to blind people, that still far surpasses anything you'll find elsewhere other than perhaps on Android devices. No Braille notetaker will let you do your shopping and banking with apps designed by the bank and grocery company you and potentially millions of sighted customers select. This access to the same apps used by sighted people could be very helpful socially to blind students and other Braille users. It's an option they've never really had before the iPhone gained its VoiceOver screen reader. You could read news articles on an app or website in Braille while talking about them with friends. And then, there are the specialized apps that take advantage of the hardware built into your iOS device. Presuming you opt for a small portable Braille display, you could use an app like Voice Dream Scanner to take pictures of the pages of a restaurant menu and then read it in Braille while conversing with your dining companions. There are all kinds of situations like that where you want access to information but also want your ears free.
    Braille is especially useful when it comes to the study of Mathematics. It can be tremendously hard to picture how an equation is laid out while using synthetic speech. A Braille display supported with software such as the VoiceOver screen reader will let blind students and others feel the positions of parts of equations. This can make solving them a far easier process. There are other instances where having the ability to feel the position of information is critical, such as when examining charts or tables. How practical that is will depend on the length of your Braille display, or feeling a table one-handed while the other hand is reading the Braille display.
    Braille displays are very costly items and are built to last. I've had the same Focus 40 display since I got my first iPhone in 2010, and it worked wonderfully until 2019. The battery can no longer hold a charge. I have since acquired a much shorter and lighter Brailliant BI14. Not the best keyboard, but splendid for reading books while on the go. The core of my system is my iPhone and the VoiceOver screen reader. It takes full control of the Braille experience. As a result, I can have the latest features without upgrading the far more expensive Braille component until that becomes absolutely necessary. Furthermore, I can use my display with more than one device. If something happens to my iPhone, I could still use the display with a new iPHONE, whether that's a new one I acquire permanently or one which I might borrow from a relative or friend for a brief while. If your notetaker breaks down, you need to repair or replace a costly device and be without all of its functions while you're taking care of that. Meanwhile, if my display breaks, I still have my iOS device that can be used with speech.
    Perhaps, you already have a Braille notetaker. If so, fear not. Most of them can connect via Bluetooth and act as Braille displays for iOS. You have the best of both worlds. Some notetakers are designed to integrate with apps on iOS devices, making them an even more powerful combination.
Attention Please: When Notifications Pop Up
You're reading along when all of a sudden, the Weather Gods app decides to reveal that it's raining heavily outside. Perhaps, a friend has chosen to send a message asking how you're doing. Unless you have your device on the Do Not Disturb focus or have Notifications turned off, you will eventually be interrupted from whatever you might be doing by a notification from another app running in the background. In such a case, the same sort of thing happens with the focus of Braille as happens with speech. The interrupting notification automatically gets focus for a short time that you can determine before focus returns to what you were doing. You can determine this length of time in the Braille settings. Furthermore, if you pan through the notification while it has focus, you should be able to read it in an unhurried manner. Remember that if they do disappear on you, you can always find them in the Notifications Centre.
Braille Screen Input:
You need not have a Braille display for Braille to be a part of your iOS experience. The Braille Screen Input feature lets you use a virtual Braille keyboard by positioning your fingers on the touchscreen as if you were writing on a braille writer. You need to enable the option in the VoiceOver settings. Use the rotor item settings to make certain that the Braille Screen Input option is selected on your rotor. You can enter this input mode by using the rotor. Alternatively, you now have the option of enabling gestures which let you enter and exit Braille Screen Input mode without using the rotor. These options and others can be found in Settings, VoiceOver, Braille, Braille Screen Input settings. If the activation gestures setting is enabled, you can enter Braille Screen Input mode by putting a finger from one hand at the top of the screen and a finger from the other thand at the bottom. Tap twice with these fingers at the same time. To exit Braille Screen Input mode, slide two fingers in opposite directions on the screen. If you don'tuse this input mode, you may find that disabling these gestures is adviseable since they can trigger accidentally at times. 
    The dot positions can be calibrated to your natural finger positions on the screen surface. This kind of input can be very useful if people are skilled in writing Braille. If you have that skill and are new to touchscreen typing or haven't mastered typing on a standard keyboard, you may find it easier than dealing with the ordinary onscreen keyboard.
    In iOS 18, the Braille screen input mode was upgraded significantly and now has two parts. There's the input mode described above. There is also now a command mode. You can switch between input mode and command mode by swiping left or right with three fingers. This lets you gain the ability to enter any commands useable on Braille displays. There are a large number of such chord commands. You don't need to use the space bar to enter these commands while in command mode. To access and customize these chord commands, go into VoiceOver settings and into the commands area. Flick right past the Braille Screen Input option until you find Braille Keyboard commands. Double tap on this, and you'll find all the assigned commands. The Braille Screen Input option we passed by contains other important settings allowing you to configure this input mode. This includes deciding whether you want haptic and sound feedback for when you enter or exit the mode, enter characters, etc. You can also choose which Braille table of characters to use such as UEB uncontracted. Between these two sets of options, this gives you easy control of the rotor, text selection, cutting and pasting, and commands to get to areas like the status bar.
    You can also decide to reverse the positions of the outer dots. This way, dots three and six are closest to the imaginary spacebar, rather than the traditional method in which dot numbers increase the farther away from the spacebar you get. This can be helpful when you're making use of the screen away mode, where you hold the iPhone screen facing directly away from you in landscape mode. In tabletop mode when your iPhone lies flat on a solid surface in landscape mode, the default setting with dots 1 and 4 near the space bar seem more natural.
    While in input mode, in addition to typing in characters, you can also perform some other special gestures which make editing text you type in easier. To enter a space, swipe right with one finger. Swiping left with a finger will delete the last character entered. Swipe right with two fingers to move to a new line. Swipe up or down with one finger to cycle through spelling suggestions. Swiping up with three fingers enters a carriage return or sends a message. This is likely an incomplete list of special gestures used while in Braille screen input mode. People are encouraged to use the current user guide offered by Apple and to search for up-to-date articles on Apple support about Braille screen input mode, as well as other Braille related subjects. In the Braille Screen Input settings, you'll find a "learn more" link which will take you to a handy set of instructions. These should be enough to get people started using this additional capability. There is a well-written guide about using Braille Screen Input mode on Applevis at:
    https://www.applevis.com/guides/guide-braille-screen-input-ios-ipados
    You can find the most current information from Apple regarding common Braille commands by going to:
    https://support.apple.com/en-us/118665
    More attention is being paid to issues with all things Braille. The addition of command mode will be a massive help to those skilled in Braille. Provided they can master the touchscreen, they will basically turn their iPhones into a compelling alternative to a specialized Braille note-taker with speech output. I can't imagine a circumstance where you'd want to use Braille Screen Input while you have a Braille display connected with its own physical keyboard. However, there may well be a use case. There may be some ultraportable Braille displays without Braille keyboards. The commands made available in Command mode will likely prove easier to learn for people who have used Braille displays in the past.
Commonly Used Commands:
This guide won't go through every single command. The set of commands available to you depends on which Braille display you're using. The place you want to reach is a page called Braille Displays Supported by iPhone, iPad, and iPod Touch. Below that heading, you'll find a series of links to specific Braille display command lists. Additionally, below this, you'll find a link to a set of universal commands that should work on any display. At the time of this writing, this helpful resource can be found at https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT202514.
    The lists of Braille Commands are comprehensive, well-organized lists divided into headings and tables. Apple might change one or more of these commands at any time, so it's best to get them directly from Apple's own documentation. However, this subsection should go through the commands you'll need to start trying things out.
    Most Braille displays come equipped with some basic control buttons or other things like wheels or rocker switches. These minimize the need to take your hands off the display to control the computer it is connected to. Pretty much all displays include a Braille keyboard to facilitate input. Presuming you've gotten your display paired, you should feel Braille pop up as you move your finger over the screen. The controls on your display should do what the instructions that came with your display indicate. For instance, panning buttons will move left or right through text. Navigation rocker switches and advance bars should behave in logical ways. To start finding out what all the buttons do, you can use the keyboard help command, which is the spacebar plus the letter "k" (dots 1 and 3). Think of the spacebar like a control key. Once you've entered keyboard help mode, try other spacebar and character combinations. You will be told via speech what they are. This also applies to any other controls on your particular Braille display. VoiceOver has full support for at least 70 different Braille displays at the time this guide is being written in 2022. Even if your display only has a Braille keyboard, there will be enough spacebar key combinations for you to control your iOS device with reasonable proficiency.
Navigating Important iOS Areas:
There's a new handy way to get to apps you want to open while using a Braille display. Use the return combination while on the home screen. That involves holding down the space bar while also pressing dots one an five together. Type some of the name of the app you wish to open. A list of apps will appear which you can cycle through. The app which is selected will have a full cell before and after its name. Use the return combination again to launch the app once you have it selected.
    Any time you would like to reach the home screens, just use the spacebar and letter "h" (dots 1,2, and 5). This should work from anywhere in iOS. While on the home screen, you can start typing in the name of an app you would like to get to, and matching items will appear in a list that can be quickly scrolled through. You can scroll through this list or through all apps on the current home screen in order via the spacebar plus dot 1 for previous, or spacebar plus dot 4 for next item.
Braille Settings in VoiceOver:
Within the settings for VoiceOver in Accessibility settings, you'll find a subgroup simply called Braille. The VoiceOver screen reader is doing all the thinking, while your ultra-expensive Braille display simply moves dots up and down in perfect obedience. Your overall experience should be similar regardless of which display you use. This certainly holds true for the group of settings we'll discuss now. However, be aware that there is another group of settings called Braille Commands we will discuss later that allows for total customization of what buttons and key combinations you enter on your Braille display will do.
    These settings let you set things such as the particular code of Braille to be used with input and output. For instance, you might want six-dot uncontracted Braille for input and contracted Braille for output. You may not want to use UEB Braille if you aren't yet familiar with it. That's perfectly possible. Furthermore, you can choose whether you want word wrap on or off. Word wrap determines whether lines end with the last possible entire word, or whether they can contain the beginning of a word completed on the next line. You can also decide whether to have the panning buttons automatically proceed to the next page when you reach a page boundary and pan further.
    A welcome recent addition is the ability to have your Braille display automatically advance over text. You might use this when reading a book. There's a setting to let you set the time between advancements. You will need to create a command to start and stop auto-advance.
Connecting a Braille Display:
The first thing to do is pair your Braille display with your iOS device. Make certain the Braille display is ready to be paired via Bluetooth, and then flick right through the Braille settings until you come to choose a Braille Display. You should then find a list of any detected Braille displays. Be careful, since it may think ordinary keyboards are Braille displays. When you come to the name of your display, double tap on it to initiate pairing. You may be asked to enter a PIN number using the Braille display to help secure the pairing and make certain input coming from the display is recognized as that. There may be other Bluetooth devices connected to your device or operating close by. The number you enter sets up a secure and easily identifiable connection. Once a display has been paired, you shouldn't have to go through this process again in normal circumstances. If your display loses connection, simply locking the screen and unlocking it again should restore the connection.
    After you have successfully paired your display, the Braille on it should change as you move your finger around the screen. It will be showing the labels of apps or information on the screen as Braille when you touch it. Selected.
    In the Braille settings, you'll find a new setting to enable Bluetooth whenever VoiceOver starts up. This will especially help people who rely on Braille completely to at least be certain that Bluetooth is ready for their displays to connect when they're turned on. Meanwhile, in the "more info" setting for each Braille display, you'll find a setting which tells it to disconnect when the iPhone goes into locked mode. It will reconnect when the iPhone is awakened. This could save battery life on the display and iPhone. However, some Braille displays might not reconnect smoothly or at all automatically so use this with caution.
    Another new addition to Braille settings in VoiceOver is called the sound curtain. It's a way of making certain that while you're using Braille, your iPhone won't make any noise. This includes VoiceOver speech, music and any notification noises. The only sound you'll hear would be emergency alerts. You'll be warned about these consequences when you try to turn this feature on. The only way to get sound back would be to disconnect your Braille display. This setting will be useful if people are giving presentations using Braille displays connected to their iPhones. It will also allow deaf blind people to be certain that their iPhone isn't making sound which they're unable to hear.
Status Cells:
You can choose to have a cell on your display be used for showing status information rather than a character of normal output. Each dot in that cell indicates something such as that your battery is low, there is more text on the current line, a message awaits your attention, etc. You can decide whether the status cell is on the left or right side of the display. You also may select whether it shows general information like I described above or text information such as format, font, etc. for the current character. This would be useful when writing a document. If you're using a status cell, you can turn the rotor to a status cell setting and flick up or down to find out what each dot on the cell means.
Math and Equations:
There is a setting where you can choose whether Nemeth Code is used for equations. Increasingly, ebooks and other documents that contain mathematical equations are accessible through reading apps and VoiceOver. If you encounter mathematical equations while using a Braille display, one of the settings deals with whether you want the Nemeth Code designed to represent mathematics in Braille to be used.
Word Wrap:
Because iOS has full control of formatting what is sent to your Braille display, it can decide when lines end. The word wrap setting lets you decide whether words rap neatly onto lines, or whether a line can end with a partial word that's completed on the next line when you pan over. The first choice may help to clarify all words encountered at the end of lines. However, the other choice, which allows lines to contain all possible text that can be accommodated by your Braille display, may allow for faster reading.
Crossing Page Boundaries:
Another setting lets you choose whether panning over a page boundary automatically moves onto the next or previous page. I have it automatically advance, but can appreciate the utility of having panning stop at page boundaries. Keep in mind that some ebooks don't always give you printed page position. Kindle books provide a location number that you can use instantly to jump to a precise position if you know the number.
Input, Output, and Braille Codes:
There are different styles of Braille, much as there are different forms of writing. Depending on when and how people learn Braille, their needs and comfort with the various forms will be different. The input and output settings let you pick whether you want six-dot, eight-dot, contracted, or uncontracted Braille. iOS can support any of those choices quite well. You can also switch between these modes as needed. You might, for instance, wish to read in contracted six-dot Braille but write in uncontracted Braille.
    In addition to the type of Braille, there is a separate setting from the input and output settings that lets you decide the overall code of Braille to be used. You can choose between US, UK, and UEB Braille codes.
