    This is where you create shortcuts that respond automatically to conditions. You'll find two buttons awaiting you here. The first lets you deal with personal automations. These would be for running on your own device. The other button lets you set up home automations for use by everyone in your home. They will be active on the device you choose to use as a home hub. I have absolutely no experience with these kinds of shortcuts. Therefore, I will simply refer people wanting to use this tab to the link I provided above to the Apple user guide on shortcuts.
    Gallery
    This is the place to discover new shortcuts created by others. It is a very full and busy tab that thankfully makes use of buttons and headings to help navigate and keep things organized. The first element you come to at the top is a search field. Type keywords related to the kind of shortcut you hope to find, and you might strike gold. Next to that search field, you'll find a series of buttons leading to specific kinds of shortcuts. One of these is "shortcuts for accessibility". These buttons are useful for filtering the constantly growing collection of different shortcuts.
    Past those buttons, you come to the first of a series of sections separated by headings. The first heading is Suggested Automations. The next one down is Shortcuts From Your Apps. Don't forget to check for buttons near the headings or at the end of sections just before the next heading; they may lead to other categories.
    When you find a shortcut you're interested in, double tap on it. You can then flick to the right and go over all the parts that make up that shortcut, which includes the phrase used to activate the shortcut via Siri. You will be able to flick over the actions that the shortcut will perform when activated. Also, you can choose to add the shortcut to Siri, which puts it in My Shortcuts.
    Creating Shortcuts
    The Create Shortcut button found at the top of the My Shortcuts tab is what you want to double tap to get started. You can then name your shortcut and add actions to it.
    The user guide from Apple referenced earlier in this section will contain the most up-to-date instructions for creating shortcuts. You may also find one or more useful books at www.nbp.org. In particular, I would direct you to the books by Anna Dresner. One of her many helpful offerings is Getting The Job Done With Shortcuts: An Introduction For Blind Users.
Apple Intelligence:
Increasingly, Siri has fallen behind other digital assistants in terms of what it can do. Apple has approached the use of artificial intelligence very cautiously to keep people's information secure. In iOS 18, they have at last begun making their efforts to catch up in this area available to their customers. This effort falls under the umbrella of Apple Intelligence and is available on any iPhones from the 15 Pro forward. Apple goes to great efforts to explain in their marketing that they don't make use of your information. This brand of artificial intelligence is put at your service and will take every possible measure to guard your information privacy when you use it. Most of the artificial intelligence systems available for public use make you agree that your data can be used in some measure. If nothing else, it's used to train their artificial intelligence to perform better than the competition. One reason why it has taken Apple longer to offer similar capabilities is that it hasn't taken this approach and has respected individual privacy.
    Given how much trouble they have taken to explain and demonstrate their commitment to information privacy, they stand to lose a great deal of trust and income if it were ever shown that Apple wasn't keeping its word about this. As a result, I personally feel far safer using Apple Intelligence than I would in using other systems for research and creative work.
    There are three major areas which Apple is focussing its efforts to employ Apple Intelligence. These are contextual awareness of your life and information, help with writing, and image related tasks. Having access to what's happening on your screen as well as information present on your iPhone, it will be able to do a lot to help in everyday situations. An example given in Apple's keynote where they announced this feature had someone use Siri to figure out whether they had time to eat lunch with a friend at a restaurant before picking someone up at an airport. Augmented by Apple intelligence, Siri was able to check on the flight arrival time, the location of the restaurant, and other factors like traffic conditions. Using all of this information, it could give a competent answer to that question within seconds.
    This has tremendous implications for accessibility and ease of learning for beginners in the future. However, as of early 2025, we're not there yet. Apple knows that it needs to take the time to get things right, or this kind of thing will come off as creepy rather than helpful. Currently, I'm hearing that these aspects will emerge in iOS 19 during the last quarter of 2025 and over 2026. I'll be writing more about this aspect of Apple Intelligence in the fourth edition, which will be written for iOS 20. This should give more time for progress through what Apple hopes will ultimately be a rejuvenating evolution in the whole idea of what a smartphone is and how we use it.
    However, at present, this contextual awareness has yet to emerge and Siri continues to be thought of as a disappointment to those who compare it with other digital assistants.
    There are two more areas which Apple has decided to focus on. These are imagery and writing tools. In both cases, these capabilities are ultimately to be achieved using onboard large language models running on your iPhone. However, while Apple continues to work out the kinks, it has made arrangements with ChatGPT so that if the onboard system can't do the best job of something, you will be asked if you want to use ChatGPT instead. Apple regards these capabilities as still being in beta testing rather than fully ready, and offers ChatGPT when users might find this advantageous. The version used is running on Apple's own secure servers and the Open AI company responsible for ChatGPT doesn't get access to your information.
    There are two aspects to the imagery related intelligence. The image playground app lets you create images based off descriptions you give it. This app is accessible with VoiceOver. Once images have been created, you can then get brief descriptions using VoiceOver's image recognition capability. It may also be helpful to share such created images with other apps, such as Be My Eyes, to get a sighted person or another artificial intelligence to describe the images for you in detail. This is the only method I can think of how a totally blind person could put this app to actual use.
    The Playground app has a fairly simple layout and interface. You'll find any images near the top of the screen. If you flick right from the top-left corner, these will be what you flick onto first. Farther down the screen, you'll find things which help you create your images. There's an edit field near the bottom where you can enter a description of the image you want to create. There are also-buttons which let you choose people, places, and suggestions of things to be used in the images.
    You are able to type in things like: "Put my mother's picture in a field of flowers with the sun shining on her. Write the words Happy Birthday Mom! In gold letters above her head." It would then try to create that image for you. Recently, a choice of having these images done in a sketch style rather than the original style has been added. I have yet to encounter much reaction to this new option from people with sight. However, the original style was often described as cartoonish. People have trouble using it for practical things.
Visual Intelligence:
This feature does for the general population what apps like Seeing AI, Envision AI, Be My Eyes, and the recently released Ally assistant from Envision have done for blind people for years now. Essentially, it lets you take a picture with your iPhone's rear camera and then ask questions and gain information about that picture. Currently, this service makes use of ChatGPT and can also use Google to search for items similar to what's in the picture you take.
    I've tested this feature out in various situations. One drawback for blind users is that ChatGPT doesn't know that you're totally blind when it formulates its descriptions and answers. You should also be careful not to put your iPhone down or take too long before typing or dictating your questions. Pressing the "ask" button will cause an edit field to appear where this is then possible to do.
    This could be fun for new users who have yet to visit the app store where apps designed for blind users are generally more likely to be helpful.
    Visual intelligence really shines when you want more practical information about something rather than a description of it. I once used it to ask if a tropical drink a friend got for me should be chilled before being consumed and got a competent and helpful reply. However, you need to be somewhat experienced in holding the iPhone and directing the camera. New blind users would frankly be much better served by making use of the above-mentioned apps, which were specially designed for blind people. They tend to give more detailed and useful descriptive answers.
Writing Tools:
Apple has offered several tools to help people improve their writing via Apple Intelligence. People can select some text or submit the entire document they're working on to various manipulations. Currently, tools include options to proofread or totally rewrite the selection differently. You can change the style to be more friendly, professional, or concise. Other tools let you summarize apiece of writing, pick out the key points, make a bullet list or table. If all that fails to do what you want, there is also an edit box where you can describe the changes you desire in your own words. For instance, you could ask it to rewrite an email in a Shakespearean style. Apple Intelligence will then attempt to carry out your request. It may not understand what you want. I've had occasions where it said it was finished, but when I checked, there was simply the word "loading" where the altered text should be. You might have to hit the "back" button and find another way of describing what you want done.
    All of this power is available system-wide. Wherever you are able to enter text, you can make use of these tools. Once in an edit field, turn the rotor to "edit" and flick up or down through the options. You will quickly come to "writing tools". Double-tap on this and a dialogue will appear with the available tools. Flick left or right through the options and double-tap on what you want to use. When you do this, a further dialogue will open up with your original writing at the bottom and the altered writing at the top. Once you've read through what Apple Intelligence has generated, you can then choose to copy the new writing into the original edit field. The new writing will appear above the older. You can also decide to replace your original writing with what the tool you selected has generated. The "back" button at the top left of the dialogue lets you return to the writing tools without making any changes. Alternatively, the "done" button lets you exit the writing tools altogether, returning you to the original edit field with your unaltered text intact.
    When I've used these tools in the previous paragraphs about them above, Apple Intelligence has taken around five seconds or less to complete the process. Larger amounts of text, such as a whole section of this book, took longer to process. Keep in mind that many decisions are being made. The more you feed into these tools at once, the more careful you should be about reading over the results. Remember that the system doesn't fundamentally understand reality or the words being used. It follows rules about sentence structure, punctuation and such. You are very unlikely to agree with all the decisions made in this area. It's simply looking through a massive database of writing and conclusions drawn from previous attempts to satisfy conditions. It might very well figure out where to place the words "cup of coffee". However, it wouldn't understand that the coffee might be hot or that the cup might be breakable.
Summarization:
Another area where people have really begun to welcome Apple Intelligence is in its ability to summarize material. People will find these summaries in the Mail app, in their notifications, messages, and other places throughout iOS. These summaries do a reasonable job of taking longer message threads or blocks of text and bringing forth the important points.
    As before, people need to remember that the system doesn't fundamentally understand what it's abbreviating. Apple has had to prevent the summarization of notifications about news articles because of mistakes which totally changed the meaning of the original material, leading people to false conclusions. When I used the summarization writing tool, I found that it didn't do as well with sets of instructions. Be careful when using these summaries.
Integration With Productivity Apps:
Apple has now taken special care to integrate Apple Intelligence related capabilities into its suite of productivity apps. This means that you can use writing tools in the Numbers, Keynote and Pages apps to edit text in spreadsheets, documents, or presentations. You can also do things like create images for use in things you produce with these apps. Another app which is getting special attention is Freeform. People who make use of Freeform for mental mapping or collaborative brainstorming can put these tools and assets created in the other apps into their Freeform canvasses. Presumably, as Siri becomes contextually aware of what you're doing, it will be able to offer suggestions and help you accomplish your work.
Reflections on Apple Intelligence and Siri:
The release of iOS 18 marks the somewhat disappointing start of the largest fundamental transformation ever attempted in terms of what it means to own an iPhone. Apple has a history of not being the first to reach a certain point, but eventually making a big splash when they enter a race from the rear and pull ahead of the competition. This time around, we have what I describe as a rather painful belly flop on our hands. Being behind in such a crucial area clearly put too much marketing pressure on Apple, which was compelled to reveal more than they were ready to.
    Clearly, Apple intends to merge Siri with Apple Intelligence to provide something very much needed. Artificial intelligence which is really focussed on individual needs and isn't sucking up their data for other purposes. Having a large language model running on your iPhone which is aware of your personal context has all sorts of implications for ease of use, privacy, and accessibility. Progress really hinges as much on Apple maintaining the trust and security of its users as on any innovations they come up with from this point forward. Had Apple waited until all three components were reasonably well polished and working smoothly, a great deal of disappointment could have been avoided.
    So far, I can't honestly say that what I've experienced of Apple Intelligence has blown me away. As things stand in mid-2025, people could have achieved often better results by simply using the artificial intelligence apps provided by the creators of ChatGPT and Google. Apple has scrambled to lessen its vulnerability to false advertising charges.
    Be that as it may, this could change drastically as Apple hits their stride over the following years. Full control of hardware and software should eventually allow Apple to offer a digital assistant which is speedy, secure, and contextually aware as promised. Having this assistant built with your privacy in mind right from the start is more important than many people realize. I've read comments from other AI companies which indicate to me that this is a scary proposition for them. It would give people the benefits of their offerings without mining and selling their data. It would truly be shaking to the industry as it now stands. This basic idea is good and would indeed offer something unique.
    At this point, they can't really back out of this initiative due to the current lamentable condition of Siri. Apple really has to make good on this overall vision as soon as possible. By lifting the curtain too early, they have increased the pressure on their development staff and disappointed their customers. Early adopter's like me are left wondering if we'll be able to experience the complete system as envisioned by Apple before needing to upgrade to new iPhones which are better equipped to handle the increased demands.
    Being an incurable optimist, I predict that Apple will make good on this promise. Internally, they have taken some drastic steps to bolster the team working on Apple Intelligence and especially Siri. Sadly, one of the consequences of the delays in this area might be that these initial iPhones built for Apple Intelligence will be rendered less desirable more quickly than might be wished. One key factor is the amount of RAM in iPhones. A minimum of 8 gb is needed to run the current large language model Apple uses. The Consistent rumours suggest that Apple will be drastically increasing the RAM in the next generation of iPhones. As contextual awareness becomes present, such constant vigilance might cause increased battery drain. There are many factors and unknowns going forward.
    Siri has continued to gain new capabilities. However, it hasn't really gotten more reliably able to understand and execute tasks. It has also not managed to keep up with other digital assistants when it comes to answering questions. Thankfully, it can now send tasks and questions to ChatGPT for processing by that artificial intelligence. Apple will soon offer a similar integration with Google Gemini and other assistants. I've found this to be a helpful, if somewhat clunky interim solution. It allows me to get more complex answers than SIri is currently capable of providing. However, it doesn't really give me a clear sense of what the actual Apple Intelligence will be capable of in the most desired area of improvement promised. That of a drastically improved Siri.
    My current need for such assistants is met by Google and the access to ChatGPT through Siri which Apple makes available free of charge. I'm not particularly worried about revealing anything sensitive through my inquiries. Having much more faith in Apple when it comes to protecting my information, I'll be eager to make increased use of its own artificial intelligence as it develops more fully.
    For other players in this space, these services are much more about collecting data and making money. Having a digital assistant especially built not to do that and to keep our personal data private would be very desirable in this time of so much misuse of information.
    Of course, being as invested in the Apple ecosystem as we are has a way of making Siri more attractive. My wife Sara and I each have Apple Watches which can tap into Siri, I have also acquired a pair of Home-pod Mini smart speakers. These have become part of our everyday life. We mostly use them to listen to radio, audio dramas and other programming which Sara and I both want to hear. I also often ask Siri questions while working at my desk and find it very convenient to have the HomePods set to listen for Siri while my iPhone is set not to. This lets me access answers to at least basic inquiries without ever leaving the app I'm in. We're both far more comfortable with Apple devices, listening for those magic words of summoning as we go about our lives. They have the least to gain and the most to lose by misusing our information.
    Siri is getting better at giving you control of music, settings on your device, taking message dictation, etc. Apple is constantly working on expanding its capabilities. Large changes are usually introduced with iOS updates, but things are doubtless still improving slowly on at their end in the cloud. Given the new focus on handling as much as possible on one's own device rather than in the cloud, I presume we'll see that side of things improves mainly with these iOS updates. Hopefully, now that this major transition to Apple Intelligence is underway, we won't see features which are so critical to seniors and other people less skilled with tech and touchscreen disabled like we did over the past while. Siri will increasingly learn about your interests, manner of speaking, and other personal things, keeping everything on your device. Efforts are constantly underway to make Siri better understand different accents and people who have difficulty speaking.
    Upgrading to a large language model really will be a jump forward for Siri. It should make a big difference and improve Siri's capabilities tremendously when Apple develops Apple Intelligence far enough to grow past its birthing pains. I have every confidence that by the time I publish the fourth edition of this guide in a couple of years, we'll have a lot more to cover in this area.

Stay Informed With Notifications:
As you begin using your iOS device in earnest, you'll frequently encounter notifications. They are a primary means of relaying information to you from apps running on your device. Typically, you'll get notifications from apps which are running in the background out of sight while you're focussing on something else. They might also appear while you're travelling with your iPhone in your pocket. They may at times interrupt your work. It all depends on how well you master the various settings and tools Apple provides to bring order to the chaos and manage how and when they appear.
    I think this is one of the most crucial areas for blind people to really comprehend what options they have to get the most out of their iOS device. For blind users, a notification will typically be spoken out loud by VoiceOver. Only after it has finished or been silenced will VoiceOver return its attention to whatever you were previously hearing. If they're using a Braille display, the notification will pull them out of whatever they may have been reading prior to its arrival. Only after a certain time has passed will the notification disappear and return the reader to the app or other area they were previously in. A crucial difference for blind people is that they will hear or read the notification in the identical voice to what they were potentially already using to work with their devices. There's no real barrier or equivalent of a change in font or designated area of appearance. VoiceOver will simply say the word "notification" and then proceed to read the information it contains. Braille will likewise jump to the notification. This can be quite discombobulating to one's mental flow. Meanwhile, sighted people can look through the notification to whatever they were viewing before its arrival. They can still see what they were working on and aren't pulled completely out of it. Furthermore, the banners are contained and easily distinguished from whatever they may have previously been focussed on. Therefore, the effect isn't as jarring for them.
    Many blind people who I've spoken to were frustrated that their iPhone was distracting them with information they didn't want while they tried to do something. Perhaps, they were trying to read a book and suddenly found themselves reading a notification about a message from a friend. There are many times when we don't want to wait to hear information before continuing to, for instance, finish typing this sentence. While navigating in the real world, you don't always want to be pulled out of your GPS app by a notification from social media. However, learning about changing weather conditions might be useful during that same time. Any effort you put into becoming familiar with notifications settings as a blind user is time very well spent. It will make the difference between you feeling effective and in control, or feeling constantly distracted and interrupted when you don't want to be.
    Provided you take the time to explore and learn about notifications and focus settings, all of this can be customized. Things may seem a little overwhelming and out of your control at first. However, you can have your cake and eat it too. You can be free of undesired distractions when you need to be. It is also possible to let desired information through so that you need not worry about missing out while working at something else.
    In this section, we'll take a deep dive into these communications from the apps and services which comprise your digital life. We'll learn how they can appear and what control we have over them.
    To begin with, let's go over what a typical notification is composed of. The very first thing a notification contains is which app or service generated it. For example, the Weather app tells me via notifications when it will rain in my current location. The word "Weather" at the beginning of this notification might seem superfluous. However, it is the name of the actual app. There are other weather related apps such as Weather Gods which also deliver notifications about the weather. Perhaps, the forecasts from two similar apps such as these might differ. Because you are clearly informed which app supplied the notifications, you are able to determine the app which proves more trustworthy over time.
    The next piece of information in a notification is roughly how long ago the notification was delivered. This is often quite useful information when it comes to prioritizing what you want to respond to or deal with. The older a notification gets, the less precise the indication of how long ago the notification was delivered will be. A more recent notification will indicate that it was delivered twenty-five minutes ago. However, a note which is hours old will specify the number of hours, but not minutes. This holds true for days and weeks etc.
    Following the creation app and time stamp, you'll come to the actual information contained in the notification. A game might wish to inform you that your warriors are ready for adventure. A social media app such as Twitter might want to tell you about a new follower or a tweet which mentioned you. A news related app may inform you of breaking news in an area which you've indicated a particular interest in being informed about. Services like the phone or messages apps will generate notifications to tell you about calls you missed or messages which have arrived. The possibilities are limitless.
    While a notification's main purpose is to deliver information, they can do more than this. They can serve as a way to get quickly into an app right to the area related to the notification. For instance, you might receive a notification from YouTube about a new video from a channel you follow. If you perform a one finger double tap on the notification, you will be taken into YouTube directly to the video in question. Similarly, doing a one finger double tap on a notification about a tweet will typically take you into the Twitter app and into the tweet or conversation thread. Notifications may make other interactive options available, such as replying to a message.
    You have a great deal of latitude regarding how intrusive notifications from apps and services are. This kind of control is vital to making your device a practical tool rather than a chattering distraction. When I'm recording lectures, I prefer not to be interrupted unless it's actually important. Perhaps, I'm waiting for delivery of a package and don't want to miss knowing about its arrival while I blather away. It's less of a hassle to stop working and get the package than to have to go and pick it up somewhere else. I therefore wouldn't want to completely shut off notifications from some apps even when I'm busy. Instead, I would create a focus mode which stopped most apps from alerting me so that their notifications appear quietly in the Notification Centre. This sort of thing is also helpful when you're using a GPS device to navigate and don't want to be pulled out of that app unless it's important. Meanwhile, I would use the notifications settings to streamline which apps were normally allowed to deliver notifications and how I wanted it done.
The Notification Centre:
Unless you specify otherwise, all notifications from your apps will appear in the notification centre. It is a particularly useful area for blind people, as it serves as a catch-all for information that might have been missed while you were busy doing something else. Often, notification announcements interrupt us when we least need them to. Perhaps, we're writing a document under time pressure or in the middle of a conversation. We may accidentally or intentionally silence them before they finish reading to get back to what we were doing. Because notifications can always be found in the notification centre, we have that safety net and can check there at our convenience to find what we missed.
    It is actually sometimes desirable to specifically set an app's notifications not to appear in the notification centre. This is especially true if the notifications are so time-sensitive as to be useless after being generated. One example of this is a number of apps which use the notifications system in iOS as a means of giving time alerts, such as quarterly chimes. The Westminster Chimes Full app is a good example of this. It uses the notifications system to be able to deliver audible chimes or time announcements at hourly or other intervals. This eliminates the need to look at a clock while busy doing other things. Having such notifications pile up in the notification centre would be quite undesirable. They contain no information which is of any use past the point when they trigger and let loose their chime or announcement of the time. There are many examples of features in iOS being used for purposes like this beyond what they were designed for.
    To reach the notification centre, touch the status bar and, with three fingers at once, swipe downward. Alternatively, touch near the top of the screen until you hear a short low tic. Drag your finger downward until you hear two more tics which rise in pitch. Lift your finger after hearing the third one, and you'll appear in the notification centre. Once there, touch your finger near the top left of the screen and flick right with a finger to explore the current contents. They will be in order from most current to older notifications, you can flick right through what is available. Double tapping on a notification will open the group of notifications related to the app which generated it. If you're inside a group or the notification doesn't belong to a group, double tapping on it will open the app that generated it and put you there.
    Flicking up or down on a given notification may yield more options, allowing for even more efficient action. This depends on how well an app has been integrated with the Notification Centre. Available options depend on the app in question. An example of what's possible is following someone who has followed you on X without needing to go into the app itself. Any interactions available directly from a notification will be basic in nature. To do anything major, you'll still have to go into an app.
    Notifications may be grouped and organized to suit your preferences. This can drastically reduce clutter in the notification centre. For instance, all notifications generated by social media apps like X can be grouped, so they don't clutter up everything else. You can then expand that group when you actually want to look at all of those particular notifications. Alternatively, you can delete all of them at once as a group. Flicking down on a group of notifications brings you to options, including one that lets you manage the group. Double tapping on this lets you determine how notifications from a given app are to be treated. My favourite use for this is to have notifications from certain apps delivered quietly, so they don't disturb my work, but are still made available in the Notification Centre when I feel like checking it. Basically, a notification is delivered quietly if it simply appears in the notification centre without triggering any sound, badge, or banner. It can make a big difference in feeling that your device is at your command rather than you at its.
    Notifications can also be organized in different orders and managed in the Settings app in the Notifications section found just to the left of Sounds & Haptics. In there, each app that can generate notifications has a style choice button beside its name. You can choose among several options depending on how intrusive you want the notifications to actually be. They can generate sounds or appear as banners that speak and then disappear. Alternatively, they can appear as persistent banners, forcing you to deal with them or dismiss them before doing anything else. As another alternative, they can simply be added to your Notification Centre and not interrupt you at all.
    You are given quite a lot of latitude here, which it is now time to explore more deeply.
Notifications Settings:
When you use the settings in this notifications section, think on a macro level. They deal with how you generally want notifications from a given app to behave in normal everyday circumstances. Perhaps, you want notifications from a messaging app to always be announced. You may, on the other hand, want notifications from news apps to appear in the notifications centre without interrupting what you're doing most of the time. You can then use the focus settings to override this normal behaviour when it's necessary to minimize distractions. This will result in you needing to spend less time changing the notification settings from what you would ordinarily prefer.
    Each app capable of generating notifications has a corresponding setting within the Notifications settings. At the start of these settings are a couple of what I think of as "master" settings. The first is new to iOS 15. It lets you schedule when you want to have summaries of possibly missed notifications created by the artificial intelligence in your device. These summaries will await your pleasure in the notifications centre. The next setting allows instant and overriding control over when notification previews are shown. Notification Previews contain some or all of the contents of a notification. For example, a notification from Twitter might include the contents of a tweet. This is all well and good provided the information isn't in some way sensitive. It can help you quickly determine whether something needs to be dealt with urgently or may safely be left until later. However, if you're likely to get an email about your outstanding debt, or a tweet about what a wimp you were in last week's boxing match, you may want that sort of information to remain safe from innocent eyes and ears. You can therefore elect to reveal Notification Previews always, only when your device is unlocked and presumably in your control, or never. When previews aren't shown, you are still notified that a given app has a notification for you. You simply won't know anything else about it until you investigate further.
    As fluke would have it, just as I wrote the preceding sentence, a Kindle book I preordered became available. Because I chose to allow Notification Previews, I learned the book's title. In this case, the book was one I had since learned was a book for children, covering the same ground as a book for adults the author wrote previously. I was therefore able to return the Kindle book right away before the window during which you can return such purchases expires. Had I not allowed for Notification Previews, I would merely have been told that the Kindle app had a notification for me. I may in consequence have failed to learn what I learned in time to get my easy refund.
    The next button lets you decide whether to allow notifications to show while you're sharing your screen or having it mirrored on a larger device, perhaps to give a presentation. Turning the option to off will prevent any such occurrences from happening.
    The next area is beneath a heading called "Siri". The options here will determine what Siri, the intelligent assistant on your device, does with notifications and suggestions. You can choose whether you want Siri to read time sensitive notifications out loud independently of VoiceOver. Siri will listen after reading a notification for any interactive response you may wish to verbally instruct it to do. The next button in the "Siri" heading gets you into an area where you can allow or disallow apps from making shortcut suggestions through Siri while on the lock screen. Each app you have can be allowed or disallowed individually.
    Past this point, we get into a section complete with a heading that is called Notification Style. This lets you determine if, how, and when apps are able to notify you about information or the results of activities that happen while the apps are running in the background and not in focus. Each app that can generate notifications has an entry. As you obtain more apps, this section will grow larger. The apps will always be listed in alphabetical order. Flick left or right over the entries in the list. You'll hear the app's name followed by the current setting for that app. For instance, "sounds and badges". To change these settings, double tap on the app's name and then flick right to go over the options. Double tap on an option you want to change and then flick right over any options presented. Double tap on the choice you wish to make. It's all pretty simple and intuitive. We will now go over the available Notification Style choices in detail.
    Let's choose the Aira app as an example. This app lets you call trained sighted agents for assistance when you need it. The app itself is free and very handy to have on one's iPhone. Double tapping on its name in the Notification Style section, the very first option we come to is whether to have the ability to produce notifications be on or off. Double tap this control to toggle between on or off as desired. Some apps can generate many notifications, so there may well be times when you simply want a total break from them. Turning this setting to off will achieve this.
    Flicking to the right of this switch, we come to another heading called "Notification delivery". Past this heading, we find options to have notifications delivered immediately or be added in the next scheduled summary. Either way, the notification may also be found in the notifications centre.
    The next heading is called "Alerts". This is followed by a series of buttons that tell iOS where you will allow notifications from an app to appear. Double tapping any of these buttons will change its state to selected or unselected. Before the button's name, you'll hear the term "selected" read out if you have set it to Selected. The first of these buttons either allows or disallows alerts from the Aira app to appear on the lock screen, which makes them readable even when your device is locked. The next option determines whether notifications from Aira appear in the Notification Centre for later reading. The next button asks whether notifications from this app may appear as "banners". Banners appear on the screen Even when you're working in other apps. If you allow banners, the next button over will let you determine whether these are "temporary" or "persistent". Temporary banners appear only for a short time before disappearing. Persistent banners will need to be dismissed before they disappear, and you can continue your other activities. Double tapping on the Banner Style button will cause the two options to be visible, so you can choose between them. You can then hit the Back button at the top left.
    The next buttons determine whether you will allow sounds to be played, alerting you to a particular app's notifications. Many apps have their own unique notification sounds that play instead of the default alert tone. Next to this on-off toggle is another similar button that lets you choose whether "badges" can be used. App badges may include pictures or numbers, such as the number of waiting messages. The Fantastical app has a number of badge options picked from within the app itself. One of these is to display a number indicating the current day of the month.
    The next couple of options are under a heading called Options. The first allows you to choose a setting for notification previews that differs from the default setting. This way, you can selectively allow or disallow previews for key apps, rather than having to have all of them be tied to the overall choice made in the first setting. The final setting has to do with how and whether notifications from a given app are grouped to make them easier to manage efficiently. Some apps like Facebook, Twitter, Mail, etc., can generate an awful lot of notifications. This setting takes you to a range of choices regarding putting notifications from this app into a group of their own, or not to group them at all. The default choice is "automatic", which lets artificial intelligence figure out how notifications should be grouped for you.
Scheduled Notifications Summaries:
One very nice new technique for dealing with the flood of notifications one might receive daily is the generation of scheduled summaries. These can appear in your notifications centre at times when it's convenient for you. The "scheduled summary" setting is found at the very start of the notifications settings. You are able to pick the best times to have these summaries generated and announced to you. While artificial intelligence on your device arranges the notifications in what it thinks is the most optimal order, you have full control of what apps can add to these summaries. Each app has an on or off toggle, which can be found in the "apps in summary" group in side the scheduled summary settings. You can sort the list of apps alphabetically or by the number of average daily notifications they generate. If an app doesn't deliver notifications to the summary, you will still see its notifications in the notifications centre. All that is affected by summary related settings is the actual summary itself.
    When you double tap on a summary in the notifications centre, it expands, and you're able to flick right through various notifications. Double tap on any which interests you to look at the full notification. It is now in focus, so you can double tap on it, flick up or down, etc. You don't need to leave the summary and find a notification in the centre to interact with it. The order in which notifications appear is determined by artificial intelligence on your device. It tries to learn based on your activities throughout the day to figure out what is likely most important for you. 
Managing Notifications From Inside Apps:
The settings discussed above are on a macro level. If you want to decide whether an app displays its notifications with persistent banners, Notifications settings is where you make such choices. However, you should also look inside individual apps for options specific to that particular app. Many apps have more unique configuration or preference options found inside the app itself rather than in the general settings app. In particular, look for a "more" tab or a settings button. Going into that tab or double tapping that button will reveal these options. If apps generate many notifications, this is where you may find options dealing with when or in what circumstances notifications are generated.
    The Fantastical app I mentioned in passing earlier is an example of an app which has its own additional settings which control the circumstances that generate notifications in the first place. You can, for instance, decide whether appointment alerts happen and how early they might appear. You can decide whether event alerts generate sounds. X is another case in point. Personally, I don't need to know when someone chooses to follow me. However, I might want to know when I'm mentioned or when a certain person tweets. To configure this, I need to go into the Twitter app and into their push notification settings.
    Not all apps offer this kind of control. It depends on the app developer. However, in my experience, it's always good to check in an app for extra options regarding notifications which may offer unique customization relevant to that particular app.
Thoughts on Notifications:
Apple has made positively massive strides in iOS 15 when it comes to letting the user be the master of what can interrupt one's life. There was a time when things were much more about what advertisers and app developers wanted your notification experience to be. You could take steps, but it was a bit like pulling teeth. Now, with the additions to notifications settings and the new focus feature, things have turned a very positive corner. You have a meaningful amount of easy control without needing to jump through hoops.
    To get the most out of notifications, take the time to go through the notifications settings for each app you have. Think what you normally want to have from that app in terms of notifications and set that as your baseline. The artificial intelligence on your device will make decisions about which notifications to group to minimize clutter. Remember that you can always go into the notifications settings for a particular app and turn off grouping, so the notifications appear individually. Once you've made a change in this area, it will be remembered. So will all adjustments you make in notifications settings. As time passes, you'll find yourself visiting the notifications settings less often as you optimize things. Don't forget to take advantage of the ability to take apps out of immediate delivery and schedule notifications to be included in summaries. That in itself can really cut back on unexpected interruptions. Take advantage of sounds rather than banners if you just want to know about the existence of a new notification in an app. That won't pull you completely out of whatever you're doing when a notification arrives.
    The focus feature makes it possible to build a stable foundation in notifications settings. Use the focus feature to build focus modes which make the changes to your normal operation that different circumstances demand without needing to change notifications settings. This lets you only allow the interruptions you actually want at any given time with a minimum of fuss. Over time, you'll make small adjustments to really optimize all of this. The result should be a system of interlocked settings which require very little maintenance that keeps interruptions to those which you desire.
    Respecting your privacy is an increasingly important pillar for Apple's branding. This has certainly formed a core part of the changes in iOS 15. App developers are going to have to win your trust and offer more substantial reasons for you to opt into their notifications. I would advise my readers to be on the lookout for more settings within apps themselves, giving you more control over when and why apps notify you of things. This kind of custom notifications settings are also increasingly found in Apple's own apps. For instance, the News app has settings in the "following" tab under the "manage" heading which let you customize which news channels send you notifications. I was informed of this in a dialogue which popped up when I first entered that tab. However, not all developers will be so conscientious. Look around your apps carefully for any such options which may be buried in settings which aren't as obvious as they might be.
    As the system learns more about your interests, the notification summaries will become increasingly useful. The onboard artificial intelligence will optimize the order of notifications. This use of artificial intelligence will likely be expanded to other aspects of dealing with notifications as time goes on. 
    I hope this section gives you a good start in understanding your options regarding notifications. Your device will feel more like your own as you take control of interruptions and distractions. Notifications can be a gold mine of concise information relevant to your unique interests if you set things up correctly. There are enough tools to do this very effectively now.

Guard Against Distraction With Focusses:
I sat on my balcony one afternoon working on segment notes for that week's contribution to the Kelly and Company show. I was covering the latest Sherlock Holmes drama released by Big Finish. They do fantastic audio dramas and I wanted to do this one justice. I sat in very welcome and rare tranquility. It was so nice to be free of the near constant construction noise in and around my apartment building. The breeze was gentle and there were no pesky wasps. People without hearing aids might not appreciate how truly unnerving those can be when they fly past your head directly over one.
    Sara and I had thoroughly enjoyed this Holmes drama. I tried to think back to all the different dramas I had heard over the years which featured the legendary Holmes and Watson. How did I want to frame this new entry against past releases? I began to think back. However, before I got very far in my recollections, I was interrupted by a notification from a game called Sonar Islands. Being blissfully unaware of my keen concentration, the game blithely chose to inform me that an upgrade to one of my islands was now complete. One of my treasure chests could now contain more gold and generate gold coins more quickly than before. The temptation to abandon my efforts and play the game was easily set aside. That extra gold would take time to accumulate. Knowing about this development gave me absolutely no immediate advantage in the game. Alas, in an unstoppable tide, other associated thoughts came hard on the heels of that distraction. There was the excellent version of Treasure Island which Big Finish had produced. Any mention of an island is more than likely to bring to my mind's ear a snatch of that production. I'll hear a line or two from Ben Gunn or Long John Silver. "Fifteen men on a dead man's chest..." It was available to me with a few swipes and taps in the Big Finish app. There were, of course, many of the Sherlock Holmes dramas I had been contemplating. I could listen to any of them just as easily, having collected them over the years via Audible. Call it procrastinative research. And then, there was the upcoming season of Survivors. I had enjoyed that show in the past and could easily use Google to look up information about where things stood. With some effort, I pulled my thoughts back on task without invoking the king of all search engines and going down that rabbit hole. It took a good five minutes to really get back into the zone and typing out my thoughts on seamstress of Peckham Rye.
    There were a myriad of other interruptions during that warm Summer afternoon. Most of them were things I was genuinely interested in and glad to know about. I simply wished I could have waited to find out about them until after I had done my segment notes. Both my wife and I were waiting for packages, so I didn't feel good about using the "do not disturb" feature. This choice ultimately proved a good one, as the packages actually did arrive that afternoon.
    On that particular day, I got numerous scam calls from an infernally annoying fellow trying to interest me in duct cleaning. I also received a very welcome call from an old friend. None of the businesses, media outlets or people had set out to thwart my progress. Even the duct cleaning scammer from Hell had no idea that I was trying to get serious work done. It was simply one of those days when the universe itself seemed bent on denying me peaceful progress. I needed something more flexible to more effectively deal with incoming calls and information than what I had at the time.
    Although unleashed by outside notifications and callers, the level of my ongoing distraction was as much due to the ease with which I could satisfy my stirred curiosities or temptations. I'm far from the only one to face this. It was why employers insisted on people not using their personal smartphones for work or monitored their performance in other ways during work time.
    Apple has begun introducing features to help us set boundaries for ourselves and others who want to contact us. They hope to make that process as easy and painless as possible. People, myself included, were finding themselves too often tempted, too easily distracted, and too available to others wanting our attention.
    The Focus feature introduced in iOS 15 is Apple's most ambitious attempt so far to deal with this problem. It allows people to create and choose from different focus options, which limit the apps and people who are able to disturb you. Rather than an all or nothing toggle, Focus lets you customize which apps and people can break through to you with notifications or calls. Where "Do not disturb" was a club, the Focus feature now presents us with a much more precise scalpel. We can eliminate the distractions we don't want while allowing critical time sensitive information through. This extends to allowing us to select which home screens are available to us while in a given focus. This puts in an extra step to go through to make that tempting game or social media app on screen five available. Combined with the new ability for notifications to be delivered in a summary when you decide, people now have a much stronger and more versatile set of options to avoid missing out on information while minimizing distraction. They can truly have the best of both worlds.
Setting up Focus Choices:
There are two major parts to the Focus feature. The main one is in settings. There, you'll find the new "Focus" setting a flick to the right of "sounds and haptics" or one flick left of "screen time". Double tapping on this will put you in a strip of options. At the top, under the "focus" heading, you'll find an "Add" button. This lets you create a brand-new focus mode. Next to this, you'll find any focus modes which are already present. The very first is that old reformed soul, called "do not disturb". Rather than simply being an on or off toggle, it is now a focus mode. There are also sample modes for work and sleep. The Sleep focus mode is special since it integrates with your sleep schedule set up in the Health app. All of these can be customized to suit your precise needs. To the right of these, you'll find a basic description of what the focus feature does. Finally, there is a toggle switch to decide whether turning on focus modes with the device you're currently using is shared across other devices. If you have more than one Apple device, this lets you choose whether each device will change its focus to the same as all other devices. This makes certain that my Apple Watch knows to go into the sleep focus I've customized for bedtime. However, since I don't want my iPhone XR responding to focus changes now that it's a backup phone, I've turned this option off on it. This means that I can turn on the "do not disturb" focus on my iPhone 13 and Apple Watch without changing the focus on my XR.
    Now, let's explore what happens when you double tap on a focus. We'll use "do not disturb" as our example. This is basically built to act like the "do not disturb" setting, which has been replaced by the "Focus" setting. It is what people who really would rather not fiddle with other focus modes are likely to gravitate to. The first thing you'll find is an on or off toggle switch. Simply double tap it to change its state. The next thing to the right is a heading called "allowed notifications". Under this heading, you'll find options to decide who can call you and what apps can disturb you while this focus mode is active. Each button, the first for people and the next for apps, puts you into a dialogue where you make the necessary decisions. It's actually the very same dialogue. In it, you'll find "people" and "apps" buttons. You can use these to change your attention to either area until you're happy with all the options in the dialogue.
    When "people" is selected, the first button is after the word "allow". It is a "remove all" button letting you erase any allowances you've made, returning the focus to exclude all interruptions from people. The next button allows you to add people to a list of people who are allowed to contact you. Double tapping this button will get you into your contacts list, where you can double tap on a person to add him or her. Any calls or messages from that person will then be let through, even when this focus is active. Next to this is "also allow". The button found to the right of these words will let you determine what to do with people inside or outside your contact list who you haven't specifically added to the list of allowed people for that focus mode. There are options to allow calls from everyone, no one, only people in your contacts, only people marked as favourite. You'll also find an option whether to allow repeated calls. If someone calls more than once during a three-minute period, that second call can be let through.
    For me, allowing calls from favourites does the trick here. These include family members and other numbers such as my apartment buzzer which works through my phone. This greatly reduces any unimportant calls which I don't want to deal with while in the "do not disturb" focus mode.
    Now, let's turn our attention to apps. As with people, the first button lets you remove all the apps you may have added, thereby eliminating any mistakes and letting you start again. The next button is "add app" and is pretty self-explanatory. You're presented with a list of your apps and can add whatever app you want. Notifications from these apps will be let through. Any apps added will appear to the right of the "add app" button. Next, like with people, you'll find "also allow" and an option to let apps not on your allowed list pass you time sensitive notifications while you're in this focus mode.
    I'm very selective about which apps I will allow to interrupt me. Any shopping and package tracking apps are on my list of allowed apps. News, games, and social media apps are excluded. This minimizes the chance that I will be needlessly interrupted, while still allowing people who urgently need to contact me to do so.
    Going past the "allowed notifications" heading contents, we come to another heading called "Options". Beneath this heading, we will find settings governing other aspects of a focus mode. The first is the focus status. This lets you choose whether you want other people to be informed that you're in a particular focus mode, should they try to contact you. If you turn the status on, they would get a message like "Michael is reading now. Send anyway?" They can still send you a message, but will hopefully realize from the name of the focus mode that you won't necessarily respond right away. Messages and calls from people not on your allowed list will still be delivered. Calls will go to your voicemail automatically. Messages will arrive in your messaging app. The notifications which normally alert you to this and interrupt you simply don't happen.
    Next, there are "home screen" and "lock screen" buttons. With the "home screen" button, you are taken to settings which let you decide whether notification badges are hidden or displayed. An example might be the badge which shows how many unread messages are in your email inbox. The next option lets you decide whether you want to only make certain home screens available while you're in this focus mode. Any selected pages are shown. Any unselected are hidden until you leave the focus mode.
    Using the app library, it is actually possible to build home screens of particular apps which will only be shown when a particular focus mode is active. Simply copy the apps you desire from the app library onto the extra page, which is always present in the edit mode. When you have all the desired apps on this new home screen, you'll note that any apps you used on other home screens haven't gone away. You've simply created new icons for that particular home screen which point to the same apps. You could, via this means, construct a special home screen with all the apps you need for work and create a focus mode which only lets you access that home screen of apps while it's active.
    In my Work focus mode, I hide every home screen beyond the first three, except the fifth. That fifth home screen contains all the apps used for package delivery tracking and shopping. With all other home screens hidden, this fifth screen becomes the fourth while in my Work focus mode. These plus any apps in the dock contain any apps I'm likely to need, but hide home screens full of games and social media. When I turn off this focus mode, I am once again able to reach all ten of my home screens. The fifth screen is back in its usual place and all the games are back in easy reach.
    For the lock screen, you can decide whether it will be dimmed while in a particular focus. You can also choose to show notifications on the lock screen, or have them not shown at all while you're in this focus mode. This overrides any settings for notifications you might have, generally making it much easier to reduce visual and auditory distractions from your locked phone when you really need to. Romantic dinners, work meetings and many other occasions come to mine. Simply deactivate the focus mode and your normal notifications settings will be back in effect.
    Apple Intelligence can play a role in focusses as of iOS 18. You can turn on a new switch found at the top of the settings for each focus. It's called intelligence in silencing. This will allow Apple Intelligence to make decisions about what it considers high-priority notifications from apps which you haven't specifically allowed or disallowed to interrupt you. If it judges a notification to be something which you'd rather be interrupted by, it will alert you to that notification. As Apple gains confidence in its artificial intelligence, we are likely to find more additions to the focus settings as time goes on.
    The final heading in the settings for a specific focus is "turn on automatically". The options in this area let you add triggers which activate the focus, so you don't have to think about doing this manually. Choices for triggers include times of day, the use of certain apps, and arriving at or leaving specific locations. For instance, the bedtime I set in the health settings is the automatic trigger from the Sleep focus mode. This mode is somewhat more stringent in keeping people and notifications from bothering me than others. You can trigger both the activation and deactivation of a focus mode. My sleep mode turns off at five A.M.
    Keep in mind that focus modes aren't meant to truly stop you from doing something you want to do. You're never trapped in a focus mode. You can manually activate or deactivate a focus mode easily whenever you wish. The intent is merely to prevent you from being unwillingly distracted. Focus modes introduce a small amount of friction to give you a moment's pause before you abandon yourself to whatever temptation or distraction beckons.
    Focus modes can have more than one automatic trigger so that they activate without your needing to take that step. You might, for example, create a focus mode for when you're reading which activates when you use any book reading app like Kindle or Voice Dream Reader. You could disallow notifications entirely, thereby preventing you from being interrupted and losing your place in a Kindle book being read by VoiceOver. The focus might, however, let family members or other select people get through to you. If you have a specific time frame during which you are working, these triggers can make certain that the focus activates. You are always informed when a focus turns on or off by an announcement from VoiceOver. This may change, as there has been some debate about whether such announcements are actually desirable or not.
    Each kind of automatic trigger has options specific to the type of trigger you're creating. For time triggers, you are able to use pickers to set start and stop times. There are also buttons for each day of the week, which you can select or deselect to indicate if you want days when the focus doesn't turn on automatically. VoiceOver hints will help beginners greatly in this area if they are enabled.
    Similarly, you can add apps to a focus. When you choose this, you are taken to a dialogue with a list of all of your apps. Double tap on the app that you want to be a trigger for the focus. Only one app can be added at a time. To add another app, go back into the dialogue and select another. Each app will then be a trigger.
    Adding a location makes use of a dialogue which has a search field at the top to put in an address. The current address where your device thinks you are is offered as a default. Once an address is selected, arriving at the address will turn the focus on, while leaving it will turn it off. Keep in mind that due to many circumstances, the accuracy of where your device thinks you are can vary greatly. Being indoors drastically limits GPS signal reception, limiting accuracy. Turning Wi-Fi off can also effect location accuracy. Be mindful of this when creating location-based triggers for a focus mode.
    Using the "add focus" button at the start of "focus" settings lets you create a focus mode from scratch. You'll be asked to give your focus mode a name and taken through the steps discussed above. This process is nicely divided into steps, where you need to use the "next" button to proceed to the following group of choices until you've done everything necessary. One of these choices is the colour or type of icon shown on the status bar when you're in that focus mode.
    Any such triggers you create will be shown in the "turn on automatically" section of the focus settings. To remove a trigger, double tap on it and flick to the right until you come to "delete automation". Double tap this, and it will be removed after asking if you're certain. Removing an entire focus mode is very similar. Go into the focus mode settings, flick right to the end, and you'll find a "delete focus" button which you can double tap.
    Setting up focus modes is much more convenient than needing to adjust notifications for various occasions or times of day every time you need things to behave differently. Simply create a new focus or customize the ones already present as needed. They can trigger automatically or be manually turned on and off. We will now discuss taking manual control of focus modes. This is my preferred method for handling the focus feature almost all of the time. My only current exception is the sleep focus, which is automatically activated at my chosen bedtime and turned off early in the morning.
The Focus Control Centre Button:
To take manual control of focus modes, you can always go into the Focus settings. The first thing in the settings for a particular focus mode is an on/off switch. More advanced users will find this a cumbersome approach, as numerous swipes and taps are needed to get to that one switch to activate or deactivate a focus mode. Furthermore, you're likely to lose your place in whatever app you were in before deciding to change the focus mode of your device.
    If all you want to do is select, activate or deactivate a focus mode, there's a far more efficient alternative. You can access your various focus modes via the "Focus" button in the control centre. In my experience, this makes certain that you don't lose your place in whatever app you're in. The Focus button can be found to the right of the "volume" slider. If you double tap on it, you toggle the focus mode you last used on and off. When it's on, the button in the control centre will read "focus selected do not disturb" or whatever the name of the active focus mode happens to be. If no special focus mode is active, the button simply reads as "focus button".
    To choose a different focus, do a one finger triple tap on the focus button to reach the focus chooser. This is a small menu containing all available focus modes. At the far-right end, you'll find a "new focus" button which takes you to the focus creation procedure also found in the focus settings. This makes manually selecting and turning focus modes on or off a breeze once you get the hang of it. Double tap on the focus you want. It will then be selected and turned on. Double tap on the focus again to deselect and turn it off. The last focus you do this to will be the focus you can more quickly turn on or off by simply double tapping the focus button in the control centre. When finished with the focus chooser, simply hit the home button or do the gesture used to reach the home screen, and you'll be returned to the focus button on the control centre. Use the home button or gesture once more to return to your app or wherever you were before, wanting to change the focus mode.
    While on the focus button in the control centre, you have even more options. If you flick down while on the "focus" button, you'll hear "open controls". Double tap this and flick right to go over a selection of choices which relate to the currently selected focus. For instance, if "do not disturb" is the current ready focus, you'd see options which let you turn it on for lengths of time, or until another condition has been met. For instance, you could turn on "do not disturb" for one hour or until you leave your current location. That's quite a lot of control available from that single unassuming little "Focus" button found in the control centre.
    Here's a good example of the advantage of using the focus button and chooser rather than going into focus settings. At around ten after two on most Thursday afternoons, I get a Skype call from the Kelly and Company show. It's time to do my segment on accessible technology and audio entertainment. I answer the call and the sound technician makes certain everything's sounding good. The show is on a break and time is ticking. Long before this point, I've taken a moment to triple tap the focus button and make certain that do not disturb is the selected focus. After I get the call, things need to go quickly and smoothly. I really don't want to be interrupted while I'm live on national television, even if only in audio. Moreover, it's important that I have time to get ready with my notes and Braille display. I go into the control centre and do a one finger double tap on the focus button. This toggles on the last focus mode I selected, which is do not disturb. My iPhone then says, "selected focus, do not disturb". The focus mode is now active, and I should be safe from needless interruption. Since I haven't entered the focus chooser, it takes only one home gesture to get back to the app I was previously in. That's Skype, which was used to answer the call. I then use the app switching four finger swipe to the right, which takes me to the app I was previously in, which is Ulysses. If all goes well, I'm now in Ulysses with my notes ready to go and safe from interruptions. Setting the focus has taken perhaps five seconds. I'm now free to get into best position in my notes and turn off speech, so it doesn't distract me while I read the notes on my Braille display. My hands won't ever have to leave the Braille display after this point until my segment concludes, and I'm done with my notes.
    At the end of my segment, I turn VoiceOver speech back on. I go back into the control centre and then double tap the focus button to deactivate do not disturb. The focus button now has nothing selected and simply reads as "focus button" when flicked over. I know I'm back in my normal mode of operation with no active focus modes. Typically, you won't have to switch between apps and will just be back in the app you were working in before deciding to turn a focus mode on or off. This took a while to read through, but actually doing this takes less than ten seconds. It starts to feel natural rapidly once you get the hang of it.
    It would certainly be possible to make a trigger which automatically activated do not disturb whenever I went into Skype. However, in my experience, this sort of thing can lead to unintended situations. There are instances when I'm in a meeting on Zoom, but don't want to miss out on my apartment buzzer informing me of the arrival of a delivery person I'm expecting. It's the same with causing my Work focus mode to trigger whenever I'm in the Fantastical or Ulysses apps. There are times when I wish to use these work related apps but don't want to cut myself off from notifications or contact. The same kind of hangups can occur with time or location-based automation triggers. Perhaps, I'm up late one night. If I was expecting a call or participating in online events, I would have to remember to turn off the sleep mode, so incoming notifications weren't blocked automatically. For me, taking manual control has been the best way to roll with the focus feature so far in most instances.
Focus Thoughts and Tips:
The introduction of the Focus feature can do a lot to offset how tempting and distracting our iPhones can be. While they don't utterly lock anything out of reach, they add that bit of friction between us and temptations and distractions not needed at the moment. Often, this small amount of friction is all we need to keep on task and mentally present in the moment. The tradeoff between the easy simplicity of the "do not disturb" switch and the complexity of focus modes is, I think, a good one.
    Take the time to learn your way around before you really have to do this quickly under pressure. Practice going in and out of the control centre and taking that step deeper into the focus chooser. Think of the focus chooser as being a deeper layer of the control centre. It takes two home gestures or home button presses to come back out to the home screens. With the focus button, it really helps to get a sense of where it's located on the control centre screen. That way, you can put your finger right near the spot and flick left or right to quickly get to the button. That's the most likely place where you might get flustered if you're in a time crunch. It's in the middle of the screen. To the left of it are brightness and volume controls, so you have one or two flicks to the right if you hear yourself touch either of those. Immediately to the right is the space where controls for any connected accessories are shown. If you touch in that area, a flick left should get you to the focus button.
    Even for beginners, the time spent mastering the focus settings, control centre button and chooser will be richly rewarded. The one thing to remember to check on is that control centre button. If it just says, "focus button" when you flick to it and nothing else, that means that no focus mode is active. You won't miss out on anything unintentionally as long as this is the case. The focus button will always indicate if a focus mode such as "do not disturb" is selected. Using this button quickly became second nature for me. I only need to go into the focus settings when I actually want to change the characteristics or triggers of a focus mode. However, some beginners may prefer to go into the focus settings, double tap on the focus they want, and double tap on the on/off toggle to be certain they know what state it's in. As usual, Apple has left more than one way to accomplish the same thing. It's a matter of practice and convenience.
    Focus modes never block access to the notification centre. You can visit the notification centre at any time to see what's new. When you consider the new notification immediacy settings and the summaries generated for you at times of your choosing, your fear of missing out on desirable information should be minimal.
    I hope this helps blind people make good use of this compelling new feature in iOS. It has proved to be a real blessing for me as I work on finishing the second edition of this guide. Once this pandemic has been better dealt with, it will be even more helpful when it comes to blocking off distractions while navigating outdoors, among other things. These devices have become the gateway to so many things that being able to control how widely open the gateway is has become a real necessity. With iOS 15, Apple has risen admirably to this challenge in many ways, including this focus feature.

Keep on Track With Lifestyle Apps:
With their extreme portability, iOS devices are uniquely positioned to be of help in many ways. From working out your share of a bill at a restaurant table with the handy calculator app, to keeping track of appointments with the included calendar app, you'll be surprised how much you can do with apps that are automatically included with iOS. These are useful in everyday life and are helpful for students. These apps are simple and offer basic functionality. Beginners can feel comfortable practicing their skills using VoiceOver and exploring the screen. Also, since they don't involve communication with anyone apart from your faithful digital assistant, there's no major worry about doing something which might lead to embarrassment. 
    Should you need more functionality or a different approach to these everyday tasks than the included apps offer, fear not. Chances are that you can get a more suitable app for your needs in the app store. I've found many apps offering alternative approaches that suit me better. The major advantages of the apps discussed here are their less complex nature and that they come pre-installed on your device. Both of these aspects are especially good for beginners.
    For lack of a better category term, I'm calling these "lifestyle" apps, since they are useful in everyday situations. Calling them utilities just doesn't seem quite right. Other apps which might very well fall under this category happen to be better fits for examples of apps in other categories. For instance, the Contacts, Messages, and Health apps have the same kind of "useful anywhere" feel. The apps I present to you below are less easy to fit in other categories and thus needed their own.
    Before we take a closer look at the lifestyle apps, remember that you can use Siri, Apple's built-in personal assistant, to perform many of the tasks these apps can do. In fact, Siri makes use of these apps on your behalf and gives beginners a nice level of control over what happens. If you tell Siri to create a reminder or appointment, it will be done using the Calendar or Reminders app that comes standard in iOS. This is particularly handy for beginners who may initially struggle with navigating and typing on a touchscreen. You'll find a section about Siri earlier in this guide.
    Learning the layouts and options in the apps themselves will lead to more in-depth control and a better overview of things like the monthly calendar.
