You'll be able to take advantage of more advanced aspects of-these apps. A good example is creating a recurring event in the calendar which doesn't use a standard interval of time. It really pays to learn how to use the touchscreen.
    Now, we'll examine the lifestyle apps that are provided by Apple in greater detail. These are all safe for beginners to experiment with. By doing this, you will gain familiarity with VoiceOver gestures and become more proficient with navigating around various screens. Currently, apps in this category include Weather, Calculator, Reminders, Calendar, Clock, Voice Memos and Journal. Information on the Notes app can now be found in the Work and Productivity section of the guide. While it's easy to make use of the Notes app, it has gained a lot of power and complexity over the past few years. The calendar might well have made a similar move, but there is still more of a distinction between its capabilities and those of apps more suitable for more complex business project and event management.
The Weather App:
No information is as useful every day than the weather. Apple has included a Weather app which comes installed as part of iOS. It provides good basic weather information which is likely to meet the needs of average users. You'll find daily and hourly forecasts. Upcoming precipitation is shown. Air quality and ultraviolet strength information will help you determine what protection you might need. You'll also find information about visibility, wind conditions, wind chill factor, sunrise and sunset times, and more.
    This app is fairly easy to navigate. Certainly, people can flick through the information for their location and gain a good idea of what to expect from the weather. Doing things this way, you won't miss out on anything. However, there's a faster way to jump through the different kinds of information offered on the main screen.
    There's a bit of a learning curve to using this app efficiently. Different portions of the weather information available for a location are stacked in a series of containers. Turn the rotor to the "containers" option, and you can quickly flick up or down between them.
    At the very top of the screen, you'll find the current weather conditions for the location you're in or that you have set as the default. All information related to a location is found on one vertically stacked screen.
    Below the current conditions, you'll find a container which will have any warnings if any conditions like wind or precipitation is present or expected soon in the day. The next container holds a more detailed forecast broken down by hour for the rest of the day. Below this, you'll find the next container with a ten-day forecast.
    There are buttons in some containers which let you access more detailed information, maps, or more extensive charts. For instance, each hour forecast in the hourly breakdown is actually a button. Double tapping on that will bring you to a more extensive screen which lets you focus in on the kind of information you want. On that screen, you can pick the day using a calendar slider near the top. You can focus on conditions, precipitation, humidity, air quality, etc using the button labelled "conditions" by default. You can also find buttons letting you choose whether actual temperature is shown or the "feels like" temperature. This detailed screen contains explanations as well as other information like precipitations mounts. Check for additional containers rather than presuming the first bunch of information you encounter is all there is.
    On the main screen, you'll find links and buttons letting you access maps. They can show temperature and precipitation for many locations.
    Flicking through the list of containers, you can find information on sunset and sunrise times, ultraviolet index, what the temperature feels like, rainfall, visibility, humidity, wind, and pressure. As usual, just use the rotor to navigate to different containers and then flick right to go over the information in that container. The air quality compares current conditions to the day before. It has a button called "see more" which gives you more information about the air quality scale and main pollutants. That might be helpful for allergy sufferers or people worried about things like smoke or smog.
    There are some important controls in the app. If you're in container navigation mode, you'll get to them right after the last container. You can also reach these at any time by touching near the bottom middle of the screen. The controls will let you report an issue with the app. Furthermore, you can access a list of locations where you can add more or remove locations from favourites. You can also manage notifications for locations, including your current location and any in your favourites.
    Look at information for different locations by using a three finger swipe to the left or right. This will switch you between any locations you have set up. Presuming you allow location services to track you, it's possible to have the Weather app automatically default to your current location as you move around. There's a slider containing any locations you've chosen to include in your favourites. Once you're on the slider, flick up or down to move between locations. Flicking left or right lets you reach the various controls. To the left of the locations list, you'll find a button letting you manage notifications. These can alert you to snow, rain and other changes in the weather. You can have them on or off for any location in your favourites. Flicking right of the location slider gets you to the location list. This is where you can add or remove locations from your favourites.
    There are some settings. You can pick whether you want Celsius or Fahrenheit. You can also decide which units to use when measuring amounts of precipitation. There aren't any other settings to select different units of measurement for pressure or anything like that.
    When you come to charts, it is possible to have VoiceOver describe them or use sound to give an audio representation. When you move onto a chart, the rotor will turn automatically to the right setting. Flick down, and you'll hear options to describe a chart, summarize it, or give an audio representation. Double tap on what you want and it will happen. After you're done, don't forget to turn the rotor back to the "containers" setting.
    For basic use of the Weather app, that's all you need to know. Taking the time to thoroughly explore and double tap on elements will yield even more rewards.
    Compared to third party weather apps, Apple offers a free alternative which offers enough information for the needs of average users. For weather enthusiasts or people who want more, there's a lot to decide from. You may need to pay a one-time fee or an ongoing subscription. However, presuming that's no object, there is a wide selection of apps which offer all kinds of different options. Some are very accessible to VoiceOver. Two of the most popular are fully accessible. Weather Gods distinguishes itself by providing soundscapes to match the current weather or the future weather you might be viewing in a forecast. Meanwhile, Carrot Weather delivers your information with a user adjustable amount of snark. There are many other options to consider. There's bound to be something which meets your weather needs.
The Calculator:
Everyday life is full of mathematics. From calculating tips in a restaurant to figuring out your budget, numbers pop up everywhere you go. To handle the kind of math problems most of us are likely to encounter, Apple has provided the Calculator app. This app is included in iOS and will likely fill the mathematical needs of most people reasonably well. The calculator works well with VoiceOver.
    In iOS 18, the calculator received a major upgrade. It has three different modes. Unlike earlier, you can use these modes in any orientation. These modes are basic, scientific, and math notes. A comprehensive collection of unit conversions is available in any of these modes. These include conversion between currencies. To access these options, you'll find a "change mode" button at the bottom left of the screen.
    The basic mode has the addition, subtraction, multiplication, division and percent functions.
    The scientific mode reveals a far more robust scientific calculator with many functions. Though somewhat harder to navigate, the reward for mastering it is a pretty good scientific calculator.
    The math notes mode allows you to deal with more complex equations. You can define and use variables, and the results will be kept up to date as you enter information.
    Unit conversions can be turned on or off in the "change mode" menu of choices which pop up when the button is pressed. These increase how cluttered the screen is since there are controls to choose the units to be converted. The basic mode without unit conversions on is the simplest configuration to start with.
Basic Mode:
Functions included in the basic mode are addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and percent.
    You'll find a numeric keypad at the left of the screen, covering most of the surface. Lower digits are at the bottom and higher are at the top. The decimal is right of 0. Equals is right of decimal.
    Above the equals sign, you'll find functions proceeding up the far right of the screen. Edition, subtraction, multiplication, and division at the top. Above the 7, 8, and 9 keys are Change Sign, clear, plus-minus, and percent keys. Above this is where the results are shown. VoiceOver automatically announces results. You can also read them more carefully with the rotor after touching the result space.
    The layout is simple and uncluttered enough to be mastered quickly. Very handy for most day to day stuff. Keys are placed where they would be if you were using a physical calculator of similar size. They are well sized and spaced, making this an excellent way to become proficient at finding the proper keys.
    Suppose you want to know how many minutes there are in a year. You would go into the Calculator app. Next, you would double tap on 3, 6, and 5 for the number of days in a year. You would then touch along the far-right side of the screen. Keeping your finger on the screen, slide it up or down until you find the "multiply" option. It is more towards the top of the screen. Once you find it, lift your finger and double tap the Multiplication button. If you're using touch typing, just lift your finger, and it will be entered. Next, you would enter the 24 hours in each day by double tapping on the 2 and 4 digits. Next, you would touch along the right side and slide your finger to find the "multiply" key again. Lift it or double tap to enter that operation, and then enter 6 and 0 for the number of minutes in each hour. Finally, touch near the bottom-right corner of the screen and slide your finger until you find the Equals button. Lift your finger, and you will hear the result, learning that there are, in fact, 525,600 minutes in a year.
    After some practice, you'll find your speed increasing as you develop a muscle memory for where various calculator functions are. I still tend to slide my finger to the right function, even after all these years. However, the basic layout of the Calculator app is a good place to begin to experience how building a mental map of where things are on the touchscreen increases your speed and efficiency.
The Scientific Calculator:
The scientific calculator has many more functions on the screen. The basic functions are all still there, but are condensed onto a small area on the right side of the screen. To the left of the numbers, you'll find the rest of the screen taken up by all sorts of higher math functions. This includes parentheses, geometric functions, exponents, and lots more.
    This layout will take longer to master, as it crams a lot more onto the screen. I recommend the use of touch typing mode. Set this with the rotor. This way, nothing is entered until you lift your finger from the surface of your device. This gives you a chance to feel around for the right digit or function and makes entry mistakes less likely. The numbers and other basic functions are crammed into a small section on the right side of the screen. There's a line for results which stretches across the top. Beneath it are a lot of functions including parentheses, exponential, trigonometric, and many more.
Math Notes Mode:
This addition to the calculator's arsenal gives it the power to handle advanced equations with variables. This can happen in the Calculator app but can also happen in the Notes and Messages apps.
    Let's use a simple example with three variables. I created a new math note using the new note button. In the text area, I typed three lines. The first line was:
    l=3
    The next was w=1500
    The next line was t=lw
    If I then entered t= on the next line, it would compute the result for me. If I changed what L or W equaled, it would update the result of t.
    The above was just a simple example. You can have many variables in your equations. All of which will be updated as you make any changes.
    If you turn on unit conversions, you'll find two buttons called input unit and result unit near the top right of the screen. The input unit button is above the result unit button. To the left of these, you'll find the input number once you've entered that using the keys. It's easiest to select your units first. There are all kinds of choices when you hit the input or result unit buttons. Everything from weights, distances, information units, and a great many more. Once you've selected your units of conversion, enter the number you want to convert.
    All of the changes I've outlined above have turned a once humble calculator into a real powerhouse of a tool which is likely to meet the needs of most users. I will almost certainly never need any mathematical capability which isn't offered here. For people working in fields involving higher order mathematics, there are plenty of even more powerful calculator apps to be found in the app store. I steer you to some accessible alternatives in the Work and Productivity section later in this guide.
The Clock App:
This app packs multiple handy time tools into a single app. It includes a world clock, an alarm clock, a timer, and a stopwatch. Each of these functions have their own tab. From a blindness perspective, there are a few unfortunately missing abilities. There is no way to tell time through vibration feedback like with the Apple Watch. Also, there is no facility to set chimes. For these abilities, you will need to acquire third-party apps. A more expensive alternative would be to obtain an Apple Watch, which does a great deal more than simply let you tell time in various ways.
The World Clock:
The leftmost tab at the bottom of the screen accesses this clock, which can display the current time in many cities around the world. The Edit button is found at the top left of the screen. Double tapping this brings you to an edit mode that lets you arrange the order cities are displayed in, as well as delete cities you don't want. Double tap and hold on the Reorder button next to a city's name, and slide your finger up or down to move it. Hit the Done button when you're finished.
    The Add button is one flick right of the words "World Clock". It lets you add new cities from a large list. You may not find your particular city, but you'll find one close enough. I have Toronto; Cupertino, California; and London, England on my world clock. Helpful for catching online events like webinars, Internet radio shows, or Apple presentations.
    On the iPad, instead of a simple list of cities, there's a world map. You can feel or flick through the cities, but you'll find more information shown, including sunrise and sunset times. All of this may prove useful, particularly for travellers.
The Alarm Clock
This is an easy alarm clock to operate. You can create multiple alarms for various days and times. For each of them, you can choose which of them are on or off. Simply double tap on the alarm to toggle its state. If you no longer need an alarm, you can delete it by flicking down and then double tapping after you hear VoiceOver say "delete".
    You can add new alarms with the Add button. Simply double tap on the "add" button, and you'll be presented with an alarm creation screen. Flick up or down on the time units to quickly adjust to the time you want the alarm to sound. You can name the alarm if you wish. Also, you can pick the particular sound you want the alarm to make from a selection of options. When you're happy with the choices you've made, use the "save" button near the top left of the screen to save the alarm. It will then appear in the list of alarms available on the alarm clock tab.
    There's an Edit button at the top left. Use that to change the characteristics of alarms by double tapping on an alarm and flicking right through the various options. There are plenty of options including snooze, sound choice, etc., allowing quite a bit of latitude in constructing your alarm. You can select different sounds, any ringtones you have, or songs from your music library.
    There is a special alarm called "sleep wake up". This is a special alarm which ties into your sleep schedule, which you can set in the Health app. This alarm takes advantage of some special alarm sounds and haptic feedback to awaken you in the best possible way. It will activate on your Apple Watch if you have one. When you set the alarm time, you'll be told whether it meets with your sleep schedule requirements. You don't need to use this alarm, but it cannot be totally removed.
    I usually end up being awake before when I need to be. I have alarms set for early morning hours that I can quickly turn on if there's a special reason why I absolutely have to be up by a certain time. The sleep wake-up alarm has been useful every so often.
Stopwatch:
You can perform all stopwatch functions easily. No automatic reading of time is done, but you can easily check it by touching the screen near the middle. There's a heading at the top, so you can set the rotor to headings, flick up to get to the heading, and then flick right to get quickly to the stopwatch time. Double tapping the Lap button will quickly give you the current progress, reading the exact moment the button was pressed. There are also Stop and Reset buttons. You can find the time display and leave VoiceOver focussed on it for a running count.
Timer:
This is your basic timer. There are no announcements as the timer counts down. You can set the duration and choose the sound that plays when the timer expires. Also, you can decide to have it stop playback of whatever music, podcasts, etc., that you're listening to. Handy if apps don't have their own sleep timers.
    Like the stopwatch, you can check timer progress while in this tab of the clock app. Additionally, presuming nothing eclipses it, you can find the timer on the lock screen. Music track information can affect this, as track information seems to get priority.
    I frequently use the timer for tasks such as washing my laundry. Also, it is helpful when cooking meals. There are many uses for a simple timer in ordinary life.
The Voice Memos App:
Designed for quick note-taking and recording, this app has been upgraded in iOS 13. It can now name recordings made automatically based on where you're located when you make them. Also, it can save those recordings in one of two formats. By default, it uses a compressed but still relatively high-quality format. However, if desired, it can use a lossless format that captures the full spectrum of audio. This would be useful for creating recordings of settings where background ambient sound is desirable.
    The app is laid out very simply. There are buttons on the top left to let you go into folders, edit and create them. At the very bottom-right corner of the screen, there's a "Record" button. This lets you create new voice memos. Double tapping this button will start recording right away. A small beep will indicate this. To stop the recording, double tap with two fingers anywhere on the screen and the memo will be automatically saved. It will be given a default name based on where and when you recorded it. When you're on the memo in the list of memos, flick up or down to find other options, such as one letting you delete the memo. Double tap with one finger on a memo to put it in focus. You can then double tap on the title of the memo to change its name. Flicking to the right, you'll find more options, including controls for playing back the voice memo.
    As of iOS 18, it is now possible to have voice memos you record be automatically transcribed into text. These transcripts are available in the Notes app and can be searched using the Voice Memos or Notes apps.
    This is a straightforward app for beginners to learn by exploration and experimentation. There are settings to go with the Voice Memos app, which can be found in the Settings app. These let you choose the audio quality which your memos will be saved in. Lossless quality offers the best clarity and can be useful for recording the whole environment as well as your voice. Everything will be nice and clear. To save space, you can select compressed formats. There are also choices letting you decide how long memos are kept before being automatically deleted. You can also decide whether you want location-based naming or not to have that be done automatically.
    Think of the Voice Memos app as being a good basic digital recorder. For more involved audio recording and editing, there are plenty of choices in the app store. However, this app will be a good start for new users as they can easily record instructions or make their own voice notes while they master the virtual screen, dictating text notes, and typing.
The Calendar App:
The calendar app has a reasonably simple layout, keeping everything on one screen. No tabs are separating different areas like you'll find in other apps. Just keep in mind that this simplicity is partially achieved by hiding things away until they're actively revealed when needed. Starting at the very top left of the touchscreen below the status bar, you'll find the Search and Add buttons. These let you search for and add events to the calendar. At the bottom right are Today, Calendars, and Inbox buttons.
    So far, so good. However, things get a little tricky in the middle. The rest of the screen is taken up with a scrolling calendar. Years are separated by headings. Setting your rotor to the Headings setting will, therefore, let you scroll easily through years. Each month is a button, so flicking left or right goes backward or forward by month. You can scroll indefinitely backwards and forwards to past or future years. Touching a month at the top of the screen and flicking left won't get you to the Search and Add buttons, but will just keep scrolling. The same goes for when you're at the bottom of the screen and flick right. It takes a bit of getting used to. To reliably get to the option buttons, it's best to touch the top left or bottom right corners, landing you on the Search and Inbox buttons, respectively. You then flick right from the Search button or left from the Inbox button to reach the additional buttons.
    When you're at a month you want a closer look at, double tap on it. You will be taken into that month's calendar. In that calendar, each day is a button which can be double tapped. Once you have gone into a particular year, month or day, there will always be a "back" button at the top left of the screen to let you go back to a broader level. The current month and day are always indicated when you go over them in their respective level detail. There are no headings in the month calendar. However, each week has its own row of days. Turn the rotor to Vertical Navigation to move quickly through the weeks of a month by flicking up or down. This keeps you on the same day of the week. Double tap on a day to see events taking place on it. They appear at the bottom right, just before the Today button when the day is highlighted. However, you can get into an even more detailed daily view, where any events in a day are shown along with their times. You can navigate this list by heading or by a special "event" setting that appears on your rotor. Double tapping on an event will show all its details and any notes. For instance. St. George's Day is a holiday celebrated in some parts of Canada on April 23. A note included in the Canadian Holidays calendar indicates that it may not be celebrated in your area. Double tap and hold on an event to change its start and end times.
    You can scroll through different weeks by three-finger swipes left and right.
    The calendar gives good functionality, but takes time and experimentation to really master. I only learned about some included capabilities while preparing this section of the guide and consulting the user guide written by Apple as part of that process. That's something you'll find as you use iOS extensively. Unless you take the time to read the user guide, there's not always a lot to point you towards useful features. It really pays to take the time to do that and also explore within various apps you use.
How to Add Events:
To add an event, double tap the Add button. An entry screen will appear with a number of edit fields and options. You can get around it by flicking left and right. Double tap on an option to bring its controls out of hiding. For instance, in order to change the date, double tap on the "starts" item. This will then reveal the controls to set the time and date of the event's start. Double tap on an edit field like "title" to enter information about the event.
    It is possible to add a lot more than date and time information. You can add the location of an event. This interfaces with your contacts and also with Apple Maps to provide such things as an estimate of travel time. The "notes" field allows you to add information you'll need. You can also use it to paste in a link for an online event. At the time of the event, you will then find a "join" button you can double tap on, which launches you into the meeting. To add a recurring event, you need to double tap on the "repeat" item. This then presents several options. The basic ones like monthly and weekly are self-explanatory. However, if you have to create something more outside the ordinary, such as the second Monday of every month, that's entirely possible. Look in the "custom" choice in the repeat option. This is a perfect example of more complex options only revealing themselves as they're actively sought after. Use the "back" button after you've made choices to return to the main "new event" screen.
    Once you're satisfied with the contents of the new event screen, find the Add button at the top left of the screen, right below the New Event heading. Once you've entered sufficient information, this button will become active and no longer be dimmed as it was when you began creating your event. Once you double tap the Add button, the event will appear in your selected calendar.
    It's quite possible to have numerous calendars on your device at once. For the purposes of this guide, we'll assume that you don't do this and stick to the default calendar. Using other calendars, some options, such as having a second alarm for an event perhaps a day prior, may not be available.
    Nothing is carved in stone. It is quite possible to change an event. Double tap on it while in the "day view" where events are listed. You can also search for it and double tap on it in the search results. You can then edit it easily and remove it.
    To make several choices regarding default and additional calendars, which day marks the start of a week, etc, go into the Settings app. Go into the "apps" area and then into "calendar". While the default choices will be good for many users, work or other factors might require you to use additional accounts and change your default calendar. Perhaps, you need to use the Google or Outlook calendar as your default due to people you need to share your calendar with using Windows, Android, or other devices. When setting your default calendar, remember that the calendar first needs access to any accounts involved. For instance, you should first add your Google account before setting the Google calendar as your default calendar. When flicking through the options in the default calendar area, keep in mind that the overall location of calendars is displayed prior to options in that location. For instance, you'll find the word "iCloud" situated prior to the home, work and potentially other calendars present in your iCloud storage. The same will be true for Outlook, Google Exchange, and other sources of calendars which might be chosen.
The Reminders App:
Apple has drastically upgraded this app in iOS 13. It integrates with Siri and is capable of handling reminders for multistep tasks. This gives you the ability to create and deal with reminders. These can be repeating or once-only reminders. You can contain reminders in different lists, such as a list for work-related reminders and a separate list for home or personal reminders.
    I deeply appreciate the work that Apple has done upgrading this particular app. The old Reminders app couldn't handle project management. You could absolutely do a reminder to tell you to get the milk at the store. In fact, you could literally cause the reminder to trigger when you were at the store. You can do this in the new Reminders app as well. However, you couldn't do anything with more complex tasks. For instance, to complete the guide I'm writing, I need to complete each of its sections. I can create a master list of reminders, called "Complete the written guide". I set the completion date on that for a future date. In that list, I can then add tasks and subtasks. Completing each major guide section is a task. They can have completion dates, priorities, and other options. Meanwhile, completing each section requires several steps that can be added as subtasks. Both tasks and subtasks are themselves reminders and can have all the properties like due dates, locations where they're triggered, priorities, etc. This ability to categorize makes it possible to manage large-scale projects and quickly get a feel for what needs doing. I no longer require a third-party app to manage my larger creative projects. Before this Reminders app came out, I needed to find a third-party app to keep things organized.
Basic Layout:
There are no tabs to worry about in this app. Instead, Apple keeps everything on one main screen. Unless you're creating a reminder or working inside a list, that's where you'll be. At the top of the main screen are an Edit button and search field. After those items, you'll find a container of four buttons leading to the Today, Scheduled, All, and Flagged smart lists. Below this, the next heading down is My Lists. Any custom lists of reminders you've created will be found beneath this heading. Finally, at the bottom, you'll find a button for adding new lists.
Smart Lists:
These special lists are always present and are automatically populated with reminders based on the contents of reminder lists you create. For instance, the Today list will contain any reminders with the current date. The Scheduled list contains any reminders that have dates, allowing you to quickly get a grasp on upcoming reminders. The flagged list contains any reminders that you've flagged. The All list simply contains all the reminders you've created in one long list. The contents of the smart lists will update as you change or add more reminders to different lists. This naturally includes the default reminders list that you will automatically operate in unless you specifically go into another list.
Custom Reminder Lists:
Below the smart lists, you'll find a heading called My Lists. Beneath it, you'll find any lists you have created, plus the default reminders list. At the very bottom, you'll find a button letting you add a new list.
    If no list is specified when a reminder is created, it will be put in the default reminders list. That's what happens when you create a reminder using Siri. You can create different lists, like I have for the guide I'm writing. Before you can create a new reminder in the app, you need to actually be in a list. Once you're in one, the New Reminder button will appear after the last reminder in the list.
    You can do a lot to the reminders while inside a list. When you're on a reminder, you can double tap it to mark it complete. Alternatively, flicking up or down repeatedly will take you through several options. You can edit the name and details, add or remove a flag, drag a reminder elsewhere into another list, delete the reminder, and do other things. Also, if you have a lot of reminders in a list, you can set the rotor to three special settings including "completed", "uncompleted", and "overdue tasks". Flicking up and down will move quickly to the next or previous reminder in that state.
Creating Reminders:
There are a few ways to create reminders. Many third-party apps let you create them. You can ask Siri to create reminders for you. However, for the greatest level of control, it's good to use the Reminders app. Once you hit the New Reminder button, you can give the reminder a title or phrase like "throw out the garbage". Flick right from that edit field, and you'll see a wide range of options. You'll find that things are reasonably uncluttered and kept out of your way unless you actually need them. For instance, you don't always have to give reminders any date or time. They can merely be part of a checklist of things to do. You need to double tap the Remind Me on A Day button to cause the appropriate facilities to reveal themselves. You will then find options for selecting the date. The same goes for time. You can set a particular time in the same kind of way that you select a date. You can choose to flag the reminder, choose a priority, and also add subtasks. Remember that subtasks are, in fact, full reminders that are tied to a reminder. You can edit their details the same as you would any reminder. When you're finished making choices about the details, hit the Done button found near the top left. Remember that you can add locations, notes, a URL, and people to reminders. If you add a person to the reminder, you will be reminded when you are messaging the person. This is useful if you're always forgetting to talk about something with someone.
    You can add images to reminders and also add badges to lists. For instance, I could add a bookmark badge to the list for my guide or a house icon to a list of reminders about chores around home.
Integration with Siri:
Siri can learn from how you use the Reminders app and offer suggestions based on where you are and what you're doing. Siri can suggest making a reminder or suggest actions based on its understanding of the sentences in your reminders. There's a lot of integration possible now with other apps. For instance, a reminder of an upcoming restaurant meal with friends might be able to hook directly into the restaurant's app, allowing you to place an order or reserve a table. A reminder of an upcoming appointment might prompt a suggestion to order an Uber ride or provide other transit information to help you be at the proper location in time for the appointment.
The Journal App:
For centuries, people have been keeping private diaries or journals. Small wonder that a portable, secure device like an iPHONE or iPad would prove a capable aid to this practice. Not only can you write or dictate your thoughts, but it is also possible to add audio recordings, videos, and pictures to journal entries. It's strange that Apple took as long as it did to introduce a dedicated journal app. There are now many well established third-party alternatives in the app store which offer additional features. However, Apple has provided a simple and uncluttered free app which is more than likely to meet the needs of the average user. Below, we'll go over the basics of journaling and examine the Journal app in detail. For alternative apps which may offer different features, look in the App Store Expedition section for information about some popular and accessible alternatives.
    Basically, journaling is about writing down our thoughts privately in a habitual, systematic way. This can help us clarify and keep track of our thoughts and ideas. People also keep journals to document times in our lives. Unlike writing a blog, a journal is written initially, at least for your own private purposes. It's not meant for everyone to see. Certainly, not right away like a blog or article. Nothing at all prevents people from using apps like Bear, Notebooks or the Notes app included by Apple for this purpose. Many people take this very approach. Journaling apps must always be constructed with this basic reality in mind. They need to facilitate more mindful writing and provide tools to make it easier for people to get into the habit of journaling. For example, a commonly offered feature is daily prompts or questions. These might range from "what do you value the most among your possessions?" To "if you had to change your name, what would your new name be?". These are helpful, especially if you can't always think of something to write about. You don't have to start with a blank text field. If you're not used to thinking about life and writing thoughts down, it can be a lot less intimidating if a prompt or question is there for you to answer. Many journaling apps offer templates which you just need to fill out like a form. This can help avoid the terror of the empty text field and provide a routine for people who prefer this.
    The Journal app which Apple has produced and included in the iOs operating system offers a secure place to record your private thoughts, experiences, and reflections. It takes advantage of the secure information storage and machine learning capabilities of your iPhone. As you use your iPhone in everyday life, it learns about you. Typically, it uses this information for offering suggestions via Siri. The Journal app can tap into that collected information about where you've been, what music you've listened to, and who you've conversed with, among many other things your iPhone tracks in the background. It can then make various suggestions about what you might want to write journal entries about. These reminders can be scheduled to arrive at convenient times. There is also a more generic collection of writing prompts which can be shuffled and will presumably be added to over time.
    When you first run the app, you will be given some information on a screen which introduces the app. You can also take the opportunity to set your journal reminder schedule and notification settings. At the far right of such screens, you'll find a "continue" button, allowing you to proceed if you would rather not set other options immediately.
    The main screen of the Journal app is very simple. Near the top left is a "filter" button. Double tapping this will let you choose which entries should be displayed on the screen. By default, all entries will be shown. Each entry has a heading with the date of its creation. The entire entries will be shown in chronological order from the most recent descending into the past. Using the rotor, you can leave a bookmark at a particular entry. This may prove useful, especially as your journal becomes large. Flicking left or right will move to the previous or next entry. Right moves farther into the past.
    At the very bottom-right corner, you'll find a "compose" button. Double tap this to reach the entry composition screen.
    This screen has a number of choices on it. You can flick through and double tap the one you desire. The "new entry" choice will open up a blank text field for you to write in. There are also buttons to select from recent or recommended moments in your life to write about which your iPhone has taken note of. You may have gone somewhere or had a cherished song on repeat. There are also reflections. These are questions to answer by writing a journal entry. Double tap on the one you want to use. You can also flick up or down on these reflections to reach an option to shuffle them making different questions be displayed.
    Once you're in the entry text field, you can simply write down or dictate your thoughts. The rotor will have the usual text selection, misspelled words and edit options to help you perfect your entry. When you're finished, You'll find the "done" button near the top left. There are also "bookmark" and "more" buttons. The bookmark button will leave a bookmark at that entry. The "more" button lets you delete an entry, change the date, and may offer additional options in the future. Flicking past the text field, you'll find a series of buttons to get smart suggestions, add photos, use the camera, add audio, and add the location where you are to the entry.
    With these tools, it is easy to document events in your life and reflect on things. Everything is kept private and as secure as you wish.
    There are some settings for the Journal app found in the Settings app. These allow you to skip over the step where you're presented with suggestions and prompts before beginning to write. You can also choose whether you want to lock your journal so that you'll need to verify your identity with Touch or Face ID before gaining access to the app. You should also look in the Privacy settings area, where you'll find a "journal suggestions" category. There, you can determine which apps or aspects of life can be monitored and used by the Journal app to offer suggestions about what to write.
    While other third party journaling apps offer more features, Apple has given people a good basic set of tools to keep a journal on an iPhone. Occasionally, the iCloud system has suffered outages. However, I have yet to lose any information stored in iCloud. I certainly feel secure about my private thoughts being stored there.
Further Thoughts on Lifestyle Apps:
I hope the above information helps give you a sense of the many ways your iOS device can help you keep on top of everyday life. Thinking back to my days as a student at university and in secondary school, I don't have to dig too deeply to imagine how much better I might have been at managing my time. These days, thanks to my iPhone, I'm easily able to keep track of the various appointments, meetings, and tasks I need to attend to. I receive notifications of things like approaching deadlines automatically. For people needing to travel frequently, you'll find that Siri often takes this into account and provides estimates of travel time from your current location to where you next have to be. As Apple improves its artificial intelligence and that housed within your device, such suggestions will increase in their scope and usefulness. The more you make use of your device, the more it will learn how best to serve you.
    Apple has designed its apps to be useful to nearly everyone. Third-party app developers have built on the basic capabilities to create tools more suitable to specific cases like managing a work schedule or business. The advent of iOS 13 has opened up Siri and made it more able to interface with apps from other developers. The results can seem like magic. These capabilities will grow more powerful and better able to suit your preferences over time.
    You might expect that being reminded of things ahead of time would feel like being nagged about everything. Perhaps, you might worry that calendar and reminder apps powered by artificial intelligence might leave you feeling less in charge of your life and that your device knows more about it than you do. I haven't found this to be the case. Rather, it feels liberating, like having a trusted companion watching over you and saving you from the consequences of forgetfulness.
    If the clock, calculator, and calendar functions aren't quite meeting your needs, Look on AppleVis and the app store. There are plenty of accessible alternatives to be had. Advanced calculator alternatives are covered in the Getting Things Done section of this guide. There are also plenty of other accessible choices for task management, note-taking. 
    And calendar functions.

Reaching Out with Communication Apps:
Your iOS device can make communication with others on your own terms easy to do. This is especially true once you have mastered typing, dictation using Siri, and navigating apps using VoiceOver. No matter which iOS device you get, it can be used to communicate with others. There are a set of apps included in iOS especially for this purpose. In addition to these, there are more apps for various social media platforms, such as Mastodon and Facebook, which are available in the app store. Additionally, there are apps designed for conferences and online gatherings. You will find these third-party apps discussed in later sections of the guide. For now, we'll focus on apps included in iOS, which you'll find already installed on your device once you've completed the setup process. All of these apps tie into contact information and, usually, tie into Siri as well. This makes communicating as effortless as possible, even when you're just getting started. There's still a learning curve. Over time, you'll gain speed and proficiency as you practice and explore the apps we'll discuss here.
    Should you wish to contact friends, family, and others while you're still learning the ropes, Siri can help you accomplish most things. As it is integrated more with Apple Intelligence, things may improve rapidly between when this edition is published and when the next is ready. Just be aware that Siri doesn't actually understand what it's saying or doing. Everything is based on pattern recognition rather than an actual understanding of language. It may misinterpret your words and will definitely misunderstand some of what you say. Make certain the right words are in messages or emails you decide to have Siri send for you. Also, be careful with anything related to images created by artificial intelligence. I've never seen anything in my life. I very rarely make use of emoji. Be as certain as possible that any pictures or images you send to people are what you intend them to be. Apple Intelligence may not understand the effect you're trying to convey. Also, it's quite possible that life as a blind person hasn't given you the context to understand the more subtle aspects of images generated on your behalf by Apple Intelligence.
The Contacts App:
The Contacts app on the home screen is your first stop when it comes to getting your device ready to help you communicate. It has remained largely unchanged so far while iOS and iPadOS have developed. This is where you should put any contact information you have about people who you want to communicate with. iOS can then make use of that information via other apps. The more information you put in this repository, the better your iOS device will serve you as a communications aid. It is quite possible to add contacts to different groups, such as for personal and work. Personally, I just have them all in a single list within the app.
    Unless you change settings, contacts will be kept in alphabetical order. By using the VoiceOver rotor and turning it to headings, you can then flick up and down to the next or previous letters. This makes for a quick and efficient browsing experience. For more control over how contacts are displayed and organized, go into the Settings app and double tap on Contacts. You'll see settings for whether contacts are sorted by last name first or by first name. There are also settings regarding the use of short names or nicknames. For some languages, these settings won't apply, since names are always ordered the same way.
How to Add Contacts:
Beginners may find it a chore to enter contact information. Dictation can certainly help, but often, the virtual keyboard is simply the best way to do things. The rewards of this labour will quickly become apparent. There is an Add button near the top left of the screen. Double tapping this button takes you to a form that you fill in. There are edit fields for all sorts of information. You can also use the Insert buttons next to fields to add more things, like additional phone numbers or email addresses. It's very comprehensive. You can specify different ringtones for contacts if you desire. My parents have a different ringtone assigned, so I always know when it's them calling.
    Some apps such as Facebook will present you with opportunities to integrate your contacts. This adds information from companies like Google and Facebook where you may have contact lists into the library of contacts on your iOS device. This information will then populate your list in the Contacts app. Before this step is ever taken, you will always be asked to be certain you want this to happen. Generally speaking, iOS is cautious when it comes to your privacy. On that note, look in the Privacy settings, and you'll find a Contacts category. This lets you control which apps have access to your contacts. Further along, you'll find similar buttons for Facebook and Twitter. No decision you make is ever written in stone regarding contact integration.
Accessing and Editing Contact Information:
As your contact list grows, you may want to use the search field near the top left of the app to quickly narrow down the selections. Type any part of the contact name into the field, and you'll likely see it pop up. Flick right through the choices to arrive at the contact. Double tapping on a contact opens it, giving access to its information. You can then perform actions such as sending a message, initiating a FaceTime call, sending an email, etc. The Back button gets you out of that contact's information back to the general pool of contacts. Before doing that, though, notice the Edit button near the Back button. This lets you access and edit the information. You can also completely delete the contact.
    Once information is in the Contacts app, iOS will start using it to make the social part of life easier in many ways. If you have an iPhone, the first result of these efforts you're likely to notice is that you'll know who's calling. Phone calls will be identified by name. You will also be able to make use of that information from within apps like the Phone app, Mail, FaceTime, or Messages apps. Furthermore, Siri can use this information. This lets you order Siri to do things, which is a lot easier than swiping and typing, especially as you're mastering the basics of VoiceOver. You can teach Siri about relationships. For example, it knows that Sara is my wife and Dan is my brother. This lets me say things like "tell my wife I'll be late for dinner" and be understood. You can dictate text messages, emails, and Facebook posts without having to go into the respective apps first. A lot of work has gone into making Siri a good communications aid. The Contacts app is how you give your iOS device and Siri what they need to help you keep in contact with people who matter to you.
    Any time you need address information, chances are you'll find an option to get it from your contacts. For instance, I sent my mother a gift from the app store and quickly got her email address thanks to the information about her in the Contacts app. Contact information is also used by the Maps and other GPS apps. This lets you ask for directions to reach addresses stored in the Contacts app. This can include transit, walking, and driving directions via the Maps app, BlindSquare, or other apps that can take advantage of this pool of information.
    While there are options to call or message people inside the Contacts app, it is mainly useful as a repository. You'll mostly use it to search for and add new contacts. Other communication apps will typically let you access contact information directly from inside themselves. Even so, it's a good idea to take the time to explore the Contacts app thoroughly.
The Phone App:
People who have iPhones will be happy to know that the actual Phone app is very comprehensive and easy to use. It was originally one of the centrepieces of the iPhone. These days, it is all but forgotten by many users until they occasionally need to receive or make a phone call. The app is one of many examples of something done right and left largely unchanged throughout the many improvements made to iOS.
    Making, receiving, and managing calls are all easily achieved presuming you have mastered operating the touchscreen with VoiceOver. Siri is fully integrated with this app, so you can call anybody in your contacts by simply asking Siri to call the person's name. Indeed, it is perfectly possible to ask Siri to call a number that you recite. Just don't pause for too long, or it will presume you've finished and won't realize you're having trouble remembering the rest of the number. It is also possible to ask Siri to answer an incoming call or end a call in progress.
    While a call is in progress, it is possible to start and stop recording it. The button to record a cal can be found on the screen which appears during a call. 
    For blind users, I strongly suggest going into the Settings app and into the settings for "Phone". Find the "incoming calls" option and double tap this. Flick right and double tap the option for "full screen" rather than banner. This makes the app far easier to deal with as a blind user. For sighted people, a recent thought was to make phone calls less intrusive by having the control area take up less of the screen in case they were looking at an app or video. Finding the banner is possible, but difficult to do consistently for blind users trying to quickly respond to calls. It is far easier to use the classic full-screen interface and have the options take up the whole screen while we feel around for the one we want.
    There are five tabs across the bottom of this app. They are Favourites, Recent, Contacts, Keypad, and Voicemail. Double tapping on a tab takes you to that particular area, which will occupy the rest of the screen.
Dealing with Calls:
If a call comes in, a screen pops up with numerous options. If you simply want to answer it, just double tap with two fingers anywhere on the screen. This is also how you hang up. If you're wearing wired EarPods or other headsets, there should be a button you can press to answer or end a call. On the EarPods that may have come with your device, it's the long indented section that feels like it's been carved out of the remote in between the two round parts that can raise or lower volume. If you're wearing AirPods, double tap either one to answer or end a call.
    You can also do other things. At the top of the incoming call screen are Message and Remind buttons. These will make a reminder to return the call later or respond to the call with a message you can type in. Declining a call will pass the caller on to your voicemail, where he or she can leave a message. At the bottom left, and right corners are Decline and Accept buttons. You'll also find a button which lets you record a call in progress. A voice announces this out loud on the call, so everyone knows a recording is being made. Double tap the button you want to use. You can press the Sleep/Wake button twice quickly to decline a call. Pressing that button once will allow you to lock your screen, so you don't hit keypad buttons.
Favourites:
Having contacts added to your Favourites has a couple of implications. First of all, you can call them by going into the Favourites tab, flicking through the list of names, and simply double tapping on the one you want. Your iPhone will then make the call for you. Nice and speedy. Also, there are different rules regarding Favourites when it comes to Do not Disturb settings. You can have these set to always allow people on your Favourites list through when they call, even when in Do Not Disturb mode. I'm rather thankful for this as I would typically rather not miss a call from a family member, good friend, or my landlord.
Recents:
Any calls you have missed, made, or received are all shown in this tab. They are organized in chronological order, with the most recent call at the top. Flick right or scroll up with three fingers to quickly move through the list of calls. It is a handy way of easily returning calls, especially if the number hasn't yet been added to your contacts. Simply double tap on the number or name to return the call. Alternatively, flick down repeatedly with one finger, and you'll find options such as one for deleting the call, and a More Info button. Double tap this button to obtain any known information, plus find options to add the number to your contacts, thereby creating a new contact. There are other options similar to what you'll find in the Contacts app.
Contacts:
This tab is basically like the Contacts app. Double tapping on a contact name will move you into that contact's entry, where you'll find the usual options.
Keypad:
This tab gives you access to a virtual phone keypad. As you input a number, you'll even hear touchtone beeps as you would if using an actual telephone. This is good for blind people, as you'll know when you've successfully entered the right digits. If you need to delete a digit, you'll find the button you need near the top right of the screen. Just below the numeric keypad but above the row of tabs, you'll find a Call button in the middle. It's right above the Contacts tab. Double tap that button to make a call.
    During a call, the keypad is displayed so that you can make use of touchtone systems. There are occasions, however, when this is less than desirable, as it's possible to accidentally press keys with your cheek. There is a button that hides the keypad if you wish. You'll find options right below the keypad to end the call, mute, or hide that keypad. Once the keypad is out of the way, you'll find options to switch the call to speaker, among others such as muting the microphone. The options are always in the same position once you've reached the screen you want. This means that you can become used to flicking quickly left and right to go over options and double tapping the one you want. Alternatively, you can take the time to explore the screen and learn where the options are placed. Touch near the option you want and slide your finger until you find it. Then, lift your finger and double tap or keep your finger on the option and tap with another finger anywhere on the screen. The result will be that the option is implemented. Call a friend or family member if you need to look at the screens available during a phone call. Make certain you're speaking with someone who has the time to wait while you feel around the screen and perhaps try various things out. All the better if you know someone with an iPhone who can offer helpful information on where options are on the screen as he or she is seeing it.
Voicemail:
This last tab is a very nice addition, presuming your carrier supports it. Not all phone plans come with what is called "visual voicemail". Presuming you have it, this tab will be where you go to receive your messages, set your greeting, etc. Messages will be downloaded to your phone for you to easily review at your leisure. I've become quite attached to this feature and pay a small fee for a package of additional features that includes "visual voicemail" as part of my phone plan.
    If, for whatever reason, you don't wish to use this or can't get a plan that has it, you can still use the normal voicemail offered by pretty much all phone companies. You simply use the keypad discussed earlier to enter your passcode and operate the menus as you would with an ordinary touchtone phone. This may prove stressful for beginners, as they have yet to gain proficiency with finding and entering digits on their touchscreens. Visual voicemail eliminates this hassle and does away with any time pressure.
    To use visual voicemail, double tap the tab, and you'll find a greeting button near the top of the screen. This lets you record your voicemail greeting that people hear when you miss or decline their call. I don't recall needing to do any other things to set up visual voicemail. I got it some years ago and have kept it ever since. You may have to get help from your carrier. When you receive messages, they are put in a chronological list, with the most recent messages at the top. You can simply flick through them and double tap on a message to start it playing. Double tap on the More Info button next to a message if you want to get to the same contact page as you'd arrive at through the Contacts tab or the More Info button found in the Recents tab.
    You can pause a message during playback, move back or forward through it, and do other things like return the call, delete the message, etc. This makes it easy to manage messages, even if you have yet to deal with the rotor and flicking gestures. It makes for a very efficient, stress-free way of dealing with messages.
    Another sometimes incredibly handy thing about visual voicemail is that it produces a transcript of any messages you receive. These aren't always perfect. However, they can prove helpful at times to quickly see what a message is about.
    There are other options such as call waiting, ending a first call and receiving a call that has come in while you're on a first call, adding people to calls, etc. I suspect that carriers need to support these features. In appropriate circumstances, options will appear on the screen while you are in a call.
    It is also possible to be in a call while still using other apps. Simply press the Home button or make the equivalent home gesture if your device lacks a home button. This allows you to get out of the phone app. Your call will continue even as you do other things. There is a bar near the top left of the screen that you can double tap to return to the call screen if you like.
FaceTime:
Pandemic restrictions around the world kept family and friends physically apart from each other for unnaturally long periods of time. This has kicked efforts to bridge those separations via online social tools into high gear. Many companies were quick off the mark to capitalize on the desperate, sudden social need. Apple arrived late to this particular party. However, it has learned valuable lessons over these turbulent years. These lessons have gone into dramatic developments in their whole ecosystem of services to make sharing experiences possible which go well beyond conversations. The FaceTime app is the centrepiece of these efforts. The ability to have group video and audio conversations has been dramatically improved upon. Through FaceTime, people can now watch movies together in synch with each other, fully able to witness and discuss what they see and hear at the exact same time thanks to Apple keeping things in synchronicity. They can listen to the same album while conversing. If the shared experience is a comedy show, they would all laugh at jokes they heard and saw at the same time as other members of their group, no matter how far apart they might be. Those conversations take place in spatial audio, with people's voices coming from positions analogous to where they show up on everyone's screens. All of this has taken massive amounts of time and effort on Apple's part. However, the payoff will likely be immense given current circumstances. Who hasn't missed the ability to have a movie night with friends and family or talk while hearing the same music? In order to take full advantage, everyone will need to be subscribed to the appropriate Apple services in question. This is easily accomplished, especially for families who share a family subscription to these services.
    FaceTime is used to make audio or video calls to others who use iOS devices or computers supporting FaceTime. Now, this also includes people outside the Apple ecosystem who can join in FAceTime experiences through their web browsers. To use FaceTime, you need an Apple account for yourself. Presuming your device has been set up, you have already created your Apple account. You'll also need to know an email address or phone number of people who you want to contact via FaceTime. This information may be found in the Contacts app or added in directly from within the FaceTime app. Once done, that person will be found in the Contacts app.
How to Make a FaceTime Call:
You can do this in a few ways. From inside the FaceTime app, you can double tap on either the Audio, or Video buttons near the top of the screen. Next, double tap a contact's name. This will make a call to that person. You can also use Siri from anywhere on your iOS device to make a call. Simply invoke Siri and then say "FaceTime" or "FaceTime audio" followed by the person's name. This will initiate a call. Also, you can initiate a FaceTime call from within the Contacts app. Just go into the contact entry you're interested in, and flick right until you reach the FaceTime Call button. Double tap to initiate the call. Groups can be called as well. This can be done by adding and inviting people to a call in progress, or by creating a group. 
    There are options you can use during a FaceTime call. Video calls can make use of the front or rear-facing cameras built into your iOS device. You'll find buttons to choose which camera to use on the call screen. You can also end a call in progress, switch to an incoming or waiting call, or mute your microphone. Double tapping with two fingers will accept or end a call. You don't have to be in the FaceTime app to receive a FaceTime call. A two-finger double tap will accept the call from anywhere. Also, a menu pops up giving you options that you can flick over should you want to decline the call, for example.
    During a call, you can go into the control centre and set your microphone in a few ways. You can set it to wide spectrum to capture all the sound in your environment. For instance, you could be at a presentation or listening to a radio or TV program. You could set the microphone to wide spectrum and everyone in your FaceTime call would hear what you were hearing as well as anything you might say. Alternatively, there's a voice isolation mode, which makes it easier to hear your voice even in noisy environments. The default standard mode is also available for when you don't need either of these two extremes. During a FaceTime call, you'll find the mic mode button near the top right of the control centre once you've invoked it. Note that these mic modes require an iPhone or iPad with an A12 chip or later. This includes the iPhone XR and XS at the very bottom end. For iPads, any iPad created in 2018 or later should have the A12 chip or an even more modern one. These chips have the required artificial intelligence capabilities to perform the machine learning required for these mic modes, letting them respond quickly to environmental audio conditions.
    Near the top of the screen, you'll find an Edit button letting you delete FaceTime contacts. You'll find a Search field letting you look for contacts by name, email, or number. Past this, you'll find a button called "Create link". This lets you create a link which you can then send to people via email, message or social media. These people may use the link to join a FaceTime call with you. It works even when people use Android, Windows, or other devices because it makes use of their web browser to do so. As host of the call, you can reject unwanted participants and will have other options to manage the call.
    The "New FaceTime" button lets you manually add one or more contacts and then initiate a FaceTime call with them. These calls can be audio only or video calls which use the cameras and microphones in the devices used by participants. 
    Also, look in the Settings app, where you'll find specific settings for FaceTime. These let you determine whether people can contact you through FaceTime via your email address or phone number. There are settings to decide whether the tiles containing pictures of the current speaker become more prominent automatically. You can also choose whether to make use of the new Shareplay feature. This allows you to share audio or video being played on your device with fellow call participants. You will also find settings regarding notifications generated by FaceTime. You can decide how they are displayed and whether they are announced by Siri separately from what VoiceOver will announce. To specify whether FaceTime can use cellular data, look in the Cellular setting. Remember that FaceTime must use either Wi-Fi or cellular data. Also, video calls use more data than strictly audio ones.
    I have found FaceTime to be especially useful in a few ways of particular interest to blind people. I've used it to show distant relatives what my apartment was like, using the ability to switch to the rear-facing camera on the back of my iPhone. This has also been a useful way to have a sighted person help read things my OCR apps can't understand. They can help me look for lost items. You could theoretically use FaceTime to have someone sighted help you navigate somewhere, or at least see where you were to find you more easily.
The Messages App:
This is where any text, video, or audio messages are sent, received, and managed. You can send messages to groups or individuals. These are organized as "conversations". Messages are sent through Apple's service if they're to other Apple devices. These can be Mac computers or other iOS devices. You need to be connected to the Internet to use the Messages app. These go through Wi-Fi or cellular Internet connection and don't count against your texting plan. Otherwise, if they're to non-Apple phones, they are regular text messages and will use your texting plan. You can attach media from other apps, record audio or video messages, and decorate your text messages in all sorts of ways.
    True to form, Apple keeps things as free of complexity as possible. There are no tabs in this app. At the top, you'll find Edit, Compose and Search buttons. Between the Edit and Compose buttons is the app title, which is a heading. You can always turn your rotor to headings and get right back to the top easily. Flicking right past the Compose button, you come to a search field. This lets you look for contacts and conversations, which is useful as you get more of these. Past the search field, you start with the main area filled with the names of groups or people and previews of the most current messages of each conversation. It is organized with the most recent conversation first. This continues to expand as you communicate more. Double tap on a conversation to enter it.
How to Send a Message:
There are a few ways to send messages. The easiest is to simply use Siri. Say something like "tell Norman I'll be late for lunch". Siri will compose the message, ask if it understood you correctly, and then offer you a chance to cancel or change the message. Otherwise, you can just say "yes", and it'll send the message. You can also ask Siri to read messages to you. This would be especially useful for beginners still getting used to VoiceOver.
    Double tapping on the Compose button opens a screen letting you make full use of the app's capabilities. You can add one or more names from your contacts. Typing a partial name will cause likely candidates from your contacts to be listed. You can flick right to get to these and double tap the one you want to add. There are plenty of possibilities when it comes to creating your messages. You can type and edit your message in the edit field after double tapping on it. Flicking over the field when it's ready to receive input, you should hear VoiceOver say "is editing". You can type your message or find the Dictate button to the left of the spacebar on the virtual keyboard. Double tap and speak your message, finishing by double tapping again to stop. Messages can have more than one line, so use the Return button if you like. When finished, flick right to get to the Send button and double tap it. Recording an audio message is also simple. Double tap and hold with one finger on the Record Audio button. While doing this, speak your message and release your finger when you're done. You can then play what you've recorded to make certain it's correct before sending the message via the Send button.
Receiving Messages and Viewing Conversations:
When messages arrive, VoiceOver will read them to you, presuming you haven't changed any settings in Notifications to stop this from happening or have a focus turned on which prevents notifications from disturbing you. This makes it possible to carry out conversations without ever typing or swiping. All fine and good for current simple stuff. When you want to look back through a conversation, double tap on it and go into that conversation's screen. You can then flick right through the messages from oldest to most recent. At the end of the messages, you'll find tools to compose your next reply in that conversation. This will always be at the bottom right. You can also see if messages have been delivered and whether any additional content has been added such as "stickers", "files", etc. Near the top left, by the contact name, you'll find a More Info button. This shows you anything you've entered about the contact and gives you a series of options such as making a FaceTime call, sending an email, etc.
Participating in Group Conversations:
Once you've added more than one contact to a message you've composed, you will start a group conversation when you send that message. You can also receive a message that involves you in a group conversation when you reply to it. You can name groups once they're created. To accomplish this, go into the group conversation, and use the More Info button. Flick right from the top left, and you'll find a "name" field. This is where you can enter a group name. The More Info screen also has other options, letting you add new group members or leave a group conversation you no longer wish to participate in.
Concerning Emojis:
VoiceOver will describe any emojis other people use in their messages to you. If you want to use them yourself, while you're in an edit field, find the spacebar at the bottom of the keyboard and flick left past the dictate button. You'll find a Next Keyboard button. One such keyboard is full of these emoji images. Once you've switched to that keyboard, you can find whatever emoji you want and double tap it. Use the Next Keyboard button to cycle through any keyboards you've added and get back to your normal preferred keyboard. Descriptions for emojis are generally well-thought-out and brief, so this is perhaps the easiest way to clarify your meaning through imagery for sighted people. It also doesn't cost anything.
Settings Associated with the Messages App:
Go into the Settings app and double tap on Messages. These settings let you control many aspects of how the Messages app behaves. For instance, you can choose whether subject fields are shown. You can also turn on a setting that sends images in low quality to save data. You'll also find a Blocked button, which lets you manage blocked contacts you want to avoid hearing from. There's another setting letting you select not to be notified when people not on your contacts list send you messages. They are kept in a separate list for you to review at your convenience. There are many more settings. Also, remember that settings in other areas like Privacy can influence how the Messages app functions. It's one of those central apps that ties into a lot in iOS.
More to the Messages App:
Apple has built considerably more capabilities into their Messages app. The Digital Touch aspects will allow people to add drawings, backgrounds, and other things to their messages. That was what I used accidentally to send my good friend an angry fireball. I haven't had any success using this effectively with VoiceOver. The sketching and drawing aspects seem to be the real core of Digital Touch. If you receive messages with drawing or Digital Touch elements, you'll be told the elements are there, but not what they are.
    There are a set of "effects" you can attach to your messages. They can either be contained in bubbles or else occupy the whole screen along with your messages. To use these, write your message first. Next, double tap and hold on the Send button or press firmly on it if you have 3D Touch enabled. This adds a panel to your message screen containing choices. There are a more limited number of choices for bubble effects. These include slam, gentle, loud, and invisible ink. It may be possible to add more choices here. Screen effects include lasers, balloons, confetti, and many more. It will default to one effect, but if you flick right past this, you'll come to a page slider that changes the effect to be sent. After choosing the desired effect, find the Send button and double tap it. If you get a message with an effect, you may hear appropriate sounds as the message is read. The effects have descriptions that VoiceOver will read out in addition to your message.
    One of the easier elements to make use of for blind people are "stickers". Think of these like stamps. Using them is just as simple as sticking a stamp onto paper. Next to the Digital Touch button, you'll find a Messaging Apps button. Double tap on this and more options will appear on the touchscreen. If you're already in a message, you need to flick left to find a Show More button and double tap that. Then you can access the Messaging Apps button. This gives you access to a lot. Once you enter this area, a slider moves you between pages of options. You start on a "recents" page, but if you've never used Messaging Apps and stickers before, nothing will be on it. Go to the next page, and you can look through options. Near the bottom of the screen, there are buttons for browsing apps and stickers. You default to the stickers section, which will contain any stickers you've acquired. Some apps come with stickers. For instance, the Weather Gods app is popular among blind people, and it has a number of well-described weather stickers. There are also stickers you can purchase depicting favourite movie characters, locations, and much more. Flick right through the stickers you have and double tap the one you want to add. It's possible to add more than one sticker, but I don't think you can position them manually.
    Stickers are designed for decoration, whereas emojis are images carefully chosen and constructed to make the emotional context of messages clear. Think of stickers like stamps and emojis like psychological punctuation marks. There are a far more limited number of emoji symbols. They are all included in the Emoji virtual keyboard included as part of iOS. Emojis are free and available for use in any app capable of accepting typing. You won't find a Luke Skywalker emoji, since Star Wars images are trademarked and don't clearly convey emotional meaning to people unfamiliar with that fictional universe. One emoji is a slice of pizza. While this is a food of western civilization, you can easily tell that it's food and conclude that the message sender may be expressing he or she is hungry.
