There are a good number of accessible Chess apps. Many of them have stood the test of time well as iOS has upgraded over the years. Chess-wize, Pulsar Chess, and Shredder Chess are three notable examples in the app store. My geospatial skills aren't well suited at all for the advanced move planning needed to be a good player of the game. I will therefore leave it to wiser heads than mine to point people to "the best" of these apps.
    Shredder Chess:
    Shredder Chess has been in the app store for years and was recently updated in April 2020. It allows for online play against opponents or play against the Shredder Chess engine. It costs 5.49 Canadian in the app store. This app will serve as our example board game. Other Chess apps are operated in similar fashion, but may boast a different set of features.
    Once you launch Shredder Chess, you'll find the top of the screen taken up with the game board. If you're playing white, you'll find the squares from A8 through H8 right below the status bar. The white piece will be at the bottom. Below the board, you'll find information on the status of the game. This will include captured pieces, whose move it is, and other information. You will also find hint, Redo Move, Move, Disc, and Action buttons. At the very bottom, you'll find a series of five tabs. These are Play, which you start in, Puzzle, Rating, Info, and Settings. Other Chess apps will display a similar board and have other features in separate tabs. Having a full board displayed requires apps to have two or more tabs to deal with other features important to players.
    Once I've hit the Actions button and selected New Game, I can make my first move. Setting my rotor to Vertical Navigation, I touch near the bottom of the board on the screen, which is over halfway down. I end up on C1. Wanting to move my pawn at E2, I flick up once to reach row B and then flick right to reach the pawn at E2. I double tap on this pawn and then flick up twice to square E4. Double tapping on this square completes my opening move. The computer then makes its move, and this is announced by VoiceOver. You can then examine the board at your leisure as well as the information beneath it that will also contain the last move made.
    While the engine at the core of this game has been outperformed since its creation, it should be more than sufficient for beginners through to experts. You can set its level of competence along with a great deal else in the Settings tab at the far right. Those wishing to play different variants of Chess, such as Atomic chess or Crazy House, might prefer a more recent app called Pulsar Chess. This seems more geared towards play between human players, but also has a long-established Chess engine for play against your device. Both apps should be very suitable for beginner players to learn the game. Shredder Chess does have somewhat more available in terms of help.
Jiangfen Wu:
If you've ever wanted to play a strategy game with a large map and units to move around, there's a new developer who is going to great lengths to include blind players. I only just became aware of the games released by this developer in March 2022. So far, I've found a game which is a clone of Heroes of Might and Magic, a Civilization clone and one of Sim City. These are games I used to play with the help of sighted friends and family while I was growing up. They had to control everything, describe everything, and give me a chance to think my way through what I couldn't examine for myself. Now, with the efforts of this developer, it is possible to play versions of these games independently using VoiceOver. One can examine the map, select and move units, and choose options. Sound and music are optional. People who attempt these games should be skilled at using VoiceOver and expect some rough spots. Work is ongoing with these games, including improvements to VoiceOver support.
    I learned about this game via Applevis. My impression is that this developer has only very recently attracted the attention of blind people hungry for larger strategy games. Wu could be the next rising star of accessible games if enough people develop the skill with VoiceOver needed to enjoy these masterpieces.
Lost Cities:
This very special card game was designed by Reiner Knizia, a famous board game author. Compared to a two-player game of Solitaire, Lost Cities has a visual theme of going to ancient mythical places. While blind people largely miss out on the eye candy present on the playing cards, the game itself is wonderfully accessible. It includes a human narrated tutorial plus well-written rules to help people get started. There's no time pressure as the game waits patiently for your next move. Wait, long enough, and you can hear the music that people who don't use VoiceOver hear as they play the game. You can play against computer or human opponents.
    There are no tabs to worry about in this app. You start in the main menu of Lost Cities. Flick left and right through the options and double tap on what you want. First time players will want to look at the rules. For this example, we'll play a game against Ms. Lindenbrock. She's an artificial intelligence player, complete with simulated emotions and play style. I've won and more often lost a number of games against her. As a first move, she plays a "coin" in the white lane. There are five lanes in which cards are placed. There are five colours or suits of cards, and the "coin" cards are special, taking the place of number one. Each suit has cards from coin up to ten as the highest card. You need to play the cards in sequence from lowest to highest in their lane. You are allowed to discard a card rather than playing one during your turn. Each lane starts with a value of 0 points, but 20 points are deducted the moment you play a card. You therefore have to play enough cards to make up those 20 points for it to be worthwhile playing a lane. Coins are special. They must be used before any other cards are played in a given lane. Each coin multiplies the total points in a lane, so Ms. Lindenbrock now has a score of minus 40 points.
    I touch near the bottom of the screen below the lanes and discard piles. Flicking right through my current cards, I find that I have a red coin plus the 2 and 5 red cards. Playing the red coin seems like my best first move, since I can then play the 2 and hope for useful cards to be drawn in each of those turns. I double tap on the red coin, which selects it. I am then automatically moved to the Play button. I could still change my mind, opting for another card, but I'm certain of my move, so I double tap the button. I am then moved to the draw stack and can draw a new card. It turns out to be one of the yellow coins, which wasn't what I had hoped for. Ms. Lindenbrock then plays the yellow 4 card. The game continues in this fashion. There are sounds for cards being played and selected. You can feel the board at any time, discovering what cards are in which lanes. Also, thanks to the VoiceOver Hints system, you'll receive all the information you most often need during play simply by flicking through your cards. Lost Cities was developed by TheCodingMonkeys and costs $2.99 in the app store.
BitLife:
Very popular among blind and sighted players, this style of game attempts to simulate the decision-making aspect of life. Starting out as a child, you choose from a growing number of options and areas to focus on as your character ages through childhood into adulthood. Although you play as a single player, you can nevertheless take part in community challenges and ongoing discussions among players.
    There are a growing number of these games in the app store. Although they weren't originally designed to be accessible, developers have been quite responsive to blind players who found the largely text-based games to be somewhat accessible. Popular titles in this space include Life Simulation and a classic from the 1980s called Alter Ego, which is fully accessible to VoiceOver. By far, the most extensive, accessible, and continually popular of these games is called BitLife. It was created by Candywriter LLC and continues to be expanded and updated regularly. Although subsequent apps by this developer are graphical and not accessible, the developer has been very responsive to blind players and has made certain that BitLife remains accessible to VoiceOver users.
    Starting a new game, you can either let factors be random or flick right through various choices. The game uses standard form controls including pickers, buttons, etc. One thing to be aware of is that there are many popup windows. When you double tap on an area such as Activities, a window pops open that overlays other parts of the game. Before you can do something like go to another area of focus or reach the main menu, you need to close any such open windows by making a choice in them or finding the Close button that makes them disappear. This is a good app for learning how to use form controls and deal with something that wasn't originally designed to be accessible to blind players. Note your statistics near the bottom of the screen. These will change according to the choices you make. The thing that sets these games apart from roleplaying games is that there's no grand quest to solve. Games like BitLife are all about living through a simulated life and making of it what you wish to. To be successful in a job interview, you can help your prospects by improving your smarts stat as well as possibly your looks stat. To survive a violent encounter, your health, and strength scores come into play. Just like in life, how you spend your time matters. Relationships matter. The choices you make interacting with simulated people in your virtual life will have consequences over time.
Accessible Roleplaying Games:
There are many of these games available now. Interest in this genre is pretty reliable. Combining story with combat, character building and resource management, these games appeal to the adventurer waiting in all of us. There are a couple of well established long-running series. Namely, the Eldron series and the Adventure To Fate series. Both of these now include numerous titles. Each series has won at least one award for its games. They cast the player in the role of a central character in a branching story. Games from both series have sound and music to pull you into their stories. The differences show themselves in how you navigate their worlds, the mechanics they use for combat and other things, and how important puzzles and thorough exploration are to ultimate victory.
    More developers are wanting to include blind players in increasingly ambitious games designed for people with sight. As a result, those who want to create and control a party of characters in a quest to save the world are now in luck. A new series is emerging called Endor is emergin. Tfhere are now two titles: Depths of Endor, and Endor Awakens. Both are supported by ads but offer in-app purchases to get rid of them and gain other benefits. How entycing these games are to blind payers remains to be seen as they have emerged quite recently in 2025. The developer is eager for feedback to continue to improve accessibility.
    There are also a growing number of standalone games made by other developers. A game called Forgotten tells a sprawling story with relatively simple mechanics. meanwhile, another more recent game called Bardcard uses a Concentration style card matching game to turn its dungeon exploration into a memory exercise. Much easier than a map for some of us blind people to handle.. People wanting more should definitely visit the Applevis website and look in the games section of the iOS app directory. The Hosted Games app, discussed earlier, features a number of titles which are more rpg-like than simple choice-based stories.
A Dark Room:
This is a unique creation. Elements of the experience are timed. It is a text game with statistics, resource management, a map, and other complexities, but the author has made certain that it's all fully accessible through VoiceOver. After being made aware of interest from blind players, he has become a strong advocate for making games accessible where it's possible to do so. He built an alternative ending section of his game, so blind people could complete it.
    In addition to making good use of VoiceOver's Hint system, this game also contains bonus material recorded by the author that only blind players will find. If you enjoy A Dark Room, you may also like the prequel game called The Ensign that has a similar style.
Six Ages: Ride Like the Wind:
The Tandora clan wasn't off to the best of good starts. Having settled in a valley on the right bank of the Eel River, they were slowly building up their lands and defences. An attempt was made to finish building everyone's houses. Sadly, it ended in failure as cooperation broke down among clan families. A subsequent raid by trolls had exacted a stiff price from the clan, despite aid from another in the area in fighting them off. As the second year of settlement began, an effort to clear sufficient pastureland while everyone was still healthy seemed reasonable. To increase cooperation, the appropriate blessing was asked of the earth goddess Nyalda, and a shrine was built in her honour. This seemed to work as the attempt succeeded and the shortage of pastureland was seen to properly with minimal injury. Perhaps, with the shrine providing a permanent boost to cooperation, an attempt to finish building homes would succeed in the following year. Meanwhile, more warriors needed to be recruited, and a watchtower was built to aid in the defence of this still-fragile settlement. In this world thrown into disarray by an ongoing struggle among the gods, could the Tandora clan hope to thrive? Only time would tell.
    This was how a game of Six Ages: Ride Like the Wind began for me. In this game, you must make decisions on behalf of a clan of horse riders who have been forced to flee their city due to climate change caused by a war among the gods. Players must become familiar with the ways and highly developed mythology of Glorantha, the Bronze Age fantasy world in which the game takes place. Chance, learning the mythology, and risk management skills all play a part in this grand combination of a choose-your-own adventure gamebook and strategy simulation.
    Certainty is very fleeting as even poor choices can sometimes succeed, and even the best choices come with a chance of failure. Make choices for the characters who make up your clan and get to know their personalities as they grow older, more skillful, and wiser. The better you know your people and the cultural narratives and forces at work in their lives, the better you will do as a player.
    In addition to lessons in leadership and managing the consequences of one's choices, Six Ages is a stunning example of the kind of accessibility that is possible when developers think about it from day one and use the tools Apple has built into the operating system. The app developer has made extensive use of the VoiceOver Hint system, reducing the need to go looking for information. The exploration and map system has been simplified, so blind people won't struggle with that aspect of the game. All the decisions regarding exploration must still be made. The only change is that a system has been devised, so there's no need for blind people to deal directly with the map during the game. The map was a large hinderance to blind players attempting to play A Sharp's first game, King of Dragon Pass. This game is also accessible and worth checking out. However, Six Ages is a much easier game for beginners to dive into. This holds true for a new sequel game released after the second edition was published. Lights Going Out takes place as conditions are dire an it seems that the end of the world is at hand. You must guide your clan through the end times and perhaps, through some means, survive the coming end. Figuring out what values make sense at such a point in history is no small exercise in clan leadership.
    Besides easing aspects of map exploration, Six Ages features many other improvements, such as a deeper, more complex combat system. Nothing happens until the player makes a decision, so there's never any rush. Another welcome surprise was the inclusion of descriptive text specially written for blind players. This text is found after all the options and other text, but only appears to VoiceOver users. Different scenes and other works of art found in the game are described for blind players. Adding in these descriptions is an ongoing process, and more are found after each update. Six Ages: Ride Like The Wind and Six Ages: Lights Going Out are the first games in a planned six-game set that will allow players to see how their clan fairs over different periods of history in the world of Glorantha.
    The game can teach many lessons about leadership, consequences, risk management, and relationships. It also reinforces all kinds of skills, including swiping, double tapping, careful screen exploration, and other basic skills. It turns these activities into steps in an epic journey so full of other interesting aspects that you won't even realize you're mastering screen reader basics.
Accessible Online Games
There have been browser-based online games as well as multiuser dungeons for decades. Nothing at all stops blind people from playing these using their web browser or specially designed apps like MUDRammer. There are lots of these games around. Playing them is certainly a great way to become practiced at typing, reviewing the screen, and using form controls on websites.
    I'll leave it to you to find these games and learn to play them on your own. However, as starting examples, I would recommend checking out two browser-based games that have stood the test of time. The first is the oldest. It's called Sryth. Think of the gamebook style apps like Choice of Games, which I discussed above. Sryth is a lot like that, only it keeps track of everything. You just have to make decisions for your character. Sryth has continued to expand over the past seventeen years and is now absolutely massive. You play as a single player, but there are community contests and tournaments you can enter. The developer has done a great deal to make certain Sryth remains accessible to blind players, including using alt tags to describe pictures and maps. Find it at:
    www.sryth.com.
    You won't regret signing up for an account and joining the adventurer's guild. While the game can be played free of charge, it is possible to purchase resources to improve your character's fortunes and capabilities.
    Another excellent browser-based game for people more into science fiction than fantasy is called Tau Station. The developers of this adventure in the far-flung future were keen to have their game be accessible to blind users. This is what is known as a massively multiplayer online game, or MMO. Thanks to the accessibility work done on the game, blind players are on an equal footing with sighted players in the gigantic universe of choices and adventures. You can find it at:
    www.taustation.space
Storium:
Game available at:
    www.storium.com
    Free to play with limitations
    Pay what you want monthly or annually for membership
    What would inspire people to voluntarily write over two hundred and thirty million words worth of stories in four years? Storium is the answer. You pay what you want to play this unique game of shared creative writing.
    I was new to Kickstarter in 2014 and hunting for something interesting to try backing. I wanted something which wasn't physical that I might enjoy and which would potentially help other people in some way. I stumbled on Storium during one of my first searches and knew I had found something worth supporting. As things turned out, it was the first Kickstarter I backed which succeeded in reaching its funding goal. It was one thousand and five percent successful.
    Stories, writing, and wordplay have always been fascinating to me. The idea of turning creative writing into a cooperative game seemed like something which ought to exist. I could picture it helping people to truly enjoy reading and writing. Especially teens and young adults. If people can cooperate to tell better stories, they might better be able to extend that enhanced communication skill to other areas of life. It seemed like such a far out idea that I just had to back it and see if it ended up taking off.
    Storium combines creative writing with cards for a very unique experience. Basically, the playing cards aren't like a normal deck. There are different decks of cards which form worlds where stories can take place. Instead of suits and numbers, each card is an element of a character or story which fits the rest of the world deck and serves as an inspiration for creativity. Each character has a nature card which has a description of the character. There are also strength and weakness cards, asset cards, subplot, and goal cards among other kinds. Players write parts of the story on these cards when they are used during scenes in the game. At the end of a scene, players refresh their hand of cards, receiving new ones to replace what they used.
    There are three different roles for participants in Storium. Like other story-driven games, one player is called the narrator. Much like a game master in a roleplaying game, the narrator is in charge of the story. He or she plays different cards. These include place, character, asset, obstacle and other cards which facilitate creating scenes. These scenes are stocked with challenges and possibly rewards for other players. The role of narrator isn't carved in stone. It might rotate between players or be passed to a player by the host.
    Hosts don't get any special cards. They are responsible for inviting people to the game, settling disputes, and potentially passing the role of narrator to another player. They are in charge of keeping things convivial for all involved. Often, the narrator is also the host. Otherwise, the host is one of the character players.
    Other than the narrator, each player will control a character in the story. They will receive cards which help the character overcome challenges and progress through the story. Characters receive a hand of strength, weakness, and other cards which they can play against challenges set by the narrator within the current scene. Once a scene has been completed, players refresh their hands of cards before the next scene begins.
    Several decks are available free for players regardless of whether they have a paid membership. These are created by Storium staff and are designed to support any kind of traditional generic story. For example, there are decks for basic fantasy, science fiction, mystery, romance, etc. A major perk of paid membership is access to more richly detailed worlds. These special worlds were each crafted by professional authors and game designers for maximum storytelling fun. The cards in these worlds have more fancy artwork and feature characters, challenges, places and other things unique to those particular worlds. A lot of the money raised in the Kickstarter campaign went towards the creation of these worlds.
    Here's how a typical scene might play out. Let's say we're in the middle of an adventure story. Investigating a cave, we find an ancient artifact near the back of it. However, there's a chasm in the middle of the floor which needs to be crossed. A loud roar informs the group of players that a wild bear is also present in the cave and unhappy with your group's activities. The back of the cave where the artifact is happens to be very dark. The narrator sets out three challenge cards. The darkness, the bear, and the chasm to be crossed. Players would then decide which of their cards to play against each of the challenges. Each challenge has a number representing the difficulty of overcoming it. Each card played on a challenge reduces this number by one point. Strength cards push the resolution of a challenge towards a strong outcome which is advantageous to the players. Weakness cards push the challenge towards a weak outcome which still resolves the challenge but with outcomes less favourable to the players, possibly introducing new complications. Perhaps, a player decides to play a weakness card of being afraid of the dark. This would send the challenge towards a weak outcome. However, other players can play strength cards to tend towards a strong outcome for a challenge. Subplot cards can also be played which are neutral in terms of strength or weakness but still count as a point against the challenge total of cards needed. You need to play all of your strength and weakness cards before you refresh and get new ones, so finding places to use weakness cards is an important strategy. Players have to choose up to two cards to play in a move and then write what happens as they play their cards to support their narrative. For instance, they might play a "carries a lantern" strength card against the darkness challenge, reducing it by a point. If more strength cards are played against the darkness than weakness cards, a strong outcome is achieved. Perhaps, all the light will reveal more hidden treasure. When all challenges are overcome, the scene comes to an end.
    This game remains very accessible. The developers took the trouble to make their game accessible and encourage people to write descriptions for any art they use in their story cards. The website is easy to use and should work with any browser.
Other Opportunities for Fun:
But wait! There's more! Lots more! So far, I've been telling you about fully programmed games. However, there are opportunities for solitary and social play beyond these that still take advantage of the capabilities of your iOS device. We'll briefly touch on some of these possibilities below.
    Let's start with books. Amazon makes several gamebooks from various authors available as Kindle books. Rather than having people scroll through the book looking for the correct paragraph to turn to when making a choice, Kindle books have active links that take you instantly to the right spot when you activate them using VoiceOver. Just turn your rotor to links and flick up or down to go through and find the correct link. At that point, double tap on it. Usually, these books aren't merely just a set of such choices. There are dice and statistics involved. That's not a problem though. You could easily use apps like the Notes app to keep track of statistics and other important information. As for dice, have no fear. There are a number of simple and accessible dice rolling apps. One popular choice here is an older app called Natural 20. The author took the time to make the app fully accessible with VoiceOver. It is very powerful and easy to customize to whatever your particular gaming needs might be. This includes creating special dice or cards. This app has stood the test of time very well and remains popular among blind and sighted players.
    I doubt that I have discovered every Kindle gamebook out there. However, here are some that I've found. The Critical If series of gamebooks includes Down Among the Dead Men, Heart of Ice, Once Upon a Time in Arabia, Necklace of Skulls, and possibly others. Another popular and fully playable series of gamebooks is called Destiny Quest. These are written by Michael Ward. The series starts with The Legion of Shadows. The story continues in The Heart of Fire, The Eye of Winter's Fury, and Raiders of the Dune Sea.
    Beyond these single-player gamebooks, you can also obtain other books related to games. There are many excellent books related to game design that could help you create your own games. Also, there are core rulebooks, sourcebooks, and campaign or adventure books for various roleplaying game systems. In a roleplaying game or RPG, you and other players basically collaborate to tell a story together. Most of the players play the main characters in the story, making decisions and dealing with the consequences. Usually, one player is the game master and controls the situations and other characters encountered by the players. There are rules governing what happens so that it's an actual game and not just a shared storytelling. Dice and statistics are often used so that neither the game master nor the players are in full control of how events unfold. Many of these are available as Kindle books. However, I have gotten most such books as PDF or ePUB books directly from the publishers of the various games and RPG systems. Also, many of these books are included in bundles sold at places like www.drivethroughrpg.com and www.bundleofholding.com and a personal favourite, www.storybundle.com.
    I would use an app like Voice Dream Reader to read such titles. It makes navigating ebooks simple. However, the Books app which is already present on your iPhone can handle books written in PDF and EPUB formats quite well also. Most of these ebooks are sold without any digital rights management complicating things. I keep copies of any such books I purchase in iCloud as well as in the app I'm reading the books in. They are then always at hand, ready for use.
    A lot of the material for the latest edition of Dungeons & Dragons can be obtained in an app called D&D Beyond. The various books can be purchased from within the app and may also be read quite accessibly in the app. Tables and charts may require sighted assistance for ease of understanding. However, the rules themselves are certainly fully accessible.
    There are other publishers who have gone out of their way to make their RPG system materials accessible to blind users. These include:
    Chaosium Inc.: www.chaosium.com - This long-established company is responsible for the highly regarded Call of Cthulhu and RuneQuest game systems, among other excellent offerings. All the rules and adventures and such are offered electronically, and it's all very accessible for blind readers.
    Monte Cook Games: www.montecookgames.com - This well-established game developer is widely praised for the Cypher system that can be used to tell any kind of story. They also have the more mysterious Sci-Fi-based Numenera system that focusses heavily on exploration and discovery rather than combat. Their family-friendly No Thank You, Evil! The RPG system is suitable for all ages. All of the book and campaign materials are available as very accessible ebooks. Monte is eager to include everyone and has been making his ebook material accessible to screen readers for quite some years now. More recently, Monte Cook Games used Kickstarter to fund the launching of a line of books to aid in improving the RPG experience. These include Your Best Game Ever, Stay Alive, and other titles.
    Some people skilled in the use of spreadsheets have put their capabilities to use in the service of fun. They have created complex character sheets for efficiently keeping track of statistics. Also, I've heard of people using spreadsheets as a way to set up accessible game boards using cells as spots. You need to be willing to do all the moving of pieces and updating of conditions or cards in play manually. However, people have successfully done this while apparently having fun.
    There are many apps built specifically for aiding in the play of tabletop roleplaying games. This includes the Roll20 app and web service. Apparently, much of the app and website are accessible to blind players.
    A couple of well established groups are dedicated to making this kind of gaming as accessible to blind players as possible. One such group is called Knights Of The Braille. Check out their activities at:
    https://knightsofthebraille.com
    While the Knights of the Braille group is focussed on playing rpgs using the web, another group is striving to make the books and equipment for the hobby more accessible. The DotsRPG project has worked with game publishers and others to achieve this objective. Find out more about its activities at:
    https://www.dotsrpg.org
    Keep in mind that there are also physical accessible gaming accessories designed to be used via touch. Decks of standard Braille cards are widely available. There are also actual Braille dice to roll. The six sided variety have been available for decades now. A pair of these more standard dice are what most game books will require that their players have on hand. These don't actually use Braille numbers but feature raised bumps in arrangements which make quickly determining the results of rolls straightforward.
    More recently, Thanks to the Dots RPG Project partnering with Die Hard Dice, there are now very durable, well-made mass-produced polyhedral dice used including those use in more complex 
    A company called 64 OZ Games produces accessibility kits for many modern board and card games. Using 3D-printed pieces, Brailled sleeves, QR codes and other techniques, they provide what is needed for blind people to play on equal terms with others. Your iPhone can help you read any QR codes which typically take you to web addresses with card text, rules, or other information. You could use the Notes app or other apps to help keep score or keep track of other information which might change throughout the game. If interested, go to:
    https://64-ounce-games.myshopify.com
Where Blind People Stand in iOS Gaming:
Things have certainly gotten better for those of us seeking accessible fun to be had on our iPhones since I wrote the first draft of this section. In a little over five years, there have been many exciting new game titles made accessible to blind players. Many different factors have led to this. Changes in app store economic options have given developers more ways to make money for their efforts. Subscriptions and in-app purchases are far more common than they used to be.
    By far, the introduction of a plugin to make it easier for games made using the Unity development platform was the most unexpected and welcome advancement. It will have a tremendously beneficial wide-ranging impact going forward. Now that there's a standard and affordable way to add accessibility, the odds have increase substantially that developers approached to make their games accessible will say yes rather than no. This, when combined with a thankfully spreading awareness of blind iPhone users, should result in many more games becoming accessible even after they're released. This benefit will also hold true outside of games and should increase the number of accessible apps in other categories such as productivity.
    VoiceOver has gained the ability to describe images and read any text which might be present on them. This too will have implications for playful possibilities. While Apple intelligence has yet to reveal its potential in this regard, one could certainly use the visual intelligence feature to quickly obtain descriptions of physical game elements.
    Games have long been a driving force for technological improvements.
    Over the past few decades, games have become an increasingly important part of our culture. People have realized the potential of games to help us connect with and learn from each other. Games aren't just wastes of time because the act of play isn't a waste of time. Play is crucial to a healthy mind. It helps us form deeper connections in the brain and lets us learn deeply. Games can help us to better understand our world, technology, and each other. Whenever I've gotten some new and different accessible technology, one of the first things I do is look for opportunities for play. I might grudgingly spend an hour trying to figure out how to use the screen review capabilities of my screen reader. This sort of effort is necessary at times to grasp the basics. On the other hand, I'll cheerfully spend a whole weekend attempting to win an adventure or master a game I can play with other people. When Monday rolls around, and it's work time, last weekend's fun has given me skills that make the work I need to do much easier. I hope this section of the guide has pointed you to something you can thoroughly enjoy.
    It's critical that we go into this area with realistic and reasonable expectations. None of the developers making accessible games are making large sums of money for their troubles. The pressure to move onto the next game rather than add accessibility or other improvements is always there. Awareness is slowly spreading among sighted developers about blind iPhone users and their hunger for accessible games. There isn't very good advertising which developers are likely to know about necessarily. I've often been asked what magazine, radio show, website, etc to place advertisements which would let blind people know about accessible games. There are a growing list of answers, including and beyond Applevis, but it's hard to achieve the same kind of penetration that can be achieved advertising to sighted gamers where information channels are far more established an better funded. Apple has nominated several accessible games for its yearly Apple Design Award. However, these games must compete with apps that have often achieved great good. Blind Drive was nominated but lost out to Be My Eyes not so very long ago.
    The Applevis site now features a "best game" category and also allows games to be voted for which weren't in the initial list of apps. This is a good step in the right direction and may give more games a chance for an unexpected win. However, there aren't any other awards for accessible games which I'm aware of. Nothing which would recognize achievements such as best accessible sound design, best user interface, etc. There really ought to be something which dives more deeply into categories of accomplishment in accessible game creation. Efforts to spread awareness of the Applevis community among game developers would potentially do a lot of good. So would mechanisms in the app store which advertised accessible apps and games to VoiceOver users.
    Sad as it might be, not all games can be made accessible to blind people. Many games simply require sight to play. Any attempt to make them accessible would so fundamentally alter the game experience as to constitute a completely different game. Ian Hamilton, based in Australia, is a strong advocate for accessible games. He points out that all games involve some sort of challenges, and that this essentially means that standards for accessibility must differ from other industries. Games often simply can't include everybody and remain true to themselves. For instance, some games can induce seizures in epileptic people. Others demand a level of visual perception. Games reliant on audio are splendid for blind people, but exclude those who cannot hear or who have poor hearing. My own hearing loss has rendered games based heavily on echolocation somewhat less attractive to me than they once were.
    Bearing this in mind, we're in a paradoxical position as blind consumers of iOS games. On one hand, we still face the classic situation where around 95% of games are inaccessible to completely blind players. It would be foolish to presume that a game picked at random from the app store was accessible. At least one blind person thought to try Super Mario Run from Nintendo when it was released in late 2016. Quickly, an entry appeared on AppleVis which chronicled the disappointment possible when expectations exceed the reality of where we stand. Thankfully, the game was free to try. It takes a special effort and careful, well-considered use of sound to make arcade-style games accessible. There's a big difference between using sound as ear candy and a minor source of information and using sound as the only source of critical information. Don't expect even large companies like Nintendo to put in that level of extra effort without substantial legal or financial incentives. I believe it would be quite possible to make a similar audio arcade game fully accessible to blind people. However, it would take expertly considered audio design and extensive testing by blind gamers. It's more than simply adding sounds and spoken textual information. The small number of blind people who would be at all interested in a given specific title makes it hard to justify the costs involved.
    The odds are far better with smaller app developers. Especially if accessibility is brought to their attention early while they're working on their app. It is much easier and less costly to plan accessibility from day one than to add it in later. The same goes for instilling the kind of thinking that leads to a real desire to put in the effort to make games as inclusive as possible.
    The iOS platform greatly lowers the resources and effort required to make many kinds of games accessible. At the same time, the economic environment set up by Apple is a favourable one for smaller developers or even single individuals skilled in programming. There has never been a situation where the economics and potential for being included in less complex, time-sensitive games has been better. The audio capabilities of an iPhone would certainly be sufficient for spectacularly fun purely audio games. However, don't imagine that making even a text-based game accessible to VoiceOver is always as simple as flipping a switch.
    There are, sadly, many instances where games that could quite feasibly be made accessible simply aren't. This is due to a lack of awareness on the part of app developers as well as higher up the chain. Platforms like Unity that are used to develop apps don't always make it easy for developers to add accessibility using Apple's built-in tools like VoiceOver. The accessibility plugin developed for Unity has resulted in a small wave of unusually deep and complex games being made accessible after being released. I am personally very hopeful that some examples sighted in this section will prove inspiration to more developers to get on board the accessibility bandwagon.
    We aren't being excluded out of malice. I hope people keep this in mind when contacting developers whose games are inaccessible to blind players. Rather, it is due to a lack of awareness and lack of economic incentive. Blind people make up a small percent of users of iOS devices, despite how widely they have been adopted by the blind community. This results in developers having to make choices favouring ease of construction over others that might allow for better accessibility but be more costly and difficult to work with. Therefore, you run into games that sound from their descriptions like they should be fully playable. They may be described as text-based games not even requiring typing, and yet be utterly useless to blind people. Efforts are underway to change this sort of problem, but change is slow in coming. Economics are a big part of that.
    More developers seem to be getting the message. Especially smaller independent developers. There are now a number of new accessible games which I have felt compelled to add to this guide. Thanks, largely to changes in the app store, I haven't needed to remove any titles from the section. Given the relatively small number of accessible games compared to inaccessible ones, this is a very positive thing. Due to Apple's commitment to accessibility, we've never been in a better position. A lot of potential for different game experiences begs for exploration. Board games that provide audio and tactile feedback are possible. Audio experiences taking advantage of sensors built into iOS devices have been created already. There are many areas of games I believe could be made accessibly on iOS devices that simply haven't been yet. For instance, it should be very possible to make a Mario style platformer game. More complex modern board and card games should also be feasible. It's a matter of skill, resources, economics, and time. Economics are such that independent game developers can create more inclusive games and experiment with new ideas. Awareness of what's happening and polite, timely communication are the keys to greater inclusion. This is an area where being an active, informed consumer can really pay off. If you hear about a game you're interested in, find out as much as you can about it. Have an idea how an inaccessible game might be made accessible when you approach its developer. They often don't know where to begin with accessibility. People are still discovering the possibilities of iOS, and there's a willingness to experiment. It's important that we be aware of what we're asking for, and that economics can be very tight for smaller developers. They may not have the money to spend on the time and effort needed to make games accessible.
    I've long felt that organizations of and for blind people could be a lot more supportive in this space than they have been. Games are not just frivolous wastes of time and money. They're tools that can teach, unify, and reach people far beyond the classroom. They're also the dominant art form, pulling in more revenue than movies and music combined. Innovations like 3D Touch combined with vibration and oral feedback could help make it possible to play board, card, and strategy games. Back in the 1980s, a series of adventure gamebooks called Fighting Fantasy won awards for encouraging children to read. Teens who didn't enjoy reading were drawn into the worlds of these books that were as much games as story. Blind people completely missed out on this and many other phenomena, since it would have been very costly to transcribe these books into Braille. The books would have spanned multiple thick volumes, even if they didn't include tactile pictures. Finding the correct next paragraph to read would have been somewhat more cumbersome than it was for sighted readers who had all the text in a single paperback volume. Technology has now reached the point where much of the cost and bulk could be removed entirely. Text-based games combined with iOS devices and affordable Braille displays like the Orbit Reader 20 could make a tremendous difference for Braille literacy, particularly among blind youth. Paragraphs can be linked. Portability is no longer a factor when thousands of full-length books can be carried easily on even a cheap smartphone. For me, Braille was simply never exciting or fun. In hindsight, the advantages of learning and reading Braille seem obvious. However, unless the story was interesting to me, the motivation to practice just wasn't there. In Braille, I read what I was forced to. On the computer and through tapes and CDs in those days, I listened to what I actually wanted to in far more portable forms. Organizations like CNIB, RNIB, AFB and others could support game development economically. They could provide advertising space in their publications, so blind people know what's out there. They could also put time and resources into making game developers aware of the potential of the blind audience and of the tools and techniques required to make games accessible when possible.
    Before obtaining a game from the app store, do a bit of research to avoid disappointment. Check on the AppleVis site to make certain games that interest you are, in fact, accessible and suitable for your level of skill. Go to www.AppleVis.com. The app directories are full of descriptions and reviews of games that have turned out to be either inaccessible or accessible. The deck is stacked in favour of accessible games. People tend to want to share positive experiences, leading others to them. However, there are thankfully some people brave enough to try apps and report back to the community when they face the disappointment of discovering that an app is inaccessible. Don't presume that just because a game has an entry on AppleVis that it is accessible. Take the time to actually read the entry. Do the homework, and you won't spend money on apps you can't use.

Physical and Mental Health:
Having a portable, powerful computer like an iPHONE which is carried everywhere by its owner presents some wonderful opportunities when it comes to tracking and caring for mental and physical health. Furthermore, there are opportunities for research based on informed consent. All manner of people, from health professionals to concerned individuals have come forward with a flurry of apps to take advantage of this data gold mine and of ways to help all of us live better, healthier lives.
    One innovative example is an app called ZRX. It combines a workout training app with audio drama and game elements in an attempt to motivate people to exercise. Using motion sensors in your iPhone or Apple Watch, this app tracks your runs on a treadmill, on the spot, or through the real world via GPS tracking.
    Still very popular in 2024, the app originally known as Zombies Run has rebranded and is called ZRX. While the original content and story of defending Able Township from a zombie filled land is still present and substantially expanded, many additional audio adventures have been added. These include adventures based on heroes in the Marvel universe.
    In this section, we will explore the many ways your iOS device can help you understand where you are in terms of mental and physical health. We'll also look at apps and other resources designed to help you take the steps necessary to improve and protect it. This is a relatively new territory for me. I live a largely sedentary life and have only sporadically taken much interest in fitness and overall physical health. My interest in mental health is more robust. Even so, the apps dealing with mental wellness are ones which I only began to seriously explore due to the isolation the Covid-19 pandemic forced upon all of us. I hope that the discoveries of accessible apps and options which I discuss below will be of some help.
    In a nutshell, the HealthKit is Apple's attempt to serve customers interested in improving their health. It is a repository for all kinds of data that comes mainly from third-party apps and wearable devices like Apple Watch or other third-party fitness trackers. There are also many apps that let you track the calories you burn while exercising. There are apps that take your health data into account and help you keep track of the water you drink during the day. Examples include the ZRX app I mentioned earlier. Those who love snark will perhaps find the CARROT Fit app to be a pleasantly sadistic workout coach. These apps can track data and interface with the Health app on your iOS device. Diet apps such as MyFitnessPal can help you keep track of and determine how many calories you're consuming. Other apps help you keep hydrated, taking account of the water you drink.
    All of this adds to the data stored in the Health app. This is your main interface with the HealthKit component of iOS. This data can, in turn, be used to motivate and advise you in matters of exercise and health. It is also used to store medical data. Apps developed by health researchers allow that data to be collected anonymously and used for large-scale studies. This is proving tremendously helpful to health science as it tries to tackle everything from heart health to cancer.
    If you have an iPhone or iPad, it will have an accelerometer allowing it to sense motion. This allows for counting steps taken as you walk or run. However, to really get the most out of HealthKit's abilities requires an Apple Watch or other somewhat cheaper fitness tracker accessory. There are some kinds of exercise equipment that can interface with your iOS device, allowing you to control them in an accessible manner. Data generated by these machines is integrated into HealthKit.
    When it comes to health and personal medical data, things can get complicated. Just because something is possible, that doesn't always mean that you'll be able to take advantage of it. Medical regulations in various countries can result in features being blocked and unavailable unless they are approved. A recent example of this is the hearing aid capability added to second generation AirPods Pro earbuds. Apple gave them the ability to function like over the counter hearing aids. This was approved rapidly in the US. However, Canada lacks a category for devices which aren't prescription hearing aids. Apple is likely to find a way to gain approval for this in Canada, but as of this writing, this hasn't happened yet. I totally understand that the goal of this legal blockage is to try and make certain that people who think they need help with hearing loss actually see an audiologist and don't skip that opportunity to get professional help. Properly adjusted proscription hearing aids would absolutely be a better solution in most cases. Despite this, Ifind the continued blocking of this feature from being activated for people in Canada deeply frustrating for me. It would have been very helpful to have them as a backup for when my actual hearing aids break down. They're rather expensive for anybody who wasn't quite wealthy to keep an extra set handy for such occasions. I would have been very thankful for this feature during the pandemic when I had to go months with one working hearing aid.
    Another example is the ability for the Apple Watch to perform ECG tests, which appeared in series 5 watches. Initially, this ability to perform an ECG was present in the watch hardware and software, but blocked for users in Canada. It only later became useable once medical approval had been obtained. Similarly, the ability to participate in medical research programs that collect data via HealthKit will also be specific to various countries. Before investing in health related hardware, it is wise to check that the features you are interested in will be available in your country.
The Health App:
This is your interface to all the information stored and collected in HealthKit. You are also able to input data into the Health app. At the top left of the screen, you'll find a Profile button. This lets you input medical information and also lets you access settings to control which apps have access to this data. You can also inform HealthKit that you use a wheelchair, which changes how motion is counted during workouts.
    The Health app is the main place where you can interact with all data related to your health. It has three tabs on the bottom. The first tab is called Summary. It is meant to be a kind of dashboard where you can keep track of the health data that is most important to you. At the top of the tab, you'll find an Edit button. Double tapping this will take you to an area where you can turn on or off different aspects of health data, thereby adding or removing them from the contents of the summary. You can read any data in the summary and double tap on any Show All buttons to expand what is there.
    At the bottom of the Summary tab, you'll find a heading called Get More From Health. Underneath this heading, you'll find articles and apps related to health that may be of interest. I read one having to do with hearing loss, as I actually have moderate hearing loss and use hearing aids. Keep in mind that the recommended apps and articles may be older and out of date.
    The "Sharing" tab is where any matters concerning the sharing of your health data are managed. Apps will record or check data in order to help you directly or to aid in research you've agreed to participate in. For instance, many apps such as Headspace can check or add to your mindful minutes statistic. Mindful minutes are those spent meditating or engaged in other activities which encourage mindfulness and good mental health. The meditations or activities I do in Headspace take time which is recorded in my health data as mindful minutes. Apps will need to have your permission to read or record mindful minutes as you use them.
    In addition to apps needing your permission to adjust information stored in Healthkit, they will also need your permission to share that data. You will be able to control which apps or individuals you share your health data with. You might, for example, share your workout data with a family member or close friend. Perhaps, you might share your heart rate with someone who was monitoring you during an experiment or while you attempted an arduous task.
    The Browse tab contains all the health data organized into health categories. There's a search field at the top, so you can find what you need without having to drill down. Otherwise, each category of information has a button. Double tap it to go into that category. Any information will be available. Furthermore, you'll find a button to add data. Most often, data will be added via apps or equipment like an Apple Watch. However, you'll find options inside categories letting you log data directly, find out more about the area of interest, pin or unpin the category from the summary tab, and other options like scheduling reminders to take action.
    When you first run the Health app, you will be asked to enter information to complete a health profile. You will also be given an opportunity to create a medical ID that can contain information important for first responders or other health professionals who might need to treat you. This information is made available to first responders in a manner accessible from the Emergency SOS Dialer without needing to know your passcode. If you choose not to set this up right away, you can always do so from the Settings app in the Health section. There, you will also find settings that let you manage which apps and devices can access your health data.
    Apple takes your privacy very seriously, and you can always change your mind about letting an app or exercise equipment access your health data. Should you wish to share the information with medical professionals like your doctor, it is possible to export the information.
Bedtime:
In the summary, you can have a section called "Sleep". This lets you schedule a reminder to go to bed plus a wakeup time. You can select from a number of attractive wakeup sounds as a gentler approach to wakefulness than the alarm clock. Moreover, you can set things, so you're not woken up on weekends. It's pretty flexible. It analyzes your usage of your device to help determine when you're actually sleeping or when you might perhaps have gotten up early. Data is recorded and placed in the Health app, where it may be used with other information or third-party apps. There are numerous apps designed to track and analyze your sleep to improve your health.
    While in sleep mode, you can decide whether to have your Apple Watch or iPHONE show the time and date. Other than that, the sleep mode will automatically do things like turn on "do not disturb" so you won't be roused by notifications or calls. The iPHONE or iPAD alone can only track basic stuff, like when you're clearly awake and using it. For more detailed sleep tracking, the sensors on the Apple Watch or other compatible sleep tracking aids can yield more detailed results. For instance, I can receive information on how long I've spent in different states of sleep.
Thoughts on the Apple Watch:
My wife Sara and I have each invested in an Apple Watch. Having taken the plunge far earlier than your somewhat sedentary author, she has gotten plenty of use out of hers over the years that it has lasted.
    Wearable devices like an Apple Watch contain more capabilities, such as the ability to measure your heart rate via optical or electrical sensors against your wrist. These additional sensors can let the Health app know about more precise information. More capabilities are constantly emerging. A recent addition lets your watch measure the audio levels in your environment and warn you if there's a dangerous level of noise. More advanced Apple Watches can also measure your blood oxygen level. This can be useful for fitness tracking and also for sleep tracking. You can receive notifications if sensors detect problems like low blood oxygen level or irregular heart rhythm.
    Your watch can also display information such as upcoming events, news, etc. Many iPhone apps can partner with apps on your watch, which can come in handy. Perhaps, you want to know the weather but don't want to lose your place in an app you're using. The watch can make that sort of thing possible.
State of Mind and Mood Tracking:
The Health app now also contains a mental wellbeing category. You can choose whether it is displayed in the "Summary" tab. In that area of the Health app, you will find options letting you take mental health questionnaires. These will measure your risk for anxiety and depression. You will also find a mood logging facility letting you indicate your current mood. It will also let you record the causes of the mood you're in. For example, friends, family, work, etc. Over time, this can help you figure out what to focus on in order to feel better. You can have your iPhone remind you to do these mood logs during the day if this would be helpful.
    In the mental wellbeing section of the Health app, you will also find an option to take a general anxiety and depression questionnaire. The results of this will help you understand your risk of encountering these difficulties. This doesn't replace what professionals in the area of mental health can do. Rather, it may help to alert you if you are possibly in need of such professional help. You may also be able to take other steps to improve your mental health short of such professional help.
    These tools plus the mindful minutes statistic form the core of the resources Apple makes available to stay apprized of your mental state. For ways to better take care of your mental health, their apps should be investigated. This includes the Fitness app, which has a suite of mental health resources.
The Fitness App:
Apple has introduced a Fitness app and Fitness Plus service to its offerings. Professional coaches and famous people give workouts for the body and meditations for the mind. New workouts and material is added constantly. For blind people, the workouts are largely difficult to use. This was a big disappointment to many blind people. Apple hasn't provided any written descriptions of moves for workouts, which can be heard or read ahead of doing them. However, they're interested in improving the usefulness of the Fitness Plus service to blind users. Very recently, in early 2022, Apple took the first big step forward. There are now some audio hints offered for VoiceOver users which attempt to describe what trainers don't. These are short bits of explanation read in between or during what trainers are saying. Hints are read out loud by VoiceOver. The only way to get an idea of how moves go would be to listen to a workout with the audio hints before actually doing it. There's no way to look over complete descriptions of posture and movements outside of a workout at a slow step by step pace. Coaches go at a fast pace which presumes that people can see the movements and don't need them described extensively.
    Now that workouts can be shared via the SharePlay feature, it would be possible for a sighted person to go through the various moves along with a blind person. The sighted person could give the description required for the blind person to know he or she understands a given move and is doing it right. Apple seems willing to add accessibility. I'm hopeful that the audio hints are a step on the journey. If this was the big idea that Apple hoped would placate the blind community, letting them count Fitness Plus as accessible, it falls short.
    There are some parts of the app which lend themselves to easier use by blind enthusiasts. Guided meditations and podcasts meant to be enjoyed during a walk are two elements which are easy for blind people to make use of. The walking podcasts are done by famous people who offer interesting talks while one goes for a walk. Meditations typically give good instructions and are easy to follow.
    The app has a pretty simple layout with three tabs. The "Summary" tab gives you a basic look at how you're doing in terms of activity. It can be edited to include more information and categories of particular importance to you. Think of it as your dashboard. It will always contain a button which will let you examine your activity rings. If you have an iPhone, it can track your steps presuming you're carrying it when you make them. If you're wearing an Apple Watch, more information will be tracked including movement, breathing, standing. You'll also find buttons letting you examine any workout trends, awards you've earned or might work towards, and trainer tips.
    The central tab is "Fitness Plus" which is where you can access all the workouts and offerings of the services presuming you've subscribed to it.
    Finally, the "Sharing" tab at the right lets you participate with friends and others in shared activities. These may be competitions happening when people have time individually. Alternatively, they may be at agreed upon times when people can participate in a workout together. This may prove a useful way of having workouts described by a patient family member or friend with time to pause, go back, and explain movements. The blind person might take notes or record this as it happens so that he or she can practice the movements at their own leisure and then be able to participate in the workouts at full speed.
    Apple seems open to doing more to make this service more accessible to the blind if they can figure out a way to do this which fits their style of inclusivity. Hopefully, this will eventually result in a service blind people can really enjoy fully and independently with minimal effort apart from that demanded by workouts. Meanwhile, I would suggest making use of other apps and resources described below:
Some Accessible Tools for Physical Health:
There are thousands of apps that take advantage of your iOS device's data storage and computational capabilities to attempt to help you keep fit and healthy. Unfortunately, most of these are not designed with the accessibility needs of blind and other disabled users in mind. This is one area where you should do as much as possible to check if an app is accessible with VoiceOver before you make a purchase or subscribe. Look on the Applevis site or your preferred blindness related sites to find out if anyone has successfully used the app you're interested in. With third-party apps, even when they're made by the same people, you take a chance that you'll end up with something completely inaccessible for VoiceOver users. This is even the case with the other apps made by developers of the superbly accessible ZRX! On the other hand, CARROT Fit and CARROT Hunger are both perfectly accessible.
The Carrot Apps:
There are several apps made under the Carrot monicker. Carrot Fit and Carrot Hunger are the two most useful for health and wellness. Carrot Fit gives you short workouts comprised of different moves. It does so in a fun way, playing the role of an evil artificial intelligence full of nerdy references and snark. Instructions are spoken out as the workout progresses. The app integrates with Healthkit and you can keep track of calories burned. You are also rewarded in various ways for doing your workouts each day.
    Carrot Hunger is a calorie tracker. Whenever you eat something, you are encouraged to add it to your daily intake in the app. With snark, encouragement and some discipline on your part, this app can be a helpful addition to your toolbox.
ReVision Fitness Production:
This app is designed to be accessible for blind and sighted people interested in getting fit. Workouts are designed to be easy to follow for blind people. Pre-workout cessions containing descriptions of all movements made during the actual workout are provided so that it's easier to familiarize yourself as a blind person with new exercises. There's also a "classroom" tab where you can go through materials about various exercises.
    This app has five tabs across the bottom. The Dashboard, at the far left, is where you can read news about new additions to the app. You can also comment or like particular items of interest. This is still a relatively new app and I expect more will be added here.
    The next tab to the right is called Classroom. It is where you can find several lessons about foundational movements, postures, and exercises. The lessons found here will help you master the various workout exercises more quickly and safely. New lessons are added frequently. You can either read the lessons in text or hear them read out loud by a human instructor.
    Next over is the "Fitness Studio" tab. It's in the centre of the bottom of the screen. This is where you'll come to find all the workouts on offer. You can search, favourite and activate the various workouts. You'll be coached through them by a human trainer. Controls are present to play, pause and go back or forward within a workout.
    The "Fitness Plan" tab is next. It contains various plans to help you do things like lose weight, gain muscle, etc. The plans are designed to be done over a period of days or weeks. Currently, no notifications or reminders are given. It's totally up to the user to follow these plans and do the workouts as the plan suggests.
    The More tab on the far right has options to sign in or out, manage your subscription, read the legal waver you agree to by using the app, and learn about the app. You'll also find contact options to get in touch and offer feedback. The app requites you to subscribe one a fourteen-day trial is complete. As of April 2022, the costs are around $5. US for a monthly subscription or $59 for a yearly plan.
    This app will be very useful to people who want full descriptions of exercise moves. The developer has put hours into making the app as easy to use for VoiceOver users as possible, and to giving good descriptions for the various moves. Hopefully, enough people will subscribe to make this approach economically sustainable. People should be aware that this app doesn't integrate with the Apple healthkit in any way. It just offers workouts and instructions in an accessible form. People can get wearable fitness trackers, such as an Apple Watch, to fill in this gap nicely. The Apple Watch is very accessible and can track things like motion, heart rate, etc.
Eyes Free Fitness:
Beyond apps, you can find plenty of workout videos on the web. One especially useful collection of audio workouts can be found in a channel called Eyes-free Fitness. These are available as YouTube videos that you can play on YouTube. You may also still be able to find some or all of the workouts as MP3 files which you could load into an app such as Voice Dream Reader and play the workout following the instructions. There are methods to convert the sound of YouTube videos into MP3 files. This goes beyond the scope of the guide, so you'll need to track down a suitable method to do this yourself. Even the first level cardio workout can tucker me out. I dread trying the Bootcamp workout. Full audio and text descriptions of the exercises were also included. Unfortunately, the business that produced these workouts was ultimately unsustainable. The workouts were, therefore, made free for anybody to download. At the time of this edition's publication in 2022, the website which hosted these materials has sadly expired. The YouTube channel above is the only remaining source for the workouts which I'm aware of.
Aaptiv:
This is an app and service which produces audio workouts you can use on your iOS device. You can pay for a subscription, giving you access to all the workouts. For Audible members, some material from Aaptiv has also been made available on that service. This would be a good way to see if their style of encouragement would be suitable for you.
Mental Health Apps:
At present, the Healthkit in iOS can keep statistics of your state of mind, mood, mindful minutes, and sleep quality. Your time spent sleeping is tracked as much as possible. This is either done based on your bedtime schedule and whether you're using your iOS device or not. Alternatively, there are accessories like an Apple Watch, which provides Healthkit more information to go on when determining the timing and quality of your sleep. The latest high-end Apple Watch has sensors to monitor your heart rate and blood oxygen level. These will change as you sleep.
    The other measurement is called "mindful minutes". Many apps have been developed which help people take the time to care for their own mental health. Such apps track how long people spend engaged in the meditation and other practices they offer, and use this facility in Healthkit as a common metric.
    Beyond this, there are a wide and fast-growing range of apps which take advantage of the artificial intelligence, connectedness, and portability of your iOs device to help you take care of your own mental health. Some apps help you meditate and offer other mental coaching to instil positive, calm thinking. Others offer soundscapes, videos, and other facilities to help in various ways. There are a growing number of journaling apps designed to help you derive maximum benefit from writing down your thoughts about aspects of your life. Many of these apps are paired with communities of people who use them which form on social media platforms and are typically managed by company staff to keep them as safe for their customers as possible.
    Aside from all this, there are all kinds of other resources which apps on your iPHONE can allow you to make use of. One recent example is an increasing number of mental health offerings on Netflix. Subscribers to that service can watch the Headspace Guide to Meditation and the Headspace Guide to Sleep. There are also many other documentaries about the brain and mental health. Most streaming services, including Apple TV and Amazon Prime Video, will have documentaries and other shows geared towards mental health. YouTube is an endless fountain of videos on this. Audible has a massive, an ever-increasing selection of free offerings about mental and physical health and wellbeing. And then, there are all the books on mental health to be found in Kindle, Apple Books, digital libraries like CELA, etc. Many podcasts deal with mental health as well.
    When it comes to mental health, it's very much up to you to take it seriously and put effort into using the advice, resources, or techniques available. It is perfectly possible to be in a heated argument while your iPHONE app thinks you're meditating and credits you with mindful minutes. Some apps may use sensors in the iPhone or in accessories like an Apple Watch to try to tell empirically to some degree whether you're focused. However, when it comes to mental health, it's really all on the honour system far more than physically measurable workouts and such. You'll get better results if you're self-motivated and accountable enough to follow advice provided by apps or other mental health media.
Overall mental Wellness Apps:
Combining expertly crafted meditation and mental wellness tools with the portable convenience of an iPHONE or iPAD has proved to be a very popular and successful line of thought. Much as a gymnasium offers exercise equipment for the body, the basic idea is to offer something similar for the mind. Resources and coaching to help people develop good mental habits which lead to increased resilience and overall happiness are offered through these apps to millions of users. Meditation is a big part of this, but there's more to it. There's also guided self reflection, habits of positive thinking, compassion for yourself and others, mental awareness, and relaxation. Typically, there are communities or forums for constructive discussion, which the people behind these apps will host. The apps also help with tracking your mental health through journaling and keeping statistics. Apple's health kit takes and shares data with these apps to help build a better picture of your overall health. You can then look over your mental wellness and get a sense of how you're doing over time. You pay for ongoing access to the courses, coaching services and other resources these apps provide, just like you'd pay a membership fee for a gym.
    For the vast majority of people, one of these overall mental wellness apps I discuss here in this subsection should be sufficient to meet your needs. All of them allow you to try out what they offer before committing to pay for a subscription. Back in January 2021, I paid for an annual subscription to two very differently focussed, notable apps in this category. Namely, Headspace and Shine. I continued to use and explore both apps and note any updates and new offerings they introduced over that time. Headspace is one of the more traditional, well established heavyweights in this space. They're based in the US and UK. They were founded by an English meditation enthusiast who became an ordained Buddhist monk who met a stressed advertising executive. Furthermore, they want to bring the benefits of mindfulness and meditation to as many people as possible. They're very aware of their blind audience and have put sustained effort into making their app accessible. Meanwhile, the now unavailable Shine app gained attention from Apple, being placed in the best apps of 2020. They were founded by American women of Black and Asian heritage who feel that the mental wellness industry is pricy, privileged and essentially ignores their past traumas and experiences. They met as co-workers and formed the Shine community to support everyone who felt similarly passed over by the more established mental wellness community. Its staff is 80% BIPOC. I was curious to see if they actually brought a substantially different vibe or tools and ideas to the offerings. Paying for annual subscriptions has given me unhurried access to each app's full kit of resources. I've taken time to dip into each of their libraries of music, videos, meditations on different topics, etc. Moreover, I've tried to get into the daily habits and routines which each app encourages its users to do. This deep exploration of Headspace and Shine is further supplemented by less costly and thorough trials of some other notable apps in this category, such as Calm and Ten Percent Happier.
    The company behind the Headspace app acquired the staf and assets of Shine some time after my subscription to that app expired. People can find the Shine collection in the headspace app and continue to benefit from the expertise and unique viewpoints of its diverse mental wellness coaches.
    I've learned a little about meditation over the years in school and various Summer camps. However, I never approached it in an earnest, sustained way like these apps help you to do. I've largely found other different helpful habits to support my mainly positive attitude. Things like taking time to sit and listen to music, using soundscape apps like Nature Space, and lots of reading. Meditation just never got explored seriously before. Even as the pandemic took hold in 2020, I felt like I was already ahead of the game. I had plenty of audio entertainment, thousands of books, good Internet connectivity, and extensive familiarity with what was available online to help my wife and I stay safe, positive and well supplied. Being used to spending a lot of time in my apartment, especially during Winter months, I felt as well-equipped as anybody.
