What I slowly discovered as lockdown measures and viral danger continued was that choice really makes all the difference. Missed visits with family and friends, cancelled excursions and activities, began to make me feel more confined and empty. Each trip out for appointments and essentials seemed like a slightly dangerous proposition and not to be undertaken lightly. Even as my family and friends continued to be safe and well, there was that constant low-grade fear that chance or carelessness would catch up eventually and someone I knew would be in danger. Not seeing friends and family over the 2020 holiday season pushed me to what is commonly said to be a mental pandemic wall. I felt inexplicably irritable, down and lacking in motivation. There was clearly a need for more tools in my kit. I decided to give these mental wellness apps a serious go.
    Both of the apps I chose have some free content available. To unlock the rest of their resources beyond this content, they ask people to pay a monthly or annual subscription. Typically, this unlocks premium features, coaching and other benefits. This money keeps them profitable, letting them continue to improve the app. It also makes them able to keep producing new content for their users. This is a very competitive space, so these improvements and extras are important. For anywhere near the same amount of in-person life coaching, you would pay much more than a year's subscription. These apps can't replace such professional coaching. However, for people who have the desire and discipline to help themselves, they offer tools and techniques which can make a big difference.
    Commitment and self-discipline are vital. I can't stress that enough. You'll be paying somewhere in the neighbourhood of $60 to well over $100 Canadian per year in some cases depending on the app you choose to subscribe to. If you're putting that much money into a service, please take it seriously and put in the time to make use of it. That money gives you access to a lot of well produced content. So much content, in fact, that I don't see any reason why you'd want to subscribe to more than one of these apps at a time. It may be worthwhile to subscribe for a month to a mental wellness app which interests you so that you have a good amount of time to get a proper sense of it and whether it suits you. A month's subscription will typically cost around $20 Canadian, give or take. Once you find an app which is most suitable to you, subscribe to that one annually to get the best possible bang for your buck.
    While competing in the same pond and offering similar kinds of help, these apps try to stand out from each other in many ways. They may focus on helping different groups of people. Furthermore, they usually put a lot of focus on a set of key ideas. These ideas may only differ a little. However, where emphasis is placed can make the mental journey seem very different. For instance, Shine really focussed strongly on people who feel disadvantaged or discounted. There's a lot of self affirmation and what I think of a self-esteem building stuff. Moreover, there is a major focus on self reflection and journaling habits. They provide edit boxes for such writing, typically after you have listened to a meditation. There are other opportunities in the app for such journaling. This helps people to stop and really take the time to think about how they feel and what might be happening in their lives. On the other hand, Headspace is more about helping you reach a state of awareness and calm through various meditation techniques. The approach feels more laid back, with almost no emphasis on writing down one's thoughts. The same core services and resources are offered by both apps. However, because of where focus is placed, the journeys feel very different. There are guided meditations about a whole range of issues and desires. Everything from getting better sleep to being more creative to conquering jealousy. If you have a mental issue you want a little guidance with, chances are that you'd find something applicable in any of these mental wellness apps. How much content you find which suits your particular needs will likely differ quite a bit between apps. It's important to really check at least a few of them out and get a feel for their overall style. I think that's going to be your best way to maximize what will be available to you when you really need it.
    Unique personalities are another key difference between these apps. If you've ever watched the movie called You've Got Mail, you'll remember that each of the competing book stores had their own staff of people keeping things running how the owner of the business wanted it. In similar fashion, each app has its special crew of regularly featured experts and coaches, bringing you the daily cessions and fresh advice. Headspace has Andy Puddicombe. His calm, friendly teaching style and tremendous knowledge gained through years of travel and study adds to the overall atmosphere of Headspace. The same held true for the largely female teaching coaches behind Shine.
    There is also the special content produced by famous people they manage to bring onboard. Headspace recently announced that Kevin Hart, the comedian, was doing a meditation series on Headspace. Another accessible mental wellness app called Calm has a bedtime story read by Matthew McConaughey. People who subscribe to the app will get access to this celebrity produced content and hear many well-liked and famous voices helping them on their mental journey. Special content may go beyond meditation cessions and stories. Apps often contain videos featuring experts in all manner of subjects deemed helpful to mental wellness. I've heard scientists talk about particle accelerators, astronomers, plant experts, and animal documentaries extolling the techniques and habits of various creatures.
    In 2022, the Shine app and community were acquired by Headspace Health. People who are interested in the sense of diversity and self advocacy which the Shine brand was known for should check out the Shine collection in Headspace and keep an ear out for familiar names and voices on the Headspace app.
Headspace:
Www.headspace.com
    Available free with limited access from the app store. Subscription unlocks all features.
    Monthly subscription: $17.99
    Yearly subscription: $89
    This-app advertises itself as a mindfulness and meditation solution for any mood, any mind and any goal. It has gone out of its way to support VoiceOver users and make its website accessible. Headspace is at the top level of apps in this category. The only other app with as wide an awareness that I've ever come across is one called Calm. At this level, there's enough money and resources to extend way beyond the app itself. Celebrities are paid to record some meditations. There are YouTube ads and a Headspace YouTube channel. For subscribers to Netflix, there's the Headspace Guide to Meditation and another guide about sleep, which they can avail themselves of. There are a number of podcasts which are free to follow. These include Headspace Radio, Dear Headspace, and The Long-Time Academy among others. This is good advertising for the more extensive coaching and mental health resources made available in the Headspace app. However, don't think that this in any way diminishes the quality of what is offered in the guides and podcasts. Both offer a lot of useful information and are good introductions to the idea of meditation and good mental habits. They are both provided with audio description, available for blind users. They also have a very extensive and well-built website with accessibility features.
    I had been attracted to Headspace by hearing a Ted Talk and advertisements on YouTube presented by one of the app's founders. Andy Puddicombe. I very much liked his calm friendly voice, insights and speaking style. That liking increased when I read about his background and experience. He has gone to great lengths and travelled widely to learn about meditation and mindfulness. He has even become an ordained Buddhist monk. It sounded to me like this man had well and truly earned his following and expertise. Having previously heard that other blind people had found the app to be accessible, I figured I'd be in pretty good hands.
    Rapidly, it became obvious that care had been taken to support VoiceOver right from when I first opened the app. Controls, buttons, tabs and such were all properly labelled. Also, if you have VoiceOver hints enabled, you'll hear brief guiding phrases which explain what given buttons and controls do. For instance, if you pause over the "settings" button in the player, you are told that this lets you customize the length of the cession you're listening to where this makes sense. If you hear a sleepcast story, you can move a slider, which alters the balance between the vocal and ambience. There are many touches like that all through the app. Also, the app makes use of standard headings and buttons, which make it easy to get at what you want.
    Headspace uses basic interface elements very well. There are five tabs. From left to right, these are "today", "meditation", "Sleep", "Move", and "Focus". The contents in each of the tabs is pretty extensive. The "Today" tab is where you start upon opening the app. Right near the top of that tab, you can use a slider to switch what the top section shows. You can choose between showing material you've recently engaged with, or else show recommended material given what you've done with the app so far. Below this section, you'll find three other sections which don't change. They are beneath headings which you can use the rotor to navigate through. Once you flick to a heading, flick right to go through whatever contents are beneath it. You'll find a Featured Collection heading which will present different collections which change over time. Below this, you'll find a heading called Mindful Moment. Flick to the right to find a mindful moment of the day. Double tap on it to enter. Below this, you'll find a heading called Community Story. This displays a testimonial from someone who was helped by the Headspace app and wanted to share. Double tap on the title of the story to go into it. You'll also find an option below the story where you can share your story. The last things at the bottom of all tabs are two buttons. Double tap the Profile button to get into an area where you can manage settings and account information. There's also a button called Explore. Double tap this, and you can search the complete resources of Headspace for what you might want.
    Each of the other tabs takes you into a place where you can explore resources relevant to the tab's name. All of them work essentially the same way. At the top, you'll find one recommended resource. Past that, you'll find a top section, which you can choose whether it displays your most recently used resources or some recommended resources. Below that, you'll find sections divided by handy headings which have resources relevant to the tab names. For instance, in the "Sleep" tab, you'll find a heading called "explore sleep". Flick right past that heading, and you find a series of buttons. These take you to collections of that kind of resource. For example, the button called sleep casts takes you to a collection of stories with a soothing ambience which change slightly each time they're heard. I think the ambience changes rather than the stories. There are other resources such as meditations to prepare you for sleep. Another button is called "sleep SOS" and it gets you to a collection of tools to help if you wake up from sleep and need more. The other tabs are similarly stuffed with resources. Everything from short meditations to mindful workouts and videos. There are hundreds of items available.
    There aren't many trouble spots in terms of accessibility. One thing I've noticed is that the back button to get out of a particular meditation or cession you're playing is beside the Play button, rather than at the top left. There's always a Back button somewhere on the screen but for some reason, they don't stick to the convention of having it at the top left of screens. That might throw off beginners a bit. Also, there's no way to independently adjust the volume of the available soundscapes. They're of excellent quality but tend to overpower VoiceOver volume, so it's difficult to hear what you're doing while listening to them. If you just want to bask in a soundscape, they're great for that. Using audio ducking solves this problem nicely once you've found a good ducking amount. Furthermore, the help and support is buried in the "profile" "settings" area of the app. It could have been more prominently placed. People searching for help would do better to go to the Headspace website:
    Www.headspace.com
Journaling:
Therapists and psychologists have long advocated for people to take up writing journals to help with mental health. One very popular type of journal is a gratitude journal. People take the time each day to stop and think about what they're grateful for and write those things down. This can be used later as a reminder of the good things in your life. This in itself can be of great help. There is also a more immediate and important effect. The very act of thinking about and writing these thoughts down brings what you're grateful for more firmly into your mind. This can help tremendously if you're facing a challenging day. It can help you keep a more positive perspective on life.
    Writing down your thoughts can also help you to stop and question any negative ones. It gives a moment's pause, granting the time and space to examine them before letting them pile up or perhaps acting on them in the heat of the moment.
    You will find extensive coverage of Apple's Journal app introduced in iOs 17 in a dedicated section earlier in this guide. However, I thought it was important to leave some brief remarks about the mental health benefits of journaling here in this section as well. If the Journal app doesn't meet your needs, here are some alternative suggestions:
How We Feel:
This is a free app designed by therapists, engineers and others wanting to help people understand their mental health. Packed with all kinds of features, the app makes it easier to track your mood, describe emotions, track relationships, and other factors important to mental wellbeing. It won an Apple award and, based on a brief examination, seems to be accessible to VoiceOver users.
    Understanding emotions is at the ore of this app. A lot of work has gone into making it easier to figure out what youfel and track factors using Healthkit which might contribute. Some early reviews of this app noted concerns about privacy. Before making extensive use of this app, take the time to read the current policy regarding your information.
Personal Diary:
Developed by Eng Tat Lim
    https://www.wernjie.com/personal-diary/
    Price: free in the app store
    Sometimes, you just want a simple free diary app which does what you need. Back in 2015, a teenaged app developer decided to create that. Even better, he made certain that his app worked well with VoiceOver. He has kept updating that app to this day. New features are added as experimental, so people who are interested in them can act as testers. Once a feature has been properly polished, it is then added to the standard features offered to everyone in the app.
    Keep in mind that this is a free app by a younger developer, learning as he goes. Nothing but personal pride, delight in creation, and a sense of responsibility to his largely happy users keeps him going. That's certainly good enough for me. The basic features are well established and working. However, if you choose to use the experimental ones like multiple journals, they're still being worked on and might not be as stable.
    It's another one of these apps with no tabs across the bottom. Everything is right on the main screen and different features will pop up when you double tap on the right button. There's an "edit button at the very top. A flick to the right of this is a heading called "timeline". To the right of this, you'll find a button called "settings". Next to this is the "add" button, which lets you add entries. The next thing is a search field, letting you look for entries in different ways. Past that, you'll find a heading which changes and asks questions like "how are you?" Or "What's new?" Past that, you can find and flick through all the entries you've made previously. It's cleverly simple to find your way around. Each entry title is a heading, so you can use the rotor to flick up or down between them.
    The capabilities here are very well laid out. Double tap the Add button, and you can then flick left or right to find the elements you want. There's actually a button called "editing help". You'll find the text field where you can type your entry. Also, you'll find a button for weather, mood, etc. This lets you choose the weather and your mood. Alternatively, you can have the app select those for you automatically using artificial intelligence. You will find pickers to change all of those aspects after double tapping that button. Once you're done writing the entry, simply double tap the "done" button. Everything works quite well with VoiceOver.
    There are options in the settings which are purely visual, such as the theme or size of text. These should be helpful to low vision users. Also, there are options such as whether you want entry preview text to show up in your timeline. You can choose to hide previews if you prefer. You can also choose whether the mood and weather can be chosen automatically. There are security settings to protect your diary. The spectrum of settings is excellent, even before you go into the experimental features settings. There's a help and support button as well as a tip jar if you want to support the developer financially.
    As far as free apps go, this one offers a splendid range of features while keeping things simple. It offers many things for free that other apps demand payment for. If you just want a simple diary app, this certainly delivers the goods. It even comes with a watch app which you can synch with and use the Flicktype keyboard to more easily type entries on the watch. Be certain to look in the experimental features section and provide feedback to the developer, so they can be worked on. Over time, more of the features become fully developed and leave the experimental section.
Day One Journal:
Developed by Bloom Built Inc.
    Www.dayoneapp.com
    ? Free to download with $5.49 or $46.99 monthly/annual pro subscription.
    This app has really stood the test of time well. It's been around since 2011 and has proved very popular among serious sighted journalers. Once they caught the accessibility bug, they have consistently kept everything accessible using VoiceOver. If you use VoiceOver hints, you'll hear short explanations as you flick over buttons and other elements in the app.
    Day One tries to be all things to all people. It has maintained its position at the top of its category by offering all sorts of premium features while keeping the subscription price affordable. People wanting to keep a diary and store moments or memories securely will find everything they might want. The basic free offer is more than good enough for people wishing to keep everything in one simple journal. You can make use of templates and daily prompts. Entries can have one photo added. Weather, location, activity and other things can be added to each entry. You can easily post entries to social media if you like.
    The layout is simple enough that you can get to everything by flicking left or right and double tapping on what you want. There are no ads or anything to get in your way. Everything is kept on a secure private server and only the device you've started a journal on can be used to add to or access it. You can, of course, upgrade to a new device and have that new device be the one with access.
    For people wanting more than what is freely offered, the pro subscription delivers all sorts of perks. You can keep unlimited journals. These can have unlimited photos and audio, as well as documents attached. The pro subscription gets you unlimited secure storage for your journals and anything attached to entries. That includes audio and video files, as well as documents. You can have PDF documents which can be scanned in. Audio entries are transcribed so they're searchable. The watch app lets you dictate entries right on your wrist. You get unlimited synching among your devices. There are other perks like bonus colours for your journals.
    You can find help and support at the Day One website:
    Www.dayoneapp.com
    There's a support section with many helpful articles. You can also learn about the app and the people who use it through the Day One podcast. There's also a thriving community of enthusiasts on Facebook. The pro subscription entitles you to customer support on a 24-hour basis.
    There are no tabs to worry about. At the top, there are a series of buttons. The journals, search, and More buttons come first. The journals button gives you options dealing with doing things to them as a whole. For instance, exporting a journal. The search button lets you search your entries for keywords or information. The more button gives you a set of options dealing with the current journal in focus. There are journal settings to help customize that particular journal, among other things. You'll find several buttons after that which let you immediately jump into a blank new entry to add text, photo, video, etc. If you know what you want to write or record, these are the buttons for you. If not, go down to the bottom of the screen. There, you'll find buttons to make reviewing your journal easier. There's a button to bring up an entry timeline, another for a timeline of stored media, a map of locations where you recorded your entries, and another to bring up a calendar. More importantly, you'll find the new entry menu button right in the middle of the bottom. This lets you access a menu of options including the daily prompt, special templates, or different media like drawing or audio. Just flick through the options and double tap on what you want. The daily prompt is included right in the menu, with an "answer" button one flick to the right of the question. Just double tap that and answer, or flick further right to find a button letting you start a blank text entry.
    The entry screens are easy to work with. You'll find text fields or whatever else you might need easily. There are buttons to let you control what additional information is saved along with entries you make if you want to control things on an individual basis. It has all been very well-thought-out to make journaling as easy a habit to get into as possible.
    If you're serious about documenting live events and keeping more than one journal, it's absolutely worth the price. Personally, though, I just haven't journaled to the degree that you'd need to, so you really made use of all the features. I'm a writer primarily, so all the video and audio capabilities went largely unused. However, if you wanted to document events and milestones with video and audio recording often, it's a small price to pay for the secure storage and abilities. Had I discovered it earlier, I may well have done more with it and kept paying the subscription.
Soundscapes:
Despite my moderate hearing loss, I frequently find having a well constructed soundscape playing in my AirPods to be a very useful thing. When you spend as much time in one place as I have over the past few years, there's often very little variety of ambient noise. Hearing different background sounds can break up the monotony and stimulate the mind. Alternatively, there may be noise which can't be escaped from, like when construction is happening in your building. My wife and I went through long stretches of this as the balconies were replaced over the course of a year. The vibration and pounding would shake the building, and the construction sounds would feel like they were cutting into your head at times. Soundscapes provide a different background noise of your choosing, which provides more mental relief than one might expect. Even I, who had the option of turning off my hearing aids and being positively thankful for the hearing loss which I had until then regarded as an unmitigated curse, was driven to utter distraction. Soundscapes add audio decoration, much as people with sight might put art up on their wall or trinkets on their desk. There are times when you don't really want music. It's typically designed to really catch and hold your attention. Sometimes, you just need more of a background ambience, which may change slowly over time. I can have the sounds of a busy café, the shore of a lake or ocean, a forest, or perhaps something more surreal like dreamy train noises. It can be totally private coming through my AirPods, or fill the apartment if I switch it to the HomePod Minis on my desk. Having that constant background noise can actually let me enjoy music at the same time while I'm working without it distracting me so much. The music changes, but the other background noise is more stable and constant.
    There are many apps which can provide you with soundscapes. Some allow greater control over aspects of what you hear than others. Apple added a background sounds feature to iOS, which you'll find in the accessibility settings. Just be certain to set the volume of the soundscape to low so that you can slowly bring it up and not find it suddenly impossible to hear VoiceOver. I carefully had to talk a lady who found herself in that circumstance through the steps to turn off the feature. It is quite possible to enjoy the soundscapes provided by this accessibility feature with VoiceOver, provided you get the relative volume levels right. Apple put the feature in to help people with ADHD and other conditions where a constant familiar sound can prove calming and conducive to less distraction. It is designed to interact with other audio played-from your device at the same time. For instance, the background sound would lower when you are also listening to someone speaking.
Nature Space:
This app gives you access to the Nature Space catalogue of soundscapes, letting you purchase and play them on your iOS device. The app is fully accessible and designed to work well with Voiceover. Nature Space developers are very aware of their blind audience. A demo and walkthrough by Scott Davert is available on the Applevis podcast. The app is free and comes with six soundscapes. Additional ones can be gotten through in-app purchases made in the Nature Space Catalogue.
    I use this app with Voiceover's audio ducking feature disabled. It can be jarring when the volume of your soundscape drops each time you take action on your iOS device. Use the rotor, turning it to the audio ducking setting, and flick up or down to turn the feature on or off.
    These soundscapes are recorded to give a good sense of space and are actual recordings of nature rather than artificially created. They are both a form of audio decoration and useful tools for people. It can be useful to have background sound which has variety but doesn't change volume or captivate the same way as music does. Sounds of waves or wind through trees can be relaxing and stimulating. Bird sounds can be energizing. Soundscapes can also help mask other sounds like construction noise. They're the audio equivalent of wallpaper. Engaging when focussed on, but can fade into the background of awareness.
    Your installed soundscapes start at the top left of the screen after the "Scroll to playing track" button. Double-tapping the button gets you near the track being played. Useful with a large collection of soundscapes. Flick left and right or use a three-fingered swipe up or down to get through your soundscapes as your collection gets bigger. Most of the rest of the main screen is all your installed soundscapes. Below these are seven buttons in a row:
    The Console button opens the console, where you can configure the Nature Space app to best serve you. Flick left and right to get through the settings. I prefer the "Mix audio with other apps" option set to on. This way, you can customize the Nature Space soundscape volume and find a good balance with your main system volume. You can then also play music at the same time. Other useful options include an "Airplay" button letting you switch between Bluetooth speakers, headphones or other devices. You can email for tech support, and there's also a button for deleting any previews of full tracks which are on your device. To close the console, use the "done" button at the top left.
    The "Share" button lets you use social media to share what soundscape you're currently listening to.
    The "Transitions Timer" lets you set timers designed to play sounds for helping you wake up or go to sleep. You can use both timers together, or just one of them.
    Four buttons over from the bottom left is the catalogue button. This is where you purchase additional soundscapes or download ones you've already purchased. You can easily navigate this area. There are headings you can flick up and down between using the rotor. Also, buttons for specific categories are there to help navigate the collection. In particular, check out the "Suggested use" button which presents additional buttons leading to collections of sound ideal for focussing, waking, sleeping and other things. The shopping experience couldn't be much easier. As usual, you'll find a particular soundscape, double-tap on it, find and tap on the button with the price of the track, and confirm your ID. When finished purchasing sounds or exploring the catalogue, use the "done" button at the top left to close it.
    To the right of the catalogue button are three more buttons. "Display full-screen image" will do just that, showing a picture related to the selected track. The "details" button brings up an information screen about the track being played. This has a description of the track, plus any notes about how it can be best used. The "display" or "hide" folder editing controls button gives you access to a mode which lets you organize and remove tracks from your device. If the editing controls are shown, there's a "reorder" button which lets you enter the mode where you can move and delete tracks. You can also create additional folders if it suits you. Normally, these controls should be hidden to reduce clutter. Use the "done" button when finished editing a folder, and then use the "hide folder editing controls" button at the bottom right to return to normal.
    Watch your storage space with this app if you don't have much to spare. Some soundscapes are fairly large and will fill a device with lower storage capacity rapidly. Don't be afraid to use the folder editing controls to remove soundscapes you don't want at the moment. You can always download them when you want them later. I have 29 different soundscapes installed, and they take up 647 MB. I often write with audio ducking off and a soundscape running with the Nature Space volume balanced nicely with my system volume. Some favourite soundscapes are:
    Walk to the Beach, Electric Desert Sunset, Equinox, Equatorial Midnight, Each Year, and Solstice.
MyNoise:
Produced by myNoise BVBA
    Available free in the app store with in-app purchases
    My Noise is a soundscape creator which lets you build and sculpt your ideal soundscape using component sounds called generators. A key aspect of the soundscapes created is that patterns don't ever repeat. Components of sounds are changed and played randomly so that your brain doesn't catch on repeated predictable loops unless you use a generator which intentionally has them. The app also lets you calibrate many soundscapes to compensate for hearing loss or mask bothersome environmental noise. You can use each generator on its own. For example, if I wanted a café soundscape, I could start that generator playing. However, you can also combine up to five generators to create a supergenerator. For instance, I could add a crackling fireplace, random piano music, and the sound of the Irish coast to add to the café ambience.
    While the accessibility of this app isn't as intuitive as it could be, the app is fully useable if you have VoiceOver hints enabled. Just wait a second after you land on and element and VoiceOver will say "possibly", whatever it is. That's new in iOS13, having VoiceOver try figuring out unlabelled controls. There are a few unlabelled buttons which voiceOver only hazards a guess at intermittently, such as the "play/pause" button. However, it's the last button farthest to the right before you reach the "Timer" and "Multi" buttons. All the sliders are perfectly accessible, although I have had occasions where VoiceOver jumps off a slider. Due to these kinds of issues, I would say take the time to explore the screens of this app and learn what things do. Your efforts will be rewarded.
    Each generator has ten sliders which control the volume of different components of that overall soundscape. Think of it a bit like an equalizer on a stereo. In some generators, that is precisely what those sliders actually are. Increasing the value will increase the amount of bass or treble frequencies in a soundscape. However, in many generators, each slider controls the volume of an aspect of the overall soundscape. This might consist of several sounds. For instance, the far-left slider controls the volume of bass restaurant rumble. Another couple of sliders are devoted to babble and chatter, another is for kitchen noises. Yet another is for table related sounds, like cutlery or plates being put down or moved. Some are for different types of restaurant, such as café versus a cocktail party. If you give your device a shake, the positions of the sliders will randomize. This is handy for changing things up a bit without having to leave the app you're working in while myNoise runs in the background.
    Don't panic at the thought of dealing with all the sliders. If you flick to the right of all the sliders past the "menu" button, you'll find a "my noises" option. Double tap on this and a new dialogue will pop up. This has presets for those sliders. When you first flick onto a picker, you'll hear VoiceOver say "random". Flick to the right, and you'll find an "I feel lucky" option. Flick up or down on this to keep changing the sliders randomly. For more intentional different presets, flick left onto the "random" picker and flick up. You will find a number of options, which usually include one called "scene" or "mood". Once that is selected, flick right to the right picker, which said, "I feel lucky" when random was selected. The contents of this right picker change depending on what the left one is set to. You'll find that flicking that upward yields a number of different choices. For instance, the café generator has options for chatter, the table in front, patrons only, and other presets. Once you selected the one you want, flick right to find the "select" button and double tap on that. If you find the volume isn't high enough, you can always adjust the sliders to more suitable levels, keeping their settings relative to each other the same to preserve the overall scene. There are actually buttons over to the right when a generator has been selected which let you raise or lower all the sliders by ten percent to achieve a good overall volume.
    Once you have a generator sounding the way you want it to, flick right and double tap on a button called "Multi". This brings up the supergenerator creation screen. You'll find a "back" button at the top left. Flick right a couple of times to find the "add generator" button. Double tap this, and you'll be presented with the list of all the generators available to you currently. I started with the café generator we covered earlier as a foundation. Next, I wondered where I wanted this place to be and found the "Irish Coast" generator. I double tapped on this, adding it to my supergenerator. Once you do this, examine the screen again, and you'll find buttons for each generator letting you either remove or customize the sound coming from it. Double tap on the "customize" button for a generator to bring up the sliders and options for it. When done customizing, flick right to the "multi" button to return to the supergenerator creation screen. You can add up to a maximum of five generators. I added the Irish coast generator to my café. Next, I added some singing bowls to give it a mystical feel. I had to customize that one to raise the volume of the bowl hits and eliminate the harmonic sliders. Next, I found a generator called Take it Easy, which had some nice electronic musical sounds. After adjusting those sliders to my liking, I return to the supergenerator creation screen by double tapping the "multi" button. Flicking all the way over to the right of this screen, I found the "save" button, which let my name and save my creation. I called it the Inspirations Seaside Café, and it's automatically added to the "Favourites" tab.
    There are five tabs in the app. From left to right, they are "my noises", "favourites", "Calibrations", "Downloads" and "More". You should take the time to explore all of these tabs for yourself. All the stuff we've talked about in terms of using single generators or creating supergenerators happens in the "My Noises" tab. If you find and double tap the "heart" button while on a particular generator's slider panel, you'll mark it as a favourite, and it'll be added to the "Favourites" tab. Given the large number of generators, this is very helpful.
    The "Menu" button lets you save additional presets of slider settings you like. Also, you can change the name of presets or delete ones you don't want. It may do more depending on context.
    Basically, the app itself is free and comes with a number of free generators. However, there are many additional generators which you can buy. Each generator costs $1.39. There's another option of buying all available generators plus any future additions for a one-time payment of $13.99. There are currently over 150 individual generators. The app celebrated its tenth year of existence in 2022 and more updates are being developed.
Rootd:
This app has garnered awards and special attention from Apple ap store editorial staff. It is designed to help people deal with anxiety and panic attacks. It provides lessons in everything from relaxation to breathing exercises to techniques for calming the mind. With image and text recognition enabled, I've found this app to be accessible for more experienced VoiceOver users. It really tries hard to get you to agree to a paid subscription. However, you can try a lot of the app's features at no cost if you're willing to deal with tis.
Habits With Henry:
Some apps called habit trackers are designed to help you develop good mental habits. One such app is called Habits with Henry. Henry is the name of a virtual pet kitten in the app who helps teach you the psychology of good habits. The app combines habit tracking with a kind of virtual pet game. You can unlock additional pets by doing well at sticking with your habits. Unlike other apps in this space, habits with Henry doesn't require an ongoing subscription. It costs around $6 Canadian.
    The developer of the app has been made aware of interest in the app from blind users. He has moved quickly to address accessibility problems for VoiceOver users. The app makes all kins of psychology information, motivation, and other resources available to you. People on the app store seem generally quite pleased with the app. You can learn more about it by visiting:
    https://habit-henry.com
Other Mental Wellness Resources:
Our iPhones can help us to access many resources which can be as helpful for blind people as they are for the general population regarding our mental wellbeing. These resources will be ready and waiting to offer us information, comfort, and calm wherever we bring our iPhones. For me, the best examples are books, podcasts, online communities, and music. These are things which you can access easily and often at no cost on your iPhone.
    Thanks to my iPhone and the trust put in its security by book publishers, I can easily obtain the latest books on mental health and wellness. One weekend in February 2022, I heard a show on CBC Radio called Sunday Magazine. The interviewed Johann Hari, the author of Stolen Focus. It's a book all about how to regain our lost ability to really pay deep attention to things. I was able to make a note of the book title and find it on Kindle. It's also available on Audible and likely other accessible places like CELA. A podcast clued me into another book by Julie Smith called Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before. It's a book by a clinical psychologist just published this January. In it, she lays out the basics of what we know about various things like managing grief, keeping motivated, dealing with low moods, and much more. Another CBC show had an interview with Jennifer Buchanan. She's a music therapist who wrote Wellness Well-played: The Power of a Playlist. If you need scientific proof to justify the time you spend listening to music, look no further. Thanks to my iPhone, I was able to purchase all three of these books on Kindle and even make certain before I did so that they would be fully accessible to me. When we hear about a resource like a book which interests us, chances are excellent that we will be able to get it right away when it actually might apply to our current situation.
    There are a great many podcasts which are made to give people help dealing with all sorts of mental wellness issues. Since they're entirely an auditory form of expression, blind people will face no difficulties accessing them. One of my more recent discoveries is a podcast called On Purpose with Jay Shetty. He explores all kinds of interesting aspects of the mind. There are over 300 episodes, which typically seem to be around an hour long. Everything from six mistakes we make when communicating in our close relationships to how to deal with anxiety. The Cram Podcast explores ideas and research that doesn't always get widely publicized, but could change how we live our lives. A recent episode dealt with insomnia and getting a good night's sleep. Podcasting has given space for many experts with some time to spare to share their thoughts freely on all kinds of things, including mental issues.
    Your iPhone gives you easy access to online communities and social media. Connection with others via these methods shouldn't be thought of as a perfect substitution for in person contact with other people. However, when opportunities for such in person contact are unavailable, the ability to keep in contact from a distance has largely proved to be a blessing. Certainly, a mixed one. I often advise people who are new to social media to approach it with a thick skin. Humanity at its best and worst can be found in the global village.
    This is why I believe that people seeking safe and positive connections while in any kind of mental distress might better be served by joining smaller, more moderated communities. The keys here are the size of the community and whether there's moderation or other defensive options if you find yourself being attacked. Pretty much anybody can follow you on X, Facebook or other platforms. If you're basically in a good frame of mind, I think there's a lot of value to be found in social media like Twitter. I have many followers who I genuinely respect and have had some great conversations. However, it's hard to completely avoid the trolls and really negative people on these platforms. With smaller communities, there's more connection between participants and more of an incentive to keep things civil and positive. A relatively small, safe group of people who regularly get together for conversation can do wonders for one's mood.
    Many organizations have offered virtual meetings, which people can register to attend freely. For example, the CNIB has been offering many virtual programs to teach skills and discuss various subjects over Zoom. Having that regular contact with a moderated group of people with at least one shared interest can be very helpful. I also participate in Zoom discussions offered by the CCB. I actually lead one of their discussions once a month, all about iOS apps, games, and entertainment. Over time, you get to know the people who attend such groups, and this can be very helpful in maintaining a positive outlook on life. There are also many online forums and email lists people can join. Look to be certain that there are community rules and procedures in place for when people break those rules.
    And then, there's music. Everyone has their favourite songs or artists. Music is often turned to in times of upheaval to give comfort and solis. These days, I mainly use the Music app included in iOS. I've made playlists of instrumental and pop music which I like. Even if you would rather not do that work, there are many radio stations and curated playlists available through Apple Music. Using Siri, you can ask it to play any radio station you can think of. It'll look in directories of TuneIn and iHeart Radio, among others, to try to find stations you ask for. I find it's always good to add the word "radio station" to the end of your command when you want to hear one of those. Alternatively, you can specify which app a radio station is available from. If you tell Siri to "Play my radio station", it will generate a station for you based on music that it thinks you like. If that isn't an ego boost, I don't know what is.

Internet Radio and Podcasts:
Your iPhone or iPad, with help from Bluetooth speakers or headsets, can be a tremendously portable gateway to all kinds of stimulating audio entertainment and community. Outside of audiobooks and dramas sold by companies directly to consumers, the only things it may cost you are storage space on your device and the data used to download or stream content. Presuming you are satisfied with what Apple provides on your device, you can potentially tap into Internet radio and podcasts without spending any money at all. For more hardcore enthusiasts, there are various third-party apps that offer additional features to enhance listening and let you tune into countless radio stations and subscribe to podcasts. More podcasts are being produced which require paying subscriptions to access. As a result, the terminology surrounding podcasts in particular is undergoing some change. Podcasts can be "followed" for no cost which mens that you'll get any free content they offer. Subscribing to a podcast will unlock access to additional content available to paid subscribers. This might give access via special feed to longer episodes, bonus content such as interviews with creators, or other perks.
    The Internet is the wild west of broadcasting and publishing. The costs to produce and stream content are low enough that practically anyone who is interested can participate and publish content. Enthusiasts can create Internet radio stations broadcasting exclusively via the Internet rather than via radio waves. Most actual radio stations these days will also allow you to listen via the Internet. This offers the advantage of perfect reception, provided your Internet connection is good, and you have the necessary bandwidth.
    Using email and other social media tools such as Facebook, Mastodon or X, people can go beyond merely listening and interact with each other as well as content creators. This opens up tremendous possibilities for helping to make content better, make new friends online who share your interests, and offer any talents or knowledge you might have to help others. Many blind people have decided to become involved in broadcasting on Internet radio stations or in the creation of podcasts. It is now possible to do this content creation using apps on your iOS device.
    Podcasts are shows you can follow or subscribe to. As the shows are released, you can stream or download them from the Internet to your iOS device using an app built for this purpose. There are podcasts about any subject you might imagine. This includes everything from audio storytelling and drama, to podcasts about blindness-related information, to podcasts about sports, culture, and mythology. The sheer amount of content available in podcast form is breathtaking and usually free for anybody to listen to. Using recording apps and services on the Internet, it's possible to create podcasts using only your iOS device, although accessories and the right apps can drastically improve sound and overall quality.
    In this section, I'll share some of my treasured experiences and discoveries exploring both of these mediums. I'll also cover the facilities Apple has included related to podcasts and radio listening.
    iOS 13 introduced major developments, making it possible to use Siri in conjunction with the Music app to tap into Internet radio. They also provide an app called Podcasts that allows you to subscribe to and enjoy countless podcasts available online. This makes it easy for new users of iOS devices to simply jump in and start listening. Further refinements were made in iOS 15, particularly to the Podcasts app. It now offers the ability to support and access podcasts through subscribing to them. However, there are many third-party apps that preceded Apple deciding to up its game in these areas of audio entertainment. These apps offer compelling capabilities to make exploring what's out there and listening even more pleasant. I will discuss my preferred apps for accessing this content and explain why you might want to look at other options when you could do it all free of any costs.
    Please realize that there is a mind-boggling amount of choice in this space. There are many podcast apps as well as those for listening to Internet radio on your device which can be obtained from the app store. And then, there's enough actual content to consume multiple lifetimes. Even with nothing else to do, there would be no way that I could keep up with all the podcasts and Internet radio shows that cater to my particular interests. All the apps I'll present in this section have facilities to help you seek content and learn about what's currently available.
    The station and podcast examples I'll use when describing how to use various apps have been chosen to maximize the benefits of taking the time to listen even before you know how to interact. At the end of the portion of this section devoted to Internet radio, you'll find a list of stations that are either my favourites to listen to or are stations particularly helpful to blind people. Similarly, you'll find a list of podcasts awaiting you at the end of the part of this section devoted to them. If nothing else, I hope this gives newcomers a good place to start. Things do change over time. Podcasts come and go. Also, some content is Geoblocked and may not be available in your area for that reason. Typically, this has to do with copyright and marketing restrictions. While there's no charge to listeners for this content apart from data and possible subscription costs, money is certainly needed to produce it. I live in Canada, so the resources I feature here will reflect this. As far as I know, they should be available in most places. A great many originate outside of Canada. That being said, let's dive right in.
Internet Radio:
A SocialSonic Springboard:
    The day had finally arrived. It was April 27, 2012, when I found an email awaiting me. The time had come for the Mushroom FM Weekend Virtual Birthday Cruise. It was by far their biggest, most intricate celebration event ever staged at the time. For long-time listeners like me, it was very much a cause for anticipation and excitement. I made certain my weekend was clear of any other plans, wanting to catch as much of this as possible.
    There was, of course, no need to pack for this "weekend away". The event took place online and in the cheerful minds of its participants, who were in many countries around the world. The good ship Fungus was an imaginary construct reinforced by the willing suspension of disbelief, aided by well-crafted sound effects. Our cabins were identity numbers allowing for easy tallying of correct trivia answers, votes cast, etc. The virtual rooms were hosted by the station show hosts and staff to the delight of all involved. Sitting comfortably at home or wherever we happened to be, we could, nonetheless, participate in this fifty-five hour continuous audio party.
    Only a year into my iPhone experience, I took part mainly through my desktop computer. The speakers filled my apartment with the proceedings of the virtual cruise. Well-picked music was interspersed with interludes complete with atmospheric shipboard background sound effects where the current host would update everyone on contests, ask participation and trivia questions, conduct poles, etc. Anybody at all could tune in and listen. However, registration before the event meant that you had a cabin onboard and could partake in the more interactive elements of the experience, including contests and votes. This was done via social media including Twitter, Facebook, and via email. Hashtags were used on X, which was where people had ongoing conversations and participated with the hosts most frequently. Hashtags allowed people to find messages from participants they weren't already following. Also, emails from people not on social media and updates on some of the conversation happening on X were read on the air. This event served to powerfully demonstrate the potential of the Internet to bring people together. I still converse with friends I made on X during that weekend of extended broadcasting. Many people who normally only interacted with others who listened to the same shows were exposed to different hosts and audience members they may not have otherwise encountered. The result was a stronger community of listeners and lasting online friendships.
    If the same event took place now, I would participate entirely through my iPhone. At home, I could use smart-speakers to hear the event broadcast. If I was somewhere else, I could just as easily hear the event via earbuds or pair my iPhone with Bluetooth speakers to share it with others. Social media and email apps are very accessible, so I could participate fully through my iPhone. Ideally, I'd use a physical Bluetooth keyboard for typing. For times when I was away from handy wall sockets, a power bank and charging cable would complete my desired equipment.
    Marathon Events like the virtual cruise I described above are relatively rare. They require a lot of dedicated effort to pull off. For event creators and hosts, the more game or interactive elements there are in an event, the more effort and skill are needed to bring them off satisfactorily. My wife Sara has become deeply involved in the Mushroom FM internet radio station. She hosts two regular shows, including one that happens every weekday. During the final weekend before I published the first edition of this guide, April 25th and 26th of 2020, Mushroom FM celebrated its 10th birthday. The main event of these celebrations was Mushroomstock 2020. Modelled after the legendary Woodstock festival, this twelve-hour event featured live recordings made by groups who had already passed on or else couldn't reunite and play together. I got a peek behind the scenes, or ... sounds in this case, as Sara prepared for her three-hour slot where she would host proceedings. A lot of work goes into fine-tuning the crowd noise used during portions between the music when you hear from the various show hosts and broadcasters involved. There's all the work selecting acts comprised of live recordings possibly performed at different events and making it all sound like it fits naturally into the same event held at a completely fictitious Fungus Field. Where else would Mushroom FM hold a music festival?
    For audience members participating in such events, the bar is much lower. Of course, they need whatever skills that doing well in a particular event demands. Also, they need to be familiar enough with whatever social media platform is being used to facilitate interaction to use it quickly. Some events are conducted with Zoom or other group-conferencing platforms, letting participants simply talk to the hosts and each other. Other times, recorded or typed communication is expected via email or Twitter. This lets creators have more control over what gets broadcast. It can also allow for easier private conversation to occur off-air between audience members tuned into the broadcast.
    For many blind and visually impaired people, social isolation can be a major issue. Finding people with similar interests and experiences can be tricky. One approach to hooking up with others is through Internet radio stations. Nothing can replace spending time with people who are physically present. However, many meaningful and worthwhile relationships have grown out of participation with communities of listeners that form around shows and stations accessible freely online. Neither transportation nor a lack of funds will stop you from participating and contributing meaningfully to the communities that grow around stations and shows. All you need is your iOS device, an Internet connection, and your preferred accessories for listening and typing. If you're unfamiliar with social media, please see the section in this guide titled A Truly Global Village. If you aren't quite feeling ready to plunge into that just yet, fear not. Most Internet radio stations will have email addresses that you can use to give feedback at a minimum. Many broadcasters will even check emails while a show is happening and read them to listeners along with activity from social media platforms. Interaction is a major reason for them to produce broadcasts. They are usually keen to offer assistance and encouragement to newcomers.
Apple's Approach to Internet Radio Enjoyment
If you've read the section about the Apple Music app, you'll know that Apple steers you towards its own curated group of radio stations. They currently run three flagship stations. Apple Music 1 focusses exclusively on current and brand-new music. On that station, you'll find a lineup of live and prerecorded shows hosted by professional DJs as well as big names in the music industry, including Elton John. The Apple Music Hits station concentrates on older popular music. As with Apple's other stations, it features shows produced by top-notch talent familiar with the songs and the people behind them. Finally, Apple music Country gives fans of that genre of music the same caliber of curated content and live shows. Each station streams twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. Each station has a schedule of shows. If you miss a favourite show, fear not. Simply go into the schedule, double tap on the show name and find the episode you missed in the content page for that show.
    In early 2020, scrolling around the contents of tabs in the Music app wasn't as easy as it should be, thanks to issues with VoiceOver focus and stability. Things have improved substantially over the past two years. Scrolling through the contents of the tabs still isn't as intuitive as it should be. People will need to make use of the vertical bar on the right side of the screen to jump past points and then use the rotor turned to headings. I've found that VoiceOver keeps being unable to move to headings lower down in the tab until they're actually on the screen to begin with. This means that you'll have to scroll up and down or flick right over songs until that heading is present. Alternatively, you may need to get to the heading below the one you're interested in and then flick left to find content near the bottom of the heading of interest. You'd simply jump over it going the other way. Beginners should know that the struggle you're having isn't a lack of proficiency on your part.
    Presuming you can explore and use that tab normally, you will find headings such as Recently Played, Apple Music Radio, Radio by Genre, and many more.
    A lot of that tab is taken up by information and shows broadcast on the three Apple Music stations. This is one way you can find out about shows offered on the stations. To explore beyond these, you first need to get past this. Simply double tap on a show to reach its show page. There, you can read a bit about the show and double tap on an episode to start listening. Apple throws substantial resources into this content. Finding other content such as third-party terrestrial stations broadcasting music or news can be somewhat tricky. There are headings called "Local Radio", "Worldwide Radio", and others. There are also buttons which get you into various genres of station. Things could and should be a lot more intuitive, but as of iOS, 15 in 2022, it is possible to get at all of the contents in the Radio tab.
    Once you start a station or show playing, the standard playback screen pops up. With prerecorded shows, you can move around as normal. However, you can't skip things during live shows. Simply use the Dismiss button to go back to the Radio tab and hide the playback screen. With Apple's three music stations, using the "Play" buttons after the "schedule" links will start the station playing without maximizing the player. This works similarly to when you double tap on a top song from an artist under the "top songs" heading, and it just starts playing.
    The Radio tab is only one of two ways Apple has provided to bring endless wonderful radio to your ears. The other is to simply look for stations through other means, such as Google, and then simply tell Siri what you want to hear. One advantage of this is that you don't even have to leave the app you're in to start something playing or change what you're hearing to something else. Another big plus is that Siri can tap into many directories of radio station streams to find what you're hoping to hear. It then simply starts playing the station in the Music app. Wait around five to ten seconds after this happens, and the Siri dialogue window will close, leaving you wherever you were before invoking Siri. You can always use the home screen gesture or Home button, depending on your model of iOS device, to escape this window more quickly.
    For our first example, let's say you want to hear what's currently playing on AMI Audio. This audio stream is broadcast on Canadian television. This makes it easier for those unconnected to the Internet to tune in and be informed and entertained. You can learn more about the shows and content you'll hear by going to www.amiplus.ca.
    To access this stream using Siri, you first need to invoke Siri by saying "hey Siri" if you've enabled this, or by holding down the Action button on your device until you hear a short beep. Once you've heard the beep, simply say "play AMI Audio radio station". If Siri doesn't recognize your request properly, try saying the letters separately, like you'd do with an acronym like CIA. Siri will then emit a short beep to indicate that it has stopped listening and parsed your request. If all went well, you should then start hearing whatever happens to be on AMI Audio at the moment. I've found that adding the words "radio station" to a request to hear one helps avoid occasions where a song or artist have similar sounding names.
    Once you've played a station in this manner, that station is recorded in the Music app under the Recently Played heading found in both the For You and the Radio tabs. This makes it easy to tune in again by double tapping on any stations beneath that heading. This is useful when you don't wish to disturb anyone around you by speaking to Siri. The more stations you listen to, the more is added beneath that heading. Eventually, if you don't listen to a given station, it gets pushed down farther beneath the heading. Eventually, it may no longer be there at all.
Advantages of Third-Party Listening Apps
Not everyone is satisfied with Apple's approach to Internet radio. Station exploration beyond Apple's curated set of choices is harder to do. Many people won't see this as a problem, since they can just ask Siri to play whatever station they want to hear. However, actually finding out about what else is out there waiting for your discovery can't really be done with the Music app. You could certainly use Google or word of mouth to find out about new stations. However, you then need to hear these stations to get them recorded as Recently Played, or keep your own list, perhaps in a Notes app. Also, people may want to keep a stable list of their favourites that doesn't change based on how often they listen to things. They might want to search for stations within a specific city they're visiting so they can get a feel for what the locals are hearing. Third-party apps designed for Internet radio listening offer this kind of benefit and others to increase your enjoyment. Many of these are free to download but are supported by ads. Others are sold as subscription services to access all of their features. Other apps charge a one-time fee up front that entitles you to all future updates. Let's look at a few of these apps that are accessible and have been kept up to date as iOS has changed. We'll start with a well established app which has become a favourite for me thanks to a tip from a reader named Dennis Long.
The Eter App:
This app is a nice and simple option for browsing what's available publically and freely all over the world in terms of online radio. A one-time payment of around $12 Canadian unlocks all features including the ability to keep a list of favourite stations. The app can be used freely if you don't mind searching for stations each time you want to hear them. Once you've paid the price and added some favourites, you can use the multimedia keys on your keyboard or the controls on your headset or EarPods to skip betwen stations or pause playback.
    The directory of stations used by this app seems very up to date. However, another advantage of this app is that you can add stations if you know their URL. Finding out what those are can be a bit of a stretch. It's not the home page for the station you need, but the direct link to the streaming feed.
    While you may well hear advertising from stations or from the streaming companies making their broadcast available online, the Eter app doesn't use ads to support its ongoing development. Things are kept very simple. Another perk of this app is its ability to detect the name of songs playing and letyou open right to them in the Music app. You can then add the song, artist, albums, etc, to your music library on the Apple Music Plus service. Very handy indeed.
The Triode Internet Radio App:
Triode was created by the Icon Factory. These independent app developers have demonstrated their commitment to making their apps accessible to blind people. They are most widely known for the Twitterrific app. While this app has been rendered useless due to radical changes at X, it was long regarded as the best most accessible Twitter experience available. The Triode app can be downloaded and tried out free. However, a subscription is needed to unlock all of its features. Alternatively, you can pay a one-time fee of around $27 Canadian. This helps to support the continued development and maintenance of the app.
    The interface for this app is somewhat more traditional than ooTunes and makes use of tabs. Things are nicely laid out and easy to explore. So far, the directory of stations has contained everything I've thought to search for. You can maintain a list of favourites and switch between them using the multimedia buttons on your headset or keyboard. The app is very polished and definitely worth checking out.
    We'll use Mushroom FM as your example here. This station is a kind of shared hobby for its famous owner, Jonathan Mosen. It's a way to give back to the blind community. He has several people who help out with broadcasting their own shows. Jonathan has his own popular show every weekday called Mosen Explosion which features music and other items of interest. Jonathan pays much of the cost of running the station, and community members help out when needed. To tune into this station:
    First, double tap on the Triode app to get it running. Next, feel across the bottom of the screen until you find a Find a Station tab. Double tap this. Once you're in this tab, feel near the top of the screen to find a search field. Double tap this and enter "Mushroom FM" in the field. Even if you just enter "Mushroom", you should find it among the search results. Flick right through the results and then double tap on the one you want to hear. It should start playing. Be certain to examine the playing screen that pops up and add Mushroom FM to your favourites. You can learn more and check out the schedule to find shows that interest you by visiting www.mushroomfm.com.
The TuneIn Radio App
Another very popular app is TuneIn Radio. This app can be used to listen to stations for free. One can also keep a list of favourite stations. When used in free mode, listeners will hear advertising that is above and beyond that normally heard on the stations themselves. These ads are inserted by TuneIn Radio, and revenue from them helps maintain the app and extensive station directory. This directory is also used by many other services such as Google, Siri, and Amazon, allowing them to play radio stations found in the TuneIn directory.
    If listeners want to ditch the ads that clutter the screen of the app as well as one's ears, they can pay for a subscription. This will remove the ads and offer other benefits. These include tuning into sports broadcasts, reading a selection of audiobooks, and more. The app is well laid out and presents no known difficulties to blind people when it comes to accessibility.
    For people in the UK, the RNIB offers many services. One of these is a radio station available online. To listen to RNIB Connect Radio, launch the TuneIn Radio app. Next, double tap on the Search button found near the bottom right of the home screen. You'll then find a search field where you can enter "RNIB". In addition to the station itself, RNIB makes the shows available as podcasts. TuneIn Radio can be used to subscribe to and hear podcasts if desired. However, there's a heading in the results called Stations. Underneath that heading, you'll find the RNIB Connect station. Rather than feeling beneath a heading, you can simply flick right past the heading and onto the contents underneath. Double tap on the RNIB Connect station, and it will begin playing. You can add it to your favourites if you wish.
Further Notes on Listening to Internet Radio
When tuning in via the Internet, keep in mind that there are times when technical issues will make stations temporarily unavailable. Don't give up on a station just because it doesn't happen to connect. It may just be down temporarily. The fault could be with the Internet generally or with the specific carrier or server that hosts the station you want to hear. Also, these are typically small operations. The broadcasters or owners may be experiencing difficulties.
    The list of favourite stations below doesn't even begin to scratch the surface of what's available. Traditional broadcasters, large corporations, and all kinds of enthusiasts make a staggeringly broad range of stations available. These can be heard using the apps covered above, or simply through your Internet browser of choice. Most of these stations have their own websites where you can learn more about them. For instance, you can find their broadcast schedules and what shows are available. Also, you will usually be able to find out about the broadcasters and other people behind the station. Most of them are run by people with their own agendas and interests. They are happy to be contacted by their listeners and will respond to inquiries or comments.
    Another excellent thing to look into is whether your local public radio service has produced apps that help you explore their offerings. For Canadians, the CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) has produced a wonderfully accessible app called CBC Listen. This app lets you tune into their live radio stations from across the country. Also, it has separate tabs for exploring a range of music playlists and a growing number of podcasts. You can also hear your favourite radio shows on demand if you happen to miss them. It's a very well-built app, and they've put in the effort to make certain that users of VoiceOver have an easy and enjoyable time.
    Over in Britain, the BBC has made a similar app called BBC Sounds. They are world-famous for audio drama production as well as wonderful comedy, among a great deal else. They also deeply care about their blind audience. Any apps they produce will be accessible to VoiceOver.
    In the US, the NPR (National Public Radio), is the closest equivalent that I'm aware of to our CBC. They have also produced an app to help people enjoy their audio offerings that include some incredible podcasts. You can find the NPR app in the app store.
    If you enjoy any other terrestrial radio stations that you hear locally or while travelling elsewhere, use Siri or one of the apps discussed above to search for it. You may find that it's available as an online broadcast. I was thrilled to discover that a favourite local news source, CP24, was available as an audio stream online. I used to tune in regularly while I had a TV, and it was one of a very few channels I've ever actually missed since I stopped watching TV. Having the audio available through Siri or the iHeart Radio app, among others, was a very pleasant surprise.
    The RadioPlayer Canada app has a directory of over four hundred radio stations, which are part of a collective group that sponsored the development of this app. AMI Audio can be heard on it as well as on other Internet radio apps.
Favourite Internet Radio Stations:
Here are some other wonderful Internet radio stations you might enjoy listening to. These are not in any particular order. I've certainly appreciated them over the years and hope to continue finding more stations. Keep exploring for yourself and share what you discover with others.
    680 News Radio:
    This station is also known as "city news radio". It's a twenty-four-hour news station on the AM dial and available in much better sound quality via the web. Normally, it cycles through brief checks on headlines, weather, traffic and other categories. You never have to wait long for something you're interested in being updated about. It also breaks from this pattern to carry live events like important press conferences. A very handy way to catch up with what's happening in a hurry.
    Team FM
    www.team-fm.com
    This station is run by blind music enthusiasts who want to put a positive spin on things. They share their knowledge in-between endless good music from all eras. It's all about creating a positive, cheerful community for these folks.
    Radio Rivendell
    www.radiorivendell.com
    If you've ever wished that your life had an epic soundtrack to go along with it, this is the station for you. It plays a constant stream of instrumental music from movies and video games. It leans heavily in the fantasy adventure direction. A lot of the music is from video game and movie scores, and they also feature independent instrumental composers. I've rarely disliked more than one song in a row that they've played. This station makes for a great background while writing or playing a tabletop RPG with your friends.
    Cornucopia Radio
    www.cornucopia-radio.co.uk
    Based in England, this group goes to different local venues to record audio dramas. They employ local talent and also make use of voice actors from all over the world. The range of material streamed on this station is tremendous. It's all fun and mostly quirky.
    Mushroom FM and Mushroom Escape
    www.mushroomfm.com
    I've already discussed Mushroom FM above. However, it's so spectacular that it deserves another mention. There's no better place for that than right here where I also tell you about its companion station Mushroom Escape. This station brings you a steady stream of classic and modern audio drama and comedy. Run by enthusiasts who deeply care about audio entertainment, you'll find lots to laugh at and think about whenever you need an escape.
Podcasts: Fascinating and Portable Stimulation:
I've enjoyed podcasts for years now, just about as long as I've enjoyed Internet radio. However, while I can clearly remember the first Internet radio station I ever listened to, I can't say the same for podcasts. I strongly suspect that it would have been the Main Menu show, which was made into a podcast that I first heard on ACB Radio. This show and podcast is still being produced today, well over ten years after I first came across it.
    Unlike radio stations, podcasts aren't heard live. They are audio files of complete episodes or shows published on RSS feeds online. They're great for when you don't really want to dig into a book or can't afford to. If I'm going on a trip or might be offline for a while, I'll be certain to download a bunch, so I have lots to listen to. I've often been surprised at just how much excellent listening gets put out there and completely escapes mainstream notice.
    There's no regulation when it comes to podcasts. Absolutely anything goes. Ordinary people can just decide to record podcasts on their computer or smartphone and stick them out there through a podcast hosting company. Some popular podcasts are sponsored or produced by companies as advertising vehicles. It's a very diverse and wide world to explore. Gifted amateurs frequently end up building massive, loyal audiences just as large or larger than corporate-produced efforts. Word about exceptional listening does seem to spread.
    To listen to podcasts, you need a podcast player. Apple has provided you with one that is included in iOS. We will cover it in detail along with related settings found in the Settings app. There are many suitable alternatives in the app store. We'll look at three of these.
    A quick note of podcast terminology: Apple has begun to differentiate between "following" podcasts versus "subscribing" to them. This is an attempt to draw a helpful distinction between podcasts you "follow" and listen to freely versus those podcasts you need to pay a subscription in order to hear. There is an increasing amount of such paid content which goes well beyond that offered through Apple's Podcast Plus service. More podcast creators are asking for paid subscriptions to cover their costs, rather than relying entirely on sponsors or voluntary donations. In exchange, subscribers typically receive perks like having no advertisements interrupting the podcasts or early access to episodes. Outside of Apple's Podcast Plus service, people would typically visit the website of a podcast in order to find the means to subscribe. They would then get a link in their email to a special feed meant for subscribers only.
