Unlike previous generations of students, the advent of social media means that you're never safe from bullying. It will follow you home. Those photos or videos made while a relationship is fresh and enthralling may prove inescapable after a breakup occurs. Ill-considered remarks about others, or even one's particular taste in popular music or shows might one day prove ammunition for bullying. Even if you deleted your account from every social media platform on which you had been bullied, other people could still spread false or harmful information about you. People of all ages have had their lives turned into nightmares by total strangers who spot an opportunity for sadistic fun. This has driven some people to take their own lives.
    I hope the preceding paragraphs have given you an inkling of the possible negative aspects of social media that you may well encounter. Overall, my experience has been a very positive one. Part of the reason for that is the care I've taken to use these services responsibly. To be even better informed about these online dangers, I would urge you to read the following two books:
    Extreme Mean: Ending Cyber abuse at Work, School, and Home by Paula Todd
    So You've Been Publicly Shamed by Jon Ronson
Defensive Measures:
There are things you can do to minimize any damage you might experience through using social media. Different platforms will offer their own unique options and tools to guard your information, and you should take the time to become familiar with these. Meanwhile, I can offer you the following more general advice:
    It's all about keeping your own sense of intrinsic self-worth foremost in your mind. Also, know who the important people in your life are. What they think of you is far more critical than what people you've never even met in person think of you. Don't be unkind or dismissive to people who you associate with online, but don't let their feelings or problems swallow you up.
    All platforms will have options to block and unfollow people who cause you distress. Don't be afraid to use these options. Other people are equally free to do likewise to you. Remember, also, that your time is valuable. Don't feel that you are under any kind of obligation to become involved in drama if you would rather not be.
X:
https://x.com
    X, formerly known as Twitter, is a network that focusses on brief messages between people. Public messages are limited to 280 characters. Private messages can be up to 10,000 characters. Businesses use X for advertising, as do political leaders. Due to the limitation on the length of a single public tweet, conversations tend to be ongoing casual ones or very concise debates. People often try to fit everything into one tweet, which can lead to misunderstandings. There's a lot of "stream of consciousness" discussion, where people don't always think carefully about what they tweet. X is a great place to get technical help, since you can ask publicly in a short tweet and then exchange longer private messages with people you follow who also follow you.
    From a learning curve perspective, X is becoming more of a challenge for beginners. It used to be my first pick for a recommendation. However, things have changed markedly since Twitter rebranded to X after it was purchased. People who once helped to keep Twitter safe and accessible have been fired. As a direct consequence, there is much less of a chance that problems which people encounter in both areas of experience will be addressed quickly or effectively. Over time, as changes are made to X with the goals of making money and improving the experience for users without disabilities, people who require accessibility tools like VoiceOver are finding things becoming more difficult.
    Despite these changes, the core strengths of X remain present. The platform makes it easy to find out about and connect with people who have similar interests. The platform is still very widely used, so most news organizations, companies, celebrities, and others maintain a presence on the platform. I've had some truly excellent conversations and online community experiences thanks to X. Attending a virtual end-of-world party and observing how people reacted to Harold Camping's prediction of doomsday was absolutely fascinating. On X, you get to know people slowly over time as they post short messages about their lives, ask questions, etc. One day, you may suddenly realize you have become online friends and actually care about how things are going for someone you will likely never meet in person. X allows you to be more in tune with what's happening in the world in a very personal way.
    X started out as a website. You can still use it in your browser of choice rather than using an app at all. The site has been made accessible for screen readers. As further adjustments are made to the X app for iOS and to the platform over all, people might very well find that the website is easier to use than the app, or the other way around as time moves on. Once you've mastered how to surf the web using a browser, you should see if the website gives you a better means of navigating.
    The elimination of staff responsible for safety and accessibility has already had numerous frightful results. A good example is a journalist who works for the Toronto Star. She found herself personally attacked with private information, including her bank account credentials and home address, being made public by people angry with her published opinion columns. People at X have been so unsupportive that the person who controls her account is free to keep using it to cause harm while she has left the platform she once loved. People have little chance that false accusations or hate directed towards them will be addressed or removed. Personally, I've worked hard to block objectionable people and used all of the tools still available for people to protect themselves. The minutes of effort spent blocking and reporting spam and abusive comments that I've put in over the years probably add up to hours of unpleasant effort. Despite that extensive effort, I still come across far more hateful messages and material I don't wish to read in my timeline whenever I check on my X timeline these days. As a result, this is growing less frequent. Additionally, if you are unwilling to pay a monthly feee, you are now exposed to video and audio advertisements which are streamed to you as you used the service. This can make it harder to understand what you're reading if you rely on speech output.
    More recently, users of the X app have found that it has become necessary to double tap on a post to go into its area before you can read it. All that you hear as you flick through postings on your home timeline is the name of the account which the post was written with.
    The unfortunate changes made to X have yet to result in the utter meltdown that a lot of us predicted. The app is still mainly accessible. It remains a viable platform which is easy to join. Although people have sought alternatives, there are still enough users to make it worth continuing to have a presence on. The service recommends followers with similar interests or things in their profiles so it can be easier to find new similarly minded people to engage with. You just have to be willing to ignore the increased lack of safety measures or investment in accessibility and have a thick skin.
    To use the X service, you'll need to create an account. You can do this from within the app or from the website. You'll need to give X your email address and a password. You would also be wise to set up security by giving it your phone number so that if the need arises, it can provide you a code via text message that will verify your identity. If someone hacks your account and learns your password, this verification can help tremendously when attempting to recover control of your account.
The X App:
There are five tabs across the bottom of the app. From left to right, they are Home, Search and Explore, grok, Notifications, and Messages. At the top left of every tab screen, you'll find a button called User Menu. That provides access to a menu of things affecting the user experience. There are settings, access to your user profile, and many more options. This is followed by a heading informing you which tab you're in. This isn't the case in the Search and Explore tab, where there's a search field in place of a heading. To the right of that heading, things change depending on which tab you're in. Any controls or options will be found near the top left of a tab screen.
    The Home tab is where your timeline is displayed. This includes new tweets from people you have chosen to follow. You can flick left and right to have tweets read out to you. There are also recommended tweets and recommendations on people to follow. Near the heading at the top of the tab screen, you'll find a Compose Tweet button. Past that, you'll encounter your timeline, which can scroll infinitely. If you read a tweet you want to examine more closely, double tap on it with one finger. This opens the tweet and also shows you the thread that the tweet is a part of, including any replies made to it. You can also double tap with two fingers on a tweet. This is called a "magic tap" gesture, which can perform different functions in different apps as required. This overrides the normal function of this tap, which is to pause or resume playback. While in the X app, a two-finger double tap will activate a menu, giving quick access to commonly used X functions such as Reply, Retweet, Like, etc. Flick right through the options.
    To compose a tweet, double tap on the Compose Tweet button at the top of the Home tab. You will then be put in the tweet composition screen. There, you'll find an edit field to type your 280 characters. You'll be automatically placed in it. When finished typing, flick right, and you'll find all sorts of options to add photos, broadcast video, etc. The tweet button used to send your tweet into the world is found in the bottom-right corner of the composition screen.
    The Search and Explore tab is where you can look for people or tweets of interest. The rotor set to Headings is your friend here, as you can quickly get to different exploration facilities. There are headings for Today's Moments, Trends for You, a Connect button, and many more items of possible interest. You can't do any harm by looking around.
    The Notifications tab is where you'll find any mentions of you, as well as other notifications like tweets from people you want to be certain you see. Also, if anybody follows you, Likes or Retweets a tweet you send, etc., this will be recorded in the Notifications tab. It's a good idea to check every so often for new notifications. At the top left of the tab, you can find the Notifications Settings button, where you can customize what you're notified about.
    To send a message, you can use the New Message button at the top left of the tab screen. You will be placed in the area where you specify who the message is sent to. You can use the search field or flick right through an alphabetical list of your followed Twitter contacts who follow you back. You may send private messages to these contacts. Otherwise, you must communicate with public messages until you follow each other. Private messages are limited to 10,000 characters. This can be tremendously helpful when clearing up misunderstandings or offering technical help.
    Once a conversation has started, you can double tap on a tweet with one finger to enter that thread, whether it's a private one in the Messages tab or a public one. At that point, you're examining the whole thread. Flick left or right through the tweets. There will be a text field near the bottom right where you can add to the thread by replying. Double tapping on a tweet within a thread will focus specifically on that tweet and any replies to it.
    You can easily get back out of these threads. In the top-left corner, there will always be a Back button. In other circumstances, like when you're in the composition screen and want to leave it, look at the top left for a Close button. You're never trapped anywhere. There's always a Cancel, Back, or Close button at the top left to get you back to the main screens of X.
    The latest addition is the "grok" tab. This gives people who pay X to subscribe for extra perks access to an artificial intelligence called Grok. I have no idea how useful this feature is. Nor do I have any plans to pay a cent to the company in order to find out.
Mastodon:
https://joinmastodon.org
    This social media platform was created as an alternative to ad supported algorithm-driven networks. It was designed to be open source. This means that anybody can contribute to and examine the software programming. It is also decentralized. Instead of a collection of central servers, anyone who wants to put in the time can run their own server or instance, as they're often called. An instance is like an email provider. People can choose to create an account on any instance open to the public. They are able to migrate to a different instance if they later decide that its rules and facilities are a better fit for their needs.
    No single individual or company can wreck Mastodon as has happened with X. Communities and people who want a safe and respectful environment are free to create that. Also, third-party apps which are made for Mastodon can't be rendered useless to their users by a company. Free from corporate pressures and advertising, this makes for a far better environment in all sorts of ways.
    Having no system pushing people and content at you does put more work on individuals who want to be found and followed. Once you've created an account on a server, you should create a profile. This is what you want potential followers of your posts to know about you in order to decide whether to contact or follow you. Hashtags are a common feature in Mastodon profiles. Basically, it's a hash mark or number sign followed immediately by a word. Multiword hashtags are possible, but there can't be any spaces between the words. Often, people make hashtags out of their interests. I like to read and also am interested in technology. Therefore, my profile contains these words with the hashtag or number sign symbol, the shifted number three, immediately before them. This increases the chances that someone searching for users who share my interests will find my profile. Some sentences about yourself an a hashtag list of your interests should serve you well.
    In addition to a profile, most people will also do an introductory post where they introduce themselves and perhaps expand on information found in their profile. Over time, people will find your posts and may decide to follow you. You always have the option to block them, follow them back, etc. You can decide to protect your account so that people need to request to follow you, and you must approve their request before they can follow you.
    While users have ultimate say in who can follow them and how public their posts are, much of the Mastodon experience is shaped at the level of the instance the user chooses to join. The individual or group who provide each instance can decide what rules people must follow. A major difference between instances is how many characters an individual post can contain. Most instances have rules around things like hate speech. Some might insist on people discussing topics which might offend others put content warnings on their posts where appropriate. It's purely up to the people in charge of the instance you join to enforce their rules. There is no higher level of authority.
    Instances are linked together into what is known as the fediverse. You don't have to belong to the same instance as someone else in order to follow them and exchange posts. Think of instances like email providers. I use Gmail and can freely correspond with friends using Hotmail. Nothing stops people from creating instances where hateful and offensive content is encouraged. However, such instances will find themselves blocked off and isolated from other instances wanting to foster a safer more welcoming environment. I have yet to come across a truly hateful post in all my time on Mastodon.
The Mastodon App:
The Mastodon app for iOS has been well-designed. Clearly, accessibility was a consideration from the beginning. Although not as feature rich as alternative apps found in the app store for using Mastodon, the basic app is free and sufficient for most casual users.
    There are five tabs across the bottom. These are, from left to right, "Home", "Search and Explore", "Compose", "Notifications" and "Profile". The "Home" tab is where you'll find your timeline with messages from newest to oldest. Each message is preceded by its creator's username, how long ago the message appeared, and then the post itself. There doesn't seem to be any way to sort these posts into alternative order by various criteria. 
    Rotor actions let you easily reply to, boost, follow links in, and favourite posts. Double tapping on a post would put you in the thread, which you can add to via the reply button found at the top just before the first post.
    The "Search an Explore" tab lets you do precisely that and find people who share your interests. You'll find a search field as well as buttons for browsing people, hashtags, news, and "for you". Hashtags are important on Mastodon. People use them to indicate what they're interested in. Type a name, hashtag, or keywords into the search field. Alternatively, you can double tap on the Posts, Hashtags, News and For You buttons and see what appears. This gives you the ability to see what's trending and popular at the moment. The News button focuses in on accounts from news organizations who have decided to have a presence on Mastodon. The For You button takes you to a list of accounts which seem to match with your interests as determined by what you've previously indicated by your actions on Mastodon, such as the accounts you've followed or hashtags you've searched. You'll need to do more work searching for and finding people to follow. However, nothing you aren't interested in will get pushed at you. 
    The Compose tab is where you can create posts of your own. Double tapping on the tab will put you automatically in the edit field, ready to start typing or pasting. You can use the button to the left of the edit field to set your post's privacy level. Public is the default. Meanwhile, to the right of the edit field, you'll find other options to add emoji, add a pole for people to participate in, put a content warning on your post if it's offensive or controversial, etc. Nothing stops you from posting links if it suits you. How many characters you have per post depends on the instance you decided to create an account on. You can attach pictures and add alt text to describe them for blind followers. If you go past your character limit, you cannot publish your post until you rectify this.
    The notifications tab is where you can view and act on any notifications you receive. You'll be notified when people reply to your posts, follow you, mention you, etc. You can choose which things you want to be notified of in the settings found on the home or Profile tabs. One of the areas in those settings is called notifications.
    The Profile tab at the far right is where you can edit and create your profile. This is also where you can manage which hashtags you intend to follow, manage your lists of people you follow and those who you allow to follow you. You can also access the app settings, create an avatar photo which people can see, etc. You have a lot of latitude crammed into that tab.
    This should be enough to get you started using the Mastodon app. It's freely available in the app store. For a far more customizable premium experience, I recommend people try an app called Mona. I've been very impressed with its ease of use, accessibility and all of the abilities it gives you to make your Mastodon experience uniquely suited to your needs.
YouTube:
This popular service makes it possible for anyone to create their own channel where they can publish videos they create which don't violate intellectual copyright and other laws. You can use all sorts of different cameras and gear to produce and edit these videos before you upload them to YouTube. Alternatively, you can do it all with just your iPhone, the YouTube app, and a tripod or stand to keep your iPhone's camera steady.
    People have created videos about pretty much everything. There are videos about various products, game reviews, videos demonstrating how to do things, amateur horror series, video blogs about life experiences, and much more. If people attract a high enough viewer count, they can make money from their content as YouTube can put advertisements in the content which non-subscribers must watch in order to see the rest of the video.
    You don't need to create videos in order to participate. Many people, myself included, have never created a video. However, people are able to leave written comments about the videos. They can also indicate whether they like to dislike them, share links to them, and choose to subscribe to the channel of their creators. Subscribing to a YouTube channel doesn't incur a fee. It simply causes you to be notified of new videos a creator makes and have their content fed into your personal YouTube timeline.
    It is possible to get a more premium YouTube experience free of ads and with other perks by paying for a YouTube premium subscription. One of my favourite perks such payments grant you is the ability to play YouTube videos and have them continue playing in the background while you use other apps. This lets me take notes while listening to videos about new features introduced by Apple. I might hear a video about an influencer's top twenty horror books of all time and create a list of any which interest me in the Notes app while doing so. I might then write a comment about whether I agree or disagree with conclusions drawn in the video. Thanks to YouTube, I have some idea what's actually inside my iPhone from hearing videos from a channel called JeryRigEverything. I learned what it's like to design and manufacture a backpack from a channel called Nomads Nation. Through another channel called John and Heather's Dementia Journey, I've gotten glimpses into what life is like for a loving husband who finally reached a point of moving his wife who suffers from dementia into a care facility. I know what it sounds like to be on a cargo ship at sea, be in an emergency room during the pandemic, and countless other situations I'm unlikely to ever be in personally. I believe I'm a more thoughtful fellow for all that. It can be enlightening to read comments made about the videos and be able to ask questions of their creators.
    Of course, like other forms of social media, YouTube can be addictive. It's easy to while away many hours watching video after video. Don't think for a moment that I haven't ever done that. Also, there can be cruelty. There are videos which express and encourage hateful behaviour. Additionally, people can be unbelievably cruel with their comments about videos. You should go in prepared for that reality. Unlike other social media platforms, YouTube has rules governing both videos being created and comments. Users can report bad behaviour and action may be taken. Creators of videos and offensive users have been banned. Occasionally, this happens through artificial intelligence rather than human moderators. Find out more by going to:
    https://m.youtube.com
The YouTube App:
I've had the YouTube app on my iPhone for a very long time now. Google owns this platform, and they have done an impressive job making the app accessible using VoiceOver. There's a whole-lot of content and plenty of settings and options, making for busy full screens to navigate. We won't be doing an exhaustive tour of this app. There's frankly too much to cover in that manner. However, I'll share some aspects which I've found important and give an overview of what you'll find in each tab. There is often more than fits on one screen, so scrolling through with the vertical bar down the right side or with three fingered swipes up and down will be something you do a lot.
    There are five tabs across the bottom of the app. They are Home, Shorts, Create, Subscriptions and You. By far, I spend most of my time on the Home tab. It contains the content which YouTube's algorithm thinks will possibly interest you. This is your YouTube feed or timeline. Before you get to that timeline, you'll find a bunch of useful things at the top of the screen. This includes a search button which lets you get to a search field where you can type in what interests you. You'll also find a "notifications" button, which takes you to any notifications about new videos made by creators whose channels you follow or whose videos you've liked. A series of other buttons let you filter videos by subject. I often use one called "New to you" which clears away any previously watched content.
    Your timeline consists of videos, with the name and length of each video followed by a button to go to the channel of its creator. There's also a button to take other actions, including reporting a video for rules violations. Double tap on a video's title to start watching it. There are headings on the timeline, but they're too far apart to make use of the headings rotor. You're better off scrolling with three fingered swipes up and down to get near where you want to be. There's a lot of clutter, including images and other things which can be found between videos. Accessible, but somewhat unwieldy.
    Once you go to a channel, you can find tabs letting you focus on videos, playlists, and other aspects of the channel. Double tap on the tab which interest you and explore. Playlists are related collections of videos. You can play them sequentially, jump to specific ones, etc. Take the time to subscribe to channels of interest. It's easy to forget about them if no new content appears for a while.
    After double tapping on a video to play it, new control buttons appear. There's a button to play and pause. To the left and right of that are buttons to rewind or fast-forward by ten second intervals. To the left and right of those two buttons are ones letting you skip to the previous or next video. You'll find a new but†on at the very top left of the screen, letting collapse the video so that the timeline is back taking up most of the screen. The video is still open at the very bottom, where you can find a button to close it, as well as a play/pause button.
    Some videos are live events and there'll be a chat window which appears letting people type into the communal text chat available for people watching the event. My church makes their services available online in this way. If I'm unable to attend in person, it's nice to have this option.
    The Shorts tab is where to find very short videos typically lasting seconds. Creators can briefly show a product or aspect of what they do, and people can then go to their channel to find more lengthy content. I have no use for these shorts and think they do nothing but cause clutter.
    The Create tab will open a dialogue box with all sorts of creation tools. The record button is on the bottom right. You can choose the recording mode, including live-streaming. You can add audio tracks if you wish. Having never created a video myself, I recommend that you find a mentor who has. Also, be certain to check the help available in the YouTube settings. You'll find these in the "You" tab at the far right. The settings button is near the top of that tab. The help and policies can be found at the bottom of all the settings. There are many totally blind content creators.
    The Subscriptions tab lets you manage the channels you've selected to subscribe to. It also makes for an easy way to get to those channels directly rather than using the buttons by videos posted to them. You'll be able to see which channels have new content. You can also unsubscribe from channels. So far, I haven't had any reason to do this. I appreciate the ability to drill down into channels I haven't checked in on for a while and quickly see what's new.
    The "You" tab is where you can manage your own channel if you choose to become a creator. You can also access the settings and help in those settings. Another button allows you to manage your account with YouTube. You can turn on incognito mode, which protects your privacy. I haven't made much use of this tab other than to use the settings. However, if you want to become a YouTube creator and post videos, I would encourage you to take the time to poke around this area and know what's available.
Facebook:
Facebook is a very popular social media platform that has become extremely well known and widely used. People can send messages, talk, post text or video updates to their own personal news feeds to keep friends and family informed and write comments on each other's posts. There are many games and apps specifically written for Facebook to increase social interaction and use of the service. This makes Facebook quite an expansive and complex service to become familiar with. It's trying to be the one-stop shop for social interaction. In doing this, it has become rather complex. If you can master Facebook to the point where you're comfortable with it, you should have a pretty easy time of most other things you might choose to attempt on your iOS device.
    Facebook sells data it collects as users take advantage of the Facebook service. People indicate approval of things like videos and messages by "liking" them. This quickly gives Facebook a great deal of information about the preferences, interests, and habits of its users. The data is useful to many corporations. In effect, you are the product. Businesses also take advantage of its popularity and extensively advertise on the service. The more Facebook can succeed in constantly keeping people using their service, the more money is made through advertising and sponsorships.
    Overall, Facebook is currently doing a good job of making its app and website accessible to blind users. They're very aware of their blind audience and eager to be known as an accessible service. Recently, they've started adding automatic descriptions to photos using artificial intelligence. You can hear them as you come to them in your news feed. To learn more about accessibility on Facebook, check out www.facebook.com/accessibility.
    Facebook has decided to split the many things you can do on Facebook into two separate apps. Think of the Facebook app as your public presence. You can look at peoples' news feeds, or post messages or videos to your own news feeds, comment on what other people post, etc. You can also interact with any Facebook groups you're a part of.
    Facebook Messenger is for more private communication between you and your Facebook contacts. It's quite a full-featured alternative to the far less complex messages app provided by Apple. Now, we will look at each of these apps in turn. However, be aware that they have undergone radical changes as Facebook seeks to define and differentiate itself from competing social media platforms. These apps may change at any point in time. The best overall advice I can give is to explore thoroughly, so you're aware of your options.
The Facebook App:
As of late 2019, there are six tabs across the bottom of the screen. These are News Feed, Friends, Your Profile, Groups, Notifications, and Facebook Menu. All of these are important to become familiar with. Rather than exhaustively describing everything in each tab, I'll give an overview of what you can do there. You can take time to look around using VoiceOver and figure the specifics out as you need them.
    News Feed
    You start out in the News Feed tab. Here, you can view your feed as well as the feeds of your friends. Any stories, photos, videos, etc. can be interacted with. Flick left and right through the various posts. A post will be automatically fully read without you having to do anything as you flick onto it. But wait. To read a post more carefully, double tap on it with one finger. This lets you read it, making use of VoiceOver gestures. Also, you can see how other people have commented and reacted to the post. Double tapping with two fingers takes you to some quick ways to react to the post. Additionally, flicking up or down on a post will go through a menu of options. Have VoiceOver Hints enabled so that you can take advantage of all the helpful hints Facebook has included. Near the top left, there are buttons for using your camera, searching through feeds to find items of interest, and much more.
    Friends
    This tab is all about responding to friend requests made by others, as well as finding people you may wish to request friendship with. You'll find a People You May Know heading, beneath which is a list of people Facebook considers it likely that you might want to interact with. Near the top, you'll find buttons to filter requests and who appears within this tab. For instance, you may remove people from the group Facebook suggests you may want to be friends with. Invitations to groups or events may also appear in this tab.
Your Profile:
Here is where you can create and edit your Facebook profile. This consists of information about you that others may or may not be able to see, depending on your privacy choices. You can use your device's camera or a photo in your collection to add to your profile. This is a common practice among sighted people and will allow them to recognize you more easily.
    There are different sections to your profile, including public information that everyone can see, plus many other things. You can do far more than simply write a brief autobiographical description. Adding in details like your home city, schools attended, and other details will let other people who you might wish to contact find your profile more easily. It will also give Facebook's friend-finding algorithm more information to work with, resulting in better recommendations. Be certain that you think through what information you reveal to people. The options to take firm control of this are there, but few people take the time to learn what they can do in this area. Remember that your profile is not the same as your account, which is always private.
Groups:
In addition to friends and family, Facebook also offers extensive facilities for groups of people who share common interests. The Groups tab is where you can discover groups to join, create them, and invite others to join. You can post private messages to group members that nobody outside the groups may read. Additionally, you may start group chats and post events that others may indicate whether they can attend.
    Personally, I don't do a lot with groups. I belong to one open to those who attended a school for the blind. They schedule chats that take place on Skype, as well as hold group conversations about topics of common interest. There is also a group that was started as an offshoot of a show on CBC Radio called "Now or Never". Its purpose is to allow members to encourage and help each other with various dilemmas and problems in life. The name of this group is "You Got This".
Notifications:
This tab contains any notifications awaiting your attention. These can be any posts made to groups you're a member of, event invitations, and reminders from various apps connected to Facebook you may be using. You can flick left and right through the various notifications and double tap on them to interact with them and read more closely. This opens up any previous related notifications. From there, you can flick left or right to view different notifications related to the most current one you double tapped on. Flicking up or down while on a notification gives you a menu of options such as liking, commenting, etc.
    Notifications all gathered in one tab like this are especially useful if you don't check Facebook regularly. Finding Facebook somewhat cumbersome, I fit squarely in this category of people who grudgingly pop in occasionally. The Notifications tab has alerted me to a good many events and other things that I might easily have missed without it. This holds particularly true for inquiries, messages, and other things directed at me personally.
Facebook Menu:
This is a very packed place. You can flick through the options and also use the rotor to flick between headings. Also, you can do three-finger scrolls up or down to quickly move through the contents of the tab. This area lets you access all sorts of otherwise hidden places and settings on Facebook. There are options and things in here including apps, games, shortcuts, and more. The most important thing to be aware of is the settings. These let you customize many aspects of how Facebook behaves.
The Facebook Messenger App:
Facebook wanted to have an app that competed directly with other messaging apps from other social media platforms. It, therefore, created the Facebook Messenger app for audio and video communication between closely associated groups like friends and family or business employees. The original Facebook app focusses on more widely shared communication.
    There are three tabs across the bottom. They are Chats, People, and Discover.
Chats:
Everything in terms of controls is at the top of this tab. The Settings button is at the top left. You will also find a button called Camera, which lets you share photos. A search field lets you look for specific users or words within chats. There's a New Chat button, allowing you to start a chat. The rest of the tab contains any chats you may be involved in. They are in chronological order based on the latest communication. Explore the Settings button contents. There are all kinds of ways to configure Facebook Messenger.
    While you're in a conversation, you have numerous options. Near the top of the screen, you'll find options to initiate audio or video calls with other participants. You'll find messages in a chronological list going left to right, with the right end being the most recent. After these messages, there are more options like an audio composer, media picker, camera access, and others. There are also options like waving at other participants. It's a busy space in terms of options.
People:
This tab is for dealing with all of your contacts. Also, you can add new contacts. Every option is at the top of the screen. There are buttons to change your view between all contacts and those active on Facebook. You'll also find a search field to quickly find the person you want. Below these buttons, you'll find a complete list of your contacts in alphabetical order. The rotor is your friend again, since you can set it to headings and flick up and down between letters. Double tap on the contact you want, and options appear for contacting or editing the contact.
    This tab is where you can block people who bother you on Facebook Messenger. To accomplish this, open a conversation with the person you want to block. Double tap on their name at the top of the conversation, and you'll find an option to block them. Blocking someone in Facebook Messenger stops them from sending messages, but is different from blocking them on Facebook. To achieve that, use the Facebook app. It is also possible to unblock messages should circumstances change between you and someone who has bothered you.
    Discover
    This tab concerns itself with activities and advertisements that you might choose to take part in. There are all kinds of games. Also, businesses have Facebook pages that may show up here. This is particularly likely if your friends have expressed interest in what's on offer. Many of these will be more visual in nature. However, people who are interested may find this tab to be worth exploring.
    There is a button called For You near the top as well as one called Recent. Below are a whole bunch of links to pages, apps, and games.
Meetings With Zoom:
https://zoom.us
    This might be difficult to believe given the past couple of years, but the Zoom Cloud meeting platform was originally built for business people to conduct secure and orderly meetings on. Thanks to the pandemic, Zoom might now equally be regarded as a social platform helping all sorts of people to connect with each other. In fact, it has been such a big part of my social experience during the pandemic that I've chosen to include my subsection about Zoom in the larger social media section rather than productivity software.
    There are a number of accessible meeting platforms. Microsoft Teams is another popular example known to be accessible on iOS for VoiceOver users. For this guide, I will be focussing on Zoom in this subsection. Given its excellent accessibility and rise to social prominence, it seemed the best choice as an overall example. If you can master Zoom, you'll find many online events will be open to you. Skills used in Zoom meetings are transferable to other meeting platforms. Just keep in mind that they'll have different control setups and approaches to the same task of connecting people productively.
    You don't need a Zoom account to join a meeting. Simply entering the meeting information will suffice. Most commonly, you can simply click on a link and be guided through what you may need to do. If it's your first time using the Zoom app, you may need to give permission for it to make use of cameras and microphones. However, if you'll be using Zoom regularly, I recommend creating a basic Zoom account. It doesn't cost anything. You can create the account from within the app, or do it on the Zoom website. People seem to find the website account creation experience easier. Once you log in using the Zoom Cloud Meetings app, it will remember your credentials and put your name in automatically when you join meetings. You also get a personal meeting ID number. Also, you will be able to create meetings and invite others to join you.
    A basic account lets you have meetings of any length between yourself and one other person. This can be a useful way to freely connect with people to touch base, give tech help, etc. For meetings with three or more people, you are limited to forty minutes before the meeting ends. If you wish, you can pay a monthly or annual subscription for a Zoom Pro or Business account. These provide more meeting capacity and other features, letting you host larger groups of people. There are also add-ons such as audio conferencing which can be added to further enhance what Zoom will do for you. For most smaller groups which aren't businesses, the Pro account should be sufficient. This lets up to 100 people participate at a time in meetings, which can be up to 30 hours long.
    I'll leave it to you to explore the various possibilities Zoom offers to people wanting to host conversations, large and small. In this subsection, we'll focus on what you should know in order to participate well in Zoom meetings using the Zoom Cloud Meetings app. Signing up for your account will be the first thing to do. For this, you'll need to be familiar with a web browser like Safari. Nothing says you need to sign up for a Zoom account using your iPhone. You can use a computer to do this if you feel more comfortable. The form to create an account is quite accessible. Once you've completed and submitted it, you'll receive an email with a link in it to verify that you do indeed want the Zoom account linked with that email. Once you've verified your email, the account will be active. You can then open the Zoom Cloud Meetings app and log into your new account.
    Let's explore the Zoom app while you're not in a meeting. There are four tabs across the bottom. At the far left is "meet and chat". This tab lets you join and create meetings. Unless you've paid for a Zoom room, the "start chat" button near the top of the tab won't be active. However, buttons to join, create and schedule meetings will be available and can be used. Simple double tap the option you want and then flick right to find any edit fields to be filled in or controls to set. You shouldn't have any trouble if you have a basic grasp of web browsing and using VoiceOver.
    The next tab is "Meetings". At the very top, you'll find controls letting you start a personal meeting and invite people to it. There's also a refresh button near the top of the tab. That button will refresh the list of any upcoming meetings, which occupies the rest of this tab. Double tap on a meeting in the list to reach a menu of options for that meeting. The very last one on the menu is the option to join. However, you'll also find buttons letting you change the date and time or edit the name of the meeting.
    The "Contacts" tab comes next. You can add and manage contacts here. It's possible to connect your list of phone contacts to your Zoom contact list. Alternatively, you can keep the list of contacts you want to communicate via Zoom with separate from your other contacts. I haven't made any use of this tab whatsoever.
    The final tab at the bottom right is called "settings". Here is where you can configure the app. The first button in this tab lets you create an account or sign in with an account you have already made. Enter your email and password, or do whatever procedure is required. I have my Zoom app set to let me use Face ID to log into my account. Once logged in, that first button in the "settings" tab will be labelled with your email. There are buttons in that account area to update your password, set your location and other things. Many of these won't be useable for people using basic accounts, but may work if you've paid for a pro account.
    There are other groups of settings in the tab. You'll find buttons you can double tap to reach areas about meetings, chats, contacts, and general settings. You can also create Siri shortcuts. There's quite a bit of depth to the Zoom app. I encourage you to look through all the options in Zoom settings, even though you don't really need them for basic participation. One thing you should do in the account area is set your display name. This will automatically be used when you join meetings. I use my real name. However, nothing says you have to.
    Once you've joined a meting or chat, none of those tabs are accessible. Another set of controls pops up for use while in meetings. At the bottom of the screen, there-are three buttons. These are "share content", "participants", and "more". Above these buttons, you'll find buttons letting you leave the meeting, get meeting information, start or stop sharing your video, mute or unmute your audio. People who set up meetings can decide whether people start with audio or video started or stopped. You should also know that hosts of meetings can take actions such as muting all participants, rejecting unruly guests, etc. Screen content can also be shared. However, this doesn't seem to be accessible to VoiceOver as far as I've experienced.
    Once you double tap the "share content", "participants" or "more" buttons, you'll be taken to a set of options which pertain to that button. The participants button will let you look at a list of all participants and also gives access to other options. You'll use this button often. The same is true for the "more" button. That gives you a series of options including making visual gestures, accessing the text chat, and much more. While chatting via text, you can still hear any audio proceedings which might be happening.
    Sometimes, hosts of meetings will set up breakout rooms. These allow for smaller, separate conversations to take place during larger meetings. Such rooms are also a common feature during Zoom conferences you might attend.
    Zoom is one of these popular cross-platform products which you could probably write a book about all on its own. In fact, this has been done. Sadly, that book which was so very helpful at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic has been rendered obsolete due to this rapid continuing evolution. Zoom achieved explosive growth, which they initially weren't at all prepared for. Gaming groups, school classes, friends, and families all jumped onboard Zoom when lockdowns started. As a result, Zoom had to quickly become more robust and secure. I hope that this subsection gives you enough of a grasp of Zoom so that you can feel comfortable participating in any conversations, events, meetings, or classes offered on the service. Many blindness organizations such as the CNIB continue to offer opportunities for pier supported learning and discussion via Zoom. These events can be very useful, particularly for people who are new to this technology or coming to grips with vision loss. Perhaps, you might even host your own online events.
Social Media Conclusions:
As with so many things, the pandemic has left its mark on social media platforms and what we think of it overall. Efforts to satisfy our need for connection with friends and loved ones during lockdowns have thrown developers of these platforms into high gear and given them the resources to thrive. People have also become far more aware of the systemic problems inherent in how these platforms are economically driven to maximize attention, even at the cost of cohesive society. I'm very hopeful that this mass exposure has planted the seeds for positive changes going forward. Many people have witnessed the damage that careless words and intentional attempts to divide people can result in. At the same time, people have also directly experienced many of the positive aspects of social media, as it helped keep us in contact with those we care about in a safe manner.
    For blind people, having many conferences, work opportunities and public events go virtual has been paradoxically liberating and empowering. I have attended several large events, including the virtual version of the Word On The Street festival, which I was once able to attend in person. I must say that it was far less expensive and easier to navigate independently as a virtual event. I thoroughly enjoyed the discussions, but must confess to missing that irreplaceable sensation of being with so many people who shared my love for books.
    I think it's safe to say that social media will be a large presence either indirectly or directly in modern life for the foreseeable future. Even if you don't participate in it yourself, you would be hard-pressed to avoid being affected by others whose thoughts, assumptions, and opinions have been affected by discussions on social media platforms. To help you decide how best to engage with social media, or whether you actually want to, here are some more of my own experiences with it:
    Every so often, as a single unemployed fellow, you find yourself facing a long holiday weekend when it seems like everyone else has people to be with and somewhere to go. That was the case for me on the Thanksgiving weekend of 2010. Three days of everyone else being busy and elsewhere. Three days of absolutely alone time with no reason to go anywhere. For people leading hectic, busy lives, that's often described as paradise. If, however, you feel like you've tried absolutely everything within your capabilities to contribute meaningfully, but nobody seems to care, that kind of empty long weekend can be soul crushing. No amount of solitary entertainments can fill the gaping hole left by having no friends or a partner to hang out with. If you're lucky, they might be engaging enough for you to forget your solitude for a while.
    By Sunday evening, I had reached the point where there was literally nothing else to do but look in on social media before turning in. I decided to check Twitter on the off chance that someone who I followed had actually tweeted something interesting. That happened surprisingly more often than I initially thought it would. Being on X, you would learn about the lives and concerns of the people you followed, a little bit at a time. Eventually, much like dust in a room, these little pieces of thought, ranging from what they had to eat for lunch to some casual observation typed out just after the thought was formed, would build up over time into something quite meaningful. And then, one day, you'd come across another tweet from a follower and realize that you truly cared about how this person you had never met in real life was doing. You found yourself responding and making an effort to express your own thoughts or cheer him or her up or share a hopefully helpful bit of knowledge.
    My friends had basically press-ganged me into getting with the times and joining up. I was still pretty skeptical about how meaningful one could possibly be when tweets could only be 140 characters long. Looking through the timeline of tweets from people I followed, I was rewarded. Heather, a friend I knew back in secondary school, tweeted that the first trapped Chilean miner was coming up. I checked the timestamp on the tweet. It was only a couple of minutes old.
    A group of miners had been trapped underground for weeks by a collapse. I had been fascinated by the unfolding crisis in the news. However, it had reached a point where no new developments seemed likely for months as people tried to figure out how to rescue the men. I didn't know that a rescue was at all imminent. Thanks to Heather's announcement, I was able to tune into CP24 in time to hear the first miner be freed. Hearing that happen was nothing short of incredible. You could feel the triumph of the Chilean crowd as the first man was lifted from the cave in a specially built rescue capsule. I stayed up late to hear the first few get pulled out. I had been reflecting a lot on how disconnected and fragmented we were all becoming; wondering if there was really any hope for me finding a genuine life partner at all, starting to doubt whether my projects would ultimately do anything other than pass lonely time and make me feel productive. The latest episode of Spark on CBC Radio had gotten me thinking about how little people seem to watch in common other than perhaps sports. We all seem to be on our own little islands. And then, Twitter, plus a friend I'll likely never physically meet again, got me on the same page as the rest of the world. My timeline was suddenly filled with cheerful tweets as people discussed the events happening on my own TV and so many millions of others. Thanks to Twitter, I could join in this conversation as readily as anyone else.
    Hearing the rescue was just what I needed to put things in perspective. For a while, at least, it restored and recharged my sense of patience and hope. That's a big part of the connective power of social media. After that Thanksgiving long weekend, I've never been able to think of Twitter with quite the same sense of derision. Through it, I was profoundly moved. I was sad to find it becoming a more hostile place after it was bought by a billionaire and became X. Had it become a kind of public utility not driven by corporate greed and stripped of all of its guardrails, I might never have looked for better virtual places to be. Although I still find TWitter, or X as it's now called, to be a useful source of information, I don't go there for discussion anymore. There's just too much junk and nastiness to dig through these days.
    Occasionally, we get so buried in our own misery that we lose a proper sense of perspective. You get so absorbed in your own life that all else fades. Before that Sunday night, I wasn't all that impressed by Twitter, Facebook, and the like. So much of what was posted seemed so very trivial. However, as time passed, that powerful experience became one of many. When the Fukushima disaster happened, I found out that a Japanese follower I had was stranded across the city from his wife. The phone lines being jammed, it took quite some time before he could even find out that his wife was thankfully alive and safe. Another follower living in Egypt was caught up in the events in Tahrir Square, which toppled the dictatorship. Others have tweeted about tornados, fires, and other disasters.
    Equally important, you get a sense of the good things that happen to people all over the world. I've found real pleasure in finding out how Christmas unfolded for people in countries in different time zones. All at once, Christmas has new cheer and longevity as I can read about what other people experience, the gifts they receive and the people they enjoy their holiday with. That expansive awareness has done much to addd vitality to the occasion. People also love sharing their happy discoveries, painful puns, and so much more. Occasionally, you might know something that can make a big difference to someone. I have experienced this particular joy many times now. Personally, I find this incredibly helpful when it comes to keeping a healthy perspective of my own life.
    I have also experienced some lighter forms of negative social media experience. People have taken remarks I've made completely out of context. Moments of flippancy on my part have given unintended offence to people. Of course, there is the ceaseless deluge of disagreeable spam from advertisers and others with unkind political agendas, to put it mildly. Keeping a degree of emotional detachment is a very helpful skill if you want to avoid getting sucked into often circular, hopeless arguments with people who seem to live for troublesome drama. The best and worst of us is on full display. Despite all that roughness, I, for one, plan to stick around and try to do some digital good. I hope that you'll keep a level head, take sensible precautions, and perhaps join in building a better social environment. I'll keep an ear out for you. Particularly on Mastodon, where I feel much more at home.

Navigating The World With Your iPhone:
One day, I got a call from John Morgan. I had known this kind philanthropist for years. It all started when I travelled with him to help a younger blind teen learn how to do more with his computer. Subsequently, he'd call me whenever he wanted my thoughts on accessible technology and whether it would be helpful in various circumstances. I would have gone anywhere with him.
    John called to see what I thought of a device designed to give GPS directions to blind people trying to get around on their own. He actually bought me one to try out. There were others he could give it to if I didn't find it useful. As things turned out, I ended up keeping it. I'll never forget the first time I went out on Canada Day on my own and enjoyed the fireworks show put on at the man-made lake near my building. I had previously gone around the area recording landmarks with the aid of a mobility instructor who figured out what the best points of interest would be to keep me from getting disoriented. It felt wonderful to stand with others, knowing that I would be able to find my building when things wound down without relying on anyone else. Before this, I always went to such occasions knowing that I was on someone else's timetable. If they decided to go home, I had to go with them, regardless of how good a conversation I might be having at the time. Thanks to the accessible GPS device, this was no longer the case. I didn't have to worry about being lost for ages mere meters from my place because I kept missing a landmark with my cane. This kind of thing had happened before to me many times in other situations. Miss one or two tactile clues, have familiar sounds masked by wind or other things, and you might as well be on Mars.
    That particular device cost John about as much as a current budget iPhone would cost me today. It served me very well for over half a decade. I haven't used that gadget in over ten years now. Apps on my iPhone have done a far better job locating and guiding me for pretty much that long. Right from the start when I first got my iPhone, the GPS worked very well and there were good accessible apps which put that GPS device to shame. Instead of waiting three to five minutes for the older device to locate me, my iPhone knew almost instantly where I was. Adding landmarks was much easier on the iPhone. Maps and points of interest could be updated much more easily. Things have only gotten better for iPhone users of GPS apps.
    Independent travel and gaining awareness of what's nearby have been tremendous stumbling blocks for me in life. A lot of that difficulty is due to what caused my blindness. I was born prematurely. Doctors followed what was then a common practice of providing extra oxygen to keep me alive. This oxygen certainly had that beneficial effect. However, it also destroyed my retinas and damaged part of my brain responsible for geospatial awareness. Solving spatial puzzles, comprehending geography and geometry, and keeping routes and mental maps have all proven impossible for me beyond a certain level. Things are now complicated further by moderate hearing loss, requiring me to use hearing aids. They're very helpful when it comes to hearing things happen in my immediate vicinity and participating in conversation. However, they don't give me a reliable sense of distance and direction to sounds. Too much background noise or wind can render me unable to navigate or do much of anything safely. Increasing the volume often only makes things worse, as everything, including background noise, is amplified. Even walking through relatively quiet parkland, I've had many occasions where people have suddenly appeared in front of me when it was too late to move around them. They weren't standing still or walking especially quietly, either. All of this is very unsettling when you've been accustomed to hearing everything effortlessly for most of your life.
    I thought it was vital that I explain these circumstances to you before discussing the navigational options your iOS device makes available, so you can put my thoughts in proper context. I have used an app called BlindSquare quite extensively and have done more limited exploratory testing of other apps I'll discuss here. Just be aware that this is one section of this guide where I'll be relying more on what the app makers say the apps can do and on what I've heard other people's experiences have been like. For a number of my friends, these apps are all they need to feel very confident in exploring their surroundings and going to new places completely on their own. For me, they are more helpful in finding out what's around me than actually getting to places. Using them, I can at least be confident of eventually getting home unassisted if necessary. That in itself is quite a marvellous relief.
    Having access to GPS navigation doesn't solve all the mobility and orientation problems for any blind person. Nor does it replace the need for a cane or guide dog and good mobility skills. These apps don't use your device's built-in camera to gather information and aren't aware of what's happening around you. They won't warn you of oncoming cars, bikes, or other hazards. They receive a GPS signal from satellites orbiting the earth and match what's detected to information stored on your device or retrieved from online sources. The information may not always be fully up-to-date. Businesses close or change locations. Any objects such as benches, garbage cans, etc. that you might put into the information as personal points of interest to keep on track could be moved. GPS signals can be blocked by structures, cloud cover, and other things. Defence department regulations don't allow civilian GPS receivers to be as accurate as technically possible. This is to prevent them from being used to precisely guide weapons. For all these reasons, it's not a good idea to completely rely on it. Use your own senses and common-sense.
    To help offset these difficulties, GPS apps may draw data from more than one source. Your iOS device can also tap into information received via the Internet and cell towers to help figure out where you are. Provided you are connected to Wi-Fi, these apps are even useful to owners of iPads, which don't come with GPS receivers included. These receivers can be bought separately, so it's perfectly possible, if somewhat more awkward, to use these apps with iPads while moving. While stationary, iPad owners can examine maps and virtually explore areas before going there, exactly like they could on iPhones. In fact, some people may find the larger size of an iPad helpful when exploring maps.
    Using these navigational apps takes a toll on your battery. As you move, the app constantly tracks your position indicated by the received satellite signals and checks for things to notify you of against available information. When necessary, it will check for and download online information, presuming this is possible. All of these activities require processing power. You may also incur data charges if you go over what your cellular data plan allows for. To minimize this, one thing you can sometimes do is download any maps, points of interest, etc. to your iOS device while you're connected to Wi-Fi. Over the past two years since the first edition of this guide was published, this has become a more rarely available capability. Most modern GPS apps now retrieve current data as needed from various sources and thereby provide more up-to-date information while reducing storage space taken on your device. Check the settings for the apps you use for possible ways to govern the circumstances under which data is downloaded. Investing in an external power bank is also an excellent idea for people making frequent use of GPS apps. They drain the battery of your device constantly as they monitor your location, process the GPS signal and keep map data as current as it needs to be.
    Another thing to consider investing in is a means of hearing information conveyed by these apps while on the move. Some people hold their iPhones in their hands while travelling. This can be useful, as it allows you to point the top edge of your device in directions of interest and make use of the "look around" or "geobeam" features common to GPS apps designed for blind people. This tells you what lies in the direction your device is pointing to. Most people that I talk to prefer to have their iPhones in their pockets and use small Bluetooth speakers, earbuds, or bone conduction headsets to keep informed while their hands are free for other duties. Some apps offer support for use with Braille displays. I've never attempted this, but would presume these displays would be small and light enough to wear around the neck or over the shoulder for easy access while on the move.
    There are two types of apps we'll be discussing here. The first kind are apps that are made for use by the public and are also made accessible for blind people. There are a great many choices here. We'll look at the two most popular ones. These are the Maps app that comes included in iOS, and Google Maps, its primary competition, available free from the app store. We'll also look at some apps for the public that seek to aid their users with aspects of travel. For instance, there are apps that focus specifically on travel via public transit systems. Other apps such as Uber attempt to facilitate travel by connecting would-be passengers with people willing to take them in their personal cars for a fee. Other apps help with more long-range expeditions, booking flights and planning itineraries.
    There are also several GPS apps designed specifically for blind people. These apps try to offer extra information that is helpful for blind users, as well as facilities to help make orientation easier. We'll discuss a few of the more popular options and how they differ. It takes extra effort and expertise to make apps that are as maximally built for blind people as these specially designed apps are. They typically combine functions of two or more apps into a more seamless single app, provide information tailored to be maximally helpful for blind people, and are designed with efficient accessibility from the ground up. It can be a lot easier to master the use of one of these apps than to juggle two or more apps designed for sighted people to gain similar information that is by nature more minimal.
    One thing you should always keep in mind when using any of these apps is that they are designed around car travel. Points of interest included in the maps and data these apps draw from will be located at parking lot entrances or driveways to places. When an app tells you that you have arrived, you'll still need to find the actual entrance to a place. Nothing stops you from creating a point of interest precisely at the doorway or path you must be at. However, it is up to you to perform this task and create the position markers helpful to you. It's a good habit to get into. Just be ready to still possibly have to search a little if there's GPS interference. Don't ever presume exact precision. Also, keep in mind that when you're told that a destination is a distance away at such and such o'clock, that's as the crow flies. In other words, it's a straight line to your destination that doesn't consider obstacles you'll have to cross or get around.
    You might wonder what kinds of special facilities and capabilities navigation apps designed specifically for blind people might have. Users of BlindSquare who wear earbuds or headsets will notice that the indicator sounds that immediately precede being told about points of interest are directionally positioned. You'll hear the indicator beep in the direction the point is located from your position, as much as this is possible. Another often used example is upcoming intersections. Apps designed for blind people will typically give more detailed information about these before a user reaches an intersection, so he or she has a better idea how to safely cross it. Those are just the tip of the iceberg.
    Rather than going step by step through the features and operation of each app I discuss, I have chosen to concentrate more on what these apps make possible and when they might be advantageous. There is excellent help available for each of these apps already. I see no advantage in reinventing the wheel. You can also find audio and video reviews and demos. I feel more comfortable leaving you in the hands of this expertly written help than trying to explain what I haven't used extensively. Your safety might hinge on being familiar enough with an app's capabilities so that you have the mental space to focus more on your surroundings. Presuming you've read previous sections on using VoiceOver, browsing the web, etc., you'll have the skills needed to master these navigation apps using the help provided.
    Even since the first edition of Personal Power was published roughly two years ago, there has been rapid change in this space. More of these apps are drawing upon the same sources of information. Google and Apple are allowing third-party apps to access their data. Also, the quality of openly available crowdsourced geographical data has reached the point where apps attempting to keep ongoing costs low are turning to it rather than that provided by larger companies. Advertising and business partnerships are becoming more common sources of revenue, allowing apps to be offered freely to consumers. Please review any help or instructions for the GPS apps you make use of, as they may change the capabilities they offer or the interface used to control the apps you prefer.
Going Mainstream:
Using Apps Designed for Sighted Users
    Thin, light, and portable, it's no wonder that iPhones and iPads have been turned into powerful navigation aids by clever app developers. Many apps designed for sighted users have been made accessible to blind people using VoiceOver. This has been done thoughtfully. However, blind people simply aren't the core focus for these apps. Information these apps provide is designed to give maximum aid to drivers and other people with sight who can quickly look at the screen while on the move. They have been set up to be operated as easily as possible by people with sight. In contrast, apps designed especially for blind people are carefully crafted to give extra information and easy control by touch gestures or audio menus rather than tools found at a glance. This can make quite a difference. For many people, the Maps app or Google Maps will be quite sufficient for their needs as blind travellers. One major difference is that mainstream apps don't volunteer as much information. You need to use VoiceOver and seek out what's nearby or find out how far away places might be. Other than directions to destinations, sighted people typically wouldn't appreciate being told about everything they're passing as they move along. You'll must have a good grasp and proficiency with VoiceOver to make effective use of these apps while travelling. You'll need to take your iOS device out frequently if you want to consult a mainstream app for information apart from spoken directions that comprise a route.
    As accessibility awareness and disability laws have taken hold, a lot more attention is being paid by developers of these apps to the needs of blind and visually impaired people. Both the Apple Maps app (included in iOS) and the Google Maps app have done substantial work to increase the usefulness of directions and route instructions, especially for blind users.
    Over the pandemic, these apps have continued to be improved. Typically, this has resulted in more information being made available. Google and Apple invest heavily in mapping areas using specialized gear which captures GPS information as well as visual. Crowdsourcing is also a part of the information mix. Many areas are mapped out in tremendous detail, including terrain and satellite imagery. All of this can be very helpful to sighted travellers. For the most part, it's easy for blind users to obtain any non-visual information made available. No image descriptions of buildings or other locations are available. However, air quality or transit information, traffic conditions, and other extra information should be accessible for blind users.
Apple Maps:
The Maps app is designed by Apple and comes already on your device as part of the iOS operating system. It taps directly into data maintained and collected by Apple. It isn't supported by ad revenue of any kind. It is a service meant to enhance the value of Apple products. For people concerned about privacy, this may be a better fit. You can view maps of areas and get directions to places. Apple is also integrating the Maps app with other apps like Uber and Lift to provide maximum convenience. It also supports Apple Pay and Siri. I recently heard a video that pointed out that the pricing information and ride booking procedures were better in the Apple Maps app than in Google Maps. In an effort to rival Google Maps, Apple is investing many resources into collecting geographical data. This new data is slowly being added to the Maps app as it is ready. This includes indoor maps of popular places like shopping centres and airports. Transit information as well as current climate information including weather and air quality index have recently been incorporated into Apple Maps.
    Apple Maps lives up to its name. An interactive map dominates the screen. Blind people can actually explore this map by dragging their fingers along roads. They can also use the VoiceOver rotor to flick up or down between points of interest, double tapping on an item to open an information card about it. You can choose how much of the screen is taken up by these information cards. You also have current local weather, a Tracking button, and a Settings button.
    The information cards have quite a bit of material on them drawn from various apps, as well as the address. You will also find buttons to get directions or call or visit the website of a place. If an app is associated with a place, there's a button to get that. Apple really plays to that strength of integration. The information cards are where that's most evident.
    Moving your finger around the screen allows you to explore the area around you and even follow streets. You can also find out about any nearby points of interest via the rotor by turning it to the Points of Interest setting. Flick up or down between points of interest and double tap on any that interest you. It is also possible to mark points of interest on the map.
    The Maps app is a springboard for many other apps that can incorporate aspects of maps into travel aids. This might allow an app focused on restaurants to offer the ability to give guided directions to a restaurant or show a map of where it is. It also allows Siri to give guided directions to places of interest when asked. You might never go into the Maps app itself, but will still very likely have made use of it without even being aware.
    To find help using the Maps app, the first place to look is inside the user guide for your iOS device. You can get the user guide from the Books app. I've given instructions on how to do this in the Quick Start section of this guide. The user guide from Apple will always have the most up to date and complete information about the features and capabilities of apps created by Apple that are included with iOS.
Google Maps:
Google is, and has always been, the information king. This is leveraged heavily to provide maximum contextual knowledge about places. Apple initially was going to simply tap into Google's data and pay for using the information on its products. However, the companies had a falling out and are now competing in this particular sphere of interest. The map is almost secondary to the information in Google Maps. When you enter it, you'll find a Menu button, a search field, and several further options including checking traffic, getting directions, and entering compass mode. Below, you'll find a heading called Explore (your local area name). In my case, Explore Mississauga. Flicking right below that heading brings you to buttons that are categories of places. Double tapping on one will show you local places in that category. For instance, double tapping on "coffee" will bring up places where you can enjoy coffee nearby. When you drill down like this, there will always be a Back button to get up to a higher level.
    If you double tap on a location in Google Maps, Google finds and displays everything from the website. This includes buttons for guidance to the location, a button to call a place, and all kinds of reviews provided by users of the app or from other places. You can learn a great deal about restaurants and places of business just from what comes up on a place's information screen. Don't forget to scroll down with a three-finger swipe to the left. There are usually some screens full of information. More than you'd get on Apple Maps.
    Google Maps has many features, including a compass mode as well as the ability to download a local map for offline use. If you use this latter option, be aware that some features depend on having a data connection, and you'll miss out on those if you're completely offline. All of this is explained in the app itself. To find the extensive help available from within the app, double tap on the Menu button at the top left. Next, flick right until you come to Help and Feedback.
