If you're not mindful, you can plunge people around you into your far from private story, and they'll feel compelled to listen.
    Remember that general knowledge of accessibility tools and the hundreds of apps useful for blind people in these smartphones is quite poor. The whole premise of a blind person making use of a touchscreen device isn't a very intuitive leap. Particularly for people who don't understand how blind people approach things. I still often encounter people who are amazed that I can use and iPhone or wonder if I'm faking my blindness. This can test one's patience, but I've tried to approach these situations calmly and politely whenever possible.
    Another problem this widespread lack of knowledge presents is that people don't realize that it's a far bigger ask for us to "put our phones away". They have no idea how much independence and accessibility they're asking us to forfeit. A good part of living well with a smartphone is to make your peace with that. Don't feel badly for using your smartphone when it's actually being of genuine use and benefit to you. A weekend where you've left your smartphone behind is a very different experience for blind people who are truly using them to the fullest in their lives.
    That being said, it's all too possible for blind people to be just as harmfully absorbed in their smartphones as sighted people are. We may rely more on our smartphones to access things which sighted people wouldn't have to, such as books, newspapers, print, etc. However, we also do the same kinds of things everyone else does. We are just as capable of doom-scrolling on social media, listening to podcasts or music to escape our dull surroundings, catch up on endlessYoutube videos, etc. While we're not alone, we need to be certain we're mentally present in the moment with people who may want to potentially interact with us. Short of wearing a sign saying "I'm happy to stop what I'm doing and chat!" I have yet to find a really practical way of enjoying the benefits of your smartphone while making this clear to people. Unlike people who can still see that they're being approached or that others are around and open to chatting, blind people can't read body language and might well be drowning out the sound of real life happening nearby.
    This is by no means a problem exclusively for blind people to solve. Fully sighted people seem quite capable of ignoring their surroundings at inopportune times, being absorbed in their smartphones. There is also a reluctance to break into each other's thoughts when smartphones or earbuds are in evidence. A book by Sherry Turkle called Reclaiming Conversation discusses the many hidden costs to society which have resulted from so many people being connected by smartphones to their personal circles of apps and people. At gatherings where smartphones are in evidence, conversation among attendees tends to be kept light and inconsequential. This allows people to be inattentive with relative social impunity, drifting in and out of conversation as they choose. People find it easier to text those who are absent than to talk to people in their immediate presence. One never knows when any number of people might be paying attention to their smartphones rather than each other. Turkle found in her research that people increasingly find it easier to conduct uncomfortable or important conversations via text at a distance, since they can edit what they say before sending their messages. According to Professor Turkle, and a good many others, the art of conversation is suffering under the technological on slot we find ourselves in. The book covers how this always connected lifestyle impacts different spheres of life, including everything from friendship, education, romance, work, and more.
    Don't ever feel like it's on your shoulders alone to solve this kind of societal hangup. We've reached a point with smartphones where people are beginning to appreciate what the cost we're paying in damaged in person relationships, lost moments of casual connection, and our sense of local community actually is. It's up to all of us to figure out where our social norms go from there. Smartphones and tablets are here to stay. They often tempt us with too much convenience for our own good. However, in my humble opinion, they are also capable of doing far too much genuine good in our lives to be thrown away or done without. A third, more nuanced thoughtful approach needs to be found.
    In a way, smartphones have given society at large a taste of the same kind of awkwardness I've felt all my life in public spaces where people are having conversations. Being unable to read body language, I'm never certain how welcome I would be if I chipped in, how long anybody involved is staying, etc. We're going to need some new societal expectations and social norms to win back a more natural, reliable sphere of public discourse.
    Until those come into widespread use, I think it's up to us to walk that balance between making the most of our devices and not unwittingly cutting ourselves off from offline life. A lot of that comes down to picking our moments and using the tools for managing interruptions wisely.
    Another balance which we need to be thoughtful about involves what information we choose to trust. This is critical when it comes to information we obtain from social media. Journalists have guardrails and procedures to check facts and make certain that what they publish is true. An organization may have a political bias or slant, deciding to cover things in a way which suits their audience. However, if they publish utterly false information, their reputations will suffer, as has happened. There are no such barriers on social media. Anyone can post anything. Think about the motives of the sources of your information before jumping to conclusions. Especially before coming to unfavourable conclusions about people. A tremendous amount of damage has been done because people didn't bother to check conclusions which fit their world view or that simply felt right at the time.
    Artificial intelligence is another area where caution is warranted. It can be used for criminal activity and spreading false information on social media or through emails. Also, the artificial intelligence we use to interpret what our cameras detect are prone to error. Always think about what apps and services tell you about objects in your environment. If something's really important, try to verify the information with another app which uses a different artificial intelligence, or use a sighted volunteer.
    Earlier in this guide, you'll find two whole sections devoted to focus and notifications. Those are absolutely essential tools for managing when, why and how your iPhone can interrupt you with information. Do the unglamorous work of going through notifications settings. These settings form the bedrock of when your iPhone informs you of things in normal circumstances. Make decisions for each app as to if, how and when it can interrupt you. For each app, ask yourself whether you really need to know the information it will notify you of right away. I have a lot of apps set to deliver notifications quietly to the notifications centre or put notifications into the next scheduled summary. Be certain you're only interrupted by apps where it makes sense that you are. I want to know about changing weather conditions, so the Weather app can interrupt me immediately if rain or severe weather is approaching. Perhaps, your friends and family can contact you on the FaceTime and Messages apps. You may want to let those apps interrupt you with notifications about incoming calls or messages most of the time. On the other hand, you might not want notifications to interrupt you from social media apps like X or Mona. I have these delivered quietly to my notification centre most of the time. Use the Focus settings and create options to change what can interrupt you in special circumstances. I have different focusses for when I'm sleeping versus when I'm on vacation or working on something and don't want anything to interrupt me.
     If I'm with friends, my iPhone will absolutely be with me. However, it's very unlikely that it will interrupt me with any information. I typically have it in the do not disturb focus. If I'm on a longer trip away, I have a vacation focus which does things like make certain my calendar won't notify me of events that I would miss anyway due to being otherwise occupied. There are some people who can call or message me while these focuses are active, but not very many. Some apps can also get through and notify me if necessary. For instance, the Parcel app might inform me that a package hasn't been delivered successfully. However, most things can wait or aren't that important in the first place. All other notifications are delivered quietly and await my leisure in the notifications centre.
    Barring unusual circumstances, during my time with friends or family, in-person discussion always takes immediate precedence. I might use my iPhone to dictate a brief note or obtain information about what my friends and I are discussing if there's some doubt as to our knowledge. For instance, I might ask Siri how old an actor is or perhaps play or read important news which my companions would be interested in. I might use an app to obtain a menu at a restaurant we're eating at, rather than have someone else need to read it to me. However, unless I'm in a group of people who are passing time on their iPhones while awaiting some event, I'll be careful to stay alert for conversation opportunities. I won't do anything too significant or absorbing on my iPhone. I'll save that for when I'm alone or when others are otherwise engaged. There are certainly such moments during longer gatherings or visits. For instance, if I'm at a gathering when everyone is watching a sporting event. When a game is in progress, the conversation about anything else tends to utterly tank in my experience. In-depth discussion is pretty much off the table due to attention being focussed on the game. Things revive again slightly during commercial breaks or timeouts built into many sports. The same applies when others choose to watch a TV show or movie which holds no interest for me. I might then decide to pull out my iPhone and do other things while keeping alert for conversational moments.
    Your smartphone makes an excellent device to capture and document memorable moments with. Many people no longer cary separate cameras or recorders, since what's in their smartphone is mor than sufficient for most circumstances. However, this is another case where just because you can do something doesn't mean that you should. The effort to make certain that your photo, video, or audio recording is as good as possible often means that you're not really experiencing whatever the event happens to be. This essentially turns an important experience in life into a kind of trophy to be collected. Such trophies are, in my experience, never worth the mental distraction from the event in question. Unless you can actually minimize what you need to do to start an audio or video recording and keep the mic or camera focused, you'll get too tangled in tech to be mindfully present in the moment itself.
    For years, I used an app to record moments and share them with a community of fellow users. I had quite a collection of these moments. However, I only rarely actually went through them and listened to what I had recorded. Eventually, the app turned its attentions from being a kind of community archive to more of a podcast making app. All of those recordings were lost. There were certainly other apps I could have used to continue recording life's special moments. However, this taught me that I would much rather fully experience a special moment than remove myself partially from that to preserve proceedings.
    Another thing I try to be conscious of is whether my iPhone is doing other people any good. Sometimes, I'm able to use my iPhone to help someone in some way. On a larger scale, I can participate in tech help lists and forums, sharing what I've learned. I can engage in projects like writing this book in a far more portable fashion than I could have with a laptop computer. While I'm with others, I can demonstrate how an app works, find an answer to a question they have, etc. I always take those opportunities. It not only helps them but also increases my sense of the value of what I'm carrying. People should be just as impressed with the iPhone I use to accomplish something needful in the moment as they would be if I pulled out a multitool to cut open a package, pry something loose, carve a piece of wood or tighten a screw.
    To achieve this kind of effect, don't wait until problems arise to find out such things as how to get help or properly navigate various apps. There are many ways to develop and design the iPhone apps we use every day. However, there are a lot of commonly used conventions, controls, and elements of design. Once you've taken the time to grasp these conventions of design, you'll be much more productive and much less frustrated when you encounter difficulties.
    One day, I was helping an older gentleman who had owned an iPhone for quite some time. He was very frustrated. A community bus route which he relied on to know when a bus would be at various stores and other locations had disappeared from the Transit app. I asked him whether he had investigated how to contact the app developers to get assistance. He said that he always found it a futile and frustrating hunt for that kind of thing. This surprised me, since I had very early on figured out where one should ordinarily look to find them.
    I don't tend to travel on buses and had never used the Transit app in earnest. However, it took me less than ten seconds to find the "user options" button at the top left of the screen. He had never thought to try this or look at the bottom where tabs containing such options are often easily found in other apps. This simple design convention of having important functions at the very top or very bottom, leaving the centre of the screen for information, had never become obvious to him. He simply learned the bare minimum he had to know for each app he needed. Every trouble spot would lead to fruitless frustrating bouts of searching, all because he had never been told about such a basic convention of app design.
    Unfortunately, many iPhone owners don't tend to become familiar with even basic approaches which app developers take to make various settings, contact and help available from inside the app itself. To avoid a great deal of possible frustration when you least need it, it can really help to look for such conventions and patterns. Put in the time to explore apps while you're comfortable before you require them in any sort of rushed circumstances. You'll feel far more graceful and in charge that way.
    Smartphones are designed to be used differently, for different purposes, by people with different abilities leading very different lives. All kinds of great advice is put out by well-meaning experts, myself included, about how best to use your smartphone. Before acting on such advice, or thinking that others should, take the time to think about how you typically use your phone and whether the advice makes sense in your or someone else's particular context. For me, the touch typing mode is best. However, others might actually save more time using standard typing. Many people make far more use of the haptic vibrations rather than sound cues. Different doesn't necessarily equate to inferior.
    You wouldn't go out of your way to dull the blade of your knife, put a soft pad on the head of your hammer to soften its strikes, etc, if you didn't have good reason to do such things. Don't lessen the readiness or convenience of using your smartphone unless you have a good reason. Let's go over a few examples I've encountered.
    Preserving battery charge by turning off functions of your smartphone is a prime example. Bluetooth and background app refreshing are commonly sited as things which can be done without in order to save energy. That's absolutely true. However, consider whether that energy is enough to actually be worth saving given your context in exchange for what you give up. Power banks with sufficient energy to fully recharge an iPhone twice can easily be carried in a pocket and won't cost you a fortune. Investing in one of those makes sense in any case, so you're ready if there's a power outage, or you're unexpectedly put in circumstances where you can't access a wall plug. Turning off Bluetooth means that you're unable to use any accessories such as AirPods, your Apple Watch, a Braille display or keyboard in conjunction with your iPhone without first turning Bluetooth back on. Barring unusual circumstances, I would never turn off Bluetooth. It doesn't save anywhere near enough power to be worth doing given how I live my life. Typically, I'm within easy reach of power. I constantly make use of many accessories which require Bluetooth. Perhaps, during a blackout which may last days, I'd consider turning off Bluetooth to maximally ration power given that situation.
    Background app refreshing lets apps check for new information while they're in the background. This is how your smartphone can know where you've moved while you're checking messages as you travel. This is how your weather app checks for storms or other conditions to warn you about. And yes. Your social media app uses background app refreshing to check for new postings to notify you of when you least need such distraction. Background app refreshing doesn't have to be an all or nothing choice. You can choose to turn it off for specific apps but leave it on for others. It takes a bit more work, but it's well worth doing. You'll have a much more satisfying experience than if you simply turn background app refreshing off for everything. If I had an extremely limited data plan, perhaps it would then be worth doing. However, I don't typically come anywhere near using even ten of the thirty gb of space my monthly plan includes. I turn off background app refreshing for some apps which I don't typically use, but leave it on for nearly everything without missing the small amount of data possibly wasted.
    Security is another area where people can really go overboard. Before you enable lockdown mode, restrict the use of apps with a long and all too forgettable passcode, or come up with a massively long password for your Apple account, stop and think. Seriously, think about the inconvenience you're creating for yourself. Is there good reason to incur this? Are you really in that much danger from others around you that it's better to be locked out of your iPhone than take the risk that someone somehow finds out what they need to cause havoc? The person who you've chosen to be your recovery contact might not be near his or her phone when you've forgotten your passcode or password. You may have to go through Apple's verification procedures when you're in a hurry and need your iPhone now. There are circumstances where more extreme security measures are absolutely justified. You might be entrusted with information so dangerous that extra security precautions are warranted. Perhaps, you're actually being threatened or stalked by someone. In that instance, you should certainly consider more stringent measures, despite their increased inconvenience to you. However, absent such extreme threats, the default precautions, such as a six digit passcode, enabling Face or Touch ID, a password with ten or more characters, etc, is more than sufficient. It's enough to use Apple Pay, be trusted by banking apps, and the like. Before you add in more security, really think about whether it's necessary given your circumstances.
    The above tips will help prevent your smartphone from being made needlessly less useful. One way that they are unlike other tools is that smartphones present us with the constant temptation to fill every idle moment with something of personal interest to us. Gratifying these temptations is never more than a few taps and swipes away. Our favourite music, podcasts, books, or postings on social media from our online circle of people are right there for the taking. Just because we can avail ourselves of this doesn't mean that we always ought to. Others will see the iPhone in our hand or the earbuds in our ears and likely presume we're otherwise occupied. Always being occupied isn't good for encouraging spontaneous social interaction with those around you. It also doesn't allow for more free-flowing thoughts to emerge. Take some time each day and choose not to do this. Spend those five minutes waiting in line or in the doctor's waiting room not using your smartphone.
    Even more vital than leaving room for social interaction with those around you, there's the matter of your own inner thinking. Give yourself time to simply sit and think. Be present to your own inner life of thought. Sometimes, the very thing which helps us find solutions or newfound purpose is a simple pause of action to give our minds time to wander. Boredom isn't always the enemy. If you find total silence unnerving, I've often found meditation apps or ones which give access to soundscapes to be useful. Music or sound without any words can give us a helpful point of focus. Typically though, there's plenty of sound around us already. Sometimes, I take time and simply listen to what noise can be heard in my apartment. Especially in warmer weather when windows are open. Give your mind some breathing room.
    You need not be online for your iPhone to be useful or able to entertain yourself or others. The calculator is always available. Your calendar can be accessed offline, as can your notes. I keep all of my thousands of Kindle books on my iPhone. I have a selection of music. There are audiobooks, games, and movies. Navigation information can be downloaded and used later if your Internet connection is lost. Apps like VD Scan offer the ability to read printed documents while offline. I use a certain amount of space to keep a constantly refreshing collection of podcast episodes. Enough to provide over two days worth of listening. Using an app called Kewix, I have a reasonably up-to-date copy of Wikipedia and Wictionary on my iPhone. This gives me access to an incredible amount of information even when unconnected to the web. Not everyone has the storage to spare that I do on my iPhone, and you need not go to the extremes that I have. However, be aware of what's possible even when you're offline. There's no way I'd ever be able to read all of what I have ready at hand. However, take time to get a grasp of the resources you gather on your iPhone. You never know when a cookbook of simple recipes, dictionary, or first-aid and survival instructions might be useful.
    Take the time to learn about what you have. Thinking of these devices as mere phones does them and yourself a grave disservice. They are incredibly complex advanced tools which can literally do thousands of different things for us. They are the equivalent of an astronomer's telescope or a blacksmith's forge and tools. In this world of valuable information, an iPhone can gather, sort and shape information for our pleasure and advantage. An iPhone is a house and car for our digital world. People put their lives at risk to gather the resources needed to make your iPhone. Many people work long torturous hours to assemble these tools. And that doesn't even take into account all the effort needed to make them as easy to use as they are. Even when bought used, these items aren't inexpensive. The least we can do as owners is take good care of them and invest the time to learn what's possible and how to use them in ways which enrich our lives. Taking this humble attitude and the steps I've outlined above, we can hope to live well with our iPhones and the people around us.

Economics of iOS Device Ownership:
Even on a low or fixed income, owning an iOS device makes economic sense if you take the time to master it and put it to as many uses as possible in your life. Thinking of it as a powerful, multipurpose tool and key to experiences is the best mindset to approach owning an iOS device with. It's not just a phone, and it isn't a toy or accessory. The more time and effort you invest in discovering and mastering its capabilities, the happier you'll be with your investment. You'll also be better equipped to maximize the economic benefit an iOS device can bring. I thoroughly understand how much of a sacrifice it can be to own and maintain an iPHONE. They're typically pricier than other smartphones. This is all the more true if you opt for the most current generation. Added to this is the ongoing cost of a phone and cellular data service plan. For people on fixed and lower incomes, this can be a substantial sacrifice of disposable income. In this section, we'll take a look at the costs involved and set these against the savings and economic benefits which owning an iPHONE confers on you. Most of this can apply to iPads as well. The only real difference is that you need not pay for a cellular data plan or sign a contract with a carrier. I'll also give what advice and wisdom I can about how to minimize and spread out the costs while maximizing enjoyment.
    To properly evaluate my advice here, I think it's important that you have some understanding of my financial status. I'm not about to divulge specifics. However, I do consider myself to be privileged in many ways. How am I privileged? Although I'm on a fixed income and live in a subsidized apartment, I am able to earn a modest amount of extra money for contract work that I do. I also have a very supportive family willing to offer some financial aid when required. Between these factors plus some gifts and honorariums from time to time, I fully realize that I can live more comfortably than many of my peers. There are certainly limits. I don't do any travelling beyond my local area. My situation does somewhat confine what I can do economically. This is especially the case when it comes to earning, receiving and saving money. There are rules around all of these things which I must obey or face pretty drastic consequences. For instance, if I break rules and no longer qualified for my rent subsidy, the money I had to pay to keep living in this apartment would suddenly increase to around five times as much as I currently pay. I don't take these rules lightly. However, it is a safe and relatively stable existence as long as you accept the limitations and obey the rules. My basic needs are covered. I am able to save a little but basically live month to month without the sheer desperation and stress this can entail without being certain of having ongoing income. Provided that I'm careful with my spending, I can live in what I think of as reasonable comfort. The contract work I do dovetails with my natural interests and has allowed me to invest in apps, subscribe to services, and do more than I otherwise could with my iOS device. Another major factor is that I have no costly vices apart from my love of buying books and tech accessories. That should give you as much of a sense of my economic circumstances as you need to consider my thoughts here in your own possibly very different context.
    If my own financial outlook became notably tighter, there are several things I would do to reduce my iPHONE-related costs. I would be more hesitant to purchase or subscribe to apps. My Kindle library wouldn't be added to as frequently as it has been. I would more seriously consider making due with less preferred apps which didn't have ongoing subscriptions. The iOS ecosystem doesn't lock you into ongoing cost beyond a certain point, so you can put dwindling money towards what you most value. There are certainly services which I would be loathed to do without. However, things would have to be very tight indeed before I would need to dump those services.
The Costs:
Obtaining your device is likely to be your first cost. This will vary depending on which device you choose. IPADs are typically paid for up front. It is absolutely possible to pay for an iPad in instalments, but I have yet to encounter anyone who has done that rather than save up and pay it all at once. The only additional ongoing expense is for one's Internet service and any equipment needed to provide Wi-Fi connectivity. Some people choose not to invest in home Internet and take their iPads to places where they can access Wi-Fi at low or no cost when they need internet connectivity. There are libraries, restaurants, and other places which offer this to visitors. That is about as inexpensive as online life gets.
    For iPhones, things are a bit more complicated. There's the cost of the iPHONE itself. This can either be paid all at once or, as is frequently done by people on lower incomes, paid over a couple of years as part of a contract. Such a contract typically locks you into a cellular data and phone plan with whichever carrier you select. In my own case, I paid around $115 Canadian per month for the cellular data plan plus what I owed for the iPHONE 13 while I paid off its cost over two years. Having unlimited Internet service available in my apartment is an additional expense. I forgo paying for television. I try to stretch the time between iPhone upgrades as much as possible, barring disaster or extremely useful new capabilities. In pretty much all of these areas, there are possible choices of iPHONE, carrier, service plan, etc, which would reduce these expenses to a degree. Your options will differ from country to country, depending on government regulation and other factors. You could well come to far different decisions than I have. For instance, if you're fortunate enough to be able to purchase your iPHONE outright, you're not stuck with a certain carrier until your contract has been paid, your ongoing costs between iPHONE purchases can be substantially lower. Your carrier may be willing to make a special deal in order to retain you as a customer, since you'd be free to switch carriers at any time. Those are the major fixed costs. Beyond this point, we enter the realm of personal choices and preferences.
    There are all sorts of optional extra costs which you might find worth incurring. What sorts of extras might you want? First of all, there are the services Apple offers. I use most of these, so I choose to subscribe to the premium Apple1 plan. This entitles me to make as much use of Apple Music, 2 terabytes of cloud storage, Apple TV Plus, Apple Fitness Plus, and Apple News Plus. I'm able to share all of these services with my wife Sara and a small number of others who I might add to the family plan. The cost of this plan has risen from the $37 it cost when I published the second edition. For this bundle of services, I pay around $45 Canadian per month as of May 2025. On top of this, I also maintain subscriptions to Audible Canada and Amazon Prime. Added together, those total around $40 Canadian each month. I consider this superb value for under $100 per month. There's a lot of room for people to choose services which suit their wishes. None are at all essential. However, I've found that subscribing to some services like the above greatly increases the utility of my iPHONE.
    There are more optional occasional costs. Apps in the app store will cost money. Some of these will require an ongoing subscription, while others will be a one-time payment. A surprising number will be free. Many apps, such as the Kindle app, let you enjoy digital goods from other markets. There are a wide range of choices when it comes to online shopping and digital goods like books, movies, audio dramas, some podcasts requiring subscription, etc. Indeed, your iPHONE does tend to make online shopping almost dangerously easy. I would advise budgeting for at least an occasional impulse purchase. The movie you've always wanted to own, the meal you can order with some swipes and double taps, that audio drama which sounds so epic. You get the idea.
Savings:
There are countless ways that having an iPhone can save you money as a totally blind person. A whole lot of different useful technologies are stuffed inside an iPhone. For one thing, they're actually quite powerful little pocket computers. There's as much computing power in a modern iPhone as you'd find in a high-end game console or desktop computer. Some of this is used to provide onboard artificial intelligence. The digital cameras in the front and back of iPhones are good enough that most people no longer bother owning a separate digital camera. The GPS receiver, compass, and motion sensors make an iPhone well suited to help with navigating. Bluetooth, Wi-Fi and cellular connectivity lets an iPhone help you communicate with others and use a wide array of accessories.
    How does this save you money? Having all of this in something I can hold in one hand or put in a pocket has many profound implications. Because I have an iPHONE, there are a whole lot of expensive things I really don't need to buy. Because of the camera and artificial intelligence in an iPHONE, I'll never need an OCR scanner or costly software to read my print mail and other paper documents. I don't need a costly, accessible GPS device to help me get around. My iPHONE already has a GPS receiver and inexpensive apps take care of the rest. 
    I paid for all the hardware found in most specialty devices designed for helping blind people when I got the iPhone. This means that instead of creating specialized devices for blind people only, developers can create apps which take advantage of what I've already purchased, thereby lowering the costs at both ends. It's also not as much of a stretch for developers of mainstream apps built for sighted people to make them support VoiceOver and other accessibility features Apple has created. I therefore can choose where to put my money towards apps more custom designed for blind people, and when to simply use an app made for everyone.
    An iPHONE can also save you money by making sighted help available when it's most needed. Sometimes, you simply need to borrow someone's working eyes for a few minutes in order to get something done. Combining the camera in my iPhone with secure internet connectivity, apps like Aira and Be My Eyes let me receive such help from people who can look through my camera and find the handkerchief that landed silently on the floor of my apartment. They can help me access an unfamiliar vending machine or other appliance which isn't otherwise accessible. During this past Summer, I used an Aira agent to assist me to adjust the temperature my air conditioner was set to. I can't count the times when items which I might never have found on my own have been found thanks to the connectivity and camera in my iPHONE. You save all sorts of money in avoiding costly mistakes and items presumed lost.
    By making online shopping easy and accessible, you avoid the mistakes made while shopping on someone else's schedule. You can save any transit costs for shopping trips. More importantly, you can take your time hunting for bargains, checking what you already have, etc. That saves money.
    There are a great many things that an iPHONE can become, which negates the need to purchase more bulky, separate devices. You are more free to pick your battles, spending your money where it will make the most difference. Buy one or two Bluetooth speakers and let your iPHONE be your entertainment centre. With an inexpensive keyboard, your iPHONE becomes a perfectly serviceable computer you can take anywhere. With the right apps and accessories, there's tremendous possibility for saving money otherwise spent on other things. Regarding accessories, keep in mind that just because you obtain a new iPHONE doesn't mean that the keyboard, headset, power bank, etc which you purchased will suddenly no longer be useful. Other than cases, you'll rarely be forced to upgrade many accessories just because you got a new iPHONE. Those speakers you bought at a discount might still work fantastically five years later. This lets you pick your moments to upgrade most accessories, such as when what you want is on sale.
Participation in The Mass Market:
Your iPHONE essentially allows you to access all kinds of things at the very same price as anybody else. The entertainment, services, and information an iPhone allows you to tap into are enough to boggle the mind. I haven't bought a music album in years now. Instead, I subscribe to the Apple Music service and can access more music than I could listen to over a lifetime. Subscribing to Netflix, Amazon Prime and Apple TV Plus gives me more quality entertainment than the Cable TV plan I used to pay twice as much for. As finances have gotten tighter and my entertainment preferences have changed, I've long since dropped Netflix. However, if a sighted friend tells me about something he or she watched on Netflix, YouTube, or Apple TV, I can use the very same apps and services on my iPhone to share in the joy. These streaming services now quite often include descriptive audio, which I can enjoy privately on my own device at no extra cost to me. The same holds true for news, magazines, and articles. The Apple News Plus subscription lets me read over two hundred magazines plus all the news articles I could wish for in a fully accessible manner. Because VoiceOver and efforts by app developers make the apps accessible, I am able to use what everyone else does despite being blind. This applies to books, services, and other things which I would otherwise be barred from using without sighted help.
Advice on Minimizing Expenses:
There are many things you can do to make your money go further while getting the most enjoyment possible out of your iPHONE. I'll go over as many of these bits of wisdom below as I can think of. I hope that at least some of these ideas help you reach a bit farther, explore a little more, and be happier with your investment in an iOS device.
    Learn about similar apps before purchasing one. Very often, there are many similar apps which accomplish the same thing but approach what they do differently. For instance, there are many note-taking and word-processing apps. Typically, there are a number of free apps or apps which let you try before investing money in unlocking their full functionality. See if you're happy with any lower cost or free options first, unless there's a compelling reason why a higher priced alternative attracts you. I've become very attached to the Ulysses app, which I'm actually using to write these words. However, had I found Scrivener or other alternative apps earlier in my search, I may never have resorted to Ulysses. You don't need to have every app under the sun. Find the ones which best suit you. I recommend finding at least one alternative app for any really critical functions or tasks in case your preferred choice develops accessibility problems over time. Unfortunately, accessibility is all too often not considered or tested for when updates to apps are made.
    Go over your subscriptions regularly. Increasingly, you will be subscribing to services or apps which meet your needs and interests particularly well. It's a good idea to go into the app store, into "My Account", and "Subscriptions" regularly. Go through all the active subscriptions and make certain you wish to continue paying for them. Cancel any that you no longer want. On the other hand, if there are subscriptions you know you want to stick with over the long term, consider strategically switching them to annual subscriptions rather than monthly. In most cases, this will save you money. You should time these switchovers so that you spread out the payments for individual things, so they come due when you're most comfortably able to pay them. That process will take time as you decide when or if you want to keep paying subscriptions on a monthly or yearly basis. These savings can really add up over the longer term.
    Take full advantage of storage. This is especially relevant to people with limited or intermittent Internet access. For instance, people in more northern and remote parts of my own province of Ontario are serviced very poorly by internet and cellular data providers. The costs for data can be very high and bandwidth can be very low-speed or unreliable. Meanwhile, most of the time, I'm well-connected and reasonably confident in speedy reliable internet access via Wi-Fi or cellular data. Blackouts and extended internet outages are certainly possible in my city, but they are very infrequent. People who live in areas where connectivity is costly or unreliable should first spend the extra money to get an iPhone with more onboard storage space. This will let them minimize the amount of bandwidth they will need. They might also be able to travel to spots where internet access is less costly and more reliable, and then move what they might need into their iPHONE's onboard storage. I can't put absolutely everything digital that I own into my onboard storage. However, I keep what I most want to always have available on my iPHONE. This includes my writing, my Kindle library, some music, audio dramas and books, references like the text of Wikipedia, and Wiktionary, and much more. This way, my iPHONE will still be of great use to me in a prolonged outage if it ever occurs. Keep things like ebooks, music, reference information, and other personal files stored on your iPHONE so that they're available to you without chewing up cellular or Wi-Fi data.
    For others in more connected areas, you may decide not to invest in onboard storage and instead invest in more iCloud storage. This could save quite a bit of money spent on your iPhones or iPads. Lowering the cost of your device would make upgrading to newer devices, more frequently, more affordable. Overall, though, extra storage is less costly to invest in than getting the top model of device. To me, the peace of mind and convenience of having more storage outweighs the savings. Others who live where cellular data and Wi-Fi are reliable and inexpensive will revel in the cloud with minimal onboard storage.

Why I wrote This Guide:
This project has been the most central and time-consuming project for a decade of my life with only short breaks between work on editions. It has grown to well over three hundred thousand words in length. Revising, editing, and updating obsolete sections takes hundreds of attentive hours. Some readers might well wonder what compelled me to expend so much effort and then give away its result freely. Those who don't care should feel free to skip on to the next section. For my more patient and curious readers, you will find my answers below:
    Let's start with why I'm making this guide freely available. One of the major inspirations of my continued efforts on this book is the cherished memories of a very kind man. John Morgan was someone Who I met when I was a young adult. I had yet to find any kind of purpose in life. He was looking for someone to come along with him to help a blind child learn to use a computer. Having nothing better to do, I agreed to go. It was a decision which continues to have a massive impact on my life. We built up a friendship during many visits to this blind youngster as we did our best to be of help. John began calling me more often to ask my opinions on various technology which he would procure for disadvantaged blind people in the greater Toronto area. Over the years, he also helped me financially from time to time. He never asked anything in return and always showed a genuine ongoing interest in the lives of the people he helped.
    During every encounter, I would find out a little about his life.
    He had worked as an engineer since arriving in Canada from Australia. I never learned how this engineer's life initially intersected with blind people. However, by the time I first met him, he had done a lot of volunteer work for the Canadian National Institute for the Blind. My mother originally met John there as she had also done extensive work for the CNIB. After retiring, John expanded his efforts on behalf of blind people. He believed that it was the duty of people who had found advantage and success in life to help the less fortunate. A key way in which he did this, beyond financial aid, was to value our interests, talents, and skills. He always made me feel like I had a friend rather than a benefactor. He never made me feel like a lesser person.
    I started the first edition of this book, intending to present him with an emailed copy upon its completion and telling him how much he had inspired me. Sadly, he passed away before the first edition of this book was finished. He had suffered a fall and never recovered from the damage it did to him. He wanted to have a house party and invite people who he had helped so that they could meet each other. Sadly, some of us met for the first time at his very well attended funeral. All I could do was to thank him posthumously in these pages and honour his memory with my continued efforts to have a positive impact.
    There have certainly been occasions when I've considered making each edition of the book the last one. However, the need for it continues. A moment's reflection on John's efforts and our many conversations about how helping others adds richness to our own lives has always proved a powerful cure to battered and worn down motivation. This is my way of continuing his legacy. This is how I can reach out and help those who are less fortunate than I find myself to be.
    Mainly, I think we're in a situation where the people who require this guide the most literally might not know enough to perceive its value to them. This isn't at all a case of willful ignorance or laziness on their part. Rather, the basic premise, that a device with a touchscreen can be one of the most valuable accessibility tools available, puts up a massive cognitive barrier for blind people. People with sight or people who have experienced this technology don't always appreciate how absurd it can seem to the uninitiated. For blind people who haven't tried an iOS device, it seems crazy to pay to learn what might be possible using something with almost no tactile elements to orient oneself.
    Asking blind people to believe that a device with a touchscreen could profoundly impact life demands quite a leap of faith from them.
    If you had never seen what things looked like from the top of a high mountain, how much effort would you put into climbing one with only the word of a stranger that the effort would be rewarding? Would you pay extra for instructions that no sighted people who use these devices need to pay to become competent? I think many blind people who might benefit tremendously from using an iOS device and accessible apps have approached things with that very naturally skeptical outlook and decided not to acquire smartphones and tablets. Even worse, they went ahead and got these devices, thinking that they would be just as intuitive for blind people to master as they were for people who could see. They then grow increasingly bitter because the information they lack prevents their experience from even approaching what was advertised.
    By sharing this guide with no financial strings attached, I hope to change the equation fundamentally. This guide may be shared freely and given to whoever might benefit. I'm not paid by Apple to do this. Nor am I being financially compensated by blindness organizations, who I sincerely hope will help spread this guide to their clients and benefit from it. There are a great many more enjoyable ways, and potentially a few more profitable ways, in which I could have spent the considerable time and effort that I've put into creating this guide. What has kept me going is my deep sense of how much joy and fulfillment my iPhone has allowed me to experience. I strongly believe that if more blind people can share in this enjoyment, their gains will enrich their lives greatly. Further, this will in turn increase my own enjoyment as well as that of people who already do even more with their devices than I've ever imagined was possible.
    Many people don't share the blessings of family and friends who keep me as informed as I tend to be and give me a measure of safety trying out new things. If these people are going to pay money for apps that might well drastically change their lives, they will first need to be convinced that it is possible; that a flat screen is somehow the gateway to great potential for enrichment of life that is nearly inconceivable before it is experienced. They will need information about the view at the top of that mountain so they know what they are striving for. Furthermore, they'll need the start of the climb to be as gentle as possible.
    I hope that by making this guide a free resource, more minds will be opened to the magnificent possibilities that I have been blessed to benefit from over these past years.
    I've certainly found these efforts to be rewarding in many ways. Not least of which being the many exchanges I've had with my surprisingly loyal and widespread readership. I've received emails from people in many different countries. I've been asked to be a guest on numerous podcasts. Over the years, I've been given the chance to speak to many groups online and, occasionally, in person. I've accepted the rewarding challenge of teaching a course based on the book, which is available online via Zoom or as a podcast put out by the Canadian Council of The Blind. I've called this course Unseen Touchscreen. While these opportunities have not, for the most part, resulted in financial gain, they have given me a sense of purpose and accomplishment. I've found that this has grown from a one-time project into an ongoing vocation. In a society where the first thing people want to know about us is what we do, having something like this book to point to is tremendously helpful to one's sense of self-worth. Nobody can take away the impact that I've had through this book and other efforts which have grown from it.
    While the opportunities I've gotten through using my iPhone haven't typically enriched me directly, there have been occasional rewards of a financial nature. The most unexpected and spectacular being the iPhone 16 Pro I received while working on the third edition. A group of very kind people who valued my efforts held a fundraiser so they could purchase me an iPhone. The money needed was raised within a day of the fundraiser going live. I'm still absolutely blown away by that. I've also received occasional gift cards from thankful souls from time to time.
    The capabilities offered by my iPhone have certainly saved me a lot of money and rewarded me in other ways. They have enriched my personal life with uncounted pleasures and points of meaningful interaction with others that I would never have otherwise experienced. These things have real value to me, and they'll have value to other blind people. In turn, these blind people will be more able to add value to the societies they are more fully able to engage with.
    I'm unemployed and on a fixed income. Counterintuitively, part of the reason for my benevolent act is the many rules surrounding this fixed income. When you introduce extra uncertain income that fluctuates radically from month to month, there's a danger of actually losing more and falling short in a given month as the systems can't adjust quickly. I would need to report any income to two separate government agencies. One of these provides social assistance, while the other makes the apartment I inhabit affordable on that fixed income. Breaking the rules around either agency could make things much harder going forward. Frankly, there wouldn't be enough steady income realized through selling this guide to make it worth the risk. The audience for this sort of thing is mainly blind people, their friends, and family, and perhaps, dare I hope?, some interested sighted app developers. We're not dealing with a bestseller here. For all its faults, the social support provided to people with disabilities who can't find work has given me a safe and secure economic and physical space to inhabit. From this vantage point, I'm all too aware of how many hardworking people live far more precarious lives despite all of their exhausting efforts.
    With my moderate hearing loss, sleep disorder and spacial difficulties in addition to total blindness, I don't see how I could fit into the kind of well-paying job it would take to earn enough to thrive. Thanks to the social safety net in my country, I can turn my best waking hours to contemplating and executing large projects on my own schedule. I can work on things which give me purpose and are helpful to others. Projects like this book. Consider this an example of what's possible when the constant worry about how to survive is removed from the equation. This is what can happen when we're given space to look beyond our own circumstances and share our gifts with others. Unless a way is found to eliminate the need for social assistance, I would much rather see people benefit from my efforts and reap whatever unexpected rewards come my way while moving onto the next project. If there were a way to earn a secure living offering people this kind of help gaining the most enjoyment and fulfillment from their iOS devices and other technologies, I would indeed be very interested. Most especially if that career didn't involve the pressure to sell products. I've never felt comfortable in the role of salesman.
    The path that led me to write the first edition of this guide stretches back to the unexpectedly favourable response I received after publishing the original Personal Power guide and lectures in 2009. I wrote the original Personal Power guide to help blind people who had obtained computers running Microsoft Windows and powerful screen-reading software. They were left without any idea of the many things these computers could help them do to enrich their personal lives. The guide ended up helping far more people than I ever imagined. These people were a somewhat different but no less deserving group than those whom I had actually written that guide for. I was in a South African newspaper, interviewed for several podcasts, and spoke to many online groups interested in what I had done. Add to these responses thousands of appreciative emails. Many of these were from countries I had never heard of. To everyone who took the time to write to me, thank you very much for being the positive proof that my efforts made a real difference. It is largely because of such a response to my initial guide that I felt I could once again step up to the plate and offer something helpful and meaningful here.
    By the time I chose to get my first iPhone, there seemed to be plenty of help for blind users already available. All my friends, both online and off, seemed to have a good grasp of what their iOS devices could do and where to find out what they didn't know. For several years, I didn't realize how blessed I was to be in a large and well-connected social circle. I don't tend to consider myself to be all that special. While I believe that's a good attitude to have overall, it can lead to presumptions that others are just as fortunate in their company and circumstances. Over time, these presumptions began to erode as I encountered people with iOS devices who were truly shocked when I spoke about a technique, capability, or app I had used for years. This included things I regard as absolutely basic and essential to know to do much at all with the expensive devices they owned. For example, many people were never told about the VoiceOver screen reader. Generous friends or family would give blind people iPods, iPads, or iPhones as gifts. They would show them Siri, the digital assistant that you talk to. The presumption of these well-meaning sighted people was that Siri made these devices accessible to blind people. Sadly, most sighted people are completely unaware of the VoiceOver screen reader included in every iOS device that actually serves this purpose.
    Without learning about and using VoiceOver, the built-in screen reader that Apple includes free of charge with these devices, there are a great many things blind people will not be able to do without sighted assistance. They won't be able to shop in the app store for life-changing apps that would read their mail, or tell them where they were. They couldn't review their calendar or reminders. Once VoiceOver has been mastered, these same things, plus a great many more, are easily accomplished without needing any help from sighted people.
    The more I looked into why these unfortunate blind owners of the same devices that had made such a powerful difference to me were left out, the less able I was to rest easy in my enjoyment. These people weren't living under a rock or anything unusual. Circumstances had simply worked against their finding out about the growing online community and resources enjoyed by those of us who had been well-connected. It's not caused by any lack of drive or laziness. Rather, it is the same kind of genuine unawareness that results in a blind person slipping on a patch of ice or a handkerchief lying on an already smooth floor.
    There is a real digital divide among blind people that seems to have several major root causes; economics is a large part of it. A statistic often tossed around is that roughly 80% of blind people are unemployed. If money is tight, you're not as likely or able to try new technology unless you have enough experience or information to understand how helpful and cost-saving it will be eventually. This information is out there, but it's still a case of being connected to the right people or organizations who are forward-thinking enough to stay informed. Sometimes, direct experience is the only way to be convinced enough to invest time, effort, and money into something very different and new. While iOS devices are widespread, the knowledge necessary to demonstrate the VoiceOver screen reader is not. Nor do many people know which apps are accessible and easy to grasp for blind beginners.
    Another big reason is conceptual. At a purely intuitive gut level, it seems absurd that a device with a touchscreen would be at all useful, much less truly coveted, among blind people. Knowledge of how VoiceOver and other accessibility features work isn't widely spread among sighted people who sell these devices. Everyone knows about the famous digital assistant called Siri. However, comparatively few know about the remarkable built-in screen reader called VoiceOver, which was developed specifically for blind users. There's no widespread sense of how capable it is and how many entirely different apps it makes accessible to blind users. Without such information, it's difficult to make a good case to a potential blind owner. Harder still for that owner to conceive of the possibilities without being able to try things out.
    The summer of 2016 was a pivotal one. During those hot months, my wife Sara and I attended a reunion at the W. Ross MacDonald school for the blind in Brantford, Ontario. Had it not been for her involvement with the school alumni, I might never have gone to one of these reunions. During that occasion, I had several key conversations with fellow attendees which would have far-reaching effects on what this guide has ultimately become.
    Later that Summer, Sara and I went on a week-long trip to visit our good friend Stephen Murgaski. Leaving my laptop at home, I simply brought my iPhone and accessories along. I had begun using it for writing my blog entries and was contemplating starting a more serious writing project using the Ulysses app. During that week away, I didn't miss my more bulky laptop at all. I could do everything I wanted to with the iPhone and a Bluetooth keyboard, which served me well for years before a drink spilled on it. I remarked on this to Steve during one of the marvellous conversations we always have while together. He does a splendid job at being devil's advocate. We explored the potential gains and shortcomings of using an iPhone as a computer replacement over the rest of the week. While I failed to convince him that I was right beyond my own personal use case, we discussed a broad range of situations and areas of utility. This exploration has deeply impacted my approach to this guide. He has been a good friend and sounding board for my approaches to explanations throughout the writing process.
    A couple of other pieces fell into place during that trip. One of these was listening to an audiobook by Chuck Klosterman called But What If We're wrong. In this book, Chuck explores the premise that we might one day look at things we're very certain of now quite differently. We might, in fact, view what we currently consider matters of fact, with the same kind of scorn and derision as we level against notions like an Earth-centred universe. He covers a series of things such as which pop culture would ultimately stand the test of time and areas of physics that might undergo radical changes in understanding such as gravity, etc. He puts forward the idea that we can be trapped within a false sense of certainty, strengthened by living in an age of so much shared information.
    Reading this book put me in a good frame of mind to examine all my thoughts that there was sufficient available help for blind people who had iOS devices but weren't as well-connected as I was. Perhaps, I was wrong, and it wasn't due to simple indifference and apathy. Perhaps, there were other causes I hadn't considered. Maybe, my vantage point was more skewed by a social bubble I hadn't even been conscious of as it formed around me.
    The final push came through hearing from a volunteer who had read some remarks I had made about the KNFB Reader app. He wanted to put me in touch with a lady named Joann who he thought I might be able to help. She had an iPhone, but had never been shown how to use VoiceOver. She had also never learned of the KNFB Reader app. Nor had the representatives of an organization helping blind people who she had contacted. Once I had returned home, Joann and I had several conversations over the rest of the summer. These gave me a far better grasp of how lucky I was to have the resources and friends that I do. Joann also clearly illustrated to me how tragically likely people were to remain ignorant of the very resources I had taken for granted and presumed everyone knew about. Quickly, as I explained the various aspects of iOS to her, I sensed the need for a guide like the one I have written here. Had I never learned about or spoke with Joann, this guide would never have happened. Her situation gave me the final push and radically changed the three and a half years it took me to bring the first edition of this project to a satisfactory conclusion. She provided me the newcomer's perspective that all my experience and skill had largely robbed me of. What sticks in my mind most powerfully was her absolute joy when, for the first time, she was able to take a community flyer and read it on her dining room table using the KNFB Reader app.
    Another big problem faced by blind owners of iPhones is that Apple doesn't provide many starting instructions for anyone. A book I thoroughly enjoyed on my iPhone, The One Device by Brian Merchant, offers interesting insights on this. One of the creators of the iPhone commented that the prevailing thought was if you had to ship a user manual, you had already failed to create a compelling device. For a large slice of the general public, this philosophy really seems to have been correct. People who can see do find these products quite intuitive once they get started. When my father bought his iPad, a helpful salesperson made certain he understood how to navigate and knew where to find the manual in the Apple Books app. Back then, it was called iBooks. This didn't take longer than ten or fifteen minutes. For blind people to receive comparable assistance would frankly require considerably more time. I would want at least an hour to go over basic concepts and teach enough for someone to then be able to take their device home and have a satisfactory experience exploring its capabilities on their own. VoiceOver just isn't intuitive enough without any initial instructions telling new owners about VoiceOver and directing them to the built-in tutorial.
    Even if a salesperson shows a blind customer some VoiceOver basics enough to get into Apple Books, it is doubtful they know enough about VoiceOver to give sufficient instructions. The new user must know how to obtain, navigate, and read the user guide freely available in Apple Books using VoiceOver. Doing this well requires a good grasp of numerous VoiceOver gestures and abilities. A "Getting Started" card that helps sighted people know enough to learn through experimentation comes with iOS devices. However, there is no such card for blind users. This is a profoundly unfortunate situation, since neither the possibilities nor operating techniques are anywhere near as intuitive at the start.
    This is particularly the case when blind people are given these devices as gifts or when they are ordered online. I've talked to blind people who heard how accessible iOS devices were supposed to be. They ordered an iPhone online and tried to make it work, expecting that there would be enough instructions to help them. Most often, they had to find sighted help to even get it turned on and set up to the point where they could use Siri. Unless such sighted help was familiar with the Accessibility section in the Settings, they wouldn't know about VoiceOver or other accessibility tools built into iOS. Having a built-in tutorial for VoiceOver should help people running iOS 18 or later tremendously. People on devices which are too old for this will miss out on this valuable resource.
    Adding to the problem, organizations supposed to help blind people simply weren't as aware of developments as I had presumed them to be. Given the many incredibly useful apps and possibilities like GPS guidance, object identification via the built-in camera, and apps capable of reading printed pages in mere seconds, such as VdScan, it seems criminal that this was ever the case. It is particularly sad that this ignorance is more frequently found in more remote areas where the benefits of these devices would be most useful.
    Thankfully, this landscape of ignorance has drastically improved since I started this project. Blindness organizations and agencies have truly awakened to the potential contained in smartphones and tablets. There are now all sorts of training initiatives and programs to help blind people obtain both the devices and the training needed to get started. I'll steer you to some of these many resources in a section at the end of this guide.
    Knowledge of communities like www.applevis.com where blind people can find out about accessible apps as well as tutorials is not very widespread among the general public. This means that even if blind people figure out enough to get online, they don't know where to go. The user guide available in Apple Books would be helpful, provided that a new blind owner was aware of Apple Books and understood how to use it.
    Presuming you gain knowledge of VoiceOver and the skills to use what's already on your iOS device, there's yet another uphill battle that I sincerely hope this guide helps blind people win. The expression "There's an app for that!" has become very familiar in the sighted world. If accessible apps were as widely talked about and advertised as popular and accessible games and apps, blind people might connect the dots as many sighted people do and think to check the app store to see if there's an app that will do what they require. Outside of initiatives like Living Blindfuly, AppleVis, and other blindness related initiatives, however, not a lot of attention is usually paid to apps made especially for the blind. Moreover, there is as yet no way to search specifically for apps that are known to be accessible to blind people and support the VoiceOver screen reader. While a collection of "apps that support VoiceOver" can be found under the Quick Links heading in the app store, it's a small and very infrequently maintained collection.
    For example, nothing was there to tell me that the app that my bank developed for people to use was accessible to me as a blind person. Given past experience, the natural assumption would be that I'd be wasting my time trying it. Yet, when I did try it, I was amazed at how very intentionally accessible it turned out to be. It's even better and more convenient than the completely audio telephone banking I used for decades. I haven't called that number in years now thanks to this banking app. The developers even responded to constructive criticism and improved the app's accessibility over time.
    Sadly, people are still vastly more likely to come across inaccessible apps if they do decide to look around. The path to satisfaction and real competence is far easier to find for sighted people. If my father decided one day that he wanted to garden, fish, brew beer, or damned near anything else, he wouldn't have to try very hard to find an app that would be in some way helpful to the endeavour of his choice. For blind people attempting the same thing, they must also determine whether an app is accessible with VoiceOver. The description of an app often makes it seem like a certainty that it would be accessible. However, after purchasing the app and running the word processor, calculator, text-based, story-driven game that piqued their interest and sounds like it ought to be accessible, they find that it, in fact, isn't. The new blind user may quickly stop experimenting if he or she finds too many inaccessible apps before being pointed to the thousands of fully accessible ones. Nobody who makes accessible apps has the advertising budget to make it generally known that blind people can use them. Therefore, they might never discover that their bank's app is as accessible as mine turned out to be. They might never find a writing app that suits their needs if they start with the idea that it isn't worth trying to look for accessible apps that absolutely exist. They might never delight in the extensive efforts by many developers to create welcoming, accessible experiences for blind users who dare to venture into the world of the touchscreen.
    Meanwhile, for sighted newcomers, it's easy to become downright overwhelmed with information about apps that are totally useable for them. The possibilities are seen everywhere, from popular TV shows to ads seen on Facebook while playing games. A major objective I have in writing this guide is to point blind people to a great many fully accessible apps, so they have positive initial experiences with their iOS device.
    These barriers can leave blind people walking around with very powerful life-changing devices that they can barely use at all. They don't know what they're missing out on. Nor, most likely, do those who help blind people accomplish things that they, if properly equipped and informed, could easily do for themselves. This unfortunate circumstance bothers me deeply, nagging at my conscience. Especially when all that it would take to solve the problem is having the right information available. Precisely the situation I found regarding Windows computers when I wrote the original Personal Power guide. Sadly, history really does repeat itself.
    In this case, the sense of missed opportunity is exponentially more profound. There's no outcry because the dots simply haven't been connected in the common mind. It's different for me. Those dots are very much connected. I'm certain that there is a lot of potential for good among blind people, who have thus far been left out of the growing community taking advantage of this new portable economic space. If these people are let in, everyone wins. They will have an affordable means of engaging with the online world. The more blind people there are who use these devices, the greater our engagement with the online world and our economic leverage will become. They simply need a boost up the initially steep learning curve to a point where they're connected with the online community of helpful people and resources.
    Although I've discovered a lot on my own over the years of using my iPhone, I write this guide while standing on the shoulders of generous giants. Please take the time to explore the resources I've listed in the Helpful Resources section located at the end of the guide. Many of these resources were around to help me get started on my own journey with iOS devices. A good many other friends and family helped get me out of jams my explorations got me into. You can read a little about them in the Acknowledgements. Consider this guide to be my way of passing the generosity that I experienced onward.
    If this guide enables someone to connect more with the people around them, share their enthusiasm and interests online, express themselves, travel and exercise with greater confidence, or enjoy the many digital entertainments that I've been blessed to enjoy, then I will count this project a success. I will consider myself even more richly rewarded if readers of this guide choose to share their talents, personal interests, and knowledge with the online community I have hopefully enabled you to connect with. Tell us about your discoveries of accessible apps or techniques for getting things done using iOS. Share your adventures in the form of reviews of apps and postings to blogs or social media so that others can benefit from your success. Be a positive part of the online world that I've come to appreciate so deeply. Having that world grow richer and more vibrant through your efforts and shared experiences will be reward enough for me.
    Keeping this guide up to date becomes necessary due to many circumstances. Over time, the iOS experience changes as improvements to iPhones as well as the software they run are made. This eventually means that the gap between what was written in a prior edition becomes too different from what a beginner will encounter. These differences might be great enough to cause confusion. Another issue is that apps appear and disappear over time. More suitable apps for certain tasks or for use as examples will emerge from time to time. Sadly, economics dictate that some apps won't be popular or well-maintained enough as change occurs and will be pulled from the app store. Apps designed specifically for smaller segments of iPhone owners are particularly vulnerable to this. Also, all sorts of things can change how online life happens. With this guide, I have always sought to go beyond the technical and equip any newcomers to online life with the knowledge they need to thrive and conduct themselves safely. All of these factors may mean that enough has changed to make an updated edition of this guide necessary.
    In my quest to share what Apple has made it possible to equip myself with, I lack the resources and infrastructure to distribute this guide in alternative formats to those who would benefit tremendously from this being done for them. All I can really do is set this loose on the Internet in the hope that the right people will find it and pass it on to where it'll do the most good. Please pass this guide to whomever you think should read it. If I had my way, it would be on every iOS device owned by a blind person and would be as simple as possible to access and learn about. Any organization or library for the blind should feel free to post this guide in any format. All I ask is that I be given proper credit for my work and that the content not be changed beyond whatever is necessary to produce this guide in alternative formats or make it easier to navigate.

A Fond Farewell:
What a long way we've come together. From setting up your device, to online shopping, to using the camera, I hope you've gained a good idea of the large number of possibilities that exist for your iOS device. That is my main goal with this book. Despite only a fraction of the total apps created being accessible to blind users, the scope of what that small flat slab of tech can allow us to easily accomplish still amazes me. I hope that I've also convinced you that the online world that it lets you access is meaningful and has substance; that it is worthy of your participation. For me, it has provided a place where I can be of real help to people and have an impact. It is a place where I feel that I have a voice. Through your iPhone, I hope that you will choose to step forward and help shape online life for the better. While I look forward to more adventures in the so-called "real world", I don't intend to turn my back on the good I can do in the digital space. It truly has value.
    This edition was created entirely in the Ulysses app. It continues to improve steadily and has-gained the ability to generate an interactive table of contents. This was the only thing I needed to use the Pages app for.
    Work on editing this edition has already begun before this farewell was started. For the first pass through, I'm using the ElevenReader app to read my book in an excellent, natural sounding AI-driven narration voice. I can pick from a wide variety including such famous actors as Sir Lawrence Olivier, Burt Reynolds and James Dean among others. I can pick out mistakes as I hear them, pause the reading, and pounce on the area of concern, making changes in the Ulysses app quickly. The Apple Intelligence writing tools just aren't ready to be trusted with proofreading large blocks of text. I always end up with an extra copy of the text despite telling it to replace it with the corrected version. I have somewhat more trust in the expert system built into Ulysses, which proceeds step by step, giving me the chance to decide what to do about mistakes it finds.
    Creating this guide has been a much longer and far more exhaustive process than I had originally thought it would be. Keeping it updated is quite an ongoing effort. Change is a constant in the iOS ecosystem. The goal posts just never stop moving. Some truly great apps have disappeared, and new ones have come along. We've had three major iOS updates. The slow emergence of Apple Intelligence seems like it'll be a large enough change to demand a fourth edition be ready for release in a couple of years.
    People seem to appreciate my snapshot takes on how the world is doing from my perspective. I began writing the farewell remarks for this edition on the early morning of the first of may. I always seem to be finishing editions of my book around when Earth Day is celebrated. Earth Day was observed, but given the triumph of politicians who deny climate change in the name of political expedience, it's hard to remain very hopeful. A couple of years ago, smoke was absolutely everywhere in early Summer. The people in charge of my apartment complex covered the airflow intakes with metal sheets in an attempt to keep out smoke from wildfires burning in another province.
