The smoke from those fires drifted as far south as New York, as well as across Canada. There was no relief from the acrid smell. Using air conditioning might have cooled the air, but it would have been too toxic to breathe. Had I needed a wake-up call about the reality of climate change, that would have been more than sufficient proof for me. I sincerely don't want to have this become a part of normal life. The more carbon we put into the air, the more likely that eventuality is.
    Even more alarming to me is the drift towards selfish defensive thinking which is taking root in North America right when we most need its opposite. The trust that we Canadians have had in the US for more than the five decades I've lived has been totally shattered by Trump's actions in a matter of months. There's a palpable anger towards the US now. The cup of Jumping Bean Dark Roast coffee I sip from is emphatically Canadian. It's delicious, and its galvanizing bitterness is quite emblematic of our increasingly absurd reality. Until a few months ago, I never would have given a second thought to which country produced the coffee I enjoy, the chair I sit in, the food I eat. Now, my fellow Canadians and I are ever so conscious of supporting an economy whose administration wants to annex my country. My American designed iPhone, manufactured in China, makes it possible for me to show my very real but heretofore quiet patriotism through my wallet. I do this with said iPhone by choosing Canadian made products and acquiring them through another American giant called Amazon, which has been ever so successful here. I'll show that patriotism as often as is at all practical. Canada is a far from perfect place, but we get plenty of things right. I just wish it didn't take quite as much pushing for us to get to the point of remedial action.
    As someone whose life has been improved in many profound ways by American ingenuity, these sweeping political changes are nothing short of appalling. There's a deep sense of betrayal that I doubt most Americans are at all conscious that their government has unleashed. Such sharp abandonment of leadership roles The US has had on climate action, health initiatives and science has happened in such a short time. These changes will cost lives well beyond their borders.
    I very much worry about the efforts underway to repeal laws in the US which concern accessibility. People in the prime of health don't realize how close they are to having a temporary or permanent disability. Leading conversations for a local group of people who have lost their vision recently, I have a deeper sense of how true that is. I would hate to see what accessibility and inclusion relate legislation which has been so hard fought for in Canada come under similar attack from people who can't see beyond their own wallets. These are profoundly unsettling times for anyone with even a small dash of common sense, honesty and moral decency.
    Being geographically attached to the US and saturated by American cultural and media influence, Canada really can't escape the selfish populist headwinds. I'm glad to see that more Canadians are appreciating and standing up for our more humane approach to those who are less fortunate in health and wealth. However, I worry that our resolve might not be able to withstand the rising protectionist darker sentiments, normally more dormant in Canadian culture. We too are losing our ability to find compromise as our sense of economic and existential peril increases. The US doesn't have a monopoly on people who want to burn it all down. One of the most divisive politicians we've ever had just came far too close to being our prime minister for me to have any sense of comfort.
    There are bright spots of hope out there. I hear and read more every day about people who are doing their part and helping each other. There are people working on all sorts of collaborative projects and imaginative approaches to inequality and climate change. In particular, city governments still seem to have their sights set on these issues. One source looking hard for much-needed good news is called Reasons To Be Cheerful. It's a website and publication which has definitely lifted my spirits. Check them out at:
    https://reasonstobecheerful.world
    I'm also happy to hear that not all corporations are slashing their initiatives when it comes to diversity, inclusion, and accessibility. Thankfully, Apple has stood its ground when it comes to its accessibility initiatives and its more humane stance. Accessibility does indeed seem to be a deeply rooted part of what Apple does. Enough for me not to be overly concerned about this changing at the whim of current political trends. Over the past month, VoiceOver has turned twenty years old. It has been a truly transformative part of my life since 2011, adding endless incredible possibility to a flat, smooth rectangle of glass I keep with me everywhere.
    Global Accessibility Awareness day will arrive on May 15th. I'm very hapy to be able to publish this book on that special day as my own contribution. If things proceed as they traditionally have, Apple will reveal some of what we can expect in terms of new or improved accessibility features coming to iOS. From an accessibility standpoint, iOS 18 had a lot to offer and was far from disappointing. I frankly need a Summer break from working on this book. However, I keenly look forward to finding out what to expect in the Fall from iOS 19.
    So much historical change is happening that it makes one's head spin. Against such a backdrop, it's hard not to feel that one's efforts are rather insignificant. There are so many large-scale problems which I would love to help solve. However, I've been given an increased sense of purpose from many of you, my readers. Around thirty of you got together and funded the iPhone 16 Pro, on which I write these words. Many more of you indicated your willingness to contribute. Still more of you have reached out via email and social media with kind appreciation and tales of what you've managed to find or accomplish through your iPhones. All of that is very meaningful to me. The more I hear about the good you do through knowing how to use your iPhones, the more of a sense I'll have that I've accomplished something worth-while.
    Readers have indicated that they've enjoyed learning a little about what I'm up to beyond the guide. It has become a tradition for me to indulge such curiosity in these final remarks. On a personal level, I'm feeling much more connected these days. The Unseen Touchscreen course I conduct for the Canadian Council of the Blind has been attracting people from across Canada over the past few years. It continues to go along very well. It gives me a group of people who attend regularly enough to begin to know. They continue to ask excellent questions and are eager to make the best possible use of their iPhones to enrich their lives. I'm honoured that they have continued to find it worth their time to attend my cessions.
    Meetings with my local chapter of the CCB have been similarly rewarding. Hearing loss makes me value these online connections even more, since it's easier to participate when I'm in control of my sound environment. However, now that the pandemic is behind us, we are slowly beginning to have more in-person meetings. Those can be more taxing with hearing aids, but with people truly interested in engaging, they're still very enjoyable and stimulating. I've been happy to discover that my appetite for such gatherings hasn't diminished.
    I'm also involved in helping to lead another local group sponsored by the CNIB. They are all dealing with sight loss. For a number of them, this has happened quite recently. I'm still figuring out how I can best contribute to their journeys into what I've known as normal all my life. I learned to understand what limits being blind placed on me as I grew up in a family keen to expand my horizons and chance for success as much as possible. The people I'm encountering have suddenly had their jobs end and options drastically reduced, as if someone threw a switch and turned off the world as they knew it. I try to make them aware of as much of what is possible as I can, while realizing that it takes a long time to adjust and begin to find new purpose and meaning.
    Participating in the Kelly and Company show continues to be rewarding, despite the fairly drastic changes to the show's format. I no longer cover technology but am still sharing what I find regarding entertainment which is accessible to blind people. I make appearances every second week, which people seem to be enjoying. Absolutely all of the work related to this is done on my iPhone.
    I'm hopeful this year of being able to celebrate the release of the third edition with some friends in person this time around. Perhaps not on the day of release, but soon thereafter. More people who I've come to know in person have a sense of what I've been up to. I'll hopefully be doing more socially over this coming Summer. I'm much more experienced getting around using Uber. It's at least affordable for local trips. Finding people interested in taking those trips is finally starting to seem like an actual possibility. Making new friends is a slow, hard process, but I feel like its happening.
    I've obtained some Braille RPG dice and hope to put them to use participating in a game at some point. The chances are probably better finding an online group these days. Either way, my iPhone will doubtless be of tremendous help.
    Two larger creative dreams also still beckon to me. I believe I've gathered all of the resources I need to take a good crack at either of them. Ever since my days in secondary school, I've dreamed of writing a collection of loosely connected short stories. Increasingly, the idea I have for these stories is turning into more of the outline of a novel. My other big, long-standing creative dream is to create a widely enjoyable game. I've come to the conclusion that perhaps a roleplaying game would be workable. It would share the same world as the novel but allow things to unfold in countless different ways. Slowly, I've gathered books and materials about writing, stories, and game design. It's all ready and waiting on my iPhone.
    Working on this guide really needs to remain my primary focus. People definitely seem to appreciate the approach I take. However, I'm hoping to make slow progress in organizing my thoughts on the near future Earth on which the core story takes place. I'll likely lean towards working on the novel first. I think that imagination is our best shot at coming up with the kinds of empathy, humility, and capacity for change that we'll need to find our way out of this darker patch of history moving at headlong speed.
    We have at last arrived at the end of this guide. If you've actually read this whole thing, you have my profound admiration and thanks. I didn't write it with that kind of persistence as the expectation. The idea was that people would skip around to what they were interested in or felt they needed at any given moment. I sincerely hope you have found it worth your time.
    Fifteen years is long enough to have given me a real sense of history happening in this world built by Apple and those of us who jumped aboard their iPhone train. I've been honoured to have experienced works of genius that are simply no longer available. Through countless online conversations, I've witnessed a lot of tremendous creative good take place. Having a sense of the economic forces and other factors at play will hopefully put you in a better position to direct your time and efforts to advocate for improvements thoughtfully. Over all, I've found that app developers in particular have been eager to include accessibility once they're made aware of the possibility to do so and of serious interest from people unable to use their creations due to various disabilities which can be accommodated with some effort and consideration.
    This is, by far, the largest single ongoing project I've ever undertaken. That saying about great art being abandoned rather than finished rings very true to me. I've included all of the wisdom and discoveries I could think to. Making over a decade's worth of experience available in a single document is a very tall order. I wish that I had made this a collaborative project from a very early point. By the time I got to a place where I considered it, I was in too deeply to let go of control. Especially of the overall friendly tone that I consider so important. To really do a complete all-encompassing job of this would take a team of people with more skill, varied interests and life experience. For better or worse, you're stuck with me. This book will remain my personal project for as long as I can keep going. My thanks to everyone who has come forward with suggestions and questions which help me make it a better resource. Thanks are also extended to those of you who share Personal Power and make this book available in other formats increasing its spread and accessibility. It means a great deal to me as well as the people I continue to hear from who have received the book through these efforts.
    You now know quite a bit about what keeps me cheerful and fascinated. If you've enjoyed that process, I'd love to hear from you. Of course, I'm interested in what you thought of the guide. Has it helped you? Is there something you wish that I had thought to include? A fourth edition of this guide is definitely on the way. I'm very interested in hearing about the adventures you have with your iOS devices. Just as others have helped me, I'm happy to answer your questions if I can. I'm also just as happy to have a good conversation about life, the universe, and everything. Reach me on Mastodon at "@mfeir@mstdn.social". Otherwise, there's email. Contact me at michael.feir@gmail.com.
    Until the next edition, I hope you keep safe and healthy, do what good in the world you can, and increase happiness.

Helpful Resources
Those who seek a different approach learning how to use their iOS device should take advantage of the resources listed below. All kinds of help is out there on the web. Also, many organizations offer training in the use of iOS devices. I've included as many currently available resources as I know about. These are in no particular order.
    Apple's Accessibility Website:
    www.apple.com/accessibility
    This is where Apple advertises its various efforts regarding making their products accessible to as many people as possible. There are accessible versions of product manuals. You'll also find descriptions of accessibility features as well as video demonstrations. There are resources for developers who want to make their apps as accessible as possible. You'll also find links to other online resources.
    iOS Access for All
    www.iosaccessbook.com
    iOS Access for All: Your Comprehensive Guide to Accessibility for iPad, iPhone, and iPod Touch by Shelly Brisbin.
    This book is a very comprehensive and concise guide that covers all aspects of iOS from an accessibility point of view. This extends beyond blindness and covers all accessibility features in detail. Shelly is a well known and trusted expert in this area. She shares that expertise on numerous podcasts and has written articles in disability-related publications. Anyone seeking a more traditionally written guide to iOS would do well to spend the $25 US cost to purchase her book. This is especially the case if you have more than one type of disability.
    The CNIB
    www.cnib.ca
    Canadian National Institute for the Blind.
    This charitable agency has a long history of working to improve the lives of blind people in Canada. It has recently begun the Phone It Forward program to help get more smartphones and tablets into the hands of blind people. They have also produced YouTube videos and ebooks, and also provide training workshops to instruct people on how to use their iOS devices.
    The National Braille Press
    www.nbp.org
    This American resource offers a growing number of very helpful books in ebook and physical and electronic Braille formats. A large number of books focus on accessible apps and techniques for making the most of your iOS devices.
    Get Together with Technology
    www.gttprogram.blog
    This initiative of the Canadian Council of the Blind provides online training conferences free for interested people to attend using the Zoom service. They also have a podcast featuring guests who impart helpful skills and information. Many of the episodes are recorded chat cessions which focus on iOS and blindness related topics focused on technology. This podcast also includes the Unseen Touchscreen course which I developed based on the previous edition of this book. I addition to larger discussions, they also run smaller more focussed workshops on specific apps or aspects of accessible technology.
    The Hadley Institute
    www.hadley.edu
    This non-profit organization has been around for decades but keeps moving well with the times. You will find free educational courses, information videos, and audio resources including material to help you master your iOS devices. People interested in learning will find plenty to occupy and enrich their lives here. All materials are offered free of charge.
    The iBlind Users Group:
    https://ibugtoday.org
    This group is based in the US, but welcomes participation from everywhere. They conductsocial and educational events online via Zoom and promote the use of iOs devices among other accessble technology. They feature a book club, weekly descried movie, and many other events at no cost to attendees.
    Accessible Media Inc.
    www.ami.ca
    This organization promotes accessibility in Canada and offers a wide array of audio and TV programming. Much of this is directed at keeping blind and low-vision people informed and entertained. This includes audio community-focused shows like Kelly and Company, Double Tap Canada, The Pulse, and the Now Show with Dave Brown. These shows encourage and thrive on community participation while bringing a great deal of expertise to bear on the everyday concerns for people with disabilities.
    The VIPhone List
    https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!forum/viPhone
    This list is full of people who use iPhones and other iOS devices. Any topic relevant to the use of iOS devices or apps is fair game for this friendly, high-traffic Google group. You can participate through email in your email app of choice or view discussions directly online from the Google Groups page.
    Top Tech Tidbits:
    www.toptechtidbits.com
    This is a very well produced weekly newsletter which keeps me updated about technology and accessibility related happenings. Absolutely everyone interested in these topics as they pertain to blind people should sign up for this newsletter. Many articles listed in this newsletter discuss iOS developments and various accessible apps. The community of readers of this newsletter are supportive and helpful. This is a resource well worth supporting and reading.
    Access World:
    https://www.afb.org/aw
    This is another publication which has stood the test of time. It is a full magazine produced by the American Foundation of the Blind. You'll find thorough and well written articles and reviews in every issue. All aspects of accessibility are covered with a broad sweep of interesting topics. Quite often, iOS related articles and reviews about apps and games can be found.
    The End
